PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Wellington, Kansas. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1996 Code, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the governing body. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1996 Code and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
    The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
    The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CHARTER ORDINANCES CHT:1 CODE CD1:1 CODE APPENDIX CDA:1 CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES CCT:1 STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE SLT:1 CHARTER ORDINANCES INDEX CHTi:1 CODE INDEX CDi:1  
Indexes 
    The indexes have been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the indexes themselves which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up to date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Keeping this publication up to date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    This publication was under the direct supervision of Alyce A. Whitson, Senior Code Attorney, and Beth Tattershall, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publisher is most grateful to Gus Collins, City Manager; Rose Miller, City Clerk; Michael Brown, City Attorney; John Lloyd, Fire Chief; Tracy Heath, Police Chief; Jeremy Jones, Public Works Director; Larry Mangan, City Engineer; Cliff Zens, Electric Distribution Supervisor; and Gil Berryman, Wastewater Supervisor, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs.

ORDINANCE NO. 4044 
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND ENACTING A NEW CODE FOR THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS; PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN; PROVIDING A PENALTY FOR THE VIOLATION THEREOF; PROVIDING FOR THE MANNER OF AMENDING SUCH CODE; AND PROVIDING WHEN SUCH CODE AND THIS ORDINANCE SHALL BECOME EFFECTIVE. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS: 
Section 1. The Code entitled "Code of the City of Wellington, Kansas," published by Municipal Code Corporation, consisting of chapters 1 through 40, each inclusive, is adopted. 
Section 2. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before April 7, 2009, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are repealed. 
Section 3. The repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance. 
Section 4. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof absent a specific or unique punishment prescribed shall be punished by a fine of not less than one dollar nor more than $1,000.00 or imprisonment for not more than 180 days or both a fine and imprisonment. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall continue or occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided, shall apply to the amendment of any Code section, whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the city may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief, administrative adjudication and revocation of licenses or permits. 
Section 5. Additions or amendments to the Code when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the city to make the same a part of the Code shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
Section 6. Ordinances adopted after April 7, 2009, that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
Section 7. This ordinance shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage and approval and after its publication in the official City newspaper, as provided by law. 
Passed by the Council this 7th day of July, 2009. 
Approved by the Mayor. 
      Mayor   ATTEST: 
      City Clerk     
FORM APPROVED: 
      City Attorney

PART I - CHARTER ORDINANCES[1] 
CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 1 [2] 
    A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS, FROM KANSAS STATUTES ANNOTATED, SECTION 14-207, AND PROVIDING SUBSTITUTE AND ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS ON THE SAME SUBJECT, PROVIDING FOR THE DIVISION OF WARDS IN THE CITY INTO PRECINCTS, FOR REARRANGEMENT OF PRECINCTS, FOR JOINDER OF PRECINCTS FOR CITY ELECTIONS, FOR VOTING PLACES, AND REGARDING POLL BOOKS, AND REPEALING SECTION 8-102, WELLINGTON CODE OF REVISED ORDINANCES, 1956. 
    BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS: 
    SECTION 1. The City of Wellington, Kansas, by the power invested in it by Article 12, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to and exempts itself from and makes inapplicable to it Section 14-207 of Kansas Statutes Annotated, which applies only to cities of the second class, and to provide substitute and additional provisions as hereinafter provided. 
    SECTION 2. In the City of Wellington, Kansas, the governing body may divide any ward into precincts, and may rearrange the boundaries of the precincts when good reason in its judgment exists, but so far as practicable the number of registered voters in each precinct shall be kept approximately equal when arranging and rearranging such precinct boundaries. For each primary and general election, as defined by statute, there shall be one voting place in each precinct. For each city primary, city election, and city special election all precincts in each ward shall be and are hereby joined and there shall be one voting place for such city elections in each ward, at which all duly registered voters residing in the ward may vote. In preparing poll books, the city clerk shall prepare poll books for each precinct, but for all city elections shall deliver to the election board of the precincts joined in each ward the poll books for the precincts joined in such ward for such city election. Rearrangement of precincts shall be by ordinance only. 
    SECTION 3. The first precinct of the first ward shall consist of all that part of the ward lying east of a line drawn north and south through the center of C Street. 
    SECTION 4 . The second precinct of the first ward shall consist of all that part of the ward lying West of a line drawn north and south through the center of C Street. 
    SECTION 5. The first precinct of the second ward shall consist of all that part of the ward lying north of a line drawn east and west through the center of Harvey Avenue. 
    SECTION 6. The second precinct of the second ward shall consist of all that part of the ward lying south of a line drawn east and west through the center of Harvey Avenue. 
    SECTION 7. The first precinct of third ward shall consist of all that part of the ward lying east of F Street. 
    SECTION 8. The second precinct of the third ward shall consist of all that part of the ward lying west of F Street. 
    SECTION 9. The first precinct of the fourth ward shall consist of all that part of the ward lying east of a line drawn north and south through the center of Poplar Street. 
    SECTION 10. The second precinct of the fourth ward shall consist of all that part of the ward lying west of a line drawn north and south through the center of Poplar Street. 
    SECTION 11 . This ordinance shall be published once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    SECTION 12. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one days after final publication. 
    SECTION 13. Section 8-102, Wellington Code of Revised Ordinances, 1956, and all other ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 
    PASSED BY THE GOVERNING BODY, all of the members elect voting in favor thereof, this 16th day of May, 1966. 
CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 2 [3] 
    A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS, FROM K.S.A. 14-201, AND PROVIDING SUBSTITUTE AND ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS ON THE SAME SUBJECT, RELATING TO ELECTIVE AND APPOINTIVE OFFICERS, TERMS AND COMPENSATION. 
    BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS: 
    SECTION I. The City of Wellington, Kansas, by the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to make inapplicable to it and exempts itself from K.S.A. 14-201 which applies to said city, but not uniformly to all cities, and provided substitute and additional provisions on the same subject as hereinafter provided. 
    SECTION II. There shall be elected on the first Tuesday in April of each odd-numbered year a mayor and councilmen as hereinafter provided. The mayor shall appoint, by and with the consent of the council, a city treasurer, police judge, city marshal, city clerk, city attorney, and may appoint an assistant marshal, street commissioner, and such policemen and other officers as they may deem necessary. Officers so appointed and confirmed shall hold their offices for a term of one (1) year and until their successors are appointed and qualified. The council shall by ordinance specify their duties and compensation, and by ordinance abolish any office created by them whenever they may deem it expedient. The council may retain a licensed professional engineer for specifically devices duties and provide for reasonable compensation for the services rendered. The mayor and councilmen shall hold their offices for a term of two (2) years, and all other officers for a term of one (1) year; PROVIDED, at the election in the organization of the City of Wellington as provided by law, there shall be elected two (2) councilmen from each ward, one of whom shall serve for one year and one for two years, and one (1) councilman shall be elected from each ward at each annual election thereafter. 
    SECTION III. This ordinance shall be published one each week for two consecutive weeks in the Wellington Daily News, the official city newspaper. 
    SECTION IV. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after final publication unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance as provided in Article 12, Section 5, Subdivision (c)(3) of the Constitution of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
    PASSED by the governing body, not less than two-thirds of the members elect voting in favor thereof, the 3rd day of October, 1966. 
CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 3 [4] 
    A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS, FROM SECTIONS 31 AND 32 OF CHAPTER 274 OF THE 1968 SESSION LAWS OF KANSAS INSOFAR AS THEY PERTAIN TO THE ELECTION AND TERMS OF COUNCILMEN AND CITY TREASURER AND THE APPOINTMENT OF CITY OFFICERS; PROVIDING SUBSTITUTE AND ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO THE ELECTION AND THE TERMS OF CITY COUNCILMEN. 
    BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS: 
    SECTION I. The City of Wellington, Kansas, by the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt itself from and make inapplicable to it Sections 31 and 32 of Chapter 274 of the 1968 Session Laws of Kansas insofar as they pertain to the election and terms of councilmen and city treasurer and the appointment of city officers, and provide substitute and additional provisions as hereinafter set forth in this ordinance. Such statutory section is applicable to this city but is not applicable uniformly to all cities. 
    SECTION II. There is hereby created in each ward of said City two positions for councilman, to be hereafter known as Councilman, Position No. 1 and Councilman, Position No. 2. 
    SECTION III. There shall be elected on the first Tuesday in April of each year one councilman in each ward of said City, councilmen for Position No. 1 to be elected in the year 1969, and in each odd-numbered year thereafter, and councilmen for Position No. 2 to be elected in the year 1970, and in each even-numbered year thereafter. Councilmen shall hold their offices for a term of two years and until their successors are elected and qualified. 
    SECTION IV. Charter Ordinance No. 2 of the City of Wellington, Kansas, is hereby repealed. 
    SECTION V. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    SECTION VI. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance as provided in Article 12, Section 5, Subdivision (c)(3) of the Constitution of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by the majority of the electors voting thereon. 
    Passed by the Governing Body, not less than two-thirds of the members-elect voting in favor thereof, the 12th day of December, 1968. 
CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 4 [5] 
    A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS, FROM SECTIONS 14-10a02 AND 14-10a05 OF THE KANSAS STATUTES ANNOTATED AND SECTIONS 8 AND 10 OF HOUSE BILLS 1825 AND 2051 OF THE 1970 KANSAS LEGISLATURE, AND PROVIDING SUBSTITUTE AND ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS ON THE SAME SUBJECT, RELATING TO FIRE AND POLICE RETIREMENT SYSTEMS, THE CREATION AND MAINTENANCE OF SEPARATE FUNDS FOR EACH DEPARTMENT, TAX LEVIES, DESIGNATION OF FUNDS, INVESTMENT AND THEIR EXEMPTION FROM THE LIMITATIONS PROVIDED FOR IN THE AFORESAID HOUSE BILLS AND FROM THE TERM "OPERATING EXPENSES" AS USED IN SAID HOUSE BILLS. 
    BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS: 
    SECTION I. The City of Wellington, Kansas, by the power invested in it by Article 12, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to make inapplicable to it and exempts it-self from Sections 14-10a02 and 14-10a05 of the Kansas Statutes Annotated and from Sections 8 and 10 of House Bills 1825 and 2051 of the 1970 Kansas Legislature, which apply to said city but not uniformly to all cities, and provides substitute and additional provisions on the same subject as hereinafter provided. 
    SECTION II. The City of Wellington, Kansas, may establish and maintain a separate pension fund for each the police department and the fire department of said city, which shall be set aside and used exclusively for the payment of pensions and disability benefits as authorized herein. For the purpose of creating and maintaining such pension funds, the governing body of said city is hereby authorized and shall: 
(1)  Accept gifts, grants, bequests, gratuities or any other money and credit the same to the pension fund designated by the donor; 
(2)  Levy an assessment against each officer and member of each department equal to three percent of his monthly salary or compensation, the same to be deducted from the regular payroll and to be transferred into said pension fund; 
(3)  Place into said funds the proceeds of all lost or stolen securities, money or personal property which shall remain unclaimed in possession of any department of the city for six months, together with the proceeds of all unclaimed or confiscated property of any nature which shall have been in custody of the police department for a period of six months, and the city is hereby authorized to sell at public auction such property and place the proceeds therefrom into said pension funds in equal shares; 
(4)  Transfer into said pension funds the unencumbered balance, including investments, in any existing pension fund or funds: PROVIDED, That if there is more than one pension fund existing in said city then each of said existing funds, except the firemen's and policemen's relief funds, shall be transferred into the new pension fund of a like classification; 
(5)  Carry forward the balance in said funds at the close of each budget year as revenue for the next ensuing year; 
(6)  Transfer into said fund any proceeds from any municipally-owned utility at the discretion of the governing body of said city; 
(7)  Levy annually at the time for the levying of taxes for city purposes, and in addition to other taxes authorized or limited, a tax upon all of the taxable tangible property in said city not to exceed one and one-half mill for each fund to maintain the said pension funds at a level to continue, maintain, and pay all pension and disability requirements actual or anticipated for the ensuing year, and to maintain a reserve in said pension funds as is hereinafter provided. 
    SECTION III. 
    The amount of money derived from taxes herein levied and all money received from assessments, dues, donations for the benefit of such funds shall constitute funds to be known and designated, respectively, as the policemen's pension fund and the firemen's pension fund, which funds shall be devoted exclusively to and for the purposes hereinafter enumerated. All moneys derived from the taxes so levied and money received from other sources as above enumerated shall be paid into the policemen's pension fund or the firemen's pension fund, as the case may be and shall be cumulative until a reserve fund in an amount to be determined by the governing body of the City of Wellington, Kansas, shall be built up for each fund. 
    The amount of each reserve fund shall be determined by the governing body of the City of Wellington, Kansas, and when each reserve fund, as so determined, shall reach its maximum, further tax levies shall be made only for the purpose of maintaining each fund at said level. All moneys accumulated under the provisions of this act shall be deposited by the treasurer in the same manner as other city funds; PROVIDED, HOWEVER, The board of trustees may, at their option, invest any of said reserve funds in direct obligation bonds of the United States of America maturing, or redeemable at par and accrued interest, within three years from date of purchase, or in bonds of any municipality in the state of Kansas, the total bonded indebtedness of which is less than fifteen percent of the total assessed tangible valuation of such municipality, which bonds shall mature within five years from the date of purchase. 
    SECTION IV. 
    The provisions of House Bills Nos. 1825 and 2051 of the 1970 Kansas Legislature shall not apply to or limit the levy of taxes for the payment of: 
(a)  Principal and interest upon bonds and temporary notes; 
(b)  No-fund warrants issued prior to the effective date of House Bills Nos. 1825 and 2051 of the 1970 Kansas Legislature; 
(c)  No-fund warrants issued after the effective date of House Bills Nos. 1825 and 2051 of the 1970 Kansas Legislature, when authorized by the state board of tax appeals subject to the conditions and requirements of K.S.A. 79-2938, 79-2939, 79-2941 and 79-2951 and where said board in addition specifically finds that an extreme emergency exists; 
(d)  Judgments rendered against the City of Wellington; 
(e)  Rent due under any lease with a public building commission authorized by K.S.A. 1969 Supp. 12-1757 to 12-1768, inclusive, and acts amendatory thereof, which rent is for a facility specified in a resolution adopted prior to the effective date of House Bills Nos. 1825 and 2051 of the 1970 Kansas Legislature, pursuant to K.S.A. 1969 Supp. 12-1767, and is pledged to retire bonds issued under the authority of such act; or 
(f)  Special assessments, and as used herein and in House Bills Nos. 1825 and 2051 of the 1970 Kansas Legislature the term "special assessments" shall include amounts assessed either specifically as special assessments or using other terminology but being in the nature of special assessments. 
    The provisions of House Bills Nos. 1825 and 2051 of the 1970 Kansas Legislature do not apply to the tax levies required under K.S.A. 13-14,100, 13-14a02, 14-10a02, 40-2305 and 74-4920 and K.S.A. 1969 Supp. 39-710, 39-713(j), 72-4419, 72-4420, 72-6916, 72-7007 and 74-4967 and K.S.A. 1969 Supp. 72-6916, as amended by 1970 House Bill No. 1529. 
    Amounts produced from any levy specified in this section shall not be used in computing any limitation under House Bills Nos. 1825 and 2051 of the 1970 Kansas Legislature. 
    SECTION V. 
    As used herein and in House Bills Nos. 1825 and 2051 of the 1970 Kansas Legislature, the term "operating expenses" shall mean the total expenditures of the City of Wellington, Kansas, for all purposes, except expenditures for: 
(1)  The payment of bonds, no-fund warrants, temporary notes and interest thereon; 
(2)  Capital improvements, where such expenditures are from any special building fund or other non-tax supported fund authorized by statute or from federal funds available for such purpose; 
(3)  The payment of judgments authorized by law; 
(4)  Expenses caused by any unforeseen occurrence for the payment of which the board of tax appeals has authorized the issuance of no-fund warrants in accordance with the requirements of section 22 of House Bills Nos. 1825 and 2051 of the 1970 Kansas Legislature; 
(5)  The operation of a municipally-owned utility, as defined in K.S.A. 10-1201, if such utility does not derive any revenue from tangible property taxes; 
(6)  Purposes authorized by law, where the money expended is derived from gifts or bequests from private sources; 
(7)  Rent due under any lease with a public building commission authorized by K.S.A. 1969 Supp. 12-1757 to 12-1768, inclusive, and acts amendatory thereof, which rent is for a facility specified in a resolution adopted prior to the effective date of House Bills Nos. 1825 and 2051 of the 1970 Kansas Legislature, pursuant to K.S.A. 1969 Supp. 12-1767, and is pledged to retire bonds issued under the authority of such act; 
(8)  Payment of employer contributions required under K.S.A. 13-14,100, 13-14a02, 14-10a02, 40-2305 and 74-4920 and K.S.A. 1969 Supp. 74-4967; 
(9)  Programs financed from federal grants or aid except to the extent the local share of federally-assisted projects must be budgeted as provided by law; and 
(10)  Payment of special assessments. 
    Except as provided in Sections 11 and 14 of House Bills Nos. 1825 and 2051 of the 1970 Kansas Legislature, the City of Wellington, Kansas, shall not budget for operating expenses in any fiscal year more than one hundred five percent (105%) of the amount legally budgeted for operating expenses in the preceding fiscal year or in the base year, whichever is greater. 
    SECTION VI. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    SECTION VII. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after final publication unless a sufficient petition for referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance as provided in Article 12, Section 5, Subdivision (c)(3) of the Constitution of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
    PASSED by the governing body of the City of Wellington, Kansas, not less than two-thirds of the members-elect voting in favor thereof, the 1st day of June, 1970. 
CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 5 [6] 
    A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS, FROM K.S.A. 1971 SUPP. 79-1952 AND PROVIDING SUBSTITUTE AND ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS ON THE SAME SUBJECT, AUTHORIZING AND LIMITING LEVIES IN ANY ONE YEAR ON EACH DOLLAR OF ASSESSED TANGIBLE VALUATION, AND PRESCRIBING AN AGGREGATE FOR ALL CITY-WIDE LEVIES. 
    BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS: 
    SECTION I. The City of Wellington, Kansas, a city of the second class, by the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to make inapplicable to it and exempts itself from Section 79-1952 of the 1971 Supplement to the Kansas Statutes Annotated, which applies to said city, but not uniformly to all cities, and the legislature of the State of Kansas not having established classes of cities for the purpose of imposing tax limitations and prohibitions, and provides substitute and additional provisions on the same subject as hereinafter provided. 
    SECTION II. 
    The Governing Body of the City of Wellington, Kansas, is hereby authorized and empowered to levy taxes in each year for the following city purposes, but said Governing Body shall not fix a rate of levy in any one year on each dollar of assessed tangible valuation of the city in excess of the following rates: 
    General Operating Fund (which may include the following activities): General government; police department; fire department; health and sanitation, including refuse collection and disposal; streets and highways (all public traveled ways, including bridges); street lighting; sewer maintenance, sanitary and storm; parks and cemeteries (including golf course and swimming pool): civil defense; and military memorial maintenance...18 mills. 
    PROVIDED, That any revenues derived from the motor vehicle and motor fuel taxes shall be budgeted to the credit of the highways department of said general operating fund and shall be used exclusively for the purposes for which received. 
    Library...3.00 mills 
    PROVIDED, That two mills of said levy shall be outside the aggregate levy limit prescribed by this ordinance. 
    Airport: As provided by KSA 3-113a...1.00 mill 
    Flood control works: Maintenance as provided by KSA 12-646a...1.00 mill 
    Ambulance and fire-fighting equipment: As provided by KSA 12-110b....50 mill 
    Noxious weeds: As provided by KSA 2-1318...1.00 mill 
    Fire Department: Pension fund as provided by Charter Ordinance No. 4 of said city...1.50 mill 
    Police Department: Pension fund as provided by Charter Ordinance No. 4 of said city...1.50 mill 
    PROVIDED, That the aggregate of all city-wide levies of such city is hereby limited to 19 mills on each dollar of assessed tangible valuation of said city, except levies for the payment of bonds and the interest thereon, the first two mills of a library levy, levies for the control and eradication of noxious weeds, and levies authorized by other statutes of the State of Kansas to be outside the aggregate. 
    SECTION III. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    SECTION IV. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after final publication unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance as provided in Article 12, Section 5, Subdivision (c)(3) of the Constitution of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
    PASSED by the Governing Body, not less than two-thirds of the members-elect voting in favor thereof, the 7th day of February, 1972. 
CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 6 [7] 
    A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS, FROM K.S.A. 12-1642, AND PROVIDING SUBSTITUTE AND ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS ON THE SAME SUBJECT, RELATING TO THE CUTTING OR DESTRUCTION OF WEEDS BY SAID CITY AND THE ASSESSMENT OF COSTS THEREFOR, AND REPEALING SECTION 19-202 OF THE CODE OF THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS 1969. 
    BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS: 
    SECTION I. The City of Wellington, Kansas, by the power invested in it by Article 12, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to make inapplicable to it and exempts itself from K.S.A. 12-1642 which applies to said city, but not uniformly to all cities, and provides substitute and additional provisions on the same subject as hereinafter provided. 
    SECTION II. Where weeds are not kept cut to a height of sixteen (16) inches from the ground or are not destroyed and where the occupant, owner or agent of lots or pieces of land within said city shall refuse after five (5) days written notice by the city clerk, or in cases where the owner is unknown or is a nonresident of said city, and there is no resident agent, ten (10) days after notice has been published in the official city paper by the city clerk, to cut or destroy such weeds, the street department of said city shall cut or destroy such weeds as aforesaid, and shall keep an account of the cost of the same and report the same to the city clerk; and the cost of the cutting or destruction of said weeds shall be assessed and charged against the lot or parcel of ground on which such weeds were located; and the city clerk shall, at the time of certifying other city taxes to the county clerk, certify the aforesaid costs, and the county clerk shall extend the same on the tax roll of the county against said lot or parcel of ground, and it shall be collected by the county treasurer and paid to the city as other city taxes are collected and paid. 
    SECTION III. Section 19-202 of the Code of the City of Wellington, Kansas, 1969, is hereby repealed. 
    SECTION IV. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    SECTION V. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after final publication unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance as provided in Article 12, Section 5, Subdivision (c)(3) of the Constitution of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
    PASSED by the Council, not less than two-thirds of the members-elect voting in favor thereof, the 6th day of March, 1972. 
CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 7 [8] 
    A CHARTER ORDINANCE OF THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS, PROVIDING THAT SECTIONS 14-10a01 THROUGH AND INCLUDING 14-10a15 OF THE KANSAS STATUTES ANNOTATED SHALL NOT APPLY TO SAID CITY, EXEMPTING SAID CITY THEREFROM, AND PROVIDING SUBSTITUTE PROVISIONS THEREFORE ESTABLISHING A RETIREMENT SYSTEM FOR POLICE AND FIRE PERSONNEL; PROVIDING FOR THE FINANCING OF SUCH SYSTEM AND PRESCRIBING THE AUTHORITY FOR THE INVESTMENT OF RESERVES AND THE MANAGEMENT AND ADMINISTRATION OF SUCH SYSTEM; PROVIDING FOR THE TRANSFER OF THE ACCOUNTS, RESERVES AND FUND BALANCES OF EXISTING POLICE OR FIRE PENSION FUNDS HERETOFORE ACCUMULATED UNDER AUTHORITY OF THE LAWS OF THE STATE OF KANSAS; AND REPEALING SECTIONS 9-301 TO 9-312, INCLUSIVE, AND 16-301 TO 16-312, INCLUSIVE, OF THE CODE OF THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS, 1969. 
    BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS: 
    SECTION 1. [Statutory Authority.] The City of Wellington, Kansas, a city of the second class, by the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5 of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to and exempts itself from and makes inapplicable to it Section 14-10a01 through and including Section 14-10a15 of the Kansas Statutes Annotated. 
    SECTION 2. Name and Effective Date. The Policemen's and Firemen's Retirement System of Wellington, Kansas, hereinafter referred to as the "system" is hereby established for the purpose of providing disability annuities, retirement annuities, survivors annuities and death benefits for policemen and firemen of the City of Wellington, Kansas, and their dependents, pursuant to the provisions of this Ordinance. The effective date of the system shall be June 9, 1974, but will not include any policeman or fireman employed after January 1, 1974. 
    SECTION 3. Definitions. The following words and phrases used in this Ordinance, unless a different meaning is plainly required by the context, shall have the following meanings: 
(a)  "CITY" shall mean the City of Wellington, Kansas. 
(b)  "BOARD" shall mean the Board of Trustees of the Policemen's and Firemen's Retirement System. 
(c)  "POLICEMAN or FIREMAN" shall mean, in the case of a policeman, any employee of the Police Department of the City holding the rank of Patrolman, including commissioned officers; and in the case of Fireman, any employee of the Fire Department of the City holding the rank of Fireman, including probationary Fireman, of higher rank, including commissioned officers. The term "policeman or fireman" shall not include, (1) any person privately employed as a Policeman or Fireman, (2) any person temporarily employed as a Policeman or Fireman for an emergency, or (3) any civilian employee in the Police or Fire Departments, or (4) any person employed in either the Police Department or the Fire Department after January 1, 1974. 
(d)  "MEMBER" shall mean any Policeman or Fireman of the City included in the membership of the system and receiving compensation. 
(e)  "SERVICE" shall mean service rendered to the City as a Policeman or Fireman. 
(f)  "PRIOR SERVICE" shall mean service rendered by a member prior to the effective date of this Ordinance. 
(g)  "MEMBERSHIP SERVICE" shall mean service rendered by member on or after the effective date of this Ordinance. 
(h)  "CREDITED SERVICE" shall mean the sum of prior service and membership service for which a member has received credit under the provisions of this Ordinance. 
(i)  "DISABILITY" shall mean total inability to perform permanently the duties of the position held by the member at date of disability due to a physical or mental incapacity resulting from external force or violence or disease. 
(j)  "SERVICE-CONNECTED DISABILITY" shall mean any physical or mental incapacity resulting from external forces, violence or disease occasioned by an act of duty as a Policeman or Fireman imposed by the ordinances or rules and regulations of the City, or any other disability which may be directly attributable to an act of duty. 
(k)  "NONSERVICE-CONNECTED DISABILITY" shall mean all disabilities other than Service-Connected Disabilities, except disabilities incurred in private employment or in the National Guard or in military service of United States or any of its allies. 
(l)  "ACT OF DUTY" shall mean an act performed by a member within the scope of occupational duties during the course of his employment for the purpose of protecting life or property, including any act of heroism as a member. 
(m)  "WITHDRAWAL FROM SERVICE" shall mean complete severance of employment of any member as an employee of the Police and, or Fire Departments of the City by resignation, discharge or dismissal. 
(n)  "ACTUARIAL TABLES" shall mean such tables of mortality and rates of interest as may be adopted by the Board upon recommendation of the actuary employed by the Board, provided, however, that for the first five years of operation the actuarial table to be used shall be that known as the Combined Annuity Mortality Table and regular interest. 
(o)  "REGULAR INTEREST" shall mean interest at 31/2% per annum compounded annually, for the first five years of operation, and thereafter such rate as may be prescribed by the Board based upon the experience of the system. 
(p)  "MINOR CHILD" or "MINOR CHILDREN" eligible for consideration under the provisions of the ordinance shall mean children of the blood and legally adopted children. 
(q)  "WIDOW" shall mean that person who survives the decedent that was his wife at the time of disability or retirement. 
(r)  "WIFE" shall mean that person who is the member's wife, other than at common-law, at the time of the member's death or retirement. 
(s)  "VESTED RIGHTS" shall mean a right that is absolute, without contingency, at a specified time. 
    SECTION 4. Membership. Membership of the system shall include, in addition to those persons defined as members in Section 3(d), the following: 
(a)  Any person who was a Policeman or Fireman on the effective date of this Ordinance, and 
(b)  Any Policeman or Fireman who was temporarily absent on the effective date of this Ordinance due to sickness or disability, or who was on approved leave for any cause, provided such leave shall not be extended for more than one year continuously, except for military service. 
    SECTION 5. Creditable Service. 
(a)  Credit as prior service shall be granted to any person who was a member of the system on the effective date of this Ordinance representing the same periods of time prior to said effective date for which pension credit was granted under any police pension fund or fireman's pension fund maintained by the City, by whatever name called, in which the member was a participant, and for membership service after the effective date of this Ordinance for which the member makes contributions. 
(b)  Credit for military service shall be granted in the same manner as if service was rendered the City uninterruptedly to any member entering the service of the army, navy, air force, marines or coast guard of the United States by enlistment or induction during the time of war, or other national emergency recognized by the Board, who re-enters the employ of the City within 90 days from the date of termination of his armed service after discharge, so long as said discharge is not dishonorable. 
(c)  In the computation of prior service or membership service, 15 days of service or more during any month shall constitute a month of service, and 12 months of service shall constitute a year of service. In no case, except for military service, shall credit be allowed for any period of absence without salary, nor shall less than 15 days of service during any month be considered for the computation of service, nor shall more than one year of service be credited for service rendered in any one calendar year. 
    SECTION 6. Permanent Service-Connected Disability Benefits. 
(a)  Any member, who shall, while engaged in the performance of his duties, be permanently injured or disabled, and upon examination by a physician or physicians appointed by the Board, be found to be physically or mentally disabled as a result of such permanent disability or injury so as to render him unfit for the performance of service as a policeman or fireman, shall be entitled to be retired, and the board of trustees shall thereupon order his retirement, and upon his being so retired he shall be paid each month a sum equal to 50% of his average monthly compensation computed on the basis of the 12 months immediately preceding such retirement. After five years of continuous credited service, heart and lung disease shall be presumed to be a service connected disability. 
(b)  The board of trustees may, when they deem it advisable, call back for re-examination by a physician, any member retired by reasons of permanent disability under the provisions of this Ordinance, and if said examination discloses that said member is then able to perform his duties, or any other duties to which he may be assigned in said department without reduction in salary, he may be returned to service. If said member fails or refuses for 10 days after call back for re-examination as aforesaid to submit to such re-examination, or if said member after re-examination, upon request of the board, fails or refuses to return to duty, then and in either event all payments from said system shall cease. In the event such member returns to duty, the time lost by reason of such injury or disability shall be included in his membership service for retirement purposes. 
(c)  Any such annuity shall begin to accrue from the date of disability of the member, provided that any and all payments received by the member during disability under the Workmen's Compensation laws of the State of Kansas, or under other ordinances of the City, or from any public funds of whatsoever nature, except Federal Social Security, shall be applied to reduce the amounts accruing on the annuity. 
    SECTION 7. Non-service Connected Disability. 
(a)  Any member having at least five (5) years of credited service who becomes totally and permanently disabled due to any cause other than service connected disability, except disabilities incurred in private employment, or in the National Guard or in the military service of the United States or any of its allies, while an employee of the City, shall be entitled to a non-service connected disability annuity. Such annuity shall be equal to 2.28% of the members salary for the 12 months immediately preceding such disability multiplied by the number of years of credited service of the member; for credited service in excess of 22 years 1.1% per year of credited service above 22 years shall be added to said annuity, provided, however, that no member shall receive under this Section 7(a) more than 66% of his final average monthly salary computed on the basis of the 12 months immediately preceding such disability. Such annuity shall be paid in 12 monthly payments each year. 
(b)  The board of trustees may, when they deem it advisable, call back for re-examination by a physician, any member retired by reason of non-service connected disability, and all provisions contained in SECTION 6(b) of this Ordinance pertaining to service connected disabilities shall apply to non-service connected disabilities, except, however, that in the event such member returns to duty, the time lost by reason of such non-service connected disability shall not be included in his membership service for retirement purposes. 
(c)  The annuity herein provided for non-service connected disability shall be reduced by all sums of money received by the member under the Workmen's Compensation laws of the State of Kansas, or under other ordinances of the City, or from any public funds of whatsoever nature, except Federal Social Security. 
(d)  Non-Service connected disability shall be considered total and permanent if it results in some impairment of mind or body due to mental or physical incapacity resulting from external force, or violence or disease that substantially precludes a member from performing with reasonable regularity the substantial and material parts of any gainful work or occupation that he would be competent to perform were it not for the fact that the impairment is founded upon conditions which render it reasonably certain that it will continue indefinitely. 
(e)  A non-service connected disability annuity shall begin to accrue upon the commencement of the disability, provided that if the member is receiving salary or compensation, the annuity shall begin to accrue from the date the salary or compensation has ceased. If written application shall not have been filed with the board prior to the expiration of ninety days from the date of disability, the annuity shall begin to accrue from the date application therefore has been filed, but in no event prior to the time when payments to the member on account of salary or compensation have ceased. 
(f)  Notwithstanding the provisions contained in SECTION 7(c) above, pertaining to non-service connected disabilities, a member shall be allowed to earn additional income, without reduction of the annuity herein provided for non-service connected disabilities, in an amount sufficient to make the total of the members extra earnings together with his annuity equal his final average monthly rate of pay computed on the basis of the 12 months immediately prior to the date on which annuity begins to accrue. The annuity shall be reduced by fifty percent (50%) of the amount the members extra earnings exceed his final average monthly rate of pay computed as aforesaid. The foregoing limitations on earning additional income shall cease when the member becomes eligible to retire by reason of age and years of service. 
    SECTION 8. Administration of Disability Annuities. 
(a)  The determination of disability from any cause shall be made upon the basis of reports of examinations made by at least two (2) physicians designated by the Board. 
(b)  A member receiving service connected or non-service connected disability annuity shall be required to submit to an examination at least once each year by a physician or physicians designated by the Board to determine whether the member is incapacitated for active service as a policeman or fireman and is entitled to receive a disability annuity. The Board may terminate a disability annuity upon evidence that the member is no longer disabled for service, or if the member fails or refuses to submit to such examination for ten (10) days after he is notified to submit to such examination. If upon such termination the member does not reenter service, he shall be entitled to a refund of the excess, if any, of his contributions to the pension fund created herein, without interest, over the amount received by the member as a disability annuity. 
(c)  If a medical examination or an investigation made by the board discloses that the member is engaged or is able to engage in any gainful occupation resulting in earnings for services rendered in any capacity, the disability annuity shall be reduced to an amount which, when added to the members income from such gainful occupation, does not exceed the current monthly salary being paid for the position or rank similar to that held by the member at the commencement of his disability. If the examination or investigation aforesaid discloses that the member is able to engage in any gainful occupation, and the member fails or refuses so to do, then and in that event the disability annuity shall be terminated. 
(d)  Any member receiving a disability annuity under the provisions of this Ordinance shall submit to the board at least once each year in a form to be determined by the board a full, complete and accurate statement of income for the preceding 12 months. Such statement of income may be used as a basis for adjusting any annuity payments made to a member under the provisions of this Ordinance. If the member fails or refuses to furnish the board such statement of income within 10 days after the board requests the same, or if the board determines that some material information contained in such statement of income is false the disability annuity shall be terminated. 
(e)  Any disability annuity terminated because of the members failure or refusal to submit to an examination or re-examination by a physician, or because of the members failure or refusal to engage in a gainful occupation when it is disclosed by a medical examination or investigation by the board that the member is able to do so, or because of the members failure or refusal to submit a full, complete and accurate statement of income, shall be reinstated by the board at such time as it determines that the member is in compliance with the provisions of this Ordinance under which the annuity was terminated. If the member fails for one year to comply with the aforesaid provisions the terminated disability shall not be reinstated, and the same shall be revoked by the board. 
    SECTION 9. Service Connected Death. 
(a)  Upon the death of a member resulting directly from service connected causes or from an occupational disease, a surviving widow shall be entitled to an annuity equal to fifty percent (50%) of the final average monthly salary of the decedent computed on the basis of the 12 months immediately preceding the death, or the amount the decedent would have received monthly under section 11 of this Ordinance if he be deemed to have retired at the time of his death, whichever amount is greater. 
(b)  In the event the decedent leaves no surviving widow, or in the event a surviving widow remarries or dies, then and in any of such events any surviving child or children of the deceased member under the age of 18 years shall receive fifty percent (50%) of the decedent's final average monthly salary computed on the basis of the 12 months immediately preceding the death until said child or the youngest of said children reaches the age of 18 years, or marries, whichever occurs first. In the event there is more than one surviving child eligible for benefits under the provisions of this Section 9(b), then and in that event the total benefits due hereunder shall be divided equally among the eligible children. 
    SECTION 10. Non-service Connected Death. 
(a)  Upon the death of a member resulting from non-service connected causes, if the member had at least five (5) years of credited service, a surviving widow shall be entitled to an annuity equal to the amount the deceased member would have received monthly under Section 11 of this Ordinance if he be deemed to have retired at the time of his death. 
(b)  In the event the decedent leaves no surviving widow, or in the event a surviving widow remarries or dies, then and in any of such events any surviving child or children of the deceased member under the age of 18 years shall receive the amount fixed by Section 10(a) of this Ordinance until said child or the youngest of said children reaches the age of 18 years, or marries, whichever occurs first. In the event there is more than one surviving child eligible for benefits under the provisions of this Section 10(b), then and in that event the total benefits due hereunder shall be divided equally among the eligible children. 
(c)  If, under the provisions of this Ordinance, the beneficiaries named in this Section 10 are determined not to be entitled to any benefits, such beneficiaries shall be entitled to fifty percent (50%) of all moneys contributed by the deceased member to the Policemen's or Firemen's Pension Fund of the City prior to the effective date of this Ordinance plus one hundred percent (100%) of all moneys contributed by the deceased member to the pension fund herein created subsequent to the effective date of this Ordinance. 
    SECTION 11. Service Annuity Retirement. 
(a)  Any member having credited service of 22 years or more and having reached the age of 50 years may make application to be retired, and if such application is made the board shall retire such member and pay him monthly payments in an amount equal to 2.28% of his final average monthly salary computed on the basis of the 12 months immediately prior to retirement multiplied by the number of years of credited service plus 1.1% of said final average monthly salary for each year of credited service in excess of 22 years, provided, however, that in no event shall the service annuity paid hereunder exceed 66% of the members final average monthly salary. 
(b)  If any member be discharged or terminated by resignation of for any other reason after having credited service of 22 years, the board shall order and direct that said member, upon attaining the age of 50 years, be paid monthly payments computed as provided in Section 11(a), above, and subject to the 66% limitation contained therein, except that the members final average monthly salary shall be computed on the basis of the 12 months immediately prior to his discharge or termination by resignation or other reason. 
    SECTION 12. Payment to Widow After Death of Retired Member. If any member should die after having retired for age and service, or for service only or for service connected disability, leaving a widow, said widow, so long as she remains such widow, shall receive monthly an amount equal to fifty percent (50%) of the decedent's average monthly compensation computed on the basis of the 12 months immediately preceding his retirement. 
    SECTION 13. Accounting and Actuarial Studies. 
(a)  The assets of the system shall be held for the express purposes set forth in the provisions of this Ordinance subject to the conditions prescribed herein. An adequate system of accounts and records shall be established and maintained to give effect to the requirements hereof and all assets of the system shall be credited to accounts according to the purposes for which they are held. 
(b)  An actuarial survey of the system shall be made at such times as the board deems proper and appropriate to check the mortality, turnover, disability, interest and other actuarial factors assumed in calculations of liabilities and costs. An annual actuarial valuation of the system shall be made at the close of each fiscal year for the purpose of establishing its financial condition and checking its current operating experience. 
    SECTION 14. Management - Policy Direction. 
(a)  The system created by this Ordinance shall be construed to be a trust, separate and distinct from all other entities. The responsibility for the direction and operation of the system, and for making effective the provisions hereof, are hereby vested in a board of trustees, which board shall be directly responsible to the governing body of the city. The board shall consist of eight members, as follows: 
(1)  The City Manager; 
(2)  The Chief of the Police Department and the Chief of the Fire Department; 
(3)  The City Attorney; 
(4)  Two policemen and two firemen, each having at least three years of credited service, who shall be members of the system and shall be elected by the active members from the respective occupational groups as hereinafter provided according to the rules of election to be adopted by the board. Until elections for trustees are held, the governing body of the city shall appoint four temporary trustees meeting the foregoing qualifications from among the policemen and firemen who shall hold office until permanent trustees are elected, but the terms of such temporary trustees shall not extend for more than six month. 
(b)  The original elected trustees shall serve for the following terms: one representing policemen for a term of two years and one for a term of four years; and one representing firemen for a term of two years and one for a term of four years. The trustees so elected shall take office upon their election and shall succeed the temporary trustees appointed by the governing body of the city. Their terms of office shall expire on the third Monday in April of the second and fourth year following their election as the case may be. The trustees elected to succeed the original elected trustees shall serve for terms of four years. 
(c)  A permanent trustee shall continue in office until his successor is elected or appointed, and has qualified. Any trustee who is a policeman or fireman shall be disqualified to serve in that capacity upon termination of service with the city. If a vacancy occurs in the office of elective trustee, a successor shall be elected for the unexpired term of office within 30 days by a special election, unless the regular bi-annual election occurs sooner. If a vacancy occurs in the office of an appointive trustee, such vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the office was previously filled. 
(d)  Each trustee shall take an oath that, so far as it devolves upon him, he will diligently and honestly administer the affairs of the board, and that he will not knowingly or willfully permit to be violated any of the provisions of the ordinance applicable to the system. Such oath shall be subscribed by the person taking it, and certified by the officer before whom it is taken, and immediately filed with the City Clerk. A trustee shall be deemed to have qualified for membership on the board when such oath shall have been filed. 
(e)  Subject to the limitations prescribed herein, the board shall from time to time establish rules and regulations for the administration of the system and to implement the provisions of this ordinance as may be required. It shall hold regular meetings at least quarterly in each year and such special meetings as may be deemed necessary, provided, however, that written notice of such special meetings shall be given all trustees at least 48 hours in advance of the time fixed for such special meeting. The annual meeting shall be held on the third Wednesday of January of each year. All meetings shall be open to the public. A record of proceedings of all meetings shall be kept by the board and a copy thereof filed with the City Clerk. 
(f)  Each trustee shall be entitled to one vote on the board, and the concurrence of five trustees shall be necessary for a decision at any regular or special meeting. A trustee shall receive no salary as such while serving in that capacity. 
    SECTION 15. Officers and Their Duties. The board shall have the following officers, whose duties shall be prescribed by by-laws to be adopted by the board: 
(a)  A Chairman and a Vice Chairman shall be elected from among its members. 
(b)  The administrator of the system shall be the City Clerk who shall be an ex officio member of the Board. 
(c)  The City Treasurer, ex officio, shall be treasurer of the system and shall have custody of its moneys and securities. All disbursements by the system shall be made by the treasurer upon authorization of the Board. 
(d)  The City Attorney shall be legal counsel to the Board and shall represent the board in all legal matters affecting the system. 
(e)  An actuary may be appointed by the board to serve as technical advisor in the administration of the system on matters pertaining to the technical and actuarial aspects thereof. 
(f)  A physician or physicians shall be appointed at the discretion of the board to pass upon claims for service connected and non-service connected disability annuities and service connected death annuities, on medical questions pertaining to such claims, and any other matter requiring medical advice that may arise in administration. 
    SECTION 16. Administration. Subject to the orders and resolutions of the board, the administrator of the system shall: 
(a)  Employ such clerical and professional services as may be required for the proper operation of the system, whose compensation shall be fixed by the governing body of the city; 
(b)  Establish and maintain records, files and accounts in such form and scope as will give full effect to the requirements of the system in accordance with the provisions hereof; 
(c)  Accumulate actuarial data concerning the operating experience of the system in such form as is necessary for the annual actuarial valuations and periodic actuarial studies in accordance with the recommendations of the actuary; 
(d)  Prepare periodic reports as may be required for the administration of the system; 
(e)  Prepare each year the annual report of the board to be submitted to the governing body of the City embodying, among other things, an accountant's balance sheet supported by a statement of income and expenditures, a listing of investments owned by the system, a detailed statement of investments acquired and disposed of during the year covered by the report, and such other financial and statistical data as may be deemed necessary for a proper interpretation of the condition of the system and the results of its operations. The board shall cause to be distributed among the members of the system a synopsis of such annual report. 
    SECTION 17. Investments. 
(a)  The board may keep as an available fund for current disbursements by the system an amount not to exceed the requirements for such purposes for a period of ninety days. Any amounts in excess of the aforesaid current balance shall be invested in investments authorized for idle funds of the city by other ordinances of said city. 
(b)  The board shall have the power to hold, purchase, sell, assign, transfer and dispose of any of the securities in which moneys of the system have been invested, as well as proceeds from such investments, and any other property belonging to the system. 
(c)  All investments shall be clearly marked to indicate ownership of the system, and to the extent possible, shall be registered in its name. No securities shall be purchased or sold, or in any manner hypothecated, except by action of the board duly entered in the record of its proceedings. 
(d)  Any limitations affecting the purchase of securities shall be applicable only at the time of purchase and shall not require the liquidation of an investment at any time. 
(e)  No member or employee of the board shall have any direct interest in the income or gains from any investment made by the board, nor shall any such person receive any pay or emolument for services in connection with any investment. No member or employee of the board shall become an endorser or surety, or in any manner an obligor for money loaned or borrowed from the system. The governing body of the city may remove from office any member or employee of the board who violates the provisions of this Section 17(e) if three-fourths of the members elect of such governing body vote in favor of such removal. 
    SECTION 18. Exemptions. The right to a service retirement annuity, disability annuity, death annuity or any annuity or benefit under the provisions of this Ordinance, by whatever name called, or a refund, is personal with the recipient thereof, and the assignment or transfer of any such annuity or benefit or any part thereof shall be void, except as may be provided herein. Any such annuity or benefit shall not answer for debts contracted by the person receiving the same, and it is the intention of this Ordinance that such annuity or benefits shall not be subject to execution, attachment, garnishment, or affected by any judicial proceedings including bankruptcy. 
    SECTION 19. Monthly Payments. Any service retirement annuity, disability annuity, death annuity or any other annuity provided herein shall be payable in equal monthly installments as a life annuity except as herein otherwise provided. The first payment of any such annuity shall be made for the fraction of the month elapsing until the end of the first month; and in the case of the death of a retiree, leaving no spouse or minor children, the last payment shall be a partial annuity to be paid from the end of the month for which the last payment was made to and including the date of death, and such payment shall be made to a relative. 
    SECTION 20. Fraud. Any person who knowingly makes any false statement, or falsifies or permits to be falsified, any record or records of this system, in any attempt to defraud the system, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. The system and the city shall have the right to recover by setoff or otherwise, any payments made under false representation. If any such person be a member of the system, or the beneficiary of a member, he/she shall forfeit all rights to further participation in any of the benefits hereunder. 
    SECTION 21. Creation and Maintenance of Fund. 
(a)  For the purpose of funding the system and financing and paying the cost of the annuities and benefits herein provided for there is hereby created a fund to be known as the Policemen's and Firemen's Retirement Fund into which Fund there shall be placed the following: 
(1)  Superseded pension funds which shall consist of all cash, securities and other assets accumulated by any policemen's pension fund or firemen's pension fund pursuant to any prior statute or ordinance of the city; 
(2)  An assessment against each member equal to four percent (4%) of his monthly salary and compensation, the same to be deducted from the regular payroll and transferred to this Fund; 
(3)  Proceeds from the sale of lost or stolen securities, money or other personal property which shall remain unclaimed in possession of the Police Department or the Fire Department of the city for more than six (6) months, together with the proceeds from the sale of unclaimed or confiscated property of any nature whatsoever which shall have been in custody of the Police Department for a period of more than six (6) months; and the city is hereby authorized to sell such property at public auction at such times as it deems appropriate; 
(4)  Gifts, grants, bequests, and gratuities of money or other property given to this Fund; and the city and board are hereby authorized to receive the same for placement in this Fund. If property other than cash is so received for this Fund, the board may, at its discretion, convert such property into cash or retain the same in the form it was at the time of its receipt; 
(5)  Proceeds of the tax levy hereinafter provided for, for the purpose of funding the system. 
(b)  There shall be deducted from the salary of every member, beginning on the first day of the month after the effective date of this Ordinance, four percent (4%) of his monthly salary and compensation, which sum shall be paid into the fund created in Section 21(a), above, of this Ordinance. 
(c)  For the purpose of funding all obligations of the system under the provisions of this Ordinance over and above member contributions and other income and receipts accruing to and received by the system, as herein provided, the city shall levy a tax upon all taxable tangible property in the city, which levy shall be in addition to the levies now authorized by law for corporate or other purposes. 
    SECTION 22. Refund of Member's Contributions. 
(a)  Any member who is discharged or whose services are terminated by resignation from either the Police Department or the Fire Department prior to retirement shall be entitled, upon demand, to be paid within ninety (90) days after such demand an amount equal to fifty percent (50%) of the deductions from his salary and compensation paid into the prior Police Pension Fund or the prior Firemen's Pension Fund of the city and accrued for service rendered prior to the effective date of this Ordinance, and the full amount of any deductions made under Section 21(b) of this Ordinance accruing on or after the effective date of this Ordinance. The payment of the sums provided for in the foregoing sentence shall automatically effect a waiver and forfeiture of all accrued rights and benefits of the member to whom the payment is made in the system. This Section 22(a) is to be construed as not to apply to any person receiving a disability annuity under the provisions of this Ordinance. 
(b)  Any member who has received a refund under Section 22(a) of this Ordinance shall be considered a new member upon subsequent re-employment by the Police or Fire Departments, provided that such member shall render at least three (3) years of service following his latest re-entry into service, and he shall be entitled to regain his previously forfeited credited service upon repayment of all amounts received as such refund plus regular interest from the date of the members receipt of such refund to the date of repayment. The time and manner of making such repayment shall be fixed by the board. 
(c)  If a member dies leaving no persons eligible for a death annuity under the provisions of this Ordinance, there shall be paid to any person named or designated in a written designation signed, acknowledged, and filed with the board by the decedent before his death, the amount of the decedent's contributions to the system that he would have been entitled to under Section 22(a) of this Ordinance had he been discharged or terminated by resignation before his death. In the event that more than one written designation is filed by the same member, the written designation last filed shall take precedence. In the event no written designation shall have been filed prior to the death, the amount that would have been paid to a designee, had there been such, will be paid to the decedent's legal representative. 
(d)  In the event that all beneficiaries of a deceased member, namely the surviving widow and children under the age of 18 years, lose their eligibility to receive any annuity that said beneficiaries had been receiving under the provisions of this Ordinance, then and in that event, there shall be paid to any person named or designated in a written designation in accordance with the requirements for said written designation hereinabove set forth in Section 22(c) of this Ordinance the amount, if any, by which the sum the deceased member would have been entitled to receive under Section 22(a) of this Ordinance had he been discharged or terminated by resignation at the time of his death exceeds the total amount paid to the member and his surviving widow and children under 18 years of age under the provisions of this Ordinance. In the event no person has been named or designated, as mentioned above, any sum due under this Section 22(d) shall be paid to the decedent's legal representative. 
    SECTION 23. Benefit and Disability Rights Under Prior Laws Saved. This Ordinance shall not affect the existing rights of any policeman or fireman, or his widow or children under 18 years of age, who has heretofore been killed, permanently disabled, or has died or has retired because of age and, or years of credited service under the Firemen's Pension Fund, the same being Sections 9-301 to 9-312, inclusive, of the Code of the City of Wellington, Kansas 1969, or under the Police Pension Fund, the same being Sections 16-301 to 16-312, inclusive, of the Code of the City of Wellington, Kansas 1969. Benefits and annuities to be paid by virtue of the existing rights aforesaid shall be paid from the system and fund created by this Ordinance. 
    SECTION 24. Funeral Expenses. Whenever an active or retired member shall die, the board shall appropriate and pay from the system the sum of $100.00 for funeral expenses of such member. 
    SECTION 25. Invalidity of Part. If any provisions of this Ordinance or the application thereof to any person or circumstances is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of this Ordinance which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to this extent the provisions of this Ordinance are declared to be severable. 
    SECTION 26. Repealer. That Sections 9-301 to 9-312, inclusive, and Sections 16-301 to 16-312, inclusive of the Code of the City of Wellington, Kansas 1969, are hereby repealed. 
    SECTION 27. Publication. This Ordinance shall be published once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    SECTION 28. Effective Date and Petition for Referendum. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance as provided in Article 12, Section 5, Subdivision (c)(3) of the Constitution of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by the majority of the electors voting thereon. 
    PASSED by the Governing Body, not less than two-thirds of the members-elect voting in favor thereof this 5th day of March, 1974. 
CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 8 [9] 
    A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A. 14-301 AND PROVIDING SUBSTITUTE PROVISIONS ON THE SAME SUBJECT, RELATING TO POWERS OF THE MAYOR, AND REPEALING SECTION 1-106 OF THE CODE OF THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS 1974. 
    BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS: 
    SECTION I. The City of Wellington, Kansas, by the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt itself from and make inapplicable to it the provisions of K.S.A. 14-301, and provide substitute provisions as hereinafter set forth in this ordinance. K.S.A. 14-301 is an enactment which is applicable to this city, but not being applicable uniformly to all cities. 
    SECTION II. The Mayor shall preside at all meetings of the city council. 
    SECTION III. Section 1-106 of the Code of the City of Wellington, Kansas 1974, is hereby repealed. 
    SECTION IV. This ordinance shall be published once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    SECTION V. This is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance as provided in Article 12, Section 5, Subdivision (c)(3) of the Constitution of Kansas, in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by the majority of the electors voting thereon. 
    Passed by the Council, not less than two-thirds of the members-elect voting in favor thereof, the 15th day of May, 1979. 
CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 9 [10] 
    A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS, FROM K.S.A. 79-5001 TO 79-5017, INCLUSIVE, AND ANY AMENDMENTS THERETO; AND REPEALING CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 5 OF SAID CITY. 
    BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS: 
    SECTION I. The City of Wellington, Kansas, by the power invested in it by Article 12, Section 5 of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt itself from and make inapplicable to it K.S.A. 79-5001 to 79-5017, inclusive, and any amendments thereto, which is an enactment of the legislature applicable to this City, but which is not applicable uniformly to all cities. 
    SECTION II. The provisions of K.S.A. 79-5001 to 79-5017, inclusive, and any amendments thereto, shall not apply to any taxes levied by the City of Wellington, Kansas. 
    SECTION III. Charter Ordinance No. 5 of the City of Wellington, Kansas, is hereby repealed. 
    SECTION IV. This Charter Ordinance shall be published once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    SECTION V. This Charter Ordinance shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after final publication, unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the Ordinance as provided in Article 12, Section 5, Subsection (c)(3) of the Constitution of Kansas, in which case the Ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
    PASSED by the Governing Body, not less than two-thirds of the members-elect voting in favor thereof, the 19th day of August, 1980. 
CHARTER ORDINANCE NO. 10 [11] 
    A CHARTER ORDINANCE EXEMPTING THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS, FROM THE PROVISIONS OF K.S.A. 1980 SUPP. 75-1117, 75-1120, 75-1120a, 75-1121 AND 75-1122 SO AS TO NOT REQUIRE SAID CITY TO MAINTAIN FIXED ASSETS RECORDS AND ACCOUNTING. 
    BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF WELLINGTON, KANSAS: 
    SECTION I. That the City of Wellington, Kansas, a city of the second class, by virtue of the power vested in it by Article 12, Section 5, of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, hereby elects to exempt itself from the provisions of K.S.A. 1980 Supp. 75-1117, 75-1120, 75-1120a, 75-1121 and 75-1122 and makes said statutes inapplicable to said City insofar as they require it to maintain fixed asset records and accountings. 
    SECTION II. This Ordinance shall be published once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
    SECTION III. This is a Charter Ordinance and shall take effect sixty-one (61) days after final publication unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed as provided in Article 12, Section 5, subdivision (c)(3) of the Constitution of the State of Kansas, in which case the Charter Ordinance shall become effective upon approval by a majority of electors voting at an election held on the said Charter Ordinance. 
    PASSED by the Council, not less than two-thirds of the members elect voting in favor thereof, the 16th day of June, 1981.
