If any cat is not redeemed by its owner or harborer within the time allowed for redemption as specified in section 6-66, the animal control officer, any authorized law enforcement officer, any authorized veterinarian, or any duly authorized pound personnel may destroy such cat or adopt out the cat for the costs of impoundment and keeping, plus any registration fee due for the current year. 
(3)  Conditions for adoptions of cats. Any person shall be entitled to adopt a cat from the city pound if the following conditions and requirements are met: 
a.  The cat is in good health. 
b.  The cat is not vicious, fierce or dangerous. 
c.  The cat shall be vaccinated for rabies. 
d.  The cat, whether male or female, has been surgically spayed or neutered by a licensed veterinarian, unless the cat is being adopted by someone from outside the corporate city limits. 
e.  The cat has been impounded for more than five days and the owner or harborer has failed to claim such cat; provided, however, that the cat may be adopted at any time while impounded if the owner of the cat consents to such adoption in writing. 
f.  The person wishing to adopt such cat has paid the city the boarding fee as fixed in section 5-58 for each day that the cat has been impounded over the five-day waiting period required by section 6-66. 
(Ord. No. 4124,  I, 12-18-2012) 
Secs. 6-142-6-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER 

Sec. 6-171. - Animal control officer. 
(a)  Animal control officer. There is hereby created the position of animal control officer for the city, and such officer shall be charged with the enforcement of this chapter. Any person employed by the city as an animal control officer and commissioned by the chief of police of the city shall have such powers and authority as allowed by law in the enforcement of this chapter. All animal control officers shall be subject to the supervision and direction of the chief of police of the city. 
(b)  Duty to impound animals. Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, it shall be the duty of the animal control officer to take up and impound all animals found in the city in violation of the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  Citations. As an alternative to the provisions of subsection (b) of this section, any law enforcement officer or the animal control officer may issue a citation to the owner, harborer or keeper of an animal in violation of this chapter, and the person receiving the citation shall, within ten days, appear in the municipal court of the city to answer the charged violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 4124,  I, 12-18-2012) 
Chapter 8 - BUILDINGS AND CONSTRUCTION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 8-1-8-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE LIMITS 

Sec. 8-19. - Defined. 
    The following shall be and are hereby declared to be the fire limits of the city: 
    The west half of Block 45, all of Block 46, all of Block 53, the west half of Block 54, all of Block 59, all of Block 60, south half of Block 61, east half of Block 66, all of Block 67, all of Block 68, all of Block 73, all of Block 74, north half of Block 75, east half of Block 81, all of Block 82, and the west half of Block 83, all in the original town, now City of Wellington. 
(Code 1974,  4-201; Code 1996,  4-201) 
Sec. 8-20. - Repair of frame buildings in fire limits. 
    Any existing building or structure within the fire limits of wood frame construction or of unprotected noncombustible construction which may hereafter become damaged by fire to an amount greater than 50 percent of its present value, exclusive of its foundation, shall not be repaired or rebuilt, but shall be removed. 
(Code 1974,  4-202; Code 1996,  4-202) 
Sec. 8-21. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not more than $100.00, or be imprisoned not more than three months, or be both so fined and imprisoned. 
(Code 1974,  4-203; Code 1996,  4-203) 
Secs. 8-22-8-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ADMINISTRATION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-46. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a building and codes department. The official in charge shall be known as the building official. The building official shall be appointed by the city manager. The department shall oversee all ordinances and codes related to building, zoning and code compliance. The building official is hereby authorized and directed to enforce the adopted codes relating to building, zoning, and code compliance. 
(Ord. No. 4243,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Secs. 8-47-8-63. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COMBINED TRADE BOARD 

Sec. 8-64. - Created. 
    There is hereby created the combined trade board, which shall consist of 11 members. One member shall be a licensed architect or engineer, two shall be building contractors, two shall be electrical contractors, two shall be mechanical contractors, two shall be plumbing contractors, and the final two members shall be residents-at-large. 
(Ord. No. 3928,  II, 4-5-2005; Ord. No. 4078,  I, 3-1-2011) 
Sec. 8-65. - Membership. 
(a)  Commencing no later than at the last regular meeting of the governing body in April 2011, the governing body shall appoint a building contractor, electrical contractor, mechanical contractor, and plumbing contractor to serve a term commencing April 16, 2011 through April 30, 2015. In the future, as each of these terms expires, the governing body shall appoint members to these positions for a term of four years commencing May 1st. Any member appointed to serve a four-year term after January 1, 2013, shall not serve more than two consecutive four-year terms. 
(b)  Commencing no later than at the last regular meeting of the governing body in April 2012, said governing body shall appoint a licensed architect or engineer and two residents-at-large to serve a term commencing April 16, 2012 through April 30, 2016. In the future, as each of these terms expires, the governing body shall appoint members to these positions for a term of four years commencing May 1st. Any member appointed to serve a four-year term after January 1, 2013, shall not serve more than two consecutive four-year terms. 
(c)  Commencing no later than at the last regular meeting of the governing body in April 2013 said governing body shall appoint a building contractor, electrical contractor, mechanical contractor, and plumbing contractor for a term commencing April 16, 2013 through April 30, 2017. In the future, as each of these terms expires, the governing body shall appoint members to these positions for a term of four years commencing May 1st. Any member appointed to serve a four-year term after January 1, 2013, shall not serve more than two consecutive four-year terms. 
(d)  Any member of the board may be removed by the city manager, at his discretion, for misfeasance, nonfeasance, or malfeasance, but only after he conducts an inquiry into any complaint about a member. Furthermore, if any member misses three or more consecutive meetings without good cause, his position shall be deemed vacated. 
(e)  Vacancies shall be filled by the governing body for the unexpired term. All members of said board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 3928,  III, 4-5-2005; Ord. No. 4016,  I, 5-6-2008; Ord. No. 4078,  I, 3-1-2011) 
Sec. 8-66. - Officers. 
    The combined trade board shall select a chairperson, vice-chairperson and secretary. Six or more members present for a meeting shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business and any action taken at any meeting shall require a majority vote of the quorum. 
(Ord. No. 3928,  IV, 4-5-2005) 
Sec. 8-67. - Duties. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the combined trade board to act as arbitration board in deciding any questions that may arise between the authority having jurisdiction for inspections (building official), and any person. The decisions of said board in such matters shall be final, unless an appeal, in writing, is taken to the governing body of the city. Also, it shall be the duty of the board to determine the suitability of alternate materials and methods of construction and to provide reasonable interpretations of codes governing the building, electrical, mechanical and plumbing trades. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the board to determine the methods and qualifications for the licensing of contractors in this community. 
(Ord. No. 3928,  IV, 4-5-2005; Ord. No. 4244,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Secs. 8-68-8-92. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STANDARDS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-93. - Adoption of the 2011 "Wichita Foundation, Basement and Slab-On Grade Standards". 
    There is hereby adopted by the city, for the purpose of establishing standards for the construction, alteration, and/or repair of foundations in the City of Wellington, Kansas, the "Wichita Foundation, Basement and Slab-on-grade Standards", Edition of 2011, revised November 22, 2011, of which one or more copies shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy," with all deleted or amended sections or portions thereof clearly marked to show such modification, and to which shall be attached a copy of this ordinance. Such copy or copies shall be filed with the city clerk and shall be open and available for public inspection at all reasonable hours. 
(Ord. No. 4246,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Editor's note- At the discretion of the editor, Ord. No. 4246,  I, adopted March 5, 2019, has been codified as as herein set out in  8-93. Said provisions did not expressly amend the Code. 
Sec. 8-94. - Residential decks. 
    There is hereby adopted by the city, for the purpose of establishing construction and permit requirements for residential decks, limited to deck designs using a uniform floor loading of 40 pounds per square foot live load and ten pounds per square foot dead load over the entire floor of the deck, in the City of Wellington, Kansas, the document titled "Residential Decks", dated January 1, 2017, of which one or more copies shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy," with all deleted or amended sections or portions thereof clearly marked to show such modification, and to which shall be attached a copy of this ordinance. Such copy or copies shall be filed with the city clerk and shall be open and available for public inspection at all reasonable hours. 
(Ord. No. 4247,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Editor's note- At the discretion of the editor, Ord. No. 4247,  I, adopted March 5, 2019, has been codified as as herein set out in  8-94. Said provisions did not expressly amend the Code. 
Secs. 8-95-8-112. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS 

Sec. 8-113. - Building permits-Required. 
(a)  Except as specified in the amendments listed in section 8-183, no building or structure regulated by this code shall be erected, constructed, enlarged, altered, repaired, moved, improved, removed, converted, or demolished unless a separate building permit for each building or structure has first been obtained from the building and codes department. Structures shall require additional permits for plumbing, electrical and mechanical. 
(b)  Exemption from the permit requirements of this Code shall not be deemed to grant authorization for any work to be done in any manner in violation of the Code or any other laws or ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1996,  4-101; Ord. No. 3657,  1; Ord. No. 3902,  I, 8-3-2004; Ord. No. 4244,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-114. - Same-Fees. 
(a)  There shall be charged and collected from the applicant, prior to the issuance of such permit, a fee for each permit in accordance with the fee schedule as set out in this section. The fee shall be computed on the estimated cost of construction as follows: 
(1)  New construction. For each permit obtained for construction of new one and two family dwellings or accessory buildings thereto, and all new commercial construction, there shall be charged and collected from the applicant a fee in accordance with this section. 
(2)  Swimming pools and hot tubs. For each permit issued for a swimming pool or hot tub accessory to a one- or two-family residence, a permit fee shall be charged based on the value of the work to be performed. 
(3)  Building repairs, alterations, roofing and reroofing including overlays, remodeling or additions to existing buildings. For each permit issued for repairing, altering, remodeling or additions to existing buildings, a permit fee shall be charged based on the value of the work to be performed. 
(4)  The permit fee for a fence shall be on file in the city clerk's office. No work shall commence prior to obtaining permit. 
(5)  All unused permits are subject to a refund of 80 percent if the application is made within ten days of the date of issuance. 
(b)  Permit fee schedule. The building permit fees shall be on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1996,  4-102; Ord. No. 3657,  1; Ord. No. 4012,  I, 3-18-2008) 
Sec. 8-115. - Expiration of permit. 
    Every permit issued by the city under the provisions of this Code shall expire by limitation and become null and void if the building or work authorized by such permit is not commenced within 180 days from the date of issuance of such permit, or if the building or work authorized by such permit is suspended or abandoned at any time after the work is commenced for a period of 180 days. In the event that such suspension or abandonment has exceeded one year then in order to renew action on a permit, the permittee shall pay a new full permit fee. 
(Code 1996,  4-103; Ord. No. 3657,  1) 
Sec. 8-116. - Suspension or revocation. 
    The building official may, in writing, suspend or revoke a permit issued under the provisions of this Code whenever the permit is issued in error or on the basis of incorrect information, or is in violation of any ordinance or regulation or any of the provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1996,  4-104; Ord. No. 3657,  1) 
Sec. 8-117. - Plans and specifications. 
    Before a building permit is issued for new construction or additions to existing structures, the plot plan must be approved by the city. Two copies of the construction plans (with one being an electronic copy) shall be submitted for review and approval by the building department and will be retained by the city. 
(1)  The plot plan must: 
a.  Show the location of all buildings on the construction site; 
b.  Show the location of utilities; 
c.  Show the dimensions of buildings; 
d.  Show the actual setback dimensions (reference data such as required setbacks and recorded easements should be included); and 
e.  Be drawn to scale (one inch equals 20 feet). 
(2)  The construction plan must show: 
a.  All construction details such as footing size and depth relative to ground line, crawl space height (if applicable); 
b.  Stem wall/basement wall design (size and reinforcement); 
c.  Wall details such as window and door openings; 
d.  Insulation type, placement and thickness; and 
e.  All details necessary for showing compliance. 
(Code 1996,  4-105; Ord. No. 3657,  1; Ord. No. 4244,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-118. - Building official to issue permits; authority; duties; records. 
    The following regulation shall govern the duties of the building official with reference to building permits: 
(1)  When an application for a building permit has been filed, it shall be the duty of the building official to determine whether such proposed building, structure or improvement conforms to standards set out in ordinances of the city and the building official may require that the plans and specifications for the same be submitted to an engineer authorized by the city to review said plans. If the city building official finds that such proposed building, structure or improvement meets the required standards, the building official shall issue a permit therefore. 
(2)  If the building official shall find any features of such proposed building, structure, addition, alteration or relocation not clearly covered and defined by the ordinances of the city, which in the building official's opinion may be dangerous or constitute a fire hazard, the building official shall promptly report the case to the city manager and no permits shall be issued except upon order of the city manager. Such order shall be endorsed upon the face of the permit. 
(3)  If in the process of erecting any building, structure, addition, alteration or relocation, for which a building permit has been issued, any feature is being incorporated in or upon the same, which was not specified in the application for such permit, or if such feature is not clearly covered or defined in any ordinance of the city or is in the building official's opinion dangerous or may constitute a fire hazard, the building official shall order further work upon such objectionable feature stopped and report the same to the city manager. Work upon such objectionable feature may be continued only upon the approval and order of the city manager. 
(4)  If in the process of erecting any building, structure, addition, alteration or relocation, for which a building permit is required, an excavation is to be made, which in the opinion of the building official, may be or may become dangerous, there shall be imposed and enforced on the face of the building permit a condition that a fence sufficient, in the opinion of the building official, to protect the public from such danger shall be erected and maintained around the area to be excavated at all times while the excavation or any part thereof or any construction in the excavation remains open and, in the opinion of the building official, remains dangerous. Failure to comply with any such condition shall render the building permit void, and the application for the building permit or the person who signs the building permit for and on behalf of the applicant may be punished for such failure to comply with the condition in the manner provided in this article. Each day that such condition is not complied with shall constitute a separate offense and may be punished separately. 
(5)  The building and codes department shall keep a record of all permits issued hereunder and shall file in the building department office all applications upon which permits are issued. All applications and permits shall be numbered consecutively in the order in which they are issued and shall agree as to essential detail with the application as approved. The record of permit shall give the location description, dimensions, materials to be used and the estimated cost of all work for which permits are issued. 
(Code 1996,  4-106; Ord. No. 3657,  1; Ord. No. 4244,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Secs. 8-119-8-149. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CERTIFICATE OF OCCUPANCY 

Sec. 8-150. - Required. 
    No building, structure or addition thereto constructed, built, moved, remodeled or reconstructed after the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived shall be occupied or used for an industrial, commercial or business purpose, nor shall the use of any land, building, structure or addition thereto be changed to any industrial, commercial or business use, unless a certificate of occupancy shall first have been obtained from the building official certifying that the proposed use or occupancy complies with all of the provisions of this division and all other ordinances and codes of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3774,  I, 12-2-1997; Ord. No. 4244,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-151. - Applications. 
(a)  Every application for a change of zoning, a special use permit or a building permit shall be deemed to be an application for a certificate of occupancy. 
(b)  Applications for utility services as well as inspections by the fire department and other departments of the city may indicate circumstances requiring a certificate of occupancy, in which case the utility office shall inform the applicant for service, or the fire department or other departments of the city shall inform the owner or occupant of the inspected premises of the requirement for a certificate of occupancy and shall report the circumstances to the building official. 
(c)  All applications for certificates of occupancy and all reports of circumstances that may require such certificates shall be filed with and reported to the building and codes department. 
(Ord. No. 3774,  II, 12-2-1997; Ord. No. 4244,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-152. - Issuance. 
(a)  No certificate of occupancy for a building, structure or addition thereto to which this division applies shall be issued until work necessary to comply with city ordinances and codes has been completed and the premises inspected and certified by the building official to be in full and complete compliance with the plans and specifications upon which the building permit was issued; and the premises have been inspected and certified by the zoning administrator to be in full and complete compliance with all the applicable regulations for the zoning district in which it is located, and with all other ordinances and codes of the city. 
(b)  All certificates of occupancy issued shall contain: 
(1)  The building permit number, if applicable; 
(2)  The address of the building or structure; 
(3)  The name and address of the owner of the subject property; 
(4)  An accurate description of the portion of the building for which the certificate is issued; 
(5)  A statement that the described portion of the building or structure has been inspected for compliance with the applicable ordinances and codes of the city and the use for which the proposed occupancy is classified; and 
(6)  The name of the person issuing such certificate. 
(c)  If a certificate of occupancy is not issued, a written notice shall be furnished the applicant within ten days after the application is properly filed stating the reasons why a certificate cannot be issued. 
(Ord. No. 3774,  III, 12-2-1997; Ord. No. 4244,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-153. - Temporary certificate. 
    If the building official finds that no substantial hazard will result from occupancy of any building or structure or portion thereof before the same is completed, a temporary certificate of occupancy may be issued to be valid for a period of not to exceed six months for the use of said building or structure, or portion thereof prior to the completion of the entire building or structure. 
(Ord. No. 3774,  IV, 12-2-1997; Ord. No. 4244,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-154. - Posted in conspicuous place. 
    The certificate of occupancy or temporary certificate of occupancy shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises and shall not be removed except by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 3774,  V, 12-2-1997; Ord. No. 4244,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-155. - Revocation. 
    The building official may, upon written notice to the person to whom the certificate was issued, suspend or revoke a certificate of occupancy or temporary certificate of occupancy issued under the provisions of this division whenever the certificate is issued in error, or on the basis of incorrect information supplied by the applicant, or when it is determined that the building or structure or portion thereof is in violation of this division or any other ordinance or code of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3774,  VI, 12-2-1997; Ord. No. 4244,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-156. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who or which shall violate any provisions of this division or fail to comply therewith or with any requirements thereof shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in a sum of not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00, or be imprisoned not to exceed three months, or be both so fined and imprisoned, and each day that such violation shall be permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 3774,  VII, 12-2-1997) 
Secs. 8-157-8-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - BUILDING CODE 

Sec. 8-181. - International Existing Building Code adopted. 
    The 2015 International Existing Building Code, published by the International Code Council, is hereby adopted in its entirety by the city. 
(Ord. No. 4083,  I, II, 3-15-2011; Ord. No. 4245,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-182. - Adoption of International Building Code by reference. 
    There is hereby adopted by the City for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the construction, alteration, moving, demolition, repair and use of any building or structure within the city, except work located primarily in a public way, public utility towers and poles, mechanical equipment not specifically regulated and hydraulic flood control structures, that certain standard building code known as the "International Building Code (the IBC),"2015 Edition", and Appendices "F", "H" and "J", thereto, prepared and published in book form by the International Code Council, Inc., save and except such portions as are hereinafter deleted, omitted, modified or amended, of which one or more copies of the IBC shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy," with all deleted or amended sections or portions thereof clearly marked to show such modification, and to which shall be attached a copy of this ordinance. Such copy or copies shall be filed with the city clerk and shall be open and available for public inspection at all reasonable hours. 
(Ord. No. 4083,  I, II, 3-15-2011; Ord. No. 4245,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-183. - Amendments to the 2015 International Building Code. 
    Section 101.1 shall be amended to read as follows: 
    101.1 Title. These regulations shall be known as the Building Code of the City of Wellington, hereinafter referred to as "this code." 
    Section 101.4.6 shall be deleted 
    Section 105.1.1 shall be deleted. 
    Section 105.1.2 shall be deleted. 
    Section 105.2 shall be amended to read as follows: 
    105.2. Work exempt from permit. Exemptions from permit requirements of this code shall not be deemed to grant authorization for any work to be done in any manner in violation of the provisions of this code or any other laws or ordinances of this jurisdiction. Permits shall not be required for the following: 
1.  One-story detached accessory structures used as tool and storage sheds, playhouses and similar uses, provided the floor area does not exceed 160 square feet (18.58m 2 ). 
2.  Oil Derricks. 
3.  Retaining walls that are not over 4 feet (1219mm) in height measured from the bottom of the footing to the top of the wall, unless supporting a surcharge or impounding Class I, II, or III A liquids. 
4.  Water tanks supported directly on grade if the capacity does not exceed 5,000 gallons (18,925L) and the ratio of height to diameter or width does not exceed 2:1. 
5.  Sidewalks and driveways not more than 30 inches (762mm) above adjacent grade, and not over any basement or story below and are not part of an accessible route. 
6.  Painting, papering, tiling, carpeting, cabinets, counter tops and similar finish work. 
7.  Temporary motion picture, television and theater stage sets and scenery. 
8.  Prefabricated swimming pools accessory to a group R-3 occupancy that are less than 24 inches (610mm) deep. 
9.  Shade cloth structures constructed for nursery or agricultural purposes, not including service systems. 
10.  Window awnings supported by an exterior wall that do not project more than 54 inches (1372mm) from the exterior wall and do not require additional support of Group R-3 and U occupancies. 
11.  Non-fixed and moveable fixtures, cases, racks, counters and partitions not over 5 feet 9 inches (1753mm) in height. 
12.  Exterior decks, stoops and porches not over 30 inches (762mm) above grade without overhead structures and not over any basement or story below. 
13.  Repair or replacement of roofing materials not exceeding 400 square feet (37.16M 2 ). 
14.  Repair or replacement of siding materials not exceeding 400 square feet (37.16M 2 ). 
15.  Repair or replacement of interior gypsum board on non-fire rated walls or ceilings, when the total area does not exceed 100 square feet (9.29M 2 ) within any 12-month period, and provided no framing, electrical, mechanical or plumbing changes are made. 
    Section 107.1 shall be amended to read as follows: 
    Section 107.1 General. Submittal documents consisting of construction documents, statements of special inspections, geotechnical report and other data shall be submitted in two or more sets (along with one electronic copy) with each permit application. The code official shall require documents, computations and specifications to be prepared and designed by a registered design professional having a valid State of Kansas license. Construction documents shall be drawn to scale and shall be of sufficient clarity to indicate the location, nature and extent of the work proposed and show in detail the work conforms to the provisions of this code. Where special conditions exist, the building official is authorized to require additional construction documents to be prepared by a registered design professional. 
    Exception: The building official is authorized to waive the submission of construction documents and other data not required to be prepared by a registered design professional if it is found that the nature of the work applied for is such that review of construction documents is not necessary to obtain compliance with this code. 
    Section 109.6 shall be amended to read as follows: 
    109.6 Refunds. The building official may authorize refunding of any fee paid hereunder, which was erroneously paid or collected. The building official may authorize refunding of not more than 80 percent of the fee paid when no work has been done under a permit issued in accordance with this code and which 180 days has not expired since the issuance of said permit. 
    Section 113.1 shall be deleted. 
    Section 113.2 shall be deleted. 
    Section 113.3 shall be deleted. 
    Section [F] 903.2.1.2 shall be amended to read as follows: 
    [F] 903.2.1.2 Group A-2. An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided for fire areas containing Group A-2 occupancies and intervening floors of the building where one of the following conditions exists: 
1.  The fire area exceeds 5,000 square feet (464.5m 2 ); 
2.  The fire area has an occupant load of 200 or more; or 
3.  The fire area is located on a floor other than the level of exit discharge serving such occupancies. 
    Section 907.2.1 shall be amended to read as follows: 
    907.2.1 A manual fire alarm system that activates the occupant notification system in accordance with section 907.5 shall be installed in Group A occupancies having an occupant load of 100 or more. Portions of Group E occupancies occupied for assembly purposes shall be provided with a fire alarm system as required for the Group E occupancy. 
    Exception: Manual fire alarm boxes are not required where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with section 903.3.1.1 and the occupant notification appliances will activate throughout the notification zones upon sprinkler water flow. 
    Chapter 11 shall be deleted in its entirety and replaced by the Americans with Disabilities Act as established by Federal Law. 
    Section 1507.2.1 shall be amended to read as follows: 
    1507.2.1 Deck Requirements. Asphalt shingles shall be fastened to solidly sheathed decks. Solidly sheathed decks defined in this section shall be of 4x8 plywood or OSB sheathing of minimum thickness per table 2304.8(3). Allowable spans and loads for wood structural panels for roof and subfloor sheathing and combination subfloor and underlayment or well-seasoned tongue-and- grove boards, not over six inches in nominal width and shall be 1 1/4 inch nominal minimum thickness and properly spaced and nailed. 
    Section 1608.2 shall be amended to read as follows: 
    1608.2 Ground snow load . The ground snow load for Wellington has been determined by the building official to be 15 psf (0.72kN/M 2 ). 
    Section 1609.3 shall be amended to read as follows: 
    1609.3 Ultimate design wind speed. The ultimate design wind speed for Wellington has been determined by the building official to be 115 miles per hour (51m/s). 
    Section 1609.3.1 shall be amended to read as follows: 
    1609.3.1 Wind speed conversion. The fastest mile wind velocities for Wellington have been determined by the building official to be 100 miles per hour (44 m/s). 
    Section 1612.3 shall be amended to read as follows: 
    1612.3. Establishment of flood hazard areas. To establish flood hazard areas, the applicable governing authority shall adopt a flood hazard map and supporting data. The flood hazard map shall include, at a minimum, areas of special flood hazard as identified by the Federal Emergency Management Agency in an engineering report entitled "The Flood Insurance Study for the City of Wellington", dated November 18, 2009, as amended or revised with the accompanying Floor Insurance Rate Map (FIRM) and Flood Boundary and Floodway Map (FBFM) and related supporting data along with any revisions thereto. The adopted flood hazard map and supporting data are herby adopted by reference and declared to be part of this section. 
    Section 1809.5 shall be amended to read as follows: 
    1809.5 Frost protection. Except where otherwise protected from frost, foundations and other permanent supports of buildings and structures shall be protected from frost by one or more of the following methods: 
1.  Extending below the frost line of the locality: 
2.  Constructing in accordance with ASCE 32; or 
3.  Erecting on solid rock. 
    The frost line for the City of Wellington shall be 30 inches (762mm) below the finish grade. 
    Exception: For other than Group R-2 and R-3 as applicable in Section 310.1 occupancies, one-story prefabricated buildings not over 160 square feet (18.58 m2) in floor area and supported in an approved manner may be attached to a building having a permanent foundation extending below frost line. The roof and exterior walls of the prefabricated building shall be flashed in an approved manner to form a weather-tight seal between structures. 
    Shallow foundations shall not bear on frozen soil unless such frozen condition is of a permanent character. 
    Section 2902.2 shall be amended to read as follows: 
    2902.2 Separate facilities. Where plumbing fixtures are required, separate facilities shall be provided for each sex. 
    Exceptions: 
1.  Separate facilities shall not be required for dwelling units and sleeping units. 
2.  Separate facilities shall not be required in structures or tenant spaces with a total occupant load, including both employees and customers, of 15 or fewer. 
3.  Separate facilities shall not be required in mercantile occupancies in which the maximum occupant load is 100 or less. 
4.  Separate facilities shall not be required in dining and drinking establishments when the seating capacity is 19 or less. 
(Ord. No. 4083,  I, II, 3-15-2011; Ord. No. 4245,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-184. - Adoption of International Residential Code by reference and amendments. 
(a)  There is hereby adopted by the city for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the construction, alteration, moving, demolition, repair and use of any building or structure within the city, except work located primarily in a public way, public utility towers and poles, mechanical equipment not specifically regulated and hydraulic floor control structures, that certain standard building code known as the International Residential Code (the "IRC), 2015 edition, including Appendices A through J and Appendices M through P, prepared and published in book form by the International Code Council, Inc., save and except such portions as are hereinafter deleted, omitted, modified or amended, of which one or more copies of the IRC shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy," with all deleted or amended sections or portions thereof clearly marked to show such modification, and to which shall be attached a copy of this ordinance. Such copy or copies shall be filed with the city clerk and shall be open and available for public inspection at all reasonable hours. 
(b)  The following amendments to the International Residential Code adopted herein are hereby adopted as follows: 
    Section R101.1 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    R101.1 Title. These provisions shall be known as the Residential Code for One- and Two-family Dwellings of the City of Wellington, Kansas, and shall be cited as such and will be referred to herein as "this code." 
    Section R105.2 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    R105.2 Work exempt from permit. Permits shall not be required for the following. Exemption from permit requirements of this code shall not be deemed to grant authorization for any work to be done in any manner in violation of the provisions of this code or any other laws or ordinances of this jurisdiction. 
    Building: 
1.  [a]  One-story detached accessory structures used as tool and storage sheds, playhouses and similar uses, provided the floor area does not exceed 160 square feet (18.58m 2 ) and a zoning permit is obtained prior to installation. 
[b]  Structures shall be anchored down. 
2.  Concrete or masonry fences not over 4 feet in height, (measured from the bottom of the footing to the top of the fence). 
3.  Retaining walls that are not over 4 feet [1,219mm] in height measured from the bottom of the footing to the top of the wall, unless supporting a surcharge. 
4.  Water tanks supported directly upon grade if the capacity does not exceed 5,000 gallons (18927L) and the ratio of height to diameter or width does not exceed 2 to 1. 
5.  Sidewalks and driveways. 
6.  Painting, papering, tiling, carpeting, cabinets, counter tops and similar finish work. 
7.  Prefabricated swimming pools that are less than 24 inches (610mm) deep. 
8.  Swings and other playground equipment. 
9.  Window awnings supported by an exterior wall which do not project more than 54 inches (1372mm) from the exterior wall and do not require additional support. 
10.  Decks not exceeding 200 square feet (18.58m 2 ) in area, that are not more than 30 inches (762mm) above grade at any point, do not have a roof structure, are not attached to a dwelling and do not serve the exit door required by Section R311.4. 
11.  Repair or replacement of exterior siding materials, not exceeding 400 square feet (37.16m 2 ) 
12.  Repair or replacement of interior gypsum board on non-rated fire walls or ceilings when the total area does not exceed 100 square feet (9.29m 2 ) within any 12-month period and providing that no framing, electrical, mechanical or plumbing changes are made. 
13.  Repair or replacement of roofing materials not exceeding 400 square feet (37.16m 2 ). 
    Electrical: 
1.  Listed cord-and-plug connected temporary decorative lighting. 
2.  Reinstallation of attachment plug receptacles but not the outlets therefor. 
3.  Replacement of branch circuit over-current devices of the required capacity in the same locations. 
4.  Electrical wiring, devices, appliances, apparatus or equipment operating at less than 25 volts and not capable of supplying more than 50 watts of energy. 
5.  Minor repair work, including the replacement of lamps or the connection of approved portable electrical equipment to approved permanently installed receptacles. 
    GAS: 
1.  Portable heating, cooking or clothes drying appliances. 
2.  Replacement of any minor part that does not alter approval of equipment or make such equipment unsafe. 
3.  Portable-fuel cell appliances that are not connected to a fixed piping system and are not interconnected to a power grid. 
    Mechanical: 
1.  Portable heating appliances. 
2.  Portable ventilation appliances. 
3.  Portable cooling units. 
4.  Steam, hot- or chilled-water piping within any heating or cooling equipment regulated by this code. 
5.  Replacement of any minor part that does not alter approval of equipment or make such equipment unsafe. 
6.  Portable evaporative coolers. 
7.  Self-contained refrigeration systems containing 10 pounds (4.54kg) or less of refrigerant or that are actuated by motors of 1 horsepower (746W) or less. 
8.  Portable-fuel cell appliances that are not connected to a fixed piping system and are not interconnected to a power grid. 
    Section R105.3.1.1 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    R105.3.1.1 Determination of substantially improved or substantially damaged existing buildings in flood hazard areas. Applications for reconstruction, rehabilitation, additions or other improvements of existing buildings or structures located in an area prone to flooding as established by the City of Wellington, Kansas Floodplain Management shall be governed by that management. 
    Section R108.2 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    R108.2 Schedule of permit fees. Fees for permits required hereby shall be assessed in accordance with the provisions of a fee schedule adopted by ordinance and on file in the City Clerk's office. 
    Section R108.5 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    R108.5 Refunds. The building official may authorize refunding of any fee paid hereunder which was erroneously paid or collected. The building official may authorize refunding of not more than 80 percent of the permit fee paid when no work has been done under a permit issued in accordance with this code. The building official shall not authorize refunding of any fee paid except on written application filed by the original permittee not later than 180 days after the date of fee payment. 
    Section 109.1.3 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    R109.1.3 Floodplain inspections . Floodplain inspections shall be governed by the current City of Wellington, Kansas Flood Plain Management Department. 
    Section R110.1 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    R110.1 Use and occupancy. No new one- and two-family dwellings or portion thereof shall be used or occupied, until the building official has issued a certificate of occupancy therefore as provided herein. Issuance of a certificate of occupancy shall not be construed as an approval of a violation of the provisions of this code or of other ordinances of the jurisdiction. Certificates presuming to give authority to violate or cancel the provisions of this code or other ordinances of the jurisdiction shall not be valid. 
    Section R112 Board of Appeals shall be deleted in its entirety. 
    Section 113.4 of the IRC is herby amended to read as follows: 
    113.4 Violation penalties. Any person who violates a provision of this code or fails to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who erects, constructs, alters, or repairs a building or structure in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the building official, or of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of this code shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in a sum of not more than $100.00 for each offense, and each day's failure, neglect or refusal to comply with said conditions or requirements shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense and shall be fined as in other cases. The Governing Body may, at its discretion, either suspend or revoke any license issued under this article for building, electrical, plumbing and mechanical.

    Section R303.3 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    R303.3 Bathrooms . Bathrooms, water closet compartments and other similar rooms shall be provided with aggregate glazing area in windows of not less than 3 square feet (0.3m 2 ), one-half of which must be openable. 
    Exception: The glazed areas shall not be required where artificial light and a mechanical ventilation system are provided. The minimum ventilation rates shall be 50 cubic feet per minute (24L/s) for intermittent ventilation or 20 cubic feet per minute (10L/s) for continuous ventilation. Ventilation air from the space shall be exhausted directly to the outside. 
    Section R303.4 Mechanical Ventilation shall be deleted in its entirety. 
    Section R303.7.1 Light Activation shall be deleted in its entirety. 
    Section R309.2 of the IRC is amended to read as follows: 
    R309.2 Carports. Carports shall be open on all sides unless attached to an existing structure. Carport floor surfaces shall be of an approved noncombustible material. Carports not open on all sides shall be considered a garage and shall comply with the provisions of this section for garages. 
    Exception: Asphalt surfaces shall be permitted at ground level in carports. 
    The area of floor used for parking of automobiles or other vehicles shall be sloped to facilitate the movement of liquids to a drain or toward the main vehicle entry doorway. 
    Section 310.4 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    R310.4 Bars, grills, covers and screens. Bars, grills, covers, screens or similar devices are permitted to be placed over emergency escape and rescue openings, bulkheads enclosures, or window wells that serve such openings, provided the minimum net clear opening size complies with sections R310.1.1 to R310.1.3, and such devices shall be releasable or removable from inside without the use of a key, tool, or force greater than that which is required for normal operation of the escape and rescue opening. When the window well is 30 inches or more below grade, a code complying guard, grate and/or cover shall be installed for public protection. 
    Section R313 Automatic Fire Sprinkler Systems of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    R313.1 Townhouse automatic fire sprinkler systems. An automatic residential fire sprinkler system may be installed in townhouses. 
    Exception: An automatic residential fire sprinkler system may not be required where additions or alterations are made to existing townhouses that do not have an automatic residential fire sprinkler system installed. 
    R313.1.1 Design and installation. Automatic residential fire sprinkler systems for townhouses may be designed and installed in accordance with Section P2904 or NFPA 13D. 
    R313.2 One- and two-family dwellings automatic fire systems. An automatic residential fire sprinkler system may be installed in one- and two-family dwellings. 
    Exception: An automatic residential fire sprinkler system may not be required for additions or alterations to existing buildings that are not already provided with an automatic residential sprinkler system. 
    R313.2.1 Design and installation. Automatic residential fire sprinkler systems may be designed and installed in accordance with Section P2904 or NFPA 13D. 
    Section R314.2.2 shall be hereby amended to read as follows: 
    R314.2.2 Alterations, repairs and additions. Where alterations, repairs or additions requiring a permit occur, or where one or more sleeping rooms are added or created in existing dwellings, the individual dwelling unit shall be equipped with smoke alarms located as required for new dwellings. 
    Exceptions: 
1.  Work involving the exterior surfaces of dwellings, such as the replacement of roofing or siding, the addition or replacement of windows or doors, or the addition of a porch or deck, are exempt from the requirements of this section. 
2.  Installation, alteration or repairs of plumbing or mechanical systems are exempt from the requirements of this section 
3.  Or as approved by the authority having jurisdiction. 
    Section R315.2.2 shall be hereby amended to read as follows: 
    R315.2.2 Alterations, repairs and additions . Where alterations, repairs or additions requiring a permit occur, or where one or more sleeping rooms are added or created in existing dwellings, the individual dwelling unit shall be equipped with carbon monoxide alarms located as required for new dwellings. 
    Exceptions: 
1.  Work involving the exterior surfaces of dwellings, such as the replacement of roofing or siding, or the addition or replacement of windows or doors, or the addition of a porch or deck, is exempt from the requirements of this section. 
2.  Installation, alteration or repairs of plumbing or mechanical systems are exempt from the requirements of this section. 
3.  Or as approved by the authority having jurisdiction. 
    Section 403 Footings is hereby deleted, with the exception of section 403.1.4.1. 
    Section R403.1.4.1 shall be hereby amended to read as follows: 
    R403.1.4.1 Frost protection. Except where otherwise protected from frost, foundation walls, piers and other permanent supports of buildings and structures shall be protected from frost by one or more of the following methods: 
1.  Extended six (6) inches below the frost line specified in Table R301.2 (1); 
2.  Constructing in accordance with ASCE 32, or; 
3.  Erected on solid rock. 
    Exceptions: 
1.  Protection of free standing accessory structures with an area of 250 square feet or less and an eve height of 10 feet or less shall not be required to be protected. 
2.  Freestanding accessory structures built using post and beam construction shall have an interior concrete floor protected from frost heave by extending the edge of the floor a minimum of twelve (12) inches below the finished exterior grade. The thickened slab may be placed on the outer edge of a concrete sidewalk that surrounds the structure. 
3.  Decks less than 30 inches off the surrounding grade which are not supported by a dwelling or have an overhead roof structure need not be provided with footings that extend below the frost line. 
    Section R905.2.1 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    R905.2.1 Sheathing requirements. Asphalt shingles shall be fastened to solidly sheathed decks. Solidly sheathed decks defined in this section shall be of 4x8 plywood or OSB sheathing of minimum thickness per table R503.2.1 (1). Allowable spans and Loads for Wood Structural Panels for Roof and Subfloor Sheathing and combination Subfloor and Underlayment or well-seasoned tongue-and-grove boards, not over 6 inches in nominal width and shall be 1 1/4 inch nominal thickness and properly spaced and nailed. 
    Section R908.3.1.1 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    R908.3.1.1 A roof re-cover shall not be permitted where any of the following conditions occur: 
1.  Where the existing roof or roof covering is water soaked or has deteriorated to the point that the existing roof or roof covering is not adequate as a base for additional roofing. 
2.  Where the existing roof covering is slate, clay, cement or asbestos-cement tile. 
3.  Except for asphalt shingles (3-tab comp), which shall have no more than one (1) layer of roof covering. 
Part IV - Energy Conservation - shall be deleted in its entirety. 
    Section M1411.8 shall be deleted in its entirety. 
    Section M1602.2 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    M1602.2 Return Air Openings. Return air openings for heating, ventilation and air conditioning systems shall comply with all of the following: 
1.  Openings shall not be located less than 10 feet (3048mm) measured in any direction from an open combustion chamber or draft hood of another appliance located in the same room or space. 
2.  Return and transfer openings shall be sized in accordance with the appliance or equipment manufacturers' installation instructions, Manual D or the design of the registered design professional. 
3.  Return air shall not be taken from a closet, bathroom, toilet room, kitchen, garage, mechanical room, boiler room, furnace room or unconditioned attic. 
    Exceptions: 
1.  Taking return air from a kitchen is not prohibited where such return air openings serve the kitchen only, and are located not less than 10 feet (3048mm) from the cooking appliances. 
2.  Dedicated forced-air systems serving only the garage shall not be prohibited from obtaining return air from the garage. 
3.  Taking return air from an unconditioned crawl space shall not be accomplished through a direct connection to the return side of a forced-air furnace. Transfer openings in the crawl space enclosure shall not be prohibited. 
4.  Return air from one dwelling unit shall not be discharged into another dwelling unit. 
    Section M2003.2 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    M2003.2 Minimum capacity. The minimum capacity of expansion tanks shall be determined from table M2003.2 or as determined by the design professional. 
    Section G2414.5 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    G2415.5 (403.5) Metallic tubing. Steel tubing shall be permitted to be used with gasses not corrosive to such material. 
    Section G2414.5.2 (403.5.2) shall be deleted in its entirety. 
    Section G2415.12 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    G2415.12 (404.12) Minimum burial depth. Underground piping systems shall be installed a minimum depth of 12 inches below grade for metallic pipe and a minimum of 18 inches for non-metallic piping below grade, except as provided in Section G2415.10.1 (404.10.1). 
    Section G2417.1.4 (406.1.4) of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    G2417.1.4 (406.1.4) Section testing. A piping system shall be permitted to be tested as a complete unit or in sections. A valve shall not be subjected to the test pressure unless it can be determined that the valve, including the valve closing mechanism, is designed to safely withstand the test pressure. 
    Section P2502.1 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    P2502.1 Existing building sewers and drains shall be used in connection with new systems when found by examination and/or test to conform to the requirements prescribed by this document. 
    Section P2503.4 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    P2503.4 Building sewer testing. The building sewer may be tested by insertion of a test plug at the point of connection with the public sewer, filling the building sewer with water and pressurizing the sewer to not less than 10-foot (3048mm) head of water. The test pressure shall not decrease during a period of not less than 15 minutes. The building sewer shall be watertight at all points. 
    Section 2603.4 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    P2603.4 Pipes through foundation walls. A pipe that passes through a foundation wall shall be provided with a relieving arch, or a pipe sleeve shall be built into the Masonry/foundation wall a pipe sleeve at least one-half inch (1/2) larger than the pipe passing through. 
    Section P2603.5.1 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    P2603.5.1 Sewer depth. Building sewers shall be a minimum of 12 inches below grade. 
    Section P2801.6.1 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    P2801.6.1 Pan size and drain. Is amended by striking the reference to table P2905.5 and inserting table 2906.4 
    Section P2906.4.1 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    P2906.4.1 Separation of water service and building sewer . Trenching, pipe installation and backfilling shall be in accordance with Section P2604. Where water service piping is located in the same trench with the building sewer, such sewer shall be constructed of materials listed in Table P3002.1(2). Where the building sewer piping is not constructed of materials indicated in Table P3002.1(2), the water service pipe and the building sewer shall be horizontally separated by not less than 5 feet (1524 mm) of undisturbed or compacted earth. The required separation distance shall not apply where a water service pipe crosses a sewer pipe, provided the water service is sleeved to a point not less than 5 feet (1524 mm) horizontally from the sewer pipe centerline on both sides of such crossing. The sleeve shall be of pipe materials indicated in Table P2906.4, P3002.1(2) or P3002.2. The required separation distance shall not apply where the bottom of the water service pipe that is located within 5 feet (1524 mm) of the sewer is not less than 24 inches (610 mm) above the highest point of the top of the building sewer. 
    Section 2906.4.2 is hereby created and will read as follows: 
    P2906.4.2 Tracer wire. For the purpose of locating the building service lines, all new or replacement installations using non-metallic pipe or tubing shall have a #10 copper conductor, or equivalent tracer wire installed with the service line. The tracer wire shall be installed as follows: 
    Water line. The tracer wire shall extend from six (6) inches above the meter box through the meter box to the point where it enters the building, where it shall be connected to a one half (1/2) pound anode or larger. 
    Yard hydrant. The tracer wire shall extend from six (6) inches above the surface of the ground at the back flow device to the point of connection to the water service, where it shall be connected to an existing tracer wire or grounded to a one half (1/2) pound anode or larger. 
    Lawn sprinkler. The tracer wire shall extend from six (6) inches above the surface of the ground at the back flow device to the point of connection to the water service, where it shall be connected to an existing tracer wire or grounded to a one half (1/2) pound anode or larger. 
    Exception: The tracer wire may be omitted on lawn sprinkler piping installed after the back flow device located on private property. 
    Section P3002.2.1 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    P3002.2.1 Building sewer pipe near the water service. The proximity of a building sewer to a water service shall comply with section P2906.4.1 
    Section P3002.2.2 is hereby created and will read as follows: 
    P3002.2.2 Tracer wire. For the purpose of locating building sewers, all new installations and replacements shall have a #10 copper conductor, or equivalent, tracer wire installed with the sewer. The tracer wire shall extend from the surface of the ground at the clean out to the tap, where it shall be connected to an existing tracer wire or grounded to a one half (1/2) pound anode or larger at the sewer tap or at the downstream end of the replaced sewer line. 
    Section P3005.2.6 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    P3005.2.6 Cleanout plugs. Cleanout plugs shall be copper alloy, plastic or other approved materials. Cleanout plugs for borosilicate glass piping systems shall be of borosilicate glass. Brass cleanout plugs shall conform to ASTM A74. Plastic cleanout plugs shall conform to the referenced standards for plastic pipe fittings as indicated in Table P3002.3. Cleanout plugs shall have a raised square head, a countersunk square head or a countersunk slot head. Where a cleanout plug will have a trim cover screw installed into the plug, the plug shall be manufactured with a blind end threaded hole for such purpose. 
    Section P3008.1 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    P3008.1 Sewage backflow. All new or replacement building sewers shall include a backflow prevention device. The backflow prevention device shall be installed as close to the building as is practical and upstream of the cleanout, and shall be made accessible for periodic cleaning by the building owner. Or when the backflow device is installed in the building drain, all fixtures shall be protected by a backwater valve before discharging to the building sewer. 
    Section 3008.1 of the IRC is hereby amended by adding a new section 3008.1.1 
    Section 3008.1.1 Existing building sewers. When repairs to an existing building include the removal of a house trap or replacement of five (5) feet of drain line and or installation of a cleanout the backflow prevention device shall be installed as close to the building as is practical and upstream of the cleanout. 
    Exception: Backflow prevention device may be omitted if approved by the authority having jurisdiction. 
    Section P3114.3 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    P3114.3 Where permitted individual vents, branch vents, circuit vents and stack vents shall be permitted to terminate with a connection to an air admittance valve. Individual and branch type air admittance valves shall vent only fixtures that are on the same floor level and connect to a horizontal branch drain. Permission shall be required from the building official and noted on the plumbing permit. 
    Section E3406.3 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    E3406.3 Minimum size of conductors. The minimum size of conductors for feeders and branch circuits shall be 12 AWG copper and 6 AWG aluminum. The minimum size of service conductors shall be as specified in Chapter 36. The minimum size of Class 2 remote control, signaling and power-limited circuits conductors shall be as specified in Chapter 43. [310.106(A)] 
    Section E3601.6.2 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    E3601.6.2 Service disconnect location. The service disconnecting means shall be installed at a readily accessible location outside of the building. Each occupant shall have access to the disconnect serving the dwelling unit in which they reside. 
    Section E3604.2.2 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    E3604.2.2 Vertical clearance from grade. Overhead service conductors shall have the following minimum clearances from final grade: 
1.  For conductors supported on and cabled together with a grounded bare messenger wire, the minimum vertical clearance shall be 10 feet (3048 mm) at the electric service entrance to buildings, at the lowest point of the drip loop of the building electric entrance, and above areas or sidewalks accessed by pedestrians only. Such clearance shall be measured from final grade or other accessible surfaces. 
2.  Twelve feet (3658 mm) over residential property or sidewalks accessed by pedestrians only. 
3.  Fifteen feet (4500 mm) over residential property or residential driveways subject to vehicular traffic. 
4.  Eighteen feet (5486mm) over public streets, alleys, roads and parking areas subject to truck traffic. 
[(230.24(B)(1), (2), and (4)] 
    Section E3604.5.1 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    E3604.5.1 Strength. The service mast shall be of adequate strength or shall be supported by braces or guys to safely withstand the strain imposed by the service-drop or overhead service conductors and in no case shall be smaller than 2" ridged conduit. Hubs intended for use with a conduit that serves as a service mast shall be identified for use with service-entrance equipment. 
    Section E3608.1 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    E3608.1 Grounding electrode system. (250.50) On all new construction, one or more of the electrodes specified in E3608.1.1 through E3608.1.3 shall be made available.

    Section E3706.2 of the IRC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    E3706.2 Panelboard Size. 2.  Receptacles that are part of a luminaire or appliance. 
3. The appliances shall be cord-and plug- connected to such receptacles in accordance with Section E3909.4. [406.12(A) Exception] 
4.  A single or duplex receptacle used for counter top appliance or other electric devices where such receptacles are located over a standard height and size counter top.

Sec. 8-185. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4248,  II, adopted March 3, 2019, repealed  8-185, which pertained to supplemental amendments to both building codes and derived from Code 1996,  4-302; Ord. No. 3484,  2; Ord. No. 3509,  2; Ord. No. 3657,  3; Ord. No. 3793,  I, 10-06-1998; Ord. No. 3900,  I(4-302), 8-3-2004. 
Sec. 8-186. - Supplemental amendments to the building code. 
    In addition to the adoption of the International Building Code, 2015 Edition and Appendices "F", "H" and "J" and amendments thereto, and the International Residential Code, 2015 Edition and Appendices "A" through "J" and "M" through "P" and amendments thereto, the following supplemental building regulations are hereby adopted: 
(1)  Elevation and crawl space. 
a.  Minimum requirement of elevation from final grade to top of concrete foundation is eight inches. 
b.  In all dwellings where crawl space is provided, there shall be a minimum of 24 inches clearance from the bottom of the floor joists to the ground as crawl space. 
(2)  Perimeter footing requirement. All structures in districts not zoned residential shall have a continuous perimeter footing regardless of type of construction except storage buildings less than 250 square feet. Pole type construction shall be permitted only in residential and agricultural districts for detached garages, carports and sheds, not for habitual dwellings. Small outbuildings with 250 or less square feet of roof space need not have footing or stem walls, but must be tied down. 
(3)  Exterior wall covering. Exterior wall covering shall be installed with approved materials to provide a barrier against moisture and the weather. The materials shall be installed to the manufactures specifications within 60 days of boxing the walls. 
(4)  Used lumber permitted . Used lumber may be used in construction; provided that the material is approved by the building official and is of a sound structural grade. 
(5)  Fences . Property boundaries and easement if any, shall be located prior to installation. Fences shall be located totally on the owner's property. All privacy fences shall be reduced to a maximum of height of not more than three feet when located beyond required front yard setback. 
(6)  Residential screening/fence around swimming pools . All swimming pools constructed or installed requiring a building permit, are required to be protected with a minimum five-foot permanent fence from non-authorized people. Any gate openings that allow access from pool to off premises shall be equipped with a self-locking device to prevent access from off premises. Pools installed within existing fencing less than five feet in height shall be replaced to comply with five feet minimum height requirement unless approved by authority having jurisdiction. 
(7)  Plumbing, electrical, or mechanical work performed by residential property owners. A residential property owner shall be permitted to perform plumbing, electrical (an electrical permit will require the homeowner to pass a simplified open book test), or mechanical work upon his or her own personal property; provided, that the owner shall satisfy the building official as to his or her ability to do such mechanical, plumbing or electrical work or installation, in accordance with the chapters of the city code, apply for inspection and receive a certificate for approval therefor. Installation by an owner under this section shall be by the owner, on his or her residential dwelling, without compensation, and no person shall be employed to assist him in any way on such work except an individual, firm or corporation licensed hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 3793,  I, 10-06-1998; Ord. No. 3900,  I(4-302.1), 8-3-2004; Ord. No. 4248,  II, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-187. - Building site structures. 
    There shall be permitted on construction sites inside the city limits, shanties, sheds, canopies, or trailers used as a temporary structure by a bona fide building contractor or subcontractor or their watchman other than the owner, on a duly authorized building or construction project. The structures may be placed on or adjacent to a construction site for a limited period of time as approved by the building official. A structure used for the purpose of a night watchman shall not be occupied by more than one person, and must be provided with sewage disposal facilities approved by the building official. Any such structure must be removed from a construction site prior to substantial completion of the project, or upon notice by the building official. 
(Code 1974,  4-303.1; Code 1996,  4-306; Ord. No. 4248,  II, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-188. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who or which shall violate any provision of this division or who or which shall fail to comply therewith or with any of the requirements thereof shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in any sum not exceeding $500.00, or be imprisoned not to exceed three months, or be both so fined and imprisoned, and each day that such violation shall be permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1974,  4-304; Code 1996,  4-307; Ord. No. 4248,  II, 3-5-2019) 
Secs. 8-189-8-214. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ELECTRICAL CODE 

Sec. 8-215. - National Electrical Code incorporated. 
    All electrical installations made within the city shall be in strict conformity with the provisions of this article and the ordinances amendatory thereof and with the approved standards of construction for safety to life and property. If sections contained within this article and amendments thereto, in a given situation, do not prescribe a specific type or class of material or specific standards of construction, then and in that event, the standards set forth and contained in the National Electrical Code, 2014 Edition, including Informative Annex C (Conduit and Tubing Fill Tables), and as published by the National Fire Protection Association as NFPA. No. 70-2014, as presently constituted and as may be hereinafter amended, shall apply with the exception of amendments of said publication as set forth in this article. Said NFPA No. 70-2014 was prepared by the National Electrical Code Committee and acted on by NFPA at its June Association Technical Meeting held June 10-13, 2013, in Chicago, IL. It was issued by the Standards Council on August 1, 2013, with an effective date of August 21, 2013, and supersedes all previous editions. This edition of NFPA70 was approved as an American National Standard on August 21, 2013. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  I, XII, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 4156,  I, 5-20-2014) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4056,  I, adopted Feb. 2, 2010, repealed former  8-215, and enacted a new  8-215 as set out herein. Former  8-215 pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 8-216. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Approved means approved by the electrical inspector. 
    Authorized person means any individual, firm or corporation who or which is licensed under the provisions of this Code to do the work as permitted under the specific provisions of this article. 
    City means the territory within the corporate limits and the area served by the city municipal utilities, or the legally constituted governing body thereof, its agent and its offers. 
    Conductor means a wire or cable or other form of metal suitable for carrying electric current or potential. 
    Electrical construction means and includes all work and materials used in installing, maintaining, or extending a system of electrical wiring and all appurtenances, apparatus or equipment used in connection therewith, inside or attached to any building, structure, lot or premises, except industrial plants where fulltime maintenance is provided, and other agencies providing inspections of installations and facilities. 
    Electrical contractor means any person conducting a business of installing or altering by contract, electrical conductors or any authorized person who subcontracts to do such work. 
    Electrician means a person who is engaged in the trade or business of electrical construction and who is qualified under the terms and provisions of this article. 
    Equipment means conductors, material, fittings, devices, appliances, fixtures, apparatus, motors and the like, used as a part of or in connection with, an electrical installation. 
    Inspector means any individual who has been appointed by the city manager as an electrical inspector. 
    Journeyman electrician means any individual who possesses the necessary qualifications, training, and technical knowledge to install, maintain and extend electrical conductors and equipment. Further, such individual shall be capable of doing such work in accordance with plans and specifications furnished such individual and in accordance with standard rules and regulations governing such work. 
    Master electrician means any individual who possesses the necessary qualifications, training and technical knowledge to plan, layout, and supervise the installation, maintenance and extension of electrical conductors and equipment. 
    Registered , when used with the words "electrical contractor," "electrician" or the like, means that the person has made application to the board of electricians and has satisfied the board that the person is qualified to do the work stated in the application, that the person has paid the necessary registration fees to date, and that the person's name is carried in the records of the electrical inspector as a person authorized to do electrical work as defined in this article. 
    Special permission means the written consent of the electrical inspector. 
    Special ruling means a written ruling filed in the office of the electrical inspector. 
(b)  In addition to and supplemental to the terms defined in subsection (a) of this section, definitions of terms in article 100 of the adopted National Electrical Code, shall be used where applicable and where not in conflict with the definitions set forth in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1974,  4-402; Code 1983; Code 1996,  4-402; Ord. No. 3848,  II, 7-16-2002; Ord. No. 3965,  II, 8-1-2006) 
Sec. 8-217. - Exceptions. 
    The following exceptions to the electrical code shall be adopted: 
(1)  The provisions of this article shall not apply to installations used by communication agencies in the operation of signals or the transmission of intelligence when located within or on buildings or premises used exclusively by such an agency or on public thoroughfares; provided that such agencies excepted are operating under a franchise agreement with the city. 
(2)  The provisions of this article shall apply to all electrical equipment used for power supply to radio transmitting equipment, but shall not apply to other electrical equipment used for radio transmission. 
(3)  This article shall be construed to be inapplicable to any building which is owned and operated by the United States government. 
(4)  The various departments and buildings of the city shall be subject to the provisions of this article insofar as the same may be applicable, but shall be exempt from the requirement of fees. 
(Code 1974,  4-403; Code 1983; Code 1996,  4-404) 
Sec. 8-218. - Responsibility for safe work. 
    This article shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the responsibility or liability of any party owning, operating, controlling, or installing any electrical equipment for damages to persons or property caused by any defect therein, nor shall the city be held as assuming any such liability, by reason of the inspection or reinspection authorized herein, or the certificate of approval of any equipment authorized herein. 
(Code 1974,  4-404; Code 1996,  4-404) 
Sec. 8-219. - Energizing customer's service entrance conductors. 
    Only authorized employees of the city municipal utilities shall be permitted to make the connection between the city municipal utilities service conductors and the customer's service entrance conductors. 
(Code 1974,  4-405; Code 1996,  4-406) 
Sec. 8-220. - Installing new or relocating existing meters. 
    When new electrical meters are installed or existing electrical meters are to be relocated, the disconnection, connection, or reconnection to the meter shall be made only by authorized employees of the city municipal utilities. 
(Code 1974,  4-406; Code 1996,  4-406) 
Sec. 8-221. - Administration and enforcement. 
    There is hereby created the office of electrical inspector. The person chosen to fill the office of electrical inspector shall be possessed of such executive ability as is required for the performance of the electrical inspector's duties and shall have a thorough knowledge of the standard materials and methods used in the installation of electrical conductors and equipment. The electrical inspector shall be well versed in approved methods of construction for safety to persons and property, and the provisions of the National Electrical Code. 
(Code 1974,  4-407; Code 1996,  4-407) 
Sec. 8-222. - Prohibited interests. 
    It shall be unlawful for the electrical inspectors to engage in the business of selling, installing, or maintenance of electrical conductors, devices, appliances, apparatus, or equipment, and they shall have no financial interest in any concern engaged in such business at any time while employed as an inspector by the city. 
(Code 1974,  4-409; Code 1996,  4-409) 
Sec. 8-223. - Duties of chief electrical inspector. 
    It shall be the duty of the electrical inspector to enforce the provisions of this article. The electrical inspector shall, upon application, approve permits for the installation, extension, or alteration of electrical conductors and equipment, and shall make inspections of all electrical work as provided for in this article. The electrical inspector shall keep complete records of all permits issued, inspections and reinspections made and other official work performed in accordance with the provisions of this article. The electrical inspector shall keep on file, a list of inspected electrical appliances issued by Underwriters Laboratories, Inc., which list shall be accessible for public reference during regular office hours. 
(Code 1974,  4-410; Code 1996,  4-410) 
Sec. 8-224. - Liabilities of inspectors. 
    Where action is taken by the electrical inspector to enforce the provisions of this article, such acts shall be done in the name of, and on behalf of the city, and the inspector in so acting for the city shall not render the inspector personally liable for any damage which may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act committed in good faith in the discharge of the inspector's duties, and any suit brought against the inspector by reason thereof, shall be defended by the city attorney until final termination of the proceedings contained therein. 
(Code 1974,  4-411; Code 1996,  4-411) 
Sec. 8-225. - Authority of electrical inspectors. 
    Whenever, in the opinion of an electrical inspector, it shall be necessary to call upon the police department for aid and assistance, the electrical inspector shall have the authority to do so, and it shall be the duty of any member of the police department, when called upon by the inspector, to act immediately in giving the necessary and lawful assistance. The electrical inspector shall have the right, during reasonable hours, to enter any building or premises in the discharge of official duty, or for the purpose of making any inspection, reinspection or test of the electrical equipment or installation contained therein. When any electrical equipment is found by the inspector to be dangerous to persons or property because it is defective or improperly installed, the person owning the electrical equipment shall be notified in writing and shall have any changes or repairs made as required by the electrical inspector, which will place such equipment in safe condition.
