If such work is not complete within the period specified by the inspector in the notice, the inspector shall have the authority to disconnect or order the disconnection of electric service to the dangerous electrical equipment. In cases of emergency, when necessary for safety to persons or property, or when electrical equipment may interfere with the work of the fire department, the senior officer of the fire department at the site shall have the authority to immediately cause the disconnection of any electrical equipment. 
(Code 1974,  4-412; Code 1996,  4-412) 
Sec. 8-226. - Serving of notices. 
(a)  When any order or notice is issued pursuant to the provisions of this article to any person who cannot be found after a reasonable search, then such order or notice may be served by posting it in a conspicuous place upon the premises occupied by that person or upon the premises where the defects are alleged to exist. Such posting of the notice shall be considered equivalent to personal service of the order or notice. An order sent by mail in a sealed envelope with postage prepaid and directed to the address of the electrical contractor, owner, lessee, or occupant of the premises shall be equivalent to personal service of the order. 
(b)  The electrical inspector is hereby empowered to attach to electrical cabinets and equipment, any official notice or seal to prevent the use of electricity, and it shall be unlawful for any other person to place or attach such seal, or to break, change, destroy, tear, mutilate, cover or otherwise deface or injure any official notice or seal posted by an electrical inspector. 
(Code 1974,  4-413; Code 1996,  4-413) 
Sec. 8-227. - Special ruling. 
    If a special ruling by the electrical inspector is necessary to govern electrical construction for some particular occupancy or building not covered by this article or by the National Electrical Code adopted by this Code, whereby all wiring for similar types of occupancy or building will be changed in the future, a copy of the ruling shall be filed in the office of the superintendent of utilities. 
(Code 1974,  4-414; Code 1996,  4-414) 
Sec. 8-228. - Qualification, registration of electricians. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person who is not registered as a qualified electrician in accordance with the provisions of this article to engage in the business of electrical construction or to make any repairs, alterations, additions, or changes to any existing system of electrical conductors, wiring, apparatus, or equipment within the limits of the territory served by the city municipal system, except as provided in this article. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent such person as a registered electrician of any class set out in this article, or to use the words electrical contractor, master electrician, electrician, or words of similar import or meaning on signs, cards, stationery, or by any other manner whatsoever, unless the person is properly registered within the meaning of the words used as provided in this article. 
(Code 1974,  4-415; Code 1996,  4-415) 
Sec. 8-229. - Classification of registration. 
    There shall be four classes of electrical registration which shall be known as follows: 
(1)  Electrical contractor. 
(2)  Master electrician. 
(3)  Journeyman electrician. 
(4)  Apprentice/helper. 
(Code 1974,  4-416; Code 1996,  4-416; Ord. No. 3848,  III, 7-16-2002) 
Sec. 8-230. - Registration; reciprocity. 
(a)  To secure a certificate of registration as a qualified and competent electrician in any of the classes hereinabove set out, an application shall be made in writing and addressed to the board of electricians of the city. The application shall show the applicant's name and address and such other information as may be prescribed by the board, and shall be made out on forms available at the city administration center. 
(b)  Any person who holds a certificate indicating that they have successfully passed an examination designated by K.S.A. Supp. 12-1525, or any amendments thereafter, shall be entitled to receive the appropriate electrician's license of the city without additional examinations. Nothing herein contained shall be construed to exempt electricians obtaining licenses from the city under this section from the provisions of ordinances of the city requiring the furnishing of bonds and/or insurance and the payment of license fees. 
(c)  Master and journeyman's electrician's licenses issued by governmental units other than the city shall be recognized by the city if the governmental unit issuing such license and the city shall have entered into an agreement granting reciprocal privileges to the holders of valid master and journeyman's electrician's licenses issued by the city, and if the governmental unit issuing such licenses shall have examined such licensees for the purpose of determining their qualifications to hold such licenses. Any decision to be made as to the qualifications shall be determined by the board of electricians of the city. Nothing herein contained shall be construed to exempt electricians obtaining licenses from the city under this section from the provisions of ordinances of the city requiring the furnishing of bonds and/or insurance and the payment of license fees. 
(Code 1996,  4-417; Ord. No. 3526,  1) 
Sec. 8-231. - Applicant; master electrician. 
    Applicants for a certificate as master electrician shall file with the application an affidavit setting forth that the applicant is not less than 21 years of age and produce documentation that the applicant has served no less than two years as an apprentice electrician, and not less than three years as a journeyman electrician with experience in the installation, alteration, and repair of electrical equipment and conductors. Applicant shall appear in person before the board of electricians and be examined as provided in this article. A certificate of graduation from, or an affidavit of attendance at a recognized technical school or college may, at the direction of the board of electricians, be credited as a part of the required experience. 
(Code 1996,  4-418; Ord. No. 3731,  1) 
Sec. 8-232. - Applicant; journeyman electrician. 
    Applicants for a certificate as journeyman electrician shall present documentation that the applicant has served no less than two years as an apprentice electrician and be examined as provided in this article. 
(Code 1996,  4-419; Ord. No. 3731,  2) 
Sec. 8-233. - Apprentice electrician and/or electrical helper. 
(a)  No apprentice electrician or helper shall perform any electrical work within the city unless the apprentice electrician or helper is on the job with and under the supervision of a master or journeyman electrician certified by the city. 
(b)  No city-licensed electrical contractor shall employ any apprentice or helper who is not registered by the inspection department office. 
(c)  Every apprentice or helper shall register the apprentice electrician or helper's name and address with the inspection department office and must renew such registration annually. The fees for the original registration document and for annual renewal shall be as adopted by separate ordinance for permit fees, licenses and zoning fees, to cover the administrative costs of issuing such documents. 
(Code 1996,  4-420; Ord. No. 3731,  3; Ord. No. 3848,  IV, 7-16-2002) 
Sec. 8-234. - Certificate of registration. 
    Upon presentation to the inspection department office of a certificate signed by the chairperson or the secretary of the board of electrical examiners stating the name and address of the applicant, the classification applied for, and that the applicant has passed the required examination and, after the applicant has paid to the city the registration fee prescribed in this article, the inspection department office shall register the name of the applicant in the records kept for that purpose and shall issue to the applicant a certificate of registration. 
(Code 1974,  4-421; Code 1996,  4-421; Ord. No. 3848,  V, 7-16-2002) 
Sec. 8-235. - Examination and fees. 
(a)  Every person, whether an employer or employee, except a helper, before engaging in electrical wiring and electrical work in the city shall apply to the board of electrical examiners and pass an examination as to such person's competency as an electrician and if, on examination, the applicant is found to be competent to do electrical work, the board shall issue a certificate of registration authorizing him to engage in electrical wiring and electrical work. Such certificate of examination shall continue in force until revoked or cancelled by the board of electrical examiners, but such certificate shall not be transferable. The board of electrical examiners shall have the power and is hereby directed to suspend for a definite time or to cancel or revoke at the discretion of the board of electrical examiners, any certificate of examination granted thereunder, if, after notice and opportunity to be heard, the person holding the certificate is found guilty by the board of electrical examiners of violation of the terms and conditions of this article. Such person may have ten days before having certificate cancelled, in which to appeal to the governing body of the city, for a review of the facts, conditions, and circumstances prompting the board of electrical examiners to cancel the certificate of examination. The fee for Thomson Prometric examination for administrative costs will be on file in the city clerk's office. The fees are to be paid to the inspection department office at the time the applicant applies for the examination, except as hereinafter provided, and shall be retained by the city whether or not the applicant passes the examination. 
(b)  Examinations shall be provided by experior as follows: 
(1)  Special needs for exams shall be as available by exam provider. 
(2)  That the board shall conduct examinations with utmost fairness and patience, and should any applicant fail in any examination, the board shall appraise the applicant, so far as it may be practicable to do so, wherein the applicant is delinquent or fails to meet in a reasonable manner the requirements of examination. 
(3)  Any unsuccessful applicant may make application for re-examination at such time as may be prescribed by the rules adopted by the board; provided, however, that no rule of the board shall fix or establish a waiting period of more than 30 days before a second examination may be given, nor more than six months between the second examination. 
(4)  That nothing herein contained shall deny any applicant the right to be heard on any new application at a later time; provided further, that the applicant shall comply with the other provisions of this article and the rules adopted by the board. 
(5)  No applicant shall be denied an examination or certificate on account of the applicant's affiliation with any lawful organizations, unions, associations, or persons. 
(6)  If, after two unsuccessful examinations, or for any other valid reason, an applicant feels and believes that the applicant was denied a certificate by the board on account of prejudice or any other influence, or in violation of the terms of this article, then the applicant may appeal from the decision of the board to the governing body of the city, and, if after due consideration of the applicant's appeal, the governing body is of the opinion that a probable injustice has been done, the applicant may thereupon request that the applicant be re-examined. 
(7)  The board shall be diligent and tolerant in aiding and assisting all applicants by enlightening them concerning the rules prescribed by the board of electrical examiners. 
(8)  Upon passing an examination, the board shall issue to each applicant, a certificate certifying that the applicant is qualified. 
(Code 1996,  4-422; Ord. No. 3587,  2; Ord. No. 3848,  VI, 7-16-2002) 
Sec. 8-236. - Renewal of registration. 
    Every certificate of registration provided for in this article shall expire at 12:00 midnight on December 31, following the date of its issuance, and shall be renewed by the inspection department office upon application and upon the payment to the city, of the required renewal fee. If, during the preceding year, the applicant has been convicted of a violation of this article, it will be necessary for him to be reinstated by the board of electrical examiners. 
(Code 1974,  4-423; Code 1996,  4-423; Ord. No. 3848,  VII, 7-16-2002) 
Sec. 8-237. - Lapse of certificate. 
    Any holder of a certificate who fails to renew the same by March 1st from the date of expiration shall be required to submit one of the following: 
(1)  Proof of passing a new examination as required in this article. The electrical examination will be administered in accordance with K.S.A. 12-1525 and amendments thereto, with a minimum passing score of 75 percent. 
(2)  Proof of completing an additional one and one-half hours of continuing education for each three-month period the renewal is late and only when the original certificate was issued pursuant to K.S.A. 12-1525. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  II, XII, 2-2-2010) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4056,  II, adopted Feb. 2, 2010, repealed former  8-237, and enacted a new  8-237 as set out herein. Former  8-237 pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 8-238. - Re-examination of certificate holder. 
    Should the holder of a certificate of registration take up another occupation or profession or otherwise indicate that such certificate holder has abandoned the holder's occupation as an electrician or contractor, even through the holder may apply for registration each year, the holder shall be required to be examined every two years in order to maintain the holder's registration. 
(Code 1974,  4-425; Code 1996,  4-425) 
Sec. 8-239. - Registration-Electrical contractors. 
    The following rules and regulations shall be observed by electrical contractors: 
(1)  All persons who or which undertake with or for another to do any electrical wiring or other work for which a permit is required under this article or regulations of the city for a fixed price, fee, percentage of cost or other compensation than wages, or who or which advertises or otherwise represents to the public to have the capacity or ability to undertake the installation, alteration, or renewal of electrical wiring, lighting or power fixtures and electrical apparatus of any nature (except measuring equipment and devices installed by and remaining the property of the city municipal utilities supplying the service) in or on any building, structure or premise within the city, shall for the purposes of this article be deemed electrical contractors. 
(2)  All electrical contractors shall apply to the inspection department for an electrical contractor's license. The license shall entitle the licensee to engage in the business as an electrical contractor. 
(3)  The license shall be issued in the name of the person so engaging in business upon the payment of a fee which shall be on file in the city inspection department. The city municipal utility in the operation of its electrical system shall not be deemed an electrical contractor. It shall be unlawful for any person to enter into a contract with another so as to bring such person within the classification of an electrical contractor, or to perform work as a contractor or any work under a contractor without first having been licensed as an electrical contractor by the city. The license shall not be issued until the person, firm or corporation has filed with the inspection department a good and sufficient policy of insurance naming the city as an additional insured, issued by a company authorized to do business in the state, in an amount not less $300,000.00 covering personal injury and property damage of any kind or nature whatsoever arising from the licensee's failure to comply with the ordinances, codes, rules and regulations of the city pertaining to electrical wiring and installation and such other work for which the license is required. The policy of insurance shall contain a provision that the coverage afforded by this policy shall not be cancelled or materially changed until at least 15 days prior written notice has been given to the city. This section shall not apply to any person in the employment of the city who shall do such wiring under the direction of the electrical distribution supervisor. 
(4)  A valid current certificate showing the aforesaid coverage shall be filed with the inspection department before any license is issued. 
(5)  Failure on the part of any registered electrical contractor to correct any defect, error, or deficiency in any work installed under the authority of an electrical permit issued to him within ten calendar days after written notification thereof by the electrical inspector or within such further reasonable time as may, upon request, be prescribed; the electrical inspector shall, without further notice, stop the contractor until such corrections have been made, inspected and approved. In addition thereto, the penalty provided in this article may be enforced. 
(6)  The State of Kansas requires 12 classroom hours of continuing education every two years or six classroom hours every year to renew each Master or Journeyman license. 
(7)  The City of Wellington is on a two-year renewal cycle on licenses and all licenses shall expire December 31st of each odd-number year. Copies of certificates on the classes attended must be provided at the time of license renewal. 
(Ord. No. 4126,  1, 2, 12-18-2012) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4126,  1, 2, adopted Dec. 18, 2012, repealed former  8-239, and enacted a new  8-239 as set out herein. Former  8-239 pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Code 1996,  4-426; Ord. No. 3711,  1; Ord. No. 3848,  VIII, adopted July 16, 2002 and Ord. No. 4012,  V, adopted March 18, 2008. 
Sec. 8-240. - Same-Master electrician. 
(a)  Any person holding an electrical contractors license shall appoint or employ, or shall be a qualified master electrician. 
(b)  The master electrician shall perform the work or supervise and direct the installation, alteration, repair and maintenance of electrical contractors and equipment authorized by permits issued under the authority of this article. 
(c)  When a master electrician has not acted in the capacity of a master electrician or in a supervisory position on electrical work in the city for a continuous period of two years, the master electrician shall be reexamined before the master electrician shall be certified as a registered master electrician. 
(d)  Applicants for registration as master electricians shall be not less than 21 years of age, shall have had at least five years experience in the installation, alteration, repair and maintenance of electrical contractors, equipment and apparatus, or an experience equivalent thereto. Applicants shall furnish the names and addresses of former employers, period of time employed and in what capacity, proof of which service shall be furnished in a manner satisfactory to the board of electrical examiners. Every applicant shall be required to answer a reasonable number of questions in writing to show that said applicant has sufficient knowledge and technical training to perform the work or to supervise the installation, alteration, repair and maintenance of electrical contractors and equipment authorized by permits issued by the electrical inspector's office. 
(e)  The master electrician, after having passed the required examination, shall be granted a certificate, showing that said master electrician has the necessary qualification to install or direct the installation of electrical conductors, devices, apparatus and equipment. It shall be unlawful for any master electrician to permit the master electrician's name to be used, or to knowingly permit the master electrician to be held out as the officer or employee in a supervisory capacity, of any individual person holding an electrical contractor's certificate unless such person is, in fact, an officer or employee and does, in fact, supervise the installation of electrical work performed by such persons. 
(Code 1984; Code 1996,  4-427; Ord. No. 3408,  II; Ord. No. 3848,  IX, 7-16-2002; Ord. No. 4012,  VI, 3-18-2008; Ord. No. 4175,  1, 2-17-2015) 
Sec. 8-241. - Same-Journeyman electrician. 
(a)  Applicants shall be not less than 20 years of age and shall have had at least two years' experience in the installation, alteration, repair, and maintenance of electrical conductors, and equipment or an equivalent experience thereto. Every applicant shall be required to answer a reasonable number of questions in writing to show that said applicant has sufficient knowledge and technical training to perform the work. 
(b)  A journeyman electrician's certificate shall entitle the holder thereof to engage the certificate holder in the employ of any person registered under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1996,  4-428; Ord. No. 3408,  III; Ord. No. 3848,  X, 7-16-2002; Ord. No. 3867,  I, 2-18-2003; Ord. No. 4012,  VII, 3-18-2008; Ord. No. 4175,  2, 2-17-2015) 
Sec. 8-242. - Supervision. 
    In the actual work of installing, maintaining, altering or repairing any electric conductors or equipment for which a permit is required by this article, there shall be present and in direct supervision, a qualified electrician of the proper classification. It shall be lawful for a journeyman electrician to perform electrical work without the direct supervision of a master electrician, if the work has been laid out by a master electrician. Should it come to the notice of the electrical inspector or the electrical inspector's authorized representative, that such supervision and control are not being maintained, the inspector may order the work to be discontinued and the person to whom the permit has been issued shall discontinue further work until proper supervision has been employed or supplied. Nothing herein shall be construed as prohibiting the employment of apprentices or unskilled laborers assisting a person duly registered and qualified under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1974,  4-429; Code 1996,  4-429; Ord. No. 3848,  XI, 7-16-2002) 
Sec. 8-243. - Electrical work performed by owner of one- and two-family dwellings. 
New installations in existing one- and two-family residences. 
    The owner of a detached one- and two-family residences may obtain a permit for any electrical installations on the load side of the service panelboard in the main structure and the usual accessory buildings thereto upon fulfillment of exam and plan review requirements as outlined elsewhere in this section. The owner obtaining said permit shall personally purchase all materials and shall personally perform all labor in connection with the permitted project. The owner shall call for all inspections and otherwise observe all the applicable provisions of this title. 
Electrical installations by owner constructing new one- and two-family residences. 
    Persons constructing a new detached one- and two-family residence for their own use may be permitted to install all electrical work on the load side of the service panelboard, in the main structure and the usual accessory structures thereto upon fulfillment of exam and plan review requirements as outlined elsewhere in this section. The owner shall call for inspections and otherwise observe all applicable provisions of this title; provided, however, that the service entrance raceway, service entrance conductors, meter enclosure, and service panelboard shall be installed by a licensed electrical contractor. The contractor shall call for the service related inspections. 
Examinations and plan reviews for installations required. 
    Owners applying for permits for installations as outlined above shall first qualify themselves by successfully passing a simplified open book examination dealing with relevant provisions of the electrical code. The fee for said examination shall be established by the city building official to cover the administrative costs. Successful passage of the examination shall qualify the applicant for future permits until the time of adoption of another edition of the National Electrical Code by the city. 
    Prior to permit approval, the applicant shall submit a plan of the installation drawn in format acceptable in sufficient details to satisfy the electrical inspector of the anticipated work showing the proper electrical symbols and all the circuitry for the complete project. The fee for such plan review shall be established by the city building official to cover administrative costs. 
    Permit fees shall be as set forth in section 8-249 of this article. Permits for electrical installations shall be limited to one in three years for each property unless a waiver is obtained, upon written application, from the combined trade board. Permits under this section are for residential use only and does not include commercial uses. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  III, XII, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 4249,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-244. - Exceptions from registration requirements. 
    The following classes of work may be carried out by persons who are not registered electricians: 
(1)  The replacement of lamps, fuses and the connection of portable devices to suitable receptacles which have been permanently installed. 
(2)  The installation, alteration or repairing of any wiring, devices or equipment for the operation of signal or the transmission of intelligence, and do not include generating or transforming equipment. 
(3)  Any work involved in the manufacture or test of electrical materials, devices, appliances or apparatus, but not including any installation wiring other than that required for testing purposes, if such equipment as completed, is approved by the electrical inspector before it is installed or used within the city. 
(Code 1974,  4-431; Code 1996,  4-303) 
Sec. 8-245. - Examination fee. 
    Each applicant for a certificate shall pay to the city the examination fee specified in this article. 
(Code 1974,  4-437; Code 1996,  4-437) 
Sec. 8-246. - Thomson Prometric (block and associates examinations). 
    The examinations prepared and published by Thomson Prometric, 1260 Energy Lane, St. Paul, Minnesota 55108 shall be deemed a reasonable examination, testing the knowledge and skill of alteration, repair and maintenance of electrical conductors and equipment. 
(1)  The city shall sponsor applicants for Thomson Prometric exams to be given at designated sites by Thomson Prometric. 
(2)  Upon request by applicant, the licensing official furnishes the applicant an application form to be completed and returned to the inspection department with the administration fee, which shall be on file in the city clerk's office, and documentation of related experience. The fee is paid to the inspection department office at the time the applicant applies for examination and shall be retained by the city whether or not the applicant passes the examination. 
(3)  The licensing official will screen and approve the applicants to sit for an examination and furnish the applicant an "approved" Thomson Prometric examination registration form containing the licensing official's signature, the exam sponsor code, and the exam code and exam name for which the applicant is to be tested. This form is accompanied by an instruction sheet explaining how the applicant is to fill in the form, and a list of examination schedule and test center codes. When executed, the examination registration form is sent by the applicant to Thomson Prometric indicating the exam location and date, and will be accompanied by a certified check for the appropriate examination fee. 
(4)  Upon receipt of the examination registration form and certified check, Thomson Prometric will send the applicant a letter of admission. This letter, along with a picture identification (driver's license, passport, etc.), must be presented at the exam site in order to gain entry. 
(5)  After the requested examination has been administered and graded by Thomson Prometric, the results will be sent to the inspection department for distribution to applicant. A score of 75 percent is required to pass the examination. Should the applicant not pass the examination, a request for a written review may be made to the licensing official. This analysis will be returned to the sponsoring official for transmitting to the applicant. This type of review will not be prepared for applicants scoring less than 50 percent. 
(Code 1996,  4-438; Ord. No. 3587,  2; Ord. No. 3848,  XIII, 7-16-2002) 
Sec. 8-247. - Permit required. 
(a)  No person shall enter upon the construction of any electric light or power wiring, whether original installation or any material alteration of existing installations, in any building in the city connected or to be connected to the public electric utilities of said city, without first having secured a permit therefor. Application for such permit shall be made in writing to the city building official upon blanks furnished by the city describing the proposed work, except as provided in this article and except that no permit will be required to execute any of the classes of electrical work specified in subsections (a)(1) through (3) of this section: 
(1)  The replacement of lamps, fuses, bulbs or the connection of portable electrical equipment to suitable permanently installed receptacles, and replacement of receptacles and switches, lighting fixtures and apparatus where no changes or alterations are made to the wiring. 
(2)  Any work involved in the manufacturing, repair or testing of any electrical equipment or apparatus, but not including any permanent wiring. 
(3)  Any work in industrial establishments where inspections come under the scope of other inspection agencies. 
(b)  In case any work is begun where a permit is required, but without permission being first secured therefor, or the aforesaid installations are otherwise being made in violation of this article, the electrical inspector shall have the power to stop such work at once and to order any and all persons engaged therein to stop and desist therefrom until the proper permission is secured. Such action shall not defer any other penalties which may be applicable under this article. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to secure or furnish a permit for the installation, alteration, or repair of electrical conductors or equipment to any person not entitled to the permit under the regulations of this article. 
(d)  No permits will be issued to other than licensed electrical contractors except as provided for in the section of this article covering property owner's rights. 
(Code 1974,  4-439; Code 1996,  4-439; Ord. No. 4249,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-248. - Application for permits. 
(a)  Application for permit describing work to be done shall be made to the inspection department office by the person installing the work. The application will be referred to the electrical inspector who shall determine whether the installation as described will be in conformity with the requirements of this article. The application shall be accompanied by such information as may be necessary to determine whether the installation as described will be in conformity with the requirements of this article. If it is found that the installation as described will conform with all legal requirements and if the applicant has complied with all provisions of this article, a permit for installation shall be issued. 
(b)  When required by the city electrical inspector, the applicant shall state the size of conductors to be used for all services, mains, feeders and subfeeders, size of main and subfeeder switches and fuses, the area to be served by such conductors and the basis used in computing the required size of the conductors. 
(c)  No deviation shall be made from the installation described in the permit without notifying the electrical inspector. The issuance of a permit shall not be taken as permission to violate any of the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1974,  4-440; Code 1996,  4-440; Ord. No. 3848,  XIV, 7-16-2002) 
Sec. 8-249. - Permit and inspection fees. 
    Any person granted a permit for electrical installations of conductors or equipment shall pay to the city a permit and inspection fee which are on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1996,  4-441; Ord. No. 3352,  1; Ord. No. 3655,  I; Ord. No. 4012,  VIII, 3-18-2008) 
Sec. 8-250. - Limitation of permits. 
    Every specific permit issued by the electrical inspector under the provisions of this article shall expire by limitation and become null and void, if the work authorized by such permit has not been started within six months (180 days) from the date of such permit, or if the work authorized by such permit is suspended or abandoned at any time for a period of six months (180 days) after work is started. Before such work can be started again, a new permit shall be obtained. 
(Code 1974,  4-442; Code 1996,  4-442; Ord. No. 4249,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-251. - Revocation of permits. 
    The electrical inspector shall have the right to declare a permit null and void if there has been misrepresentation of facts or any violation of the provisions of this article or for any other just cause. 
(Code 1974,  4-443; Code 1996,  4-443) 
Sec. 8-252. - Refund of permit and inspection fees. 
    An electrical permit may be canceled by the applicant at any time within six months (180 days) of the date of issuance. If no work has been done under such permit, the electrical inspector, when formally requested in writing by the applicant, shall recommend to the governing body a refund of the permit fee paid. 
(Code 1974,  4-444; Code 1996,  4-444; Ord. No. 4249,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-253. - Fees and inspections for circuses, carnivals, etc. 
    Circuses, carnivals and road shows having portable equipment shall employ a registered contractor in a supervisory capacity to be responsible for the work. 
(Code 1974,  4-445; Code 1996,  4-445) 
Sec. 8-254. - Inspection required. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every person who may have placed wiring as described in section 8-247, in any building in the city, or in any building located outside the corporate limits of the city, connected or to be connected to the public electric utilities of the city, to report the same to the electrical inspector immediately upon completion of the wiring. The electrical inspector shall, within 24 hours thereafter, make a careful inspection of the wiring so reported and if the same be approved, the electrical inspector shall, upon the payment of the fees provided in this article, issue to the owner or agent of the building in which the wiring has been done, a certificate to the effect that the wiring has been approved and shall authorize the delivery and maintenance of an electric current in the building. 
(b)  When any electric equipment is to be hidden from view by the permanent placement of parts of the building, the person installing the equipment shall notify the electrical inspector and such equipment shall not be concealed until it has been inspected, approved or authorized by the electrical inspector or until 24 hours, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, shall have elapsed from the time of such notification. On large installations, where the concealment of equipment proceeds continuously, the person installing the electrical equipment shall give the electrical inspector due notice and inspections shall be made periodically during the progress of the work. 
(c)  The electrical inspector shall have the authority to require building contractors to open such work which, in any manner, conceals electrical wiring that has been closed without the electrical inspector's knowledge or permission, and in no case shall inspectors issue clearance until satisfied that the work is in accordance with the provisions of this article. Inspectors shall also have the right to refuse to issue a clearance on any wiring, that is concealed in such manner that it cannot be fully determined that it has been done in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1974,  4-446; Code 1996,  4-446) 
Sec. 8-255. - Certificate of approval. 
(a)  When the electrical inspector finds the installation to be in conformity with the provisions of this article, the electrical inspector shall issue to the person, firm, or corporation making the installation, a certificate of approval, with duplicate copy for delivery to the owner, authorizing the use of the installation and connection to the supply of electricity and shall send written notice of such authorization to the city municipal utilities who will supply the electrical service. 
(b)  When a certificate of approval is issued authorizing the connection and use of a temporary installation, the certificate shall expire at a time to be stated therein and shall be revocable for cause by the electrical inspector. 
(c)  Permission may be given authorizing the connection and use of certain specified portions of an incompleted installation; the preliminary connection shall be revocable at the discretion of the electrical inspector. 
(d)  In no case shall certificates of approval be issued on installations or parts of installations where the work installed does not conform to the requirements of this article. 
(e)  If, upon inspection, the installation is not found to be fully in conformity with the provisions of this article, the electrical inspector shall immediately notify the person, firm, or corporation making the installation of the existing defects. 
(f)  No certificate of approval shall be issued unless the electric conductor or equipment has been installed in strict conformity with the provisions of this article and unless the installation is made in compliance with nationally approved methods of construction for safety to life and property as herein set forth. 
(g)  The electrical inspector shall be deemed the judge of whether the installation of electric conductors and equipment has been made in accordance with the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1974,  4-447; Code 1996,  4-447) 
Sec. 8-256. - Connection to installations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to make connection to a supply of electricity to any electrical equipment for which a permit is required, or which has been disconnected by the order of the electrical inspector, until a certificate of approval has been issued by the electrical inspector authorizing the connection and use of such equipment; provided that the electrical inspector may authorize a temporary connection. 
(Code 1974,  4-448; Code 1996,  4-448) 
Sec. 8-257. - Reinspection. 
    The electrical inspector shall periodically reinspect existing installation of electrical conductors and equipment. When the installation of any conductors or equipment is found to be in a dangerous or unsafe condition, the person, firm, or corporation owning, using, or operating the installation shall be notified in writing and shall make the necessary repairs or changes required to place the conductors or equipment in safe condition and have the work completed within the period specified by the electrical inspector. 
(Code 1974,  4-449; Code 1996,  4-449) 
Sec. 8-258. - Condemnation. 
(a)  If in the judgment of the electrical inspector, after inspection, the electrical conductors, appliances or equipment in any building are unsafe or dangerous to persons or property, the inspector shall have the power to cause the wires or appliances to be disconnected from the source of electrical energy supplying these conductors or equipment, and may, at the electrical inspector's discretion, seal the control switches for the same in an open or disconnected position, where upon the electrical inspector shall give notice to the owner, or the owner's agent, or by posting such notice at the site and shall also notify the city municipal utilities serving the premises. Thereafter, it shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit electric current to be supplied to the electrical conductors, appliances or equipment so sealed until they shall have been made safe and the inspector shall have issued a certificate of approval to that effect. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the electrical inspector to cause all dead wires, unused poles or electric apparatus on the outside of the buildings or in streets or alleys to be removed at the expense of the owners thereof by giving the owners written notice. 
(c)  When the electrical inspector condemns all or part of any electrical installation, the owner may, within five days after receiving written notice thereof, file a petition in writing for review of the action of the electrical inspector by the governing body of the city, upon the receipt of which, the governing body shall at once proceed to determine the facts, and within five days make a decision in accordance with their findings. 
(Code 1974,  4-450; Code 1996,  4-450) 
Sec. 8-259. - Changes; alterations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to, in any manner, change or alter electrical conductors or equipment in or on any building. If, in the course of the erection of a building or structure, electrical conductors or equipment are in such position as to interfere with the erection or completion of the structure, notice shall be immediately given the authorized person installing the electrical conductors or equipment, and the needed change shall be made by such authorized person. 
(Code 1974,  4-451; Code 1996,  4-451) 
Sec. 8-260. - Standards for electric installations. 
    The National Electrical Code adopted by section 8-215 shall constitute the minimum standards for provisions of this article, except for special requirements set forth in sections 8-261 through 8-263. 
(Code 1990; Code 1996,  4-452; Ord. No. 3502,  2) 
Sec. 8-261. - Wiring methods. 
    The following rules and regulations shall be observed for wiring: 
(1)  Fire limits. 
a.  All electric wiring for light, heat or power shall be wired in approved rigid conduit, electrical metallic tubing, metal-clad (MC) cable, metal raceway or Underwriters Laboratories tested and approved flexible electrical non-metallic conduit may be used in nonexposed areas. One- and two-family dwellings which shall be wired according to the National Electrical Code. The disconnect shall be placed on the outside of the building nearest the point of entry, or on the city utility pole after first obtaining permission from the city electric distribution department. 
b.  All buildings hereafter constructed or additions to existing buildings or for extensions or for additional wiring in such buildings, flexible metallic conduit may be used for fishing in concealed wall or ceiling spaces of existing buildings or for short flexible connections not in excess of three feet, for equipment requiring some flexibility. Flexible nonmetallic conduit may also be used for this purpose. Where the requirements of the section would in any way weaken the structure and/or be detrimental to the structure, the electrical inspector may grant permission in writing to use some other approved type wiring method in construction. 
c.  All service entrance conductors, to buildings used for business purposes in the fire limits shall be provided with a main disconnection switch or breaker of the safety enclosed type and operated from outside of the enclosure and so marked as to indicate whether the switch is "on" or "off" and shall be located at a readily accessible point nearest to the entrance of the conductors (on the outside of the building or structure) or must have written approval of the city electrical inspector. The disconnecting switch shall control all circuits and devices. 
d.  Existing residential houses converted to business uses shall be allowed to continue their use of wiring methods of NM cable (romex) or knob and tube wiring when provided with a written statement from a properly licensed electrical contractor stating that existing wiring has been inspected and found to be in a safe condition and that the service is adequate for the new loads provided the house has not been renovated to a point where it is feasible to wire in an approved raceway. All extensions and additions to existing wiring shall be in an approved raceway and future structure additions or alterations shall include rewiring the entire building to comply with the wiring method in approved conduit. This section shall apply only to buildings with an occupant load of less than 50 persons. 
(2)  Outside fire limits. 
a.  All electrical wiring for lights, heat or power in all buildings constructed to be used for business purposes, churches, public buildings, manufacturing establishments, institutional buildings and other places of assembly located outside the fire limits, except existing frame apartments, and motel buildings new or existing that do not exceed three floors above grade, the first floor of such building being that floor which is designed for human habitation and which has 50 percent or more of its perimeter level with or above the finished grade of the exterior wall line, shall be wired in approved rigid conduit, electrical metallic tubing, metal raceway, metal clad (MC) cable, or U.L. tested and approved flexible electrical nonmetallic conduit, except flexible metallic conduit may be used for fishing in concealed ceiling or wall spaces of existing buildings and for short flexible connections not in excess of three feet where the equipment requires some flexibility. Flexible nonmetallic conduit may also be used for this purpose. 
b.  All raceways installed in poured concrete floors, ceilings or outside poured walls shall be rigid conduit or cellular duct or flexible nonmetallic conduit when approved by the city electrical inspector for that purpose. Where the requirements of this section in any way would weaken the structure or be detrimental to the structure, the electrical inspector may grant permission in writing to use some other type of approved wiring method in the construction. All feeders 100 ampere or larger shall be in approved raceway. 
c.  Each set of conductors to buildings outside the fire limits hereafter constructed, or additions to existing buildings, or for additional wiring in such buildings to be used for business purposes, churches, public buildings, manufacturing establishments, institutional buildings and building occupied by more than two families and any building where instrument metering is required shall be provided with a readily accessible means of disconnecting all conductors from the source of power supply. The disconnect shall be placed on the outside of the building nearest the point of entry, or on the city utility pole after first obtaining permission from the city electric distribution department. 
d.  Existing residential houses converted to business uses shall be allowed to continue their use of wiring methods of NM cable (romex) or knob and tube wiring when provided with a written statement from a properly licensed electrical contractor stating that existing wiring has been inspected and found to be in a safe condition and that the service is adequate for the new loads and provided the house has not been renovated to a point where it is feasible to wire in an approved raceway. All extensions and additions to existing wiring shall be in an approved raceway and future structure additions or alterations shall include rewiring the entire building to comply with the wiring method in approved conduit. This section shall apply only to buildings with an occupant load of less than 50 persons. 
(3)  Single- and multiple-family. 
a.  All services to new one- and two-family dwellings shall be installed in not smaller than 11/4 inch rigid galvanized conduit or electrical metallic tubing, with three conductors of 100 ampere capacity, to a readily accessible means of disconnecting all conductors of 100 ampere rating from the source of supply, as provided in the National Electrical Code, incorporated by this article, except that 120 and 240 volt circuits shall not be grouped together. 
b.  All new meter installations to one-family and two-family dwellings shall be installed in a weatherproof type outdoor metal box or meter fitting approved by the city department of municipal utilities for such purpose, located on the outside of the building, the location to be designated by the city municipal utilities department furnishing the service. 
c.  In multiple-dwelling occupancy buildings, each occupant shall have access to the occupant's disconnection means. In a multiple-occupancy dwelling having a common readily accessible space available, the disconnecting means may be in accordance with the National Electrical Code, incorporated by this article, except that 120 and 240 volt circuits shall not be grouped together. 
d.  In new residence construction and remodeling of existing dwelling occupancies, there shall not be more than ten outlets per circuit, and branch circuits which supply receptacle outlets in the kitchen, laundry, pantry and breakfast room shall not supply other outlets and such circuits shall have a rating not smaller than 20 ampere. 
e.  Lighting fixtures in clothes closets installation and clearances to storage shelves. 
1.  Location. A fixture in a clothes closet shall be permitted to be installed: 
(i)  On the wall above the closet door, provided the clearance between the fixture and a storage area where combustible material may be stored within the closet is not less than six inches (152 mm); 
(ii)  On the ceiling over an area which is unobstructed to the floor, maintaining a six inch (152 mm) clearance horizontally between the fixture and a storage area where combustible material may be stored within the closet; or 
(iii)  A flush recessed fixture with a solid lens or a ceiling-mounted fluorescent fixture shall be permitted to be installed provided there is a six inch (152 mm) clearance, horizontally between the fixture and the storage area. 
2.  Pendants. Pendants shall not be installed in clothes closets. 
(4)  Miscellaneous requirements branch circuit protection. In new buildings constructed and in all existing buildings wired or rewired, all 15 ampere, single phase, 120 volt branch circuits, shall be equipped with dead front panels containing circuit breakers of proper rating, except that the electrical inspector may grant permission to move existing service equipment and branch circuit fuse protection on remodel work, if of an enclosed safety type. 
(5)  Underground service laterals. All service laterals for new construction with basements shall have a slip joint installed with the service riser at the structure. All underground electrical wirings shall have an approved marker tape buried in the same trench at least 12 inches below grade and no less than 12 inches above conductors. 
(6)  Outlets per circuit main ceiling light openings hereafter wired in ceilings over retail merchandise sales floors shall be wired with a minimum size wire of No. 12 B & S gauge and the maximum number of openings per circuit shall not exceed six. 
(7)  Grounding type receptacles. All receptacles installed for the attachment of flexible cords shall have a grounding conductor and said grounding terminal shall be of distinctively different appearance from the other two terminals. 
(8)  Standby/portable generator isolation. Customer-owned standby generating equipment shall be installed so that it is virtually impossible for the customer's standby generator to energize the city electric distribution system. To prevent this from occurring the customer shall install a "double-pole, double throw switch". This is necessary to ensure the safety of our customers and their equipment, as well as the safety of our linemen and equipment. The authority having jurisdiction for enforcing the Code shall have approval of the suitability of the equipment and the installation of such equipment. Diagram 453-i shall be used as a reference. 
(9)  Metal clad (MC) cable. MC cable shall meet the requirements of article 330 of the National Electrical Code (NEC). Installation shall include the following additional requirements that the metallic sheath be cut only with the recommended cutting tool of the manufacturer and that termination on each end of the cable shall include the installation of anti-short bushings which are normally supplied with the cable by the manufacturer. 
(10)  Rigid nonmetallic conduit (PVC). PVC shall meet the requirements of article 352 of the National Electrical Code (NEC). Uses permitted are hereby limited by this section; exposed uses subject to physical damage shall require schedule 80 or equivalent from grade level to eight feet above grade. Areas subject to physical damage shall include but not be limited to areas of or near to vehicular traffic such as street and alley rights-of-way, public and private drives, roads, approaches and parking areas or lots. Areas subject to physical damage shall include locations less than 20 feet from these areas described. 
(11)  Services. All services shall be installed in rigid metal conduit, intermediate metal conduit or electrical metallic tubing from the source of supply to the distribution overcurrent panel board enclosure. The service shall include metallic conduit, nipples, risers, enclosures, locknuts, bushings, auxiliary gutters, junction boxes, pull boxes, weather heads, etc. Grounding and bonding at the service shall be as required in Article 250 of the National Electric Code (NEC). 
EXCEPTION: Services provided with an outside service disconnect with overcurrent protection shall be allowed to have SE cable installed as a feeder to the distribution panel board when installed in compliance with Section 338.10(B) "Feeders" of the National Electric Code. 
(Code 1996,  4-453; Ord. No. 3731,  4; Ord. No. 3803,  II, 7-20-1999; Ord. No. 3848,  XV, 7-16-2002; Ord. No. 4106,  1, 2, 2-21-2012) 
Sec. 8-262. - Forced air furnaces with flexible cord and plug connectors. 
    National Electrical Code section 400.7 "Flexible Cords - Uses Permitted" shall be amended to include forced air furnaces. National Electrical Code section 422.16.A "Appliance Flexible Cords" shall be amended to include forced air furnace installations. Electrically operated forced air furnaces may be permitted to be cord-and-plug connected with a flexible cord with an attachment plug and shall be energized from a receptacle outlet when all of the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The flexible cord shall be suitable for the environment and physical conditions encountered. 
(2)  The flexible cord shall be a minimum size (12 AWG) with an ampacity of not less than 15 amps. 
(3)  The length of the flexible cord shall not exceed six feet. 
(4)  The flexible cord shall be terminated with a ground type attachment plug. 
(5)  The flexible cord shall be used only in continuous lengths without splice. 
(6)  The flexible cord shall be of the following types: SP-3, SPE-3, SPT-3, SO-3 or equivalent with approval of the authority having jurisdiction. 
(7)  The flexible cord shall not be run through holes in walls, ceiling or floors. 
(8)  The flexible cord shall not be installed in raceways. 
(9)  The flexible cord shall be protected from damage by bushings or fittings where passing through holes in covers, outlet boxes or similar enclosures. 
(10)  The receptacle outlet shall be located to avoid physical damage to the flexible cord. 
(11)  The receptacle outlet shall be accessible and located in the space occupied by the furnace. 
(Code 1974,  4-454; Code 1996,  4-354; Ord. No. 3848,  XVI, 7-16-2002; Ord. No. 4249,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-263. - Nonmetallic-sheathed cable: Type NM, NMC and NMS. 
    Uses permitted: Type NM, Type NMC and Type NMS cable shall be permitted to be used only in one- and two-family dwellings and their accessory structures and multifamily dwelling units. The structure shall not exceed three floors above grade. These structures shall be served only by single-phase services. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  IV, XII, 2-2-2010) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4056,  IV, adopted Feb. 2, 2010, repealed former  8-243, and enacted a new  8-263 as set out herein. Former  8-263 pertained to approved materials. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 8-264. - Sewage ejector pumps and sump pumps. 
    In a dwelling, ground fault circuit interrupter protection shall not be required on a sewage ejector pump or sump pump that is cord and plug connected to a single receptacle installed on a dedicated circuit. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  V, XII, 2-2-2010) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4056,  XII, adopted Feb. 2, 2010, repealed former  8-264, and enacted a new  8-264 as set out herein. Former  8-264 pertained to liability. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 8-265. - Intersystem bonding. 
    An intersystem bonding bar shall be mounted outside by the electric meter/service equipment or by the ground rod and shall have provisions for connecting at least three intersystem bonding/grounding conductors. This bonding bar shall be connected to the grounding electrode system with a minimum 6 AWG copper conductor. This is required on all new buildings and will also be required when the electric service is changed or upgraded. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  VI, XII, 2-2-2010) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4056,  VI, adopted Feb. 2, 2010, repealed former  8-265, and enacted a new  8-265 as set out herein. Former  8-265 pertained to penalty. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 8-266. - Arc-fault circuit interrupter protection. 
(a)  Definition: Arc-fault circuit interrupter (AFCI). A device intended to provide protection from the effects of arc-faults by recognizing characteristics unique to arcing and by functioning to de-energize the circuit when an arc fault is detected. 
(b)  Dwelling unit bedrooms. All 120-volt, single phase, 15- and 20- ampere branch circuits supplying outlets installed in dwelling unit bedrooms shall be protected by a listed arc-fault circuit interrupter, combination type installed to provide protection of the branch circuit. 
    EXCEPTION: The location of the arc-fault circuit interrupter shall be permitted to be at other than the origination of the branch circuit in compliance with (1) and (2): 
(1)  The arc-fault circuit interrupter installed within 1.8m (6 feet) of the branch circuit overcurrent device as measured along the branch circuit conductors. 
(2)  The circuit conductors between the branch circuit overcurrent device and the arc-fault circuit interrupter shall be installed in a metal raceway or a cable with a metallic sheath. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  VII, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 4249,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-267. - Truth in advertising requirements. 
    On or after January 1, 2010, any person, firm or corporation required by this article to obtain an electric license shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  It is unlawful for any such person, firm or corporation to advertise as an electrical contractor unless at the time such advertisement occurs, such person, firm or corporation has a then valid electrical contractors license issued under the provisions of this chapter; 
(2)  Any advertisement by such person, firm or corporation as an electrical contractor which is placed or published in any publication or other print medium circulated, displayed or distributed within the city limits or which is broadcast by radio or television or any other means to persons within the city limits shall include the full name of the licensed person, firm or corporation; 
(3)  As used herein, the words "advertise" or "advertisement" shall mean and include, but not be limited to, a business card, contract bid proposal form, printed letterhead, any other printed or written material designed to inform persons of the services offered by the advertising person, firm or corporation and to solicit business from such persons. Such words are intended to include telephone directory display ads but not basic white and yellow page listings. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  VIII, 2-2-2010) 
Sec. 8-268. - Approved materials. 
    No electric materials for wiring of appliances or equipment shall be installed in the city unless they are in conformity with the provisions of this article and with the approved standards of construction for safety to life and property. Conformity of materials for wiring appliances and equipment to standards of the Underwriters Laboratories, Inc., or other nationally recognized testing agencies, shall be prima facie evidence that the materials, devices, appliances and equipment comply with the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  IX, 2-2-2010) 
Sec. 8-269. - Liability. 
    This article shall not be construed to relieve from responsibility any person owning, controlling or installing electrical wiring equipment or devices, nor shall the city be held as assuming any liability of any nature by reason of the inspection authorized herein or certificate issued. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  X, 2-2-2010) 
Sec. 8-270. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not exceeding $500.00, or by imprisonment in the city jail for not to exceed 30 days, or by both fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 4056,  XI, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 4249,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-271. - Branch circuit panel-board requirements. 
    All panels installed shall be sufficiently large enough to provide four blank spaces of four overcurrent protective devices for future use. 
(Ord. No. 4156,  II, 5-20-2014) 
Sec. 8-272. - Conductor requirements. 
(a)  Commercial and industrial. 
(1)  Type. All commercial and industrial wiring conductors rated 200 amperes or less, including all service conductors required to be installed by the licensed electrical contractor, shall be copper. For parallel conductors, each individual conductor of a parallel set shall meet the requirements of this section. Parallel conductors are not to be considered a single conductor. 
Exception: Feeder circuit and branch circuit conductors rated 100 amperes or more, may be aluminum or copper-clad aluminum, provided panel-boards or disconnect switches served by such circuits are marked by manufacturer as being suitable for aluminum or copper clad-aluminum termination. 
(2)  Minimum size. The minimum size conductors shall be No. 12 AWG copper, except smaller sizes will be acceptable for control wiring. 
(b)  Residential. All residential and accessory building wiring conductors rated less than 100 amperes shall be copper. 
(c)  All mobile or manufactured (MFH) homes and their accessory building wiring conductors rated 200 amperes or less shall be copper. 
(Ord. No. 4156,  II, 5-20-2014) 
Sec. 8-273. - Color code-Branch circuits. 
    Where installed in raceways, as cable or as open work, all conductors connected to the same system shall conform to the following color code: 
Three-phase, four-wire 120/208 volt-Phase A - black; Phase B - red; Phase C - blue; grounded conductor - white. 
Three-phase, four-wire 277/480 volt-Phase A - brown; Phase B - orange; Phase C - yellow; grounded conductor - gray. 
    The grounded conductor of a three-wire 240 volt delta system shall be identified by alternating white and red stripes encircling the conductor. 
    The grounded conductor of a three-wire 480 delta system shall be identified by alternating gray and orange stripes encircling the conductor. 
    Ungrounded circuit conductors used as travelers between 3-way and 4-way switches may be of colors other than those specified. 
    All conductor sizes 6 AWG or smaller shall be identified by a continuous outer finish along its entire length. Sizes larger than 6 AWG shall be identified, at time of installation, by distinctive color markings at its terminations. This marking shall encircle the conductor or insulation. 
    All circuit conductors of the same color shall be connected to the same ungrounded conductor throughout the premises wiring system(s). 
(Ord. No. 4156,  II, 5-20-2014) 
Sec. 8-274. - Type NM, NMC, and NMS cable ampacity. 
    The ampacity of types NM, NMC, and NMS cable shall be determined in accordance with NEC 310.15(B)(16). The ampacity shall be in accordance with the 60 C (140 F) conductor temperature rating. 
(Ord. No. 4156,  II, 5-20-2014) 
Sec. 8-275. - Residential garage door opener. 
    In a dwelling, ground fault circuit interrupter protection shall not be required on an overhead garage door opener that is cord-and-plug connected to a single receptacle installed in the ceiling directly above the overhead garage door opener motor. 
(Ord. No. 4156,  II, 5-20-2014) 
Sec. 8-276. - Pools shall not be located under overhead wiring. 
    The following parts of pools shall not be placed under existing electrical, communication, CATV, network-powered broadband conductors or any other overhead wiring; nor shall such wiring be installed above the following: 
(1)  Pools and the area extending ten feet horizontally from the inside of the walls of the pool; 
(2)  Diving structure; or 
(3)  Observation stands, towers or platforms. 
(Ord. No. 4156,  II, 5-20-2014) 
Sec. 8-277. - Receptacles for refrigerators and freezers. 
    In a dwelling, ground fault circuit interrupter protection shall not be required for freezers and refrigerators located within 1.8m (six feet) of the outside edge of a sink or in a residential garage that is cord-and-plug connected to a single receptacle. 
(Ord. No. 4156,  II, 5-20-2014) 
Secs. 8-278-8-293. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PLUMBING CODE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, adopted March 15, 2011, repealed former Art. VI,  8-294-8-326, and enacted a new Art. VI as set out herein. Former Art. VI pertained to the same subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 

Sec. 8-294. - Adopted. 
    The International Plumbing Code (IPC), 2015 Edition and Appendix Chapter C and E, a model code prepared by the International Code Council, Inc. 500 New Jersey Avenue, NW, 6th Floor, Washington, DC 20001, is hereby adopted by reference and incorporated as an ordinance by the City of Wellington, Kansas, except as specific provisions thereof are hereby amended or repealed. One or more copies of the IPC shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy," with all deleted or amended sections or portions thereof clearly marked to show such modification, and to which shall be attached a copy of this ordinance. Such copy or copies shall be filed with the city clerk and shall be open and available for public inspection at all reasonable hours. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011; Ord. No. 4250,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-295. - Amendments. 
    The following amendments to the plumbing code adopted in section 8-294 are hereby adopted to read as follows: 
A.  Section 101.1 of the IPC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
Section 101.1 Title. These regulations shall be known as the International Plumbing Code of the City of Wellington hereinafter referred to as "this code". 
B.  Section 106.3.1 of the IPC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
106.3.1 Construction documents. For commercial buildings only; construction documents, engineering calculations, diagrams and other such data shall be submitted in two or more sets with each application for a permit. The code official shall require construction documents, computations and specifications to be prepared and designed by a registered design professional having a valid State of Kansas license. Construction documents shall be drawn to scale and shall be of sufficient clarity to indicate the location, nature and extent of the work proposed and show in detail the work conforms to the provisions of this code. Construction documents for buildings more than two stories in height shall indicate where penetrations will be made for pipe, fittings and components and shall indicate the materials and methods for maintaining required structural safety, fire-resistance rating and fireblocking. 
Exception: The code official shall have the authority to waive the submission of construction documents, calculations or other data if the nature of the work applied for is such that reviewing of construction documents is not necessary to determine compliance with this code. 
C.  Section 106.6.2 of the IPC is amended to read as follows: 
Section 106.6.2 Fee schedule. The fees for all plumbing work shall be as in the provisions of section 8-314 on file in city clerk's office. 
D.  Section 106.6.3 of the IPC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
Section 106.6.3 Fee refunds. The code official shall authorize the refunding of fees as follows: 
1.  The full amount of any fee paid hereunder that was erroneously paid or collected. 
2.  Not more than 80 percent of the permit fee paid when no work has been done under a permit issued in accordance with this code. 
3.  Not more than 80 percent of the plan review fee paid when an application for a permit for which a plan review fee has been paid is withdrawn or cancelled before any plan review effort has been expended. 
The Code Official shall not authorize the refunding of any fee paid except upon written application filed by the original permittee not later than 180 days after the date of fee payment. 
E.  Section 108.4 of the IPC is hereby deleted in its entirety. 
F.  Section 108.5 of the IPC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
Section 108.5 Stop work orders. Upon notice from the code official, work on any plumbing system that is being performed contrary to the provisions of this code or in a dangerous or unsafe manner shall immediately cease. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property, or to the owner's authorized agent, or to the person performing the work. The notice shall state the conditions under which work is authorized to resume. Where an emergency exists, the code official shall not be required to give a written notice prior to stopping the work. Any person who shall continue any work in or about the structure after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable to a fine of not less than [100.00] dollars or more than [2000.00] dollars. 
G.  Section 109 of the IPC, Means of Appeal is hereby deleted in its entirety. 
H.  Section 305.3 of the IPC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
Section 305.3 Pipes through foundation walls. Any pipe that passes through a foundation wall shall be provided with a relieving arch, or a pipe sleeve pipe shall be built into the foundation wall. The sleeve shall be at least one half (1/2) inch larger than the pipe passing through the wall. 
I.  Section 305.4.1 Sewer Depth of the IPC is amended to read as follows: 
Section 305.4.1 Sewer Depth. Building sewers shall be a minimum of 12 inches below grade. 
J.  Section 313.1 of the IPC is hereby deleted in its entirety. 
K.  Section 313.1 of the IPC is hereby deleted in its entirety. 
L.  Section 503 is hereby amended by adding a new section (503.3) 
Section 503.3 Hot and cold water branch lines. Hot and cold water branch lines connected to and within 18 inches of the water heater, shall be of brass, K, L or M copper, galvanized steel or an approved metallic water heater connector. 
M.  Section 603.2 of the IPC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
Section 603.2 Separation of water service and building sewer. Where water service piping is located in the same trench with the building sewer, such sewer shall be constructed of materials listed in Table 702.2. Where the building sewer piping is not constructed of materials listed in Table 702.2, the water service pipe and the building sewer shall be horizontally separated by not less than 5 feet (1524 mm) of undisturbed or compacted earth. The required separation distance shall not apply where a water service pipe crosses a sewer pipe, provided the water service is sleeved to a point not less than 5 feet (1524 mm) horizontally from the sewer pipe centerline on both sides of such crossing. The sleeve shall be of pipe materials listed in Table 605.3, 702.2 or 702.3. The required separation distance shall not apply where the bottom of the water service pipe, located within 5 feet (1524 mm) of the sewer, is not less than 24 inches (610mm) above the highest point of the top of the building sewer. 
N.  Section 603 of the IPC is hereby amended by adding a new section (603.3) 
Section 603.3 Tracer wire. For the purpose of locating the building service lines, all new or replacement, installations using non-metallic pipe or tubing shall have #10 THHN, or equivalent, tracer wire installed with the service line. The tracer wire shall be installed as follows: 
Water line. The tracer wire shall extend from six (6) inches above the meter box cover through the meter box to the point where it enters the building, where it shall be connected to a one half (1/2) pound anode or larger. 
Yard hydrant. The tracer wire shall extend from six (6) inches above the surface of the ground at the yard hydrant to the point of connection to the water service, where it shall be connected to an existing tracer wire or grounded to a one half (1/2) pound anode or larger. 
Lawn sprinkler. The tracer wire shall extend from six (6) inches above the surface of the ground at the backflow device to the point of connection to the water service, where it shall be connected to an existing tracer wire or grounded to a one half (1/2) pound anode or larger. 
Exception: The tracer wire may be omitted on lawn sprinkler piping installed after the back flow device located on private property. 
O.  Section 606.2 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
Section 602.2 Location of shut off valves. Shutoff valves shall be installed in the following locations: 
1.  On the fixture supply to each plumbing fixture other than bathtubs and showers in one- and two-family residential occupancies, and other than in individual sleeping units that are provided with unit shutoff valves in hotels, motels, boarding houses and similar occupancies. 
2.  On the water supply pipe to each appliance or mechanical equipment. 
P.  Sections 607.2.1 and 607.5 of the IPC are hereby deleted in their entirety. 
Q.  Section 608.15.4 of the IPC is hereby amended by adding a new section 608.15.4.3 
Section 608.15.4.3 Yard hydrants. When installed, water piping shall be ridge type "K" copper, brass or galvanized pipe for a distance of six (6) inches on both sides of the hydrant (freeze proof) or a minimum six (6) inch extension of type "K" copper, brass or galvanized pipe attached before yard hydrant (freeze proof). Adequate rock or gravel shall be installed at the base of the hydrant to allow for a drainage field for the hydrant drain. Hydrants shall be fitted with a non-removable hose bib vacuum breaker and the weep hole shall be fitted with a 1/8-inch ell and a short nipple. Hydrants shall be supported by a steel tee post with a minimum of (2) stainless steel bands. Bands shall be installed six (6) inches above finished grade and within six (6) inches of the hydrant head. 
R.  Section 701.2 of the IPC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
Section 701.2 Sewer required. Every building in which plumbing fixtures are installed and all premises having drainage piping shall be connected to a public sewer, where available, or a private sewage disposal system approved by the Director of Sumner County Planning and Zoning. 
S.  Section 702.3 of the IPC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
Section 702.3 Building sewer pipe. Building sewer pipe shall conform to one of the standards listed in Table 702.3 with the exclusion of any type of cellular core, foam core, and SDR type pipe to be used outside the perimeter of the structure. 
T.  Section 703.1 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
Section 703.1 Building sewer pipe near the water service. The proximity of a sewer to a water service shall comply with Section 603.2. Where the building sewer is installed within 5 feet (1524mm) of the water service, as provided for in Section 603.2, the building sewer pipe shall conform to one of standards for ABS plastic pipe, copper or copper alloy tubing, or PVC plastic listed in Table 702.3. 
U.  Section 703 is hereby amended by adding a new section 703.7 
Section 703.7 Tracer wire. For the purpose of locating building sewers, all new installations and replacements shall have a #10 THHN, or equivalent, tracer wire installed with the sewer. The tracer wire shall extend from the surface of the ground at the cleanout to the tap, where it shall be connected to an existing tracer wire or grounded to a one half (1/2) pound anode or larger. 
V.  Section 715.1 of the IPC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
Section 715.1 Sewage backflow. All new or replacement building sewers shall include a backflow prevention device. The backflow prevention device shall be installed as close to the building as is practical and upstream of the cleanout, and shall be made accessible for periodic cleaning by the building owner. Or when the backflow device is installed in the building drain, all fixtures shall be protected by a backwater valve before discharging to the building sewer. 
W.  Section 715.1 is hereby amended by adding a new Section 715.1.1 
Section 715.1.1 Existing building sewers. When repairs to an existing building include the removal of a house trap or replacement of five (5) feet of drain line and or installation of a cleanout the backflow prevention device shall be installed as close to the building as is practical and upstream of the cleanout. 
Exception: Backflow prevention device may be omitted if approved by the authority having jurisdiction. 
X.  Section 903.1 of the IPC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
Section 903.1 Roof extensions. Open vent pipes that extend through a roof shall be terminated not less than [12] inches (304mm) above the roof. Where a roof is to be used for assembly or as a promenade, observation deck, sunbathing deck or similar purposes, open vent pipes shall terminate not less than 7 feet (2134 mm) above the roof. 
Y.  Section 918.3 of the IPC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
Section 918.3 Where permitted. Individual, branch and circuit vents shall be permitted to terminate with a connection to an individual or branch-type air admittance valve in accordance with Section 918.3.1. Stack vents and vent stacks shall be permitted to terminate to stack-type air admittance valves in accordance with Section 918.3.2. When permitted, permission shall be required from the building official and noted on the Plumbing permit. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011; Ord. No. 4250,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-296. - Definitions. 
    In addition to and supplemental to the terms defined in the definitions article of that edition of the International Plumbing Code now or hereafter incorporated by the Governing Body, the following terms shall be defined as follows:
