(1)  Employing Plumber is any person who maintains a regularly established plumbing shop, who does not personally engage in work as a Plumber, but employs Master Plumbers, to do or supervise the plumbing work for the shop. 
(2)  Master Plumber is hereby defined as any person who has served at least three years as a Journeyman Plumber, and who has passed the examination of the Board of Examiners hereinafter provided for. 
(3)  Journeyman Plumber is any person who has served at least two years as an "Apprentice Plumber" and who has been examined and found by the Board of Examiners to be qualified to be licensed as a Plumber but does not possess the qualifications of a "Master Plumber." 
(4)  Apprentice Plumber is any person who is actually working at plumbing under the direct supervision of a Master Plumber, with the intention of qualifying to become a Journeyman Plumber. 
(5)  Appliance: A device which utilizes gas fuel to produce light, heat, refrigeration or power. 
(6)  Branch Lines or Branches: Those pipes which convey gas from a supply line to appliances. 
(7)  Concealed Gas Piping: Piping which when in place in a finished building, will be hidden from view by the structure. 
(8)  Gas Fitter (Journeyman): A person who has been approved by the Plumber's examining Board of the City showing such person to be qualified to do gas piping, install appliances, make repairs to gas piping systems and appliance, or in any way work at the trade of gas piping for a qualified Master Gas Fitter or Master Plumber. A Gas Fitter shall have a current certificate issued by the above-mentioned Board showing him or her to be so qualified. 
(9)  Gas Fitter (Master): A person who has been approved by the Plumber's examining Board of the City showing him to be qualified to engage in the business of gas piping, installation of gas appliances, the making of repairs to gas piping systems and appliances and who has a license and bond as required by this Article and a current certificate issued by the above-mentioned Board showing him or her to be so qualified. 
(10)  House Piping: The system of piping within a building, either exposed or concealed, which conveys gas from the outlet of the service meter to appliances at various places throughout the building any piping underground which contains measured gas. 
(11)  Outlet: The end of a branch line to which a gas burning appliance is or may be attached. 
(12)  Portable Appliance: A gas burning unit which by use demands that the same be moved from place to place, such as gas pressing iron, Bunsen burner or similar device. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-297. - Plumber's certificate required. 
    Any person now or hereafter engaging or working at the business of plumbing in the City, either as a Master Plumber, Employing Plumber; or as a Journeyman Plumber, shall first receive a certificate therefore in accordance with the provisions of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-298. - Thompson Prometric examinations. 
    The examination prepared and published by Thomson Prometric, 1260 Energy Lane, St. Paul, Minnesota 55108, shall be deemed a reasonable examination testing the knowledge and skill of each applicant to do plumbing work, involving the installation, alteration, repair and maintenance of plumbing and house drainage. 
(1)  The City shall sponsor applicants for Thomson Prometric exams to be given at designated sites by Thomson Prometric. 
(2)  Upon request by applicant, the licensing Official furnishes the applicant an application form to be completed and returned to the Inspection Department with the $15.00 examination fee and documentation of work-related experience. The fee is paid to the Inspection Department at the time the applicant applies for examination and shall be retained by the City whether or not the applicant passes the examination. 
(3)  The licensing Official will screen and approve the applicants to sit for an examination and furnish the applicant an "approved" Thomson Prometric examination registration form containing: 
a.  The licensing Official's signature; 
b.  The exam sponsor code; and 
c.  The exam code and exam name for which the applicant is to be tested. 
This form is accompanied by an instruction sheet explaining how the applicant is to fill in the form, and a list of examination schedule and test center codes. When executed, the examination registration form is sent by the applicant to Thomson Prometric indicating the exam location and date, and will be accompanied by a certified check for the appropriate examination. 
(4)  Upon receipt of the examination registration form and certified check, Thomson Prometric will send the applicant a "Letter of Admission." This letter, along with a picture identification (driver's license, passport, etc.), must be presented at the exam site in order to gain entry. 
(5)  After the requested examination has been administered and graded by Thomson Prometric, the results will be sent to the Inspection Department for distribution to applicant. A score of 75 percent is required to pass the examination. Should the applicant not pass the examination, a request for a written review may be made to the licensing Official. This type of review will not be prepared for applicants scoring less than 50 percent. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-299. - Reserved. 
Sec. 8-300. - Lapse of certificate. 
    Any holder of a certificate who fails to renew the same by March 1st from the date of expiration shall be required to submit one of the following: 
1.  Proof of passing a new examination as required in this article. The plumbing examination will be administered in accordance with K.S.A. 1508 and amendments thereto, with a minimum passing score of 75 percent. 
2.  Proof of completing an additional 11/2 hours of continuing education for each three-month period the renewal is late and only when the original certificate was issued pursuant to K.S.A. 12-1508. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-301. - Plumber's license required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in or work at the business of plumbing in the city, either as an employing plumber, a master plumber, master gas fitter, journeyman gas fitter, journeyman plumber, without first having secured a license from the inspection department to do so, in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-302. - Plumber's license, employing plumber. 
(a)  Upon the issuance of plumbing license to an employing plumber of a master plumber under the plumbing code of the city, the plumbing inspector of the city shall assign to the licensee a number which shall be recorded on the face of the license. The plumbing inspector shall keep a permanent record showing the number assigned as aforesaid, the name and address of the licensee and the date on which the number was assigned. The licensee shall retain the number so assigned until such time as the licensee fails to renew the license as provided by this Code. 
(b)  Every employing plumber or master plumber to whom a number has been assigned as hereinabove provided, shall display such number in plain view on the side of all the plumber's business vehicles in order that the same will be easily visible to all persons. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-303. - License fees. 
(a)  The fee for a license of an employing plumber and the subsequent renewal fee shall be on file in the city inspection department. The fee for a master plumber and the subsequent renewal fee shall be on file in the city inspection department. In the event that a duly licensed master plumber is also an employing plumber, only a master plumber's license is required. The fee for a license of a journeyman plumber shall be on file in the city inspection department. 
(b)  The State of Kansas requires 12 classroom hours of continuing education every two years or six classroom hours every year to renew each master or journeyman license. 
(c)  The City of Wellington is on a two-year renewal cycle on licenses and all licenses shall expire December 31st of each odd-number year. Copies of certificates on the classes attended must be provided at the time of license renewal. 
(d)  No plumber shall be granted a permit or allowed to do any work under any permit unless the plumber has obtained or renewed the Plumber's license for the current period. 
(e)  No license or fee shall be required of an apprentice plumber, but any person desiring to work at plumbing as an apprentice plumber must register said person's name with the city inspection department and give the name of the master plumber under whom said person is working as an apprentice plumber, and the time of any apprenticeship shall be calculated from the date of such registration. 
(Ord. No. 4128,  1, 2, 12-18-2012) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4128,  1, 2, adopted Dec. 18, 2012, repealed former  8-303, and enacted a new  8-303 as set out herein. Former  8-303 pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Ord. 4085,  1, 2, adopted March 15, 2011. 
Sec. 8-304. - Liability insurance required. 
(a)  In addition to the license fee set forth in section 8-303, and before the license is issued, every employing plumber or master plumber shall file with the city engineering/inspection department a good and sufficient policy of insurance naming the city as an additional insured, issued by a company authorized to do business in the state, in an amount not less than $300,000.00, covering personal injury and property damage of any kind or nature whatsoever arising from the licensee's failure to comply with the ordinances, codes, rules and regulations of the city pertaining to plumbing and such other work for which the license is required. A valid current certificate showing the aforesaid coverage shall be filed with the city engineering/inspection department before any license is issued. 
(b)  This policy of insurance shall contain a provision that the coverage afforded by this policy shall not be cancelled or materially changed until at least 15 days prior written notice has been given to the city. This section shall not apply to any person in the employment of the city who shall do such plumbing work under the direction of the water or sewer distribution supervisor. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-305. - Plumbing inspector. 
    The office of plumbing inspector is hereby created. The person chosen to fill the office of plumbing inspector shall be possessed of such executive ability as is required for the performance of the plumbing inspector's duties and shall have a thorough knowledge of the standard materials and the methods used in the installation of plumbing. The person chosen to fill the office of plumbing inspector shall be well versed in approved methods of construction for safety to persons and property and in the provisions of the plumbing code of the city. The person chosen to fill the office of plumbing inspector shall have had at least five years experience of a nature that is acceptable to the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-306. - Appointment of inspectors. 
    The plumbing inspector and the plumber inspector's inspectors shall be appointed by the city manager and shall serve under the supervision and direction of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-307. - Prohibited interests. 
    It shall be unlawful for the plumbing inspector to engage in the business of selling, installing or maintenance of plumbing devices, appliances, fixtures, apparatus or equipment, and the plumbing inspector shall have no financial interest in any concern engaged in such business at any time while employed by the city as such plumbing inspector. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-308. - Duties of plumbing inspector; inspection fees. 
    It shall be the duty of the Plumbing Inspector to enforce the provisions of this Code. The Plumbing Inspector or the Plumber Inspector's authorized assistant shall have the right and privilege to enter any building, within reasonable hours in the City for the purpose of making inspections of the plumbing, drainage or ventilation system constructed or under construction in such building. Each and every system of plumbing, drainage or ventilation shall be inspected and approved by the Plumbing Inspector or said authorized assistant, before the plumbing shall be used. When rough work or drainage and ventilation in any building shall have been constructed and before same is covered from view, the Plumber doing such work shall notify the Plumbing Inspector in writing or otherwise, that the work is ready for inspection. No inspection shall be called for until the job is ready. The Inspector shall make the inspection within 24 hours after inspection has been called for. If the work shall be found by the Inspector to comply with the Ordinances of the City, and shall stand the required tests as provided in the Plumbing Code of the City, then the inspector shall approve the work and the work may then be covered. In case the work shall not comply with the Ordinances and Code, the Plumber shall make such changes as are necessary to be made to cause the work to comply with the same as directed by the Plumbing Inspector. If the Plumber fails to make the necessary changes within 48 hours, the Plumber shall forfeit the right to obtain permits until the changes are made and approved by the Plumbing Inspector. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-309. - Arbitration board. 
    The combined trades board shall act as an arbitration board in deciding any question that may arise between the plumbing inspector and any employing, master or journeyman plumber or gas fitter that is not covered by this article, and the decision of said board in such matters shall be final, unless an appeal is taken to the governing body of the city. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011; Ord. No. 4250,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-310. - Duty to show license and permit. 
    It shall be the duty of every person doing work as Plumber or Gas Fitter in the City to show the Plumber or Gas Fitter's license, and the City permit hereinafter provided for, to any Inspector of Plumbing, Sanitary Police or regular Policeman who shall ask to see the same. No work done by any Plumber without first having procured a permit therefore shall be inspected or approved by the Plumbing Inspector, but it shall be the duty of the Plumbing Inspector to report each and every such case to the Governing Body and also the person for whom the work is being done. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-311. - Suspension of licenses. 
    Bad faith or unreasonable delay in the performance of plumbing work shall be deemed a sufficient reason for subjecting the Plumber so offending to a suspension of the Plumber's license and every plumber shall be held responsible for violations committed by laborers and help employed by the Plumber. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-312. - Permits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to do any plumbing as defined in this Article or to uncover a public sewer for any purpose, or to open or take off any manhole, flush tank or inlet cover, or to make or cause to be made any connection with the mains or laterals of the public sewers of the City, without having first received a written Plumber's permit from the Plumbing Inspector of the City, granted upon a written application describing the contemplated work, the premises to be plumbed and the fixtures to be put in. No permit shall be issued to anyone not holding a license either as an Employing Plumber or Master Plumber. No permit shall be issued to make a connection with any main outside of a Sewer District, or to make a connection with a main or lateral for the purpose of severing any property which has not been specially assessed or is legally liable to special assessment for the cost of the sewer laterals, until written application shall have been presented to and approved by the Governing Body, and the fee, which shall be fixed and determined on each application by the Governing Body, shall have been paid. No permit shall be issued to authorize a property outside the corporate limits of the City to make a connection with any main or lateral of the City sewer system, until such written application shall have been presented to and approved by the Governing Body, and the fee, which shall be fixed and determined on each application by the Governing Body, shall have been paid. Plumbing done pursuant to the permit shall be subject to all of the provisions and inspection required of plumbing done inside the corporate limits of the City. A permit and inspection will also be required if and when a property outside the corporate limits desires to make a connection to the City water distribution system. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-313. - Homeowner's rights. 
(a)  Nothing herein contained shall prohibit any bona fide property owner from personally installing any plumbing within or upon the person's own property. Homeowners are permitted to build, one single-family dwelling every three years under the provisions of this section. The owner shall file with the plumbing inspector approved plans and specification, satisfy the plumbing inspector as to the owner's ability to install the plumbing, secure a permit, pay required fees, do work in accordance with this article, and apply for an inspection and receive a certificate of approval. 
(b)  Personal installation by an owner under these homeowner rights shall be by the owner, for the owner on the owner's own property, without compensation and no person shall be employed to assist the owner in any way on such work, except a registered plumbing contractor. This shall not include commercial property. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011; Ord. No. 4250,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-314. - Fees for permits. 
    Fees for permits as provided in the preceding section shall be on file in the building and codes department. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011; Ord. No. 4250,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-315. - Permits not required. 
    No permit shall be required under this Article for minor repair work. By minor repair work is meant the repairs of leaks in pipes, traps or cocks, opening up stoppage in waste or supply pipes, traps and drains or replacing broken fixtures. Permits shall be required of any person who sells and installs a water softener or water heater. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-316. - Gas piping matters covered. 
    All matters concerning, affecting or relating to materials, appliances and the installation, alteration, repair, removal, use, location and maintenance of gas piping installed in structures in the City are presumed to be provided for by this article and all reasonable rules and regulations adopted in the furtherance thereof and in conformance therewith, except insofar as such matters are otherwise provided for by other valid law or Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-317. - General requirements relating to gas piping. 
    The general requirements relating to gas piping shall be as follows: 
1)  It shall be unlawful to use or maintain any gas piping or appliances which have been installed, altered or repaired in violation of the provisions of this article. It shall be unlawful to use any materials, devices or appliances not in accordance with the provisions of this article or not approved by the Board of Examiners. 
2)  Any company engaged in the business of supplying gas shall refuse or discontinue gas service to any system of gas piping or to any gas burning appliance, and shall notify the Plumbing Inspector in writing of its action, the use or continued use of such piping or appliance is considered hazardous by the company; or discontinue said service upon written notice from the Plumbing Inspector to do so. 
3)  Except as hereinafter provided, the Plumbing Inspector shall inspect and witness all tests of all new house piping and post a certificate of inspection at the meter location. The gas company serving the premises shall not set a meter or turn gas into the house piping until the installation has been inspected and approved by the Plumbing Inspector. Tests and inspections shall be based on the provisions of this article and all governing laws and Codes relating to the subject. 
4)  No person other than a licensed Plumber or registered Gas Fitter shall install, alter, repair or extend any gas piping or connect or disconnect any gas appliance other than an appliance generally considered as portable. No registered Gas Fitter shall do plumbing of any description as defined in the International Plumbing Code adopted by this article. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-318. - Gas service. 
    Rules and regulations governing gas service shall be as follows: 
1)  The size of the service pipe shall be in accordance with the American Gas Association Standards. Service pipe shall be laid at a depth of not less than 12 inches, and shall be laid in a ditch separated from the ditches of water, sewer or other underground pipes or conduits by no less than 18 inches of solid undisturbed earth. Gas service line laid parallel to a foundation wall shall be laid on a line not less than two feet from such foundation wall and on solid undisturbed earth. In no case shall a service line be laid parallel to the building in the backfill along the foundation wall. Where a service or supply line passes through a foundation wall, except where such wall is on a property line, the same shall enter the building above grade. A swing joint shall be construed at the meter loop and also where the service line comes up to enter the building. 
2)  A standard brass or iron body brass core stopcock, or shutoff valve shall be placed in the service line in an accessible position immediately ahead of the meter. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-319. - Gas meters. 
    Rules and regulations governing gas meters shall be as follows: 
1)  Gas shall not be turned on by gas company except as provided in this article, unless the gas company serving the premises tests the piping by observing the meter dial and finds it to be gastight. 
2)  Gas meters shall be located a safe distance from equipment where there is an unguarded flame or the possibility of electric sparks. There shall be at least eight feet between a meter and a coal, wood, oil or gas fired furnace. 
3)  When meter locations are inside a building, such locations shall be as close as possible to the point of entry of the service line, in no case exceeding 20 feet. Gas piping at the meter locations shall be rigid and capable of supporting the meter without undue strain of vibration. Piping from point of entry to meter shall be exposed. Meters shall not be placed in driveways, public passages, halls, coal bins or other places where they are subject to damage, or in places where they will be subjected to excessive corrosion. Meters shall be placed in outside locations accessible for inspection, installation and removal. Meters shall not be placed under steps, under unventilated bulkheads or show windows, or in bedroom, bathroom or small confined places such as closets and lavatories, not under a sink, over an electric or gas fixture or within three feet of an electric meter or switch box when located inside of a building. 
4)  No person, other than an employee of the gas company serving the premises, shall disconnect, remove, connect or change the location of a meter or service regulator without a permit from the gas company serving the premises. The moving of a meter or the construction of an additional meter loop requires a permit and inspection by the Plumbing Inspector. Unmetered gas shall not be piped through or under a building to a meter location outside the building. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Secs. 8-320-8-324. - Reserved. 
Sec. 8-325. - Truth in advertising requirements. 
    On or after April 1, 2011, any person, firm or corporation required by this article to obtain a plumbing license shall be subject to the following: 
(a)  It is unlawful for any such person, firm or corporation to advertise as a plumbing contractor unless at the time such advertisement occurs, such person, firm or corporation has a then valid plumbing contractor license issued under the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Any advertisement by such person, firm or corporation as a plumbing contractor which is placed or published in any publication or other print medium circulated, displayed or distributed within the city limits or which is broadcast by radio or television or any other means to persons within the city limits shall include the full name of the licensed person, firm or corporation. 
(c)  As used herein, the words "advertise" or "advertisement" shall mean and include, but not be limited to, a business card, contract bid proposal form, printed letterhead, any other printed or written material designed to inform persons of the services offered by the advertising person, firm or corporation and to solicit business from such persons. Such words are intended to include telephone directory display ads but not basic white and yellow page listings. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-326. - Penalty. 
    Any owner, agent, architect, plumber, gas fitter, contractor or other person failing, neglecting, omitting, resisting or refusing to comply with any of the conditions or requirements of this article, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in a sum of not more than $500.00 for each offense, and each day's failure, neglect or refusal to comply with the said conditions or requirements shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense and shall be fined as in other cases. The governing body may, at its discretion, either suspend or revoke any license issued under the plumbing code of the city, for any violation of the provisions thereof. 
(Ord. No. 4085,  1, 2, 3-15-2011; Ord. No. 4250,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Secs. 8-327-8-353. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - FUEL GAS CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4082,  3, adopted March 15, 2011, repealed Art. VII, which pertained to dangerous structures and derived from Code 1990 and Code 1996,  4-701-4-714. 

Sec. 8-354. - Adoption of the 2015 International Fuel Gas Code. 
    The 2015 International Fuel Gas Code (IFGC), and all appendix chapters, a uniform code prepared by the International Code Council, Inc., 500 New Jersey Ave, NW, 6th floor, Washington, DC 20001, is hereby adopted by reference and incorporated as an ordinance of the City of Wellington, Kansas, except as specific provisions thereof are hereby amended or repealed. One or more copies of the IFGC shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy," with all deleted or amended sections or portions thereof clearly marked to show such modification, and to which shall be attached a copy of this ordinance. Such copy or copies shall be filed with the city clerk and shall be open and available for public inspection at all reasonable hours. 
(Ord. No. 4087,  1, 3-15-2011; Ord. No. 4251,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-355. - Amendments. 
A.  Section 101.1 of the IFGC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    101.1 Title. These regulations shall be known as the Fuel Gas Code of the City of Wellington, Kansas, hereinafter referred to as "this code." 
B.  Section 106.3.1 of the IFGC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    106.3.1 Construction documents. Construction documents, engineering calculations, diagrams and other data shall be submitted in two or more sets with each application for a permit. The Code Official shall require construction documents, computations and specifications to be prepared and designed by a registered design professional having a valid State of Kansas license. Construction documents shall be drawn to scale and shall be of sufficient clarity to indicate the location, nature and extent of the work proposed and show in detail that the work conforms to the provisions of this Code. Construction documents for buildings more than two stories in height shall indicate where penetrations will be made for installations and shall indicate the materials and methods for maintaining required structural safety, fire resistance rating and fireblocking. 
    Exception: The Code Official shall have the authority to waive the submission of construction documents, calculations or other data if the nature of the work applied for is such that reviewing of construction documents is not necessary to determine compliance with this Code. 
C.  Section 106.6.2 of the IFGC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    106.6.2 Fee schedule. The fees for work shall be as in the provisions of section 8-314 of the plumbing code for fuel gas piping and section 8-564 of the mechanical code for fuel gas fired appliances both on file in the City Clerk's office. 
D.  Section 106.6.3 of the IFGC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    106.6.3 Fee refunds. The Code Official shall authorize the refunding of fees as follows. 
1.  The full amount of any fee paid hereunder which was erroneously paid or collected. 
2.  Not more than 80 percent of the permit fee paid when no work has been done under a permit issued in accordance with this code. 
3.  Not more than 80 percent of the plan review fee paid when an application for a permit for which a plan review fee has been paid is withdrawn or canceled before any plan review effort has been expended. The code official shall not authorize the refunding of any fee paid, except upon written application filed by the original permittee not later than 180 days after the date of fee payment. 
E.  Section 108.4 of the IFGC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    108.4 Penalties. Any person who violates a provision of this code; fails to comply with any of the requirements thereof; or erects, installs, alters or repairs work in violation of the approved construction documents or a directive of the code official or of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of this code shall be guilty of a class C violation, punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment not exceeding thirty (30) days, or both such fine and imprisonment. Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate violation. 
F.  Section 108.5 of the IFGC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    108.5 Stop work orders. Upon notice from the code official that work is being done contrary to the provisions of this code or in a dangerous or unsafe manner, such work shall immediately cease. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property, the owner's agent, or the person doing the work. The notice shall state the conditions under which work is authorized to resume. Where an emergency exists, the code official shall not be required to give a written notice prior to stopping the work. Any person who shall continue any work on the system after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable for a fine of not less than one hundred ($100) dollars or more than two thousand dollars ($2000.00). 
F.  Sections 109.1 through 109.7 of the IFGC are hereby deleted. 
G.  Section 301.2 of the IFGC is hereby deleted. 
H.  Section 303.3 shall be amended to read as follows: 
    303.3 Prohibited locations. Appliances shall not be located in sleeping rooms, bathrooms, toilet rooms, storage closets or surgical rooms, or in a space that opens only into such rooms or spaces, except where the installation complies with one of the following: 
i.  The appliance is a direct-vent appliance installed in accordance with the conditions of the listing and the manufacturer's instructions. 
ii.  Vented room heaters, wall furnaces, vented decorative appliances, vented gas fireplaces, vented gas fireplace heaters and decorative appliances for installation in vented solid fuel-burning fireplaces are installed in rooms that meet the required volume criteria of Section 304.5. 
iii.  A single wall-mounted unvented room heater is installed in a bathroom and such unvented room heater is equipped as specified in Section 621.6 and has an input rating not greater than 6,000 Btu/h (1.76 kW). The bathroom shall meet the required volume criteria of Section 304.5. 
iv.  A single wall-mounted unvented room heater is installed in a bedroom and such unvented room heater is equipped as specified in Section 621.6 and has an input rating not greater than 10,000 Btu/h (2.93 kW). The bedroom shall meet the required volume criteria of Section 304.5. 
v.  The appliance is installed in a room or space that opens only into a bedroom or bathroom, and such room or space is used for no other purpose and is provided with a solid weather-stripped door equipped with an approved self-closing device. All combustion air shall be taken directly from the outdoors in accordance with Section 304.6. 
vi.  Water heater installations in bedrooms and bathrooms shall be of the direct-vent type. Provided that with prior approval of the authority having jurisdiction, an existing water heater located in a bathroom may be replaced if it is equipped with an approved safety pilot and thermostat and is equivalent to the existing water heater. 
I.  Section 403.4.3 of the IFGC is hereby deleted. 
J.  Section 403.5 of the IFGC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    403.5 Metallic tubing. Seamless aluminum alloy and steel tubing shall not be used with gases corrosive to such materials. 
K.  Section 403.5.2 of the IFGC is hereby deleted. 
L.  Section 404.12 of the IFGC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    404.12 Minimum burial depth. Underground piping systems shall be installed a minimum depth of 12 inches below grade for metallic pipe and a minimum 18 inches for non-metallic piping below grade, except as provided in Section 404.12.1. 
M.  Section 406.1.4 of the IFGC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    406.1.4 Section testing. A piping system shall be permitted to be tested as a complete unit or in sections. A valve shall not be subjected to the test pressure unless it can be determined that the valve, including the valve-closing mechanism, is designed to safely withstand the test pressure. 
N.  Section 406.4.1 of the IFGC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    Section 406.4.1. Test pressure. Pressure shall be held for a period of 15 minutes for threaded joint pipe, 15 minutes for non-metallic pipe and 30 minutes for welded steel pipe without a perceptible loss before the test shall be deemed satisfactory. An air pressure test of 15 (PSI) pounds per square inch shall be placed upon all new service piping up to and including the meter cock and for repaired piping a pressure test of 5 (PSI) pounds per square inch will be made. Welded pipe shall be tested at 60 (PSI) pounds per square inch. Non-metallic pipe shall be tested at 100 (PSI) pounds per square inch. Mechanical gauges used to measure the test shall have a full-scale range of 30 PSI for standard tests and 100 PSI for welded and non-metallic pipe tests. 
O.  Section 414.2 of the IFGC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    414.2 Interconnections for standby fuels. Where supplementary gas for standby use is connected downstream from a meter or a service regulator where a meter is not provided, a device to prevent backflow shall be installed. A three-way valve installed to admit the standby supply and at the same time shut off the regulator supply shall be permitted to be used for this purpose. In areas where natural gas is available for use as a fuel gas, it shall be used as the primary source of fuel gas for R-1, R-2, R-3, and R-4 type occupancies. 
(Ord. No. 4087,  2, 3-15-2011; Ord. No. 4251,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Secs. 8-356-8-392. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - RESERVED[3] 

Footnotes:

ARTICLE IX. - RESERVED[4] 

Footnotes:

Editor's note- Ord. No. 4082,  3, adopted March 15, 2011, repealed Art. IX, which pertained to numbering buildings and derived from Code 1974,  4-901-4-903 and Code 1996,  4-901-4-903.

ARTICLE X. - PUBLIC WORKS BOND 

Sec. 8-464. - Bond with contractor. 
    Whenever any public official of the city shall, under the laws of the state, enter into contract in any sum exceeding $10,000.00 with any person, firm, or corporation for the purpose of making any public improvements, or construction of any public building or making repairs on the same, the officer shall take, from the party contracted with, a bond with good and sufficient sureties to the state in a sum not less than the sum total in the contract, conditioned that the contractor or the subcontractor of the contractor shall pay all indebtedness incurred for supplies, equipment, materials, or labor furnished, used or consumed in connection with or in or about the construction of the public building or in making the public improvements. 
(Code 1974,  4-1001; Code 1996,  4-1001) 
Sec. 8-465. - Filing, approval and limitations. 
    Any such bond shall be subject to the approval of the clerk of the district court of the county and shall be filed in the office of the clerk. When the bond is so approved and filed, no lien shall attach as provided by law, and if when the bond is filed liens have already been filed, the liens shall be discharged. Any person to whom there is due any sum for labor or material furnished, as stated in section 8-464, or such person's assigns, may bring an action on the bond for the recovery of the indebtedness. No action shall be brought on the bond after six months from the completion of the public improvements on public buildings. 
(Code 1974,  4-1002; Code 1996,  4-1002) 
Secs. 8-466-8-483. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - MOVING BUILDINGS 

Sec. 8-484. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. The term "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
    Applicant means any persons making application for a permit. 
    Building or structure means an assembly of materials forming a construction for occupancy or use including houses, buildings, or any other structures, but excluding mobile homes or trailers mounted on wheel or trucks for movement or transfer. 
    Building inspector means that person appointed or designated as such by the building official. 
    Permittee means any person obtaining a permit as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 3759,  I, 3-18-1997; Ord. No. 4252,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-485. - Permit required. 
    No person shall move in the city, any building or structure having either a total floor area of 200 or more square feet, a height of ten feet or more, or a width of 12 feet or more, upon, across, or over any highway, street, alley, or sidewalk in said city without first obtaining a permit to do so, issued by the building and codes department. 
(Ord. No. 3759,  II, 3-18-1997; Ord. No. 4252,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-486. - Application for permit; fees. 
    All applications for permits to move buildings or other structures described in sections 8-484 and 8-485 shall be made to the building and codes department, and such application shall state or include by attachment and be in compliance with the following: 
(1)  The intended use of the building or structure after moving; 
(2)  The dimensions of the building or structure as to length, height at its highest point when loaded for moving, and width; 
(3)  A definitive description of the building or structure proposed to be moved giving present street number, construction materials, dimensions in square feet, number of rooms and condition of exterior and interior; 
(4)  A plot plan to scale with legal description of the lot to which the building is to be moved, giving the lot number, block number and subdivision, or record if located within the city; 
(5)  The day and hour when the moving is to commence and length of time required of the move. If a variance is sought for a move not to be completed within the daylight hours of a single day other than Saturday or Sunday for the reason that such is not feasible, the application shall state the facts constituting such reason with adequate evidence thereof attached. The building official, upon adequate showing may grant such variance which shall not be effective unless set out in the permit; 
(6)  The names or location of highways, streets, alleys or sidewalks over, along across which the building or structure is proposed to be moved; 
(7)  The application shall be made not less than seven calendar days prior to the intended commencement of the moving and shall be accomplished by a fee of $10.00; 
(8)  The application must include copies of prior written notice of such application, with copy thereof, that has been delivered by the applicant to the owners of wired or other facilities, whenever the movement will affect or cross wiring for the public utilities, cable television, traffic control devices, or the crossing of any railroad located within the city limits, should such a permit be issued; 
(9)  The applicant of the building or structure to be moved, shall file with the application, sufficient evidence that all taxes and any city charges against the owner are paid in full. Applicant shall furnish a certificate of public liability insurance issued by insurance company authorized to do business in the state, and in which the city is named as co-insured, for personal and property damage exempting and saving harmless the city in a minimum amount of $100,000.00 injury each person, $300,000.00 each occurrence, and $50,000.00 property damage before a permit shall be issued; 
(10)  The applicant, if also the owner, shall include statement of ownership and if not the owner, shall attach a written statement or bill of sale signed and acknowledged by the owner, of other sufficient evidence, that he is authorized by the owner to move the building or structure; 
(11)  The applicant shall obtain a permit from the state if a state highway is involved and a copy shall be supplied to the building official; 
(12)  Application shall have attached thereto a written statement specifically identifying the persons, or contractor, intended to physically accomplish the move, including a description of the equipment and of the experience and qualifications of the same in the performance of such a moving operation. Such person of contractor shall be named in the permit and such permit shall not authorize any moving operation by anyone not so named therein. 
(Ord. No. 3759,  III, 3-18-1997; Ord. No. 4252,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-487. - Bond or letter of credit required. 
    Before such permit is issued, the applicant shall file with the building official a bond executed by applicant as principal, with corporate surety authorized to do business in the state in the amount of $5,000.00 wherein the city is named as obligee, or, in lieu thereof, and an irrevocable letter of credit issued to the city by a bank with place of business located in the county, in like amount, either of which shall be conditioned as follows: 
(1)  That principal shall pay any and all damages, costs or expenses, resulting from the moving operation, and including full compensation or any injury, to any property, public or private, related to the moving operation, whether caused by a principal, or agent thereof, or his servant, employee, workman, contractor or subcontractor. 
(2)  That principal will indemnify and protect the city from any and all liability, related to or resulting from the move, and including any cost of defense, of any claim thereof, or cost or expense of enforcement of or recovery under the terms of the bond or letter of credit. 
(3)  That said move, once begun, shall proceed continuously without interruption until completed, including removal of rubbish and materials and fill of excavation and place of premises from which the structure is moved in safe and satisfactory condition within five days from time of move. 
(4)  That in the event of any failure to fully comply with this Code, including any cessation or interruption of the moving operation before completion thereof, the city, at the election of the public works director, but without requirement therefor, may proceed by use of city personnel, or by contractor selected by it, to the completion of the move as provided by the permit, at the cost or expense of the permittee, including compensation for the time and services of city personnel, and recover all of the same, including enforcement and expense of recovery hereunder, from any and all of the principal, surety on the bond, or bank issuing such letter of credit. 
(Ord. No. 3759,  IV, 3-18-1997; Ord. No. 4252,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-488. - Duties of building official. 
(a)  Inspection . The building official shall inspect the building or structure to determine whether the standard for issuance of a permit is met and issue or deny such permit. 
(b)  Standards for issuance . The building official shall refuse to issue a permit if he finds: 
(1)  That any application requirement or any fee, deposit, insurance or bond requirement has not been complied with; 
(2)  That the building or structure is of such size and of such construction or in such a state or deterioration, disrepair or is otherwise so structurally unsafe that it cannot be moved without endangering persons or property within the city; 
(3)  That the building or structure is structurally unsafe or unfit for the purpose stated when moved, if the removal location is in the city; 
(4)  That the zoning ordinance contained in chapter 40 or any other ordinances would be violated by the location and use of the building or structure at the location intended; 
(5)  That for any reasonably ascertainable reason, persons or property in the city would be endangered by the moving of the building or structure; 
(6)  That weight, length, width or other restriction imposed upon the use of the public or private roadways within the city limits by either city traffic ordinances or state statutes would be violated. 
(c)  Fees and deposits . 
(1)  Deposits . The building inspector shall deposit all fees and deposits received with the city clerk. 
(2)  Return upon non-issuance . Upon the refusal to issue a permit, all funds deposited shall be returned to the applicant. If a permit is granted and the move is not begun by the applicant with the period of the permit, then one-half of all funds deposited will be refunded; 
(3)  Claim on bond or letter of credit . After the building or structure has been removed, the building inspector shall furnish the city building official a written statement of all expenses and damages sustained by the city in removing, repairing and replacing all property belonging to the city and of all material used in the removal and replacement together with a statement of all damages caused to or inflicted upon property, both private and public, for information as to such claim against the bond or letter of credit. 
(d)  Designate streets for removal . The building inspector shall procure from the city building official, a list of designated streets over which the building or structure may be moved. The building inspector shall have the list approved by the chief of police and shall reproduce the list upon the permit in writing. In making their determinations, the city building official and the chief of police shall act to ensure maximum safety to persons and to minimize congestion and traffic hazard on public streets. 
(Ord. No. 3759,  V, 3-18-1997; Ord. No. 4252,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-489. - Duties of permittee. 
    Every permittee under this article shall: 
(1)  Use designated streets . Move a building or structure only over streets designated for such use in the written permit; 
(2)  Completion of move . Begin and complete the move within the daylight hours of a single day other than Saturday or Sunday unless a variance is granted by the building official and set out in the permit; 
(3)  Notify of revised moving time . Notify, in writing, both the building official and the police department at least 48 hours before the move of a desired change in moving date and hour and route of move as proposed in the application and such change must be approved by the building official before becoming effective; 
(4)  Notify of damage . Notify the building official in writing of any and all damages done to public or private property within 24 hours after the damage or injury has occurred; 
(5)  Warning devices at night . If any of the move is at night, it shall be the duty of any person moving any such building or structure upon or across any street, alley or sidewalk or other public place in the city to display red lanterns or other warning devices used in compliance with city ordinances or state statutes thereon in such a manner as to show the extreme height and width thereof from 30 minutes after sunset to 30 minutes before sunrise, shall at all times erect and maintain barricades across the street in such manner as to protect the public from damage or injury by reason of removal of the building or structure, and shall have sufficient escort as provided by city ordinance, state statutes or as determined as necessary for the public safety by the chief of police; 
(6)  No building to remain on right-of-way . No building or structure or any part of any building or structure being moved shall be left deposited or remain in any parkway, street, or on the dedicated right-of-way between the curb and the front property line of any lot; 
(7)  Comply with governing law . Comply with the building code, fire code, zoning ordinances and all other applicable traffic ordinances and laws upon relocating the building or structure in the city or move the same through the city; 
(8)  Clear old premises . Remove all rubbish and materials and fill in excavations to existing grade at the original building or structure site so that the premises are left in a safe and sanitary condition within five days from the date of the move; 
(9)  Remove service connections . A reasonable time before beginning the move, notify all utilities having service connections within the building or structure or along the route of moving and otherwise located within the city limits as to any facilities and services to the general public which may be affected by the movement of the building or structure. Copies of notification and evidence of delivery shall be furnished to the building inspector; 
(10)  Compliance with city building codes. Comply with all building codes of the city within 60 days after the physical move is made; 
(11)  Compliance with permit regulations and specifications . Comply with the regulations and specifications contained in such permit granted by the building official to such permittee. 
(Ord. No. 3759,  VI, 3-18-1997; Ord. No. 4252,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-490. - Enforcing officers. 
    The building official, police department and other appropriate officers of the city shall enforce and carry out the requirements of this article as set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 3759,  VII, 3-18-1997; Ord. No. 4252,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-491. - Permittee liable for expense above deposit. 
    The permittee shall be liable for any expenses, damages, costs in excess of deposited amounts of securities, and the city attorney shall prosecute an action against the permittee in a court of competent jurisdiction for the recovery thereof, including cost and fees for services in such recovery. 
(Ord. No. 3759,  VIII, 3-18-1997) 
Sec. 8-492. - Permit time limitation. 
    Permits issued under and pursuant to this article shall be valid for a maximum term of 60 days from date issued. 
(Ord. No. 3759,  IX, 3-18-1997) 
Sec. 8-493. - Proper foundation. 
    No building shall be moved to any lot unless and until a proper and suitable permanent foundation or basement has been previously constructed on such lot upon which such building will be permanently placed unless waived by the building official. The moved building or structure shall be anchored or attached, by approved methods within ten days after arrival on the new site. 
(Ord. No. 3759,  X, 3-18-1997; Ord. No. 4252,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-494. - Violation; penalty. 
    The violation of this article is a misdemeanor and any person convicted thereof shall be fined up to $500.00 for each such offense. Each day any violation of this article shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 3759,  XI, 3-18-1997) 
Secs. 8-495-8-511. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - MOBILE HOMES 

Sec. 8-512. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dependent mobile home means a mobile home which does not have a flush toilet and a bath or shower. 
    Independent mobile home means a mobile home which has a flush toilet and a bath or shower. 
    Inspector means the legally designated city inspection authority or such designated authority's authorized representative. 
    Licensee means any person licensed to operate and maintain a mobile home park under the provisions of this article. 
    Natural or artificial barrier means any street, river, pond, canal, railroad, levee, embankment or screening by appropriate fence or hedge. 
    Permittee means any person to whom a temporary permit is issued to maintain an individual mobile home outside of a licensed mobile home park and in accordance with the provisions as hereinafter prescribed. 
    Person means any natural individual, firm, trust, partnership, association or corporation, whether tenant, owner, lessee, licensee, permittee, agent, heirs or assigns. 
(Code 1974,  13-101; Code 1996,  4-1301) 
Sec. 8-513. - License. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, maintain, operate or permit to be established, maintained or operated any mobile home park within the corporate limits of the city without first having secured a license. 
(Code 1974,  13-102; Code 1996,  4-1302) 
Sec. 8-514. - License fee. 
    The annual license fee for each mobile home park shall be on file in the city clerk's office. All licenses shall be for a calendar year. Any license issued prior to July 1 of any year shall pay the annual fee; any license issued after July 1 of any year shall pay one-half of the annual fee. 
(Code 1996,  4-1308; Ord. No. 3412,  I) 
Sec. 8-515. - Application. 
    Application for a mobile home park license for an individual mobile home as provided and required in section 8-513 shall first be filed at the office of the Building and Codes Department. 
(Code 1974,  13-111; Code 1996,  4-1311; Ord. No. 4252,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-516. - Information. 
    The application for an initial mobile home park license shall be in writing, signed by the owner and shall include the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  The location and legal description of the mobile home park. 
(3)  A complete plan of the mobile home park in conformity with all of the requirements for such as contained in this article. 
(4)  Plans and specifications of all buildings, improvements and other facilities such as electrical wiring, water service pipes and sewer service, constructed or to be constructed within the mobile home park. 
(5)  Such further information as may be requested by the building official to enable him or her to determine if the proposed mobile home park will comply with all the requirements of this article. 
(6)  Before any application as required by this section may be approved for a mobile home park there must be a recommendation from the planning commission approving the site, location, design and layout of the mobile home park. Upon the receipt of the recommendation for such from the planning commission, the building official shall then investigate and inspect the application and the proposed plans and specifications. If the provisions, plans and specifications for the proposed mobile home park are in compliance with all provisions of this article and all other applicable ordinances and statutes, the building official shall approve the application and upon completion of the mobile home park according to the approved plans and specifications, the office of the city clerk shall issue a license for such upon payment of the fee or fees as hereinbefore provided. 
(7)  Any changes in existing facilities or additions to any mobile home park or any mobile space shall be treated as required in subsections (1) through (6) of this section. 
(Code 1974,  13-112; Code 1996,  4-1312; Ord. No. 4252,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-517. - Inspection. 
    Upon inspection of any mobile home park, the building official finds that conditions or practices exist which are in violation of any provision of this article or of any provision or regulation adopted pursuant thereto, the building official shall give notice in writing to the person to whom the license was issued and unless such conditions or practices are corrected within a reasonable period of time, to be determined by the building official, the building official shall give notice in writing to the person to whom the license was issued that the license has been revoked. Upon receipt of the notice of revocation, such person shall cease operation of such mobile home park. 
(Code 1974,  13-115; Code 1996,  4-1315; Ord. No. 4252,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-518. - License; denied or revoked. 
    Any person whose application for a license has been denied or any person whose license has been revoked may request and shall be granted a hearing of the matter before the governing body upon filing an application for hearing before such body within three days following the day on which such notice was received or license denied and the governing body shall hold such hearing within 21 days after the filing of such application. The filing of such application shall not suspend any order of the building official in denying application for license until the matter has been determined by the governing body. 
(Code 1974,  13-116; Code 1996,  4-1316; Ord. No. 4252,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-519. - Duty to maintain park. 
    It shall be the duty of the mobile home park owner or licensee to enforce all provisions of this article and to see that such licensed park is kept neat, clean and orderly at all times. A copy of this article and a copy of each license shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the licensed park. 
(Code 1974,  13-214; Code 1996,  4-1331) 
Sec. 8-520. - Duty to keep records. 
    It shall be the duty of the licensee to keep an accurate record of all mobile home owners and occupants using the mobile home park. The register shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of each occupant. 
(2)  Make, model and year of all automobiles and mobile homes. 
(3)  License number and owner of each trailer and automobile by which it is towed and the state of its issuance. 
(4)  Dates of arrival and departure of each mobile home. 
    Register must be made available to all law enforcement officers at all times, and such register shall not be destroyed for a period of three years following the last registration in each register. 
(Code 1974,  13-215; Code 1996,  4-1332; Ord. No. 4252,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-521. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this article or any provisions of any regulation adopted by the building official and governing body pursuant to authority granted by this article, shall upon conviction be punished as provided in section 1-17. 
(Code 1974,  13-216; Code 1996,  4-1333; Ord. No. 4252,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Secs. 8-522-8-550. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - MECHANICAL CODE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4086,  1, 2, adopted March 15, 2011, repealed former Art. XIII,  8-551-8-564, and enacted a new Art. XIII as set out herein. Former Art. XIII pertained to the same subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 

Sec. 8-551. - Adoption of the 2015 International Mechanical Code. 
    The 2015 Edition and Appendix Chapter A (the "IMC"), a uniform code prepared by the International Code Council, Inc., 500 New Jersey Ave., NW, 6th floor, Washington, DC 20001, is hereby adopted by reference and incorporated as an ordinance of the City of Wellington, Kansas, except as specific provisions thereof are hereby amended or repealed. One or more copies of the IMC shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy," with all deleted or amended sections or portions thereof clearly marked to show such modification, and to which shall be attached a copy of this ordinance. Such copy or copies shall be filed with the City Clerk and shall be open and available for public inspection at all reasonable hours. 
    The following sections of the IMC are hereby amended or repealed as hereinafter set forth: 
A.  Section 101.1 shall be amended to read as follows: 
101.1 Title. These regulations shall be known as the Mechanical Code of the City of Wellington, Kansas, hereinafter referred to as "this code". 
B.  Section 102.8.1 shall be created to read as follows: 
Building Code Provisions. The provisions of Section 8-181 et seq., of the Building Code of the City of Wellington, Kansas shall apply to construction, alterations, repairs, replacement equipment, appliances, fixtures, fittings and appurtenances thereto. 
C.  Section 102.8.2 shall be created to read as follows: 
Electrical. The provisions of Section 8-215 et seq., of the city of Wellington Electrical Code shall apply to the installations of electrical systems, including alterations, repairs, replacement equipment, appliances, fixtures, fittings and appurtenances thereto. 
D.  Section 102.8.3 shall be created to read as follows: 
Gas. The provisions of Section 8-294 et seq., of the City of Wellington Plumbing Code and the IFG code shall apply to the installation of gas piping from the point of delivery, gas appliances and related accessories as covered by this Code. These requirements apply to gas piping systems extending from the point of delivery to the inlet connections of appliances and related accessories. 
E.  Section 102.8.4 shall be created to read as follows: 
Plumbing. The provisions of Section 8-294 et seq., of the City of Wellington Plumbing Code shall apply to the installation, alterations, repairs and replacement of plumbing systems, including equipment, appliances, fixtures and appurtenances and where connected to water or sewage systems and all aspects if a medical gas systems. 
F.  Section 106.3.1 shall be amended to read as follows: 
106.3.1 Construction documents. Construction documents, engineering calculations, diagrams and other data shall be submitted in two or more sets with each application for a permit. The Code Official shall require construction documents, computations and specifications to be prepared and designed by a registered design professional having a valid State of Kansas license. Where special conditions exist, the code official is authorized to require additional construction documents to be prepared by a registered design professional. Construction documents shall be drawn to scale and shall be of sufficient clarity to indicate the location, nature and extent of the work proposed and show in detail that the work conforms to the provisions of this code. Construction documents for buildings more than two stories in shall indicate where penetrations will be made for mechanical systems, and the materials and methods for maintaining required structural safety, fire-resistance rating and fireblocking. 
Exception: The code official shall have the authority to waive the submission of construction documents, calculations or other data if the nature of the work applied for is such that reviewing of construction documents is not necessary to determine compliance with this code. 
G.  Section 106.5.2 shall be amended to read as follows: 
106.5.2 Permit fee schedule. Fees for permits as provided in the proceeding section shall be on file in the city clerk's office. 
H.  Section 106.5.3 shall be amended to read as follows: 
106.5.3 Fee refunds: The Code Official shall authorize the refunding of fees as follows: 
1.  The full amount of any fee paid hereunder which was erroneously paid or collected. 
2.  Not more than 80 percent of the permit fee paid when no work has been done under a permit issued in accordance with this code. 
3.  Not more than 80 percent of the plan review fee paid when an application for a permit for which a plan review fee has been paid is withdrawn or canceled before any plan review effort has been expended. 
The Code Official shall not authorize the refunding of any fee paid, except upon written application filed by the original permittee not later than 180 days after the date of fee payment. 
I.  Section 108.4 shall be amended to read as follows: 
108.4 Violation penalties. Persons who shall violate a provision of this Code or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who shall erect, install, alter or repair mechanical work in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the Code Official, or of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of this Code, shall, upon conviction be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00, or by imprisonment not exceeding 90 days, or both such fine and imprisonment. Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense. 
J.  Section 109 " Means of Appeal" shall be deleted in its entirety. 
K.  Section 301.2 "Energy Utilization" shall be deleted in its entirety. 
L.  Section 507.2.1.1 shall be amended to read as follows: 
507.2.1.1 Operation. Type "1" hood systems shall be designed and installed to automatically activate the exhaust fan whenever cooking operations occur. The activation of the exhaust fan shall occur through an interlock system specified by a registered design professional and submitted for plan review with the complete construction document package. 
M.  Section 601.5 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
601.5 Return Air Openings. Return air openings for heating, ventilation and air-conditioning systems shall comply with all of the following: 
1.  Openings shall not be located less than 10 feet (3048 mm) measured in any direction from an open combustion chamber or draft hood of another appliance located in the same room or space. 
2.  Return air shall not be taken from a hazardous or insanitary location or a refrigeration room as defined in this code. 
3.  Return and transfer openings shall be sized in accordance with the appliance or equipment manufacturer's installation instructions, ACCA Manual D or the design of the registered design professional. 
4.  Return air taken from one dwelling unit shall not be discharged into another dwelling unit. 
5.  Taking return air from a crawl space shall not be accomplished through a direct connection to the return side of a forced air furnace. Transfer openings in the crawl space enclosure shall not be prohibited. 
6.  Return air shall not be taken from a closet, bathroom, toilet room, kitchen, garage, boiler room, furnace room or unconditioned attic. 
Exceptions: 
1.  Taking return air from a kitchen is not prohibited where such return air openings serve the kitchen and are located not less than 10 feet (3048 mm) from the cooking appliances. 
2.  Dedicated forced air systems serving only the garage shall not be prohibited from obtaining return air from the garage. 
N.  Section 1101.10 of the IMC is hereby deleted. 
O.  Section 1102.3 of the IMC is hereby amended to read as follows: 
1102.3 Access port protection. Refrigerant access ports shall be protected by standard port caps whenever refrigerant is added to or recovered from refrigeration or air-conditioning systems. 
(Ord. No. 4086,  1, 2, 3-15-2011; Ord. No. 4253,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-552. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Apprentice mechanical contractor is any person actually working at mechanical appliance installations under the direct supervision of a master mechanical contractor. 
    Employing mechanical contractor is any person who maintains a regularly established mechanical appliance shop, who does not personally engage in the work of installation of mechanical appliances, but employs master mechanical contractors to do or supervise the mechanical appliance installation for the shop. 
    Journeyman mechanical contractor is any person who has served at least two years as an apprentice mechanical contractor and who has been examined and found by the Board of Examiners to be qualified as a mechanical contractor but, does not possess the qualifications of a master mechanical contractor. 
    Master mechanical contractor is hereby defined as any person who has served at least three years as a journeyman mechanical contractor, and who has passed the examination of the Board of Examiners hereinafter provided for. 
(Ord. No. 4086,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-553. - Mechanical contractors; license required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in or work at the business of mechanical contractor, a master mechanical contractor, or a journeyman mechanical contractor without first having secured a license from the Building and Codes Department to do so, in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Before a license is issued to any applicant, the applicant shall pass the applicable examination, pay the required license fee, show satisfactory proof of insurance that meets the provisions of this article and obtain the approval of the combined trades board. 
(Ord. No. 4086,  1, 2, 3-15-2011; Ord. No. 4253,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-554. - Mechanical contractor's license, employing mechanical contractor. 
    Upon the issuance of mechanical contractor's license to an employing mechanical contractor of a master mechanical contractor under the mechanical code of the city, the inspector of the city shall assign to the license a number which shall be recorded on the face of the license. The inspector shall keep a permanent record showing the number assigned as aforesaid, the name and address of the licensee and the date on which the number was assigned. The license shall retain the number so assigned until such time as the licensee fails to renew the license as provided by this Code. 
(Ord. No. 4086,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-555. - License fees. 
(a)  The fee for a license of an employing mechanical contractor and the subsequent renewal fee shall be on file in the city inspection department. The fee for a license for a master mechanical contractor and the subsequent renewal fee shall be on file in the city inspection department. In the event that a duly licensed master mechanical contractor is also an employing mechanical contractor, only a master mechanical contractor's license is required. The fee for a license for a journeyman mechanical and the fee for a license for a master mechanical shall be on file in the city inspection department. 
(b)  The State of Kansas requires 12 classroom hours of continuing education every two years or six classroom hours every year to renew each master or journeyman license. 
(c)  The City of Wellington is on a two-year renewal cycle on licenses and all licenses shall expire December 31st of each odd-number year. Copies of certificates on the classes attended must be provided at the time of license renewal. 
(d)  No mechanical contractor shall be granted a permit or allowed to do any work under any permit until the mechanical contractor has obtained or renewed the mechanical contractor's license for the current period. 
(e)  No license or fee shall be required of an apprentice mechanical contractor, but any person desiring to work at mechanical contracting as an apprentice mechanical contractor must register apprentice mechanical's name with the city inspection department and give the name of the master mechanical contractor under whom the apprentice mechanical contractor is working as an apprentice and the time of any apprenticeship shall be calculated from the date of such registration. 
(Ord. No. 4127,  1, 2, 12-18-2012) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4127,  1, 2, adopted Dec. 18, 2012, repealed former  8-555, and enacted a new  8-555 as set out herein. Former  8-555 pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 4086,  1, 2, adopted March 15, 2011. 
Sec. 8-556. - Liability insurance required. 
    The employing and master mechanical contractor will purchase and maintain such insurance as will protect him from claims under workers' compensation laws, disability benefit laws, or other similar employee benefit laws; from claims for damages because of bodily injury, occupational sickness or disease, or death of his employees, and claims insured by usual personal injury liability coverage; from claims for damages because of bodily injury, sickness or disease or death of any person other than his employees including claims insured by usual personal injury liability coverage; and from claims for injury to or destruction of property, including loss of use resulting therefrom; any or all of which may arise out of or result from the mechanical contractor's operations, whether such operations be by the mechanical contractor or by any subcontractor or anyone directly or indirectly employed by an of them or for those acts any of them may be legally liable. The insurance shall be written for not less than: 
(1)  $300,000.00 personal injury. 
(2)  $300,000.00 property damage. 
(3)  Workers' compensation (as required by law) shall include contractual liability insurance. Before starting the work, the mechanical contractor will file with the city, certificates of such insurance, acceptable to the city. These certificates shall contain a provision that the coverage afforded under these policies shall not be canceled or materially changed until at least 15 days prior written notice has been give to the city. 
(Ord. No. 4086,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-557. - Examinations. 
    The examination prepared and published by Thomson Prometric, 1260 Energy Lane, St. Paul, Minnesota 55108, shall be deemed a reasonable examination or any testing agency in conformance with K.S.A. 12-1541, testing the knowledge and skill of each applicant to do mechanical work, involving the installation, alteration, repair and maintenance of mechanical appliances, mechanical heating, ventilation and air conditioning systems. 
(1)  The city shall sponsor applicants for Thomson Prometric exams to be given at designated sites by Thomson Prometric. 
(2)  Upon request by applicant, the licensing official furnishes the applicant an application form to be completed and returned to the Building and Codes Department with the examination fee, which is on file in the city engineering/inspection department, and documentation of work-related experience. The fee is paid to the Building and Codes Department at the time the applicant applies for examination and shall be retained by the city whether or not the applicant passes the examination. 
(3)  The licensing Official will screen and approve the applicants to sit for an examination and furnish the applicant an "approved" Thomson Prometric examination registration form containing: 
a.  The licensing Official's signature, 
b.  The exam sponsor code; and 
c.  The exam code and exam name for which the applicant is to be tested. 
This form is accompanied by an instruction sheet explaining how the applicant is to fill in the form, and a list of examination schedule and test center codes. When executed, the examination registration form is sent by the applicant to Thomson Prometric indicating the exam location and date, and will be accompanied by a certified check for the appropriate examination fee. 
(4)  Upon receipt of the examination registration form and certified check, Thomson Prometric will send the applicant a letter of admission. This letter, along with a picture identification (driver's license, passport, etc.), must be presented at the exam site in order to gain entry. 
(5)  After the requested examination has been administered and graded by Thomson Prometric, the results will be sent to the Building and Codes Department for distribution to applicant. A score of 75 percent is required to pass the examination. Should the applicant not pass the examination, a request for a written review may be made to the licensing official. This type of review will not be prepared for applicants scoring less than 50 percent. 
(Ord. No. 4086,  1, 2, 3-15-2011; Ord. No. 4253,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-558. - Holders of mechanical contractor licenses from other cities. 
(a)  To secure a certificate of registration as a qualified and competent mechanical contractor in any of the classes set out in section 8-557, an application shall be made in writing and addressed to the city's board of examiners. The application shall show the applicant's name and address and such other information as may be prescribed by the board, and shall be made out on forms available at the city administration center. 
(b)  Any person who holds a certificate indicating that they have successfully passed an examination designated by K.S.A. 12-1541 or any amendments thereto, shall be entitled to receive the appropriate mechanical contractor's license of the city without additional examinations. Nothing herein contained shall be constructed to exempt mechanical contractors obtaining licenses from the city under this section from the provisions of ordinances of the city, the furnishing of insurance and the payment of license fees. 
(c)  Master and journeyman's mechanical contractor licenses issued by governmental units other than the city shall be recognized by the city if the governmental unit issuing the license and the city shall have entered into an agreement granting reciprocal privileges to the holders of a valid master or journeyman mechanical contractor's license issued by the city, and if the governmental unit issuing such licenses shall examine such licenses for the purpose of determining their qualifications to hold such licenses. 
(Ord. No. 4086,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-559. - Arbitration board. 
    The combined trades board shall act as an arbitration board in deciding any question that may arise between the inspector and any employing, master or journeyman mechanical contractor that is not covered by this article, and the decision of said board in such matters shall be final, unless an appeal is taken to the governing body of the city. 
(Ord. No. 4086,  1, 2, 3-15-2011; Ord. No. 4253,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-560. - Duty to show license and permit.
