    It shall be the duty of every person doing work as a mechanical contractor in the city to show the mechanical contractor's license, and city permit hereinafter provided for, to any inspector of mechanical systems, regular policeman or fireman who shall ask to see the same. No work done by any mechanical contractor without first having procured a permit therefore shall be inspected or approved by the inspector, but it shall be the duty of the inspector to report each and every case to the governing body and also the person for whom the work is being done. 
(Ord. No. 4086,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-561. - Suspension of licenses. 
    Bad faith, unreasonable delay or misrepresentation in the performance of mechanical work shall be deemed a sufficient reason for subjecting the mechanical contractor so offending to a suspension of the mechanical contractor's license and every mechanical contractor shall be held responsible for violations committed by laborers and help employed by the mechanical contractor. 
(Ord. No. 4086,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-562. - Permits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install, alter, repair, replace, or remodel any mechanical system unless a separate mechanical permit for each separate building or structure has first been obtained from the building official. 
(Ord. No. 4086,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-563. - Property owners' rights. 
(a)  Nothing herein contained shall prohibit any bona fide property owner, from personally installing any mechanical system within or upon such person's own property. Homeowners are permitted to build one (1) single-family dwelling every three (3) years under the provisions of this section. The owner shall file with the inspector approved plans and specifications to satisfy the inspector as to the owner's ability to install mechanical systems, secure a permit, pay required fees, do work in accordance with this article, and apply for an inspection and receive approval. 
(b)  Personal installation by an owner under these homeowner rights shall be by the owner, for the owner, on the owner's own property, without compensation, and no person shall be employed to assist him or her in any way on such work, except a registered mechanical contractor. 
(c)  Commercial kitchen hoods shall be installed by professional contractors. 
(d)  This does not apply to commercial installations of mechanical equipment. 
(Ord. No. 4086,  1, 2, 3-15-2011; Ord. No. 4253,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-564. - Fees for permits. 
    Fees for permits as provided in this article shall be on file in the Building and Codes Department. 
(Ord. No. 4086,  1, 2, 3-15-2011; Ord. No. 4253,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-565. - Truth in advertising requirements. 
    On or after April 1, 2011, any person, firm or corporation required by this article to obtain a mechanical license shall be subject to the following: 
(a)  It is unlawful for any such person, firm or corporation to advertise as a mechanical contractor unless at the time such advertisement occurs, such person, firm or corporation has a then valid mechanical contractor license issued under the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Any advertisement by such person, firm or corporation as a mechanical contractor which is placed or published in any publication or other print medium circulated, displayed or distributed within the city limits or which is broadcast by radio or television or any other means to persons within the city limits shall include the full name of the licensed person, firm or corporation. 
(c)  As used herein, the words "advertise" or "advertisement" shall mean and include, but not be limited to, a business card, contract bid proposal form, printed letterhead, any other printed or written material designed to inform persons of the services offered by the advertising person, firm or corporation and to solicit business from such persons. Such words are intended to include telephone directory display ads but not basic white and yellow page listings. 
(Ord. No. 4086,  1, 2, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 8-566. - Supplementary amendments to the Mechanical Code. 
A.  Clearances for Commercial Kitchen Type 1 Hoods and Grease Ducts. 
Section 506.3.11 Grease Duct Enclosures and Section 507.9 Clearances for Type 1 Hoods of the 2015 International Mechanical Code shall govern these installations for new construction. 
    Exception: 
For existing buildings of wood frame construction where pre-existing conditions make these installations impractical, the clearances shall be reduced from 18 inches to 3 inches for wood studs or joists with 5/8 inch Type X Gypsum board installed on the hood or grease duct side of the wood. 
(Ord. No. 4118,  I, 8-21-2012; Ord. No. 4253,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Secs. 8-567-8-591. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - BUILDING CONTRACTORS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- General building and residential contractors, K.S.A. 12-1556 et seq. 

Sec. 8-592. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Contractor means any person who contracts to perform work or service at a certain price or rate. The work of a contractor consists of but is not limited to building construction, repairs, alterations, additions, remodeling, or wrecking of any building or structure, or any portion thereof, concrete work, roofing, siding, erection or construction of pools and fences, within the city or which a permit is required. The definition pertains only to those persons which are in the business of construction and does not refer to individuals working under the supervision of the property owner. 
    License types . There is hereby created the following categories of licenses required by the city: 
    Class A general contractor license shall entitle the holder thereof to contract for and to perform any act as a contractor, as defined in this section, for building, remodeling or repairing of any structure or addition thereto that is permitted by this title with an unlimited valuation. A contractor of this classification must have a minimum of five years of construction related experience in commercial, industrial, and residential construction. In addition, a contractor of this classification must successfully pass an examination from a nationally recognized third party testing agency with a minimum score of 75 percent. 
    Class B building contractor license shall entitle the holder thereof to contract for and to perform any act as a contractor, as defined in this section, limited to the erection, addition to, remodeling and wrecking of commercial buildings and single and multiple dwelling residential buildings, not exceeding three stories in height, and non-structural remodels to commercial buildings exceeding three stories in height. A contractor of this classification must have a minimum of four years of construction related experience in commercial and residential construction. In addition, a contractor of this classification must successfully pass an examination from a nationally recognized third party testing agency with a minimum score of 75 percent. 
    Class C residential contractor license shall entitle the holder thereof to contract for and to perform any act as a contractor, as defined in this section, limited to construction, remodeling, repair or wrecking of one- and two-family residences, and building accessory thereto. A contractor of this classification must have a minimum of three years of construction related experience in residential construction. In addition, a contractor of this classification must successfully pass an examination from a nationally recognized third party testing agency with a minimum score of 75 percent. 
    Class D specialty building contractor shall entitle the holder thereof to contract for and to perform any act as a contractor, as defined in this section, limited to the remodel, repair and maintenance of dwelling units as defined by each category. A contractor of this classification must have a minimum of two years of construction related experience in residential construction. In addition, a contractor of this classification must successfully pass an examination from a nationally recognized third party testing agency with a minimum score of 75 percent. 
(Ord. No. 4105,  1, 3, 2-21-2012; Ord. No. 4254,  I, 3-5-2019) 
State Law reference- General building and residential contractors, K.S.A. 12-1556 et seq. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4105,  1, 3, adopted Feb. 21, 2012, repealed former  8-592, and enacted a new  8-592 as set out herein. Former  8-592 pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Code 1996,  4-107; Ord. No. 3679,  1 and Ord. No. 3902,  II, adopted Aug. 3, 2004. 
Sec. 8-593. - Contractor license required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any general contractor to engage in or work at the business of construction without first obtaining the proper license from the city. 
(b)  Nothing herein contained shall prohibit any bona fide property owner, from performing the work mentioned in subsection (a) of this section, on such person's own property. This does not include commercial buildings. Personal construction by an owner under these property owners' rights shall be for the owner and under the owner's supervision. A property owner shall only build one (1) single family home every three (3) years for their own personal use. 
(Code 1996,  4-108; Ord. No. 3679,  2; Ord. No. 4254,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-594. - Contractor's liability insurance. 
(a)  The contractor will purchase and maintain such insurance as will protect the contractor from claims under workmen's compensation laws, disability benefit laws or other similar employee benefit laws; from claims for damages because of bodily injury, occupational sickness or disease, or death of the contractor's employees, and claims insured by usual personal injury liability coverage; from claims for damages because of bodily injury, sickness or disease or death of any person other than the contractor's employees including claims insured by usual personal injury liability coverage; and from claims for injury to or destruction of property, including loss of use resulting therefrom, any or all of which may arise out of or result from the contractor's operations, whether such operations be by himself or by any subcontractor or anyone directly or indirectly employed by any of them or for those acts any of them may be legally liable. This insurance shall be written for not less than: 
Class A contractor's license $500,000.00 personal injury  500,000.00 property damage All other contractor class licenses  300,000.00 personal injury  300,000.00 property damage  
(b)  All contractors must provide workmen's compensation (as required by law) and shall include contractual liability insurance. Before starting the work, the contractor will file with the city certificates of such insurance, acceptable to the city; these certificates shall contain a provision that the coverage afforded under the policies shall not be cancelled or materially changed until at least 15 days' prior written notice has been given to the city. 
(Code 1996,  4-109; Ord. No. 3679,  3; Ord. No. 4012,  II, 3-18-2008) 
Sec. 8-595. - License fees. 
(a)  The initial license fee and subsequent renewal fee for a Class A general contractor license shall be on file in the city building department. The initial license fee and subsequent renewal fee for a Class B building contractor shall be on file in the city building department. The initial license fee and subsequent renewal fee for a Class C residential contractor shall be on file in the city building department. The initial license fee and subsequent renewal fee for a Class D specialty building contractor shall be on file in the city building department. 
(b)  The City of Wellington is on a two-year renewal cycle on licenses and all licenses shall expire December 31st of each odd-number year. 
(c)  No contractor shall be granted a permit or allowed to do any work under any permit until the contractor has obtained or renewed the contractor's license for the current period. 
(Ord. No. 4125,  1, 2, 12-18-2012; Ord. No. 4254,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4125,  1, 2, adopted Dec. 18, 2012, repealed former  8-595, and enacted a new  8-595 as set out herein. Former  8-595 pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Code 1996,  4-110; Ord. No. 3679,  4 and Ord. No. 4012,  III, adopted March 18, 2008. 
Sec. 8-596. - Duty to show license. 
    It shall be the duty of every person doing work as a builder/contractor in the city to show such person's license, and city permit hereinafter provided for, to any inspector or regular police officer who shall ask to see the same. No work done by any builder/contractor without first having procured a permit therefor shall be inspected or approved by the building inspector. 
(Code 1996,  4-111; Ord. No. 3679,  5; Ord. No. 4254,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-597. - Application. 
    Any person desiring to do work as a general building contractor must first file with the city an application for license. A written application for a license shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, business address and telephone number of the applicant. 
(2)  A complete and accurate description of the type and extent of work to be carried on under license. 
(3)  A statement that the applicant is familiar with and will follow the building codes adopted by the city and shall be filed in the office of the city clerk together with a nonrefundable fee shall be on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1996,  4-112; Ord. No. 3679,  6) 
Sec. 8-598. - Issuance. 
    Upon the approval of the application and the filing by the applicant of sufficient proof of issuance coverage as required in this article and meeting the requirements of this article, the city building department shall issue to the applicant a license permitting the licensee to perform in the city specific type and extent of work set forth in the license. The performance by the licensee of work not specified in the license shall be a violation of this article for which the license may be revoked and/or other penalties provided in this article imposed. 
    Before a license is issued to any applicant, the applicant shall have passed an approved third party competency examination for the classification of license applied for, with the exception of a landlord's license, with a passing score of 75 percent. Exams sponsored by the City of Wellington shall have a fee established by the city manager or city building official accompanying the license application. These examinations may be provided by one of the following exam providers or their successors: 
(1)  The International Code Council, 
(2)  Thompson Prometric (Pearson Vue), 
(3)  Or any exam provider approved by Kansas State Statutes. 
    All current licensees shall not be required to pass an examination to retain current license except upon the lapse of license after a 90-day period. 
(Ord. No. 4105,  2, 3, 2-21-2012; Ord. No. 4254,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4105,  2, 3, adopted Feb. 21, 2012, repealed former  8-598, and enacted a new  8-598 as set out herein. Former  8-598 pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Code 1996,  4-113 and Ord. No. 3679,  7. 
Sec. 8-599. - License; suspension; revocation; unlawful acts. 
(a)  The license of any contractor may be suspended temporarily for a period not to exceed 30 days by the city building official upon the city building official's own motion or upon a complaint of the city building inspector. Notice shall be given in writing to such contractor giving reasonable notice of a time of hearing before the combined trades board of the complaint on the matter alleged against such contractor involving any one or more of the following: 
(1)  Misrepresentation of a material fact by applicant in obtaining a license; 
(2)  Use of license to obtain a building permit for another; 
(3)  Failure or neglect to observe conditions of permit authorizing encumbering of streets or sidewalks of safety of public; 
(4)  Performance of any building or construction work without permit (where one is required by ordinance); and 
(5)  Willful disregard of a violation of the building and construction ordinances, or failure to comply with any lawful order of the city building official. 
(b)  Any licensee may appeal in writing to the city council, any order from the city building official and/or the combined trades board, that has suspended the licensee's license, for its final decision thereon. The council may upon such hearing terminate such suspension within not more than 30 days thereafter or may revoke such license. If any license shall be revoked, the contractor shall not be eligible for a new license during a period of six months thereafter. No fee shall be refunded in the event on suspension or revocation of any contractor's license. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to engage in the occupation or trade of contractor during the time any license of such contractor has been suspended or revoked. 
(Code 1996,  4-114; Ord. No. 3679,  8; Ord. No. 4254,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-600. - Penalty. 
    In addition to the provisions of section 8-599, any person violating any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be fined an amount not to exceed $500.00, and each day's violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 4012,  IV(4-115), 3-18-2008; Ord. No. 4254,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 8-601. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4105,  4, adopted Feb. 21, 2012, repealed  8-601, which pertained to reciprocation and derived from Ord. No. 4012,  IV(4-116), adopted March 18, 2008. 
Chapter 10 - BUSINESS LICENSES AND REGULATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Obstructing sidewalks. 
(a)  No person shall place, leave or allow to be left any implements, vehicles, tools, boxes of merchandise, trash cans, crates, corn poppers, peanut roasters, ice cream containers or other obstructions in any street, avenue or alley, sidewalk or other public place for a longer time that is necessary for the loading of the same. 
(b)  The city manager may authorize the use of public sidewalks, upon application of a majority of the merchants whose businesses are situated in the business district of the city, through a local trade promotional organization, in the business district for the purpose of displaying and selling goods, wares and merchandise on the following conditions: 
(1)  Each such sale shall be of only one day duration; 
(2)  No more than five such sales may be held each year; 
(3)  Display racks, stands, tables and other devices used in the sale shall be located so that there shall be an unobstructed area of the sidewalk not less than six feet wide next to the curbline of the sidewalk; 
(4)  The display devices shall be placed so that each merchant shall display the merchandise only within the area of the sidewalk which immediately abuts the merchant's place of business. 
(c)  Local service clubs and noncommercial organizations, after obtaining approval of the city manager, may use the public sidewalks and streets in the business district of the city for the purpose of displaying and selling goods, wares and merchandise for one period not exceeding three successive days each calendar year on such conditions as the city manager may fix and determine. 
(Code 1996,  5-101; Ord. No. 3465,  1) 
Sec. 10-2. - Business incentives; legislative declaration. 
    The governing body hereby finds and declares that within the city there exists a need to attract new businesses and commercial enterprises to the city and to assist existing businesses and commercial enterprises in the city that substantially expand or enlarge their businesses for the benefit and promotion of the general economic welfare and prosperity of said city and its residents. It is hereby further declared that in order to meet such need it is necessary to provide such new businesses and enterprises electric and power rates as provided in section 38-455. 
(Ord. No. 3852,  I, 10-15-2002) 
Secs. 10-3-10-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PEST CONTROL 

Sec. 10-23. - Purpose. 
    The licenses provided for herein are solely for the purpose of providing revenue to defray a part of the expenses of the city, and not for the purpose of regulation. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  5-201) 
Sec. 10-24. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business means and includes businesses, trades, occupations, professions and also callings, rendering or furnishing a service; provided further that the name of a business, trade, occupation, profession or calling may be used, and when so used, shall refer to the particular business, trade, occupation, profession or calling. 
    License means the documents issued by the city acknowledging payment of the required amount of tax, and stating the name of the licensee, the kind of business and where located, the period which the tax covers, such other matter as may be required and signed by the proper officer. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, corporation, firm, organization, association, joint stock company or syndicate who or which is engaged in any business, trade, occupation or profession, or rendering or furnishing any service for profit or livelihood and subject to the provisions of this article; provided that any individual in the direct employ of any person licensed under the provisions of this article is not a person unless such individual operates as a subcontractor; but if such individual performs any service or practices such individual's skill for compensation for any person other than the individual's licensed employer, the individual is a person and must pay the tax and obtain a license if such be required by the terms of this article. 
    Tax means an occupation tax or license fee for city revenue without regulations upon and for the privilege of engaging in business as herein defined. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  5-202) 
Sec. 10-25. - License required. 
(a)  No person shall conduct or pursue in the city any pest control business without first procuring from the city clerk a license therefor, and paying the city clerk the license fee as provided in section 10-27. 
(b)  Any person holding a current and valid pest control operation's license from the state, who shall conduct or pursue the business of a pest control operator, for the fields of operations licensed by the state, shall pay to the city a license tax for the privilege of engaging in the fields of operations licensed by the state. 
(Code 1996,  5-203; Ord. No. 3411,  1(h)) 
Sec. 10-26. - Insurance required. 
    Before any license for the business of a pest control operator shall be issued under the provisions of this article, the person engaged shall file with the city clerk an insurance policy wherein both the applicant and the city are the named insureds, providing liability insurance with a coverage of not less than $25,000.00 for injury or death to any one person and $50,000.00 for injury or death of any number of person in any one accident and with a coverage of at least $5,000.00 for property damage in any one accident, and such coverage shall be effective whether the accident shall be caused by the licensee or the licensee's agent or employees; such insurance policy shall contain all the conditions required by the laws of the state, and by the insurance commissioner of the state, and shall carry a uniform endorsement for actual notice to the city of any changes thereon; such policy and endorsement thereon shall be in a form approved by the city attorney, and such insurance policy shall further provide that it cannot be canceled until ten days' written notice shall have been filed with the city clerk. In the event said insurance policy shall be canceled or for any reason become ineffective, or the applicant's state license is revoked, or not renewed, the city shall cancel or refuse to renew the said license. 
(Code 1996,  5-203; Ord. No. 3411,  1(h)) 
Sec. 10-27. - Expiration; renewal; license fee. 
    Each pest control operator's annual license shall expire on June 30 following issuance and shall be renewable upon expiration by the applicant meeting the requirements of this article. The annual license fee shall be shall be on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1996,  5-203; Ord. No. 3411,  1(h)) 
Sec. 10-28. - City clerk to issue licenses; fee. 
    All licenses shall be issued by the city clerk upon payment of the proper sum to the city clerk as hereinbefore set forth. All licenses shall be signed by the mayor and city clerk and countersigned by the city treasurer. The city clerk shall affix the corporate seal of the city thereto. 
(Code 1974,  12-215; Code 1996,  5-205) 
Sec. 10-29. - Date and contents of licenses. 
    All licenses shall be dated on the day of their issue, and shall state the name of the licensee, the kind of business the licensee desires to engage in, the amount paid, and the time the license shall expire; and the person having such license shall be authorized to carry on the business therein named for the period stated unless such license is revoked. 
(Code 1974,  12-218; Code 1996,  5-208) 
Sec. 10-30. - License book. 
    The city clerk shall keep a book in which shall be entered the name of each and every person licensed, the licensee's address, the date of the license, the purpose for which it is granted, the amount paid therefor, and the time when the same shall expire. 
(Code 1974,  12-219; Code 1996,  5-209) 
Sec. 10-31. - Licenses not transferable; no refunds. 
    No license issued under the provisions of this article shall be transferable or assignable. There shall be no refunds. 
(Code 1974,  12-220; Code 1996,  5-210) 
Sec. 10-32. - Licenses to be carried and presented for inspection. 
    All persons doing business in a permanent location are hereby required to have their license conspicuously displayed in their place of business, and all persons to whom licenses are issued not having a permanent place of business are hereby required to carry their licenses with them and any licensee shall present the license for inspection when required to do so by any citizen or officer of the city. 
(Code 1974,  12-221; Code 1996,  5-211) 
Sec. 10-33. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall conduct or pursue in the city limits any trade, occupation or business for which a license is required by this article after a license should have been obtained to conduct or pursue such trade, occupation or business, without having obtained the same, shall be deemed to do so unlawfully. Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not less than $5.00 nor more than $100.00. Each day that any business, trade, occupation or profession is conducted without the license fee having been paid, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1974,  12-222; Code 1996,  5-212) 
Secs. 10-34-10-54. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS, TRANSIENT MERCHANTS 

Sec. 10-55. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Canvasser or solicitor means any individual, whether resident of the city or not, traveling either by foot, automobile, motor truck, or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, taking or attempting to take orders for sale of goods, wares and merchandise, personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery, or for services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such individual has, carries, or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale or whether such individual is collecting advance payments on such sales or not. Such definition includes any person, who, for such person, or for another person, hires, leases, uses, or occupies any building, structure, tent, railroad boxcar, boat, hotel room, lodginghouse, apartment, shop or any other place within the city for the sole purpose of exhibiting samples and taking orders for future delivery. 
    Peddler means any individual, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling by foot, wagon, automotive vehicle, or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, ice cream, milk products, meats, fish, vegetables, fruits, garden truck, farm products or provisions, offering and exposing the same for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers, or who, without traveling from place to place, shall sell or offer the same for sale from automotive vehicle, railroad boxcar or other vehicle or conveyance, and further provided that one who solicits orders and as a separate transaction makes deliveries to purchasers as a part of a scheme or design to evade the provisions of this article shall be deemed a peddler. 
    Residence means and includes every separate living unit occupied for residential purposes by one or more persons, contained within any type of building or structure. 
    Soliciting means and includes any one or more of the following activities: 
(1)  Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, services, of any kind, character or description whatever, for any kind of consideration whatever; 
(2)  Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase of insurance of any type, kind or character; or 
(3)  Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals, newspapers and every other type or kind of publication. 
    Street salesperson means any person engaged in any manner in selling merchandise of any kind from a wagon or stand temporarily located on the public streets or sidewalks of the city. 
    Transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor means any individual, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, whether a resident of the city or not, who engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares and merchandise within such city, and who, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad boxcar, or boat, public room in hotels, lodginghouses, apartments, shops or any street, alley or other place within the city, for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise, either privately or at public auction. Such definition shall not be construed to include any person who, while occupying such temporary location, does not sell from stock, but exhibits samples only for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery only. The person so engaged shall not be relieved from complying with the provisions of this article merely by reason of associating temporarily with any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer, or by conducting such transient business in connection with, as a part of, or in the name of any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer. 
(Ord. No. 3431,  1; Code 1996,  5-301) 
Sec. 10-56. - License required. 
    No individual shall engage in the activities as defined in section 10-55 within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining a license. Any applicant for a license under this article shall file with the city clerk a sworn application on a form furnished by the city clerk, which shall give the following information or require the submittal of the following documents: 
(1)  Name and date of birth of applicant. 
(2)  State sales tax number. 
(3)  Credentials from the person whom the applicant is employed by or represents. 
(4)  Current photographic government identification of the applicant. 
(5)  Period of time for which the certificate and license is applied. 
(6)  Address of the applicant's present place of residence. 
(7)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold. 
(8)  Location and zoning of any temporary facility, structure, building or vehicle. 
(9)  Whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude or any felony conviction. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  5-302) 
Sec. 10-57. - Issuance of license. 
    Upon receipt of an application for a license, the city clerk shall issue a license. Such license shall contain the signature and seal of the issuing officer and shall show the name and address of the licensee, the date of issuance and length of time the license shall be operative, and the nature of the business involved. The city clerk shall keep a permanent record of all such licenses issued and submit a copy of such license to the chief of police. The solicitor shall carry the license with the solicitor at all times. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  5-303) 
Sec. 10-58. - License fee; exemptions. 
(a)  The fee for the license required pursuant to section 10-56 shall be on file in the city clerk's office. 
(b)  No license fee shall be required of businesses located with the city limits that have maintained a physical address for public access for at least three consecutive years; producers and growers, or their agents or employees engaged in the sale of farm, or garden products, or fruits grown within this state; any businesses, trades or occupations which are part of fairs or celebrations sponsored by the city or any other governmental subdivision, or the state, or when part of all the expenses of said fairs or celebrations are paid for by the city, any other governmental subdivision, or the state. 
(Code 1996,  5-304; Ord. No. 3392,  1; Ord. No. 3897,  1, 7-20-2004) 
State Law reference- Exemption from fee for any producer, grower or agent or employee for agricultural or aquacultural products grown in the state, K.S.A. 12-1617. 
Sec. 10-59. - Revocation of license. 
(a)  The chief of police may revoke any license issued under this article, for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license. 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on the business. 
(3)  Any violation of this article. 
(4)  Conducting the businesses in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the city. 
Notice of the revocation of a license shall be in writing to the applicant and the city clerk and set forth the grounds of revocation. 
(b)  Any person aggrieved by the action of the chief of police or city clerk in the denial of an application or revocation of a license as provided in this article, shall have the right of appeal to the governing body. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the city clerk within 14 days after notice of revocation or denial of the license has been mailed to such applicant's last known address setting forth the grounds for appeal. The governing body shall set a time and place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of such hearing shall be given to the applicant in the same manner as provided herein for notice of hearing on revocation. The decision and order of the governing body on such appeal shall be final and conclusive. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  5-305) 
Sec. 10-60. - Use of street. 
    No peddler shall have any exclusive right to any location in the public streets, nor shall a peddler be permitted a stationary location, nor shall a peddler be permitted to operate in any congested area where the peddler's operations might impede or inconvenience the public. For the purpose of this article, the judgment of a police officer, exercised in good faith, shall be deemed conclusive as to whether the area is congested or the public impeded or inconvenienced. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  5-307) 
Sec. 10-61. - Enforcement of this article. 
    It shall be the duty of any police officer to require any person engaged in the activities as defined in this article, who is not known by such officer to be duly licensed, to produce such person's license and to enforce the provisions of this article against any person found to be violating the same. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  5-308) 
Secs. 10-62-10-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DRILLING OF OIL OR GAS WELLS 

Sec. 10-81. - Permit. 
    No person shall commence the drilling of a well for oil or gas within the city limits, without first having procured from the city a permit therefor to be issued by authority of the governing body in accordance with the terms and conditions of this article. 
(Code 1974,  12-301; Code 1996,  5-401) 
Sec. 10-82. - File application; city clerk. 
    Before any permit shall be granted for the commencement of a well for the production of oil or gas, an application therefor shall be filed with the city clerk. Such application shall show: 
(1)  That the applicant has good and valid oil and gas leases from property owners covering at least a ten-acre tract. 
(2)  Evidence of agreement in writing between the lessee, and the lessors, if more than one, providing for a pooling of all royalties arising from production on the tract, to be distributed to the property owners in accordance with the number of acres of each owner in the tract. 
(3)  The application shall be accompanied by a plat or map of such tract showing the proposed location of the well, which location shall in no instance be closer than 300 feet of any boundary line of the tract, unless by the unanimous vote of the governing body, but not upon any street or alley; such map shall show the location of each residence upon the tract and all improvements. 
(4)  A drilling agreement providing adequate protection to the parties in interest, by enclosing the drilling rig on all sides, equipping same with adequate fire extinguishers, which are to be kept in good order, including a reasonable and adequate plan for the handling of the slush, basis sediment, and salt water that may be produced in the drilling of the well; and facilities for handling production to the end that it may not be necessary to store oil on said area in excess of 500 barrels per well; such agreement shall make further provision that in the event the well is a dry hole, or nonproductive of either oil or gas, all materials, equipment, tools, and machinery of every kind and character shall be removed therefrom within 60 days and the premises fully restored to their original condition as nearly as practicable. 
(Code 1974,  12-302; Code 1996,  5-402) 
Sec. 10-83. - Applicant bonded. 
    A good and sufficient surety bond signed by the applicant and by a corporate surety authorized to do business in the state, or a cash deposit in such amount as deemed sufficient by the governing body, but in no event less than $2,500.00 shall be tendered to the governing body and approved by the city clerk prior to the issuance of a permit pursuant to the terms of this article, conditioned upon faithful compliance with the terms and conditions hereof and any amendments hereto, and further conditioned upon saving and holding the city free and harmless from any damage resulting to the city as a result of drilling, pumping, repair or other operations by the permittee, the laying of pipelines, the setting of tanks or as a result of the moving of machinery and equipment over any street of the city. The permittee or the permittee's assignee shall pay the annual premium due upon said surety bond before the annual maturity thereof and shall file a receipt therefor in the office of the city clerk. The permittee shall carry and maintain public liability insurance on each well or group of wells and upon the vehicular equipment used in connection therewith indemnifying payment of not less than $25,000.00 for injury or death of any one person and not less than $50,000.00 aggregate for any one accident and not less than $25,000.00 property damage for any one accident and file good and sufficient proof thereof and proof of the payment of the renewal of premiums thereon with the city clerk. Default by permittee in complying with any provision of this article; or any amendments hereto, that the governing body may revoke any such permit after five days' notice to permittee by registered mail and thereupon permittee shall cease and desist from all operations under and pursuant to any such permit. 
(Code 1974,  12-303; Code 1996,  5-403) 
Sec. 10-84. - Application fee. 
    The application, as provided in this article, shall be filed with the city clerk and a fee therefor on file in the city clerk's office shall be required. Upon the filing of the application, the same shall be considered by the governing body and if the governing body shall deem such application adequate and the drilling of the well not injurious to public or private property, the same shall be granted. If a permit is denied, the filing fee shall be refunded to the applicant. 
(Code 1974,  12-304; Code 1996,  5-404) 
Sec. 10-85. - Refusal of application. 
    The governing body shall have the power and reserves the authority to refuse any application for a permit whereby reason of the proposed application for the proposed well, and character and value of the permanent improvements already erected on the tract applied for, or adjacent thereto, and the uses to which the land and surroundings are adopted, for civic purposes or for sanitary reason, the drilling of a gas or oil well, will be a serious disadvantage to the city and its inhabitants as a whole. When a permit shall be refused, for any of these reasons, but not otherwise, the deposit or cash paid with the application shall be returned to the applicant. Except as provided in this article, if an application be found by the governing body to comply in all respects with this article, the city clerk shall be authorized to issue a permit for the drilling of the well provided for, and the permit shall specify the particular location of the well to be drilled and it shall be unlawful for the permittee to drill elsewhere in the tract. 
(Code 1974,  12-305; Code 1996,  5-405) 
Sec. 10-86. - Requirements of operation. 
    In operating under any permit issued under this article or any amendment thereto, all oil, gas and water produced or arising from the operations shall be piped or otherwise conveyed or removed from the limits of the city except the ordinary use of a slush pond and the temporary storage of not to exceed 500 barrels of oil for each well; and all excavations and slush ponds shall be completely enclosed with six feet woven wire fence. That the laying of any pipe lines by any permittee shall be done under the supervision of the city engineer. 
(Code 1974,  12-306; Code 1996,  5-406) 
Sec. 10-87. - Premises to be restored. 
    It shall be the duty of every person to whom a permit may be issued, as provided in this article, after the well has been drilled in the event, the same is a dry hole or abandoned, to remove the derrick, drilling tools, equipment and machinery from the location of the well and to restore the premises to their original condition as nearly as it is practical so to do, and to see that the well is properly plugged. In the event oil or gas is produced from such well, then it shall be the duty of the holder of the permit upon the completion of the drilling of the well to remove all machinery, equipment and material not necessary to be retained for use in the production of the oil or gas from such well, and insofar as can be done, consistent with the production from such well to restore the premises to their original condition as nearly as practical. All of which, either in the event of a dry hole or a producing well, shall be done within 60 days after the completion of the drilling of the well. 
(Code 1974,  12-307; Code 1996,  5-407) 
Sec. 10-88. - Permission to drill. 
    No permit shall be granted, or issued for the drilling of a well except upon ground held by the applicant under oil and gas mining lease, grant or drilling contract from the owner giving the owners permission to drill the well; and when a permit shall have been issued, the same shall terminate and become inoperative without any action on the part of the governing body, unless within 60 days from the date of issue of such permit actual drilling of the well shall have been commenced and after the drilling of a well shall have commenced, the cessation for a like period of the drilling operations shall cancel the permit, and the well shall be considered as abandoned for all purposes of this article and it shall be unlawful thereafter to continue drilling of such well without the issuance of another permit. Neither this article, nor any permit issued hereunder, shall be interpreted to grant any right or license to permittee to enter upon or occupy in any respect in the drilling or production operations, any land except by the written consent of the owner; nor shall it limit or prevent the free right of any landowner to contract for the amount of royalty to be paid with respect to the landowner's own land. 
(Code 1974,  12-308; Code 1996,  5-408) 
Sec. 10-89. - Duration of permit. 
    No permit which shall be issued under this article or under any amendment hereto, or any rights, privileges or franchise granted hereby or hereunder, shall exist longer than for a period of ten years from the date of the issuance of the permit or as long thereafter as oil and/or gas is produced from the tract. 
(Code 1974,  12-309; Code 1996,  5-409) 
Sec. 10-90. - Penalty. 
    Any violation of any of the terms of this article, whether herein denominated as unlawful or not, shall be deemed a misdemeanor, and any person convicted of any such violation shall be fined in a sum not exceeding $500.00 and any person so convicted shall be committed to jail until such fine and costs are paid. Each day of the continuance of any such violation shall be considered a separate offense and any person, agent or employee engaged in any such violation shall on conviction be so punished therefor. 
(Code 1974,  12-310; Code 1996,  5-410) 
Secs. 10-91-10-108. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - TAXICABS 

Sec. 10-109. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate on any of the streets, avenues, alleys or public places in the city, any automobile or other vehicle used for the transportation of persons for hire without first obtaining a license for each automobile or other vehicle in the manner and form herein prescribed and complying with all of the provisions of this article and other laws of the city relating to the operation of such vehicles for hire for the transportation of persons. This article shall not apply to motor carriers duly licensed by the state corporation commission or other authorized regulatory body of the state, which motor carriers are required by the state to carry insurance. 
(Code 1974,  22-101; Code 1996,  5-501) 
Sec. 10-110. - Application for license; contents. 
    Any person desiring to secure such license from the city for the carrying of passengers for hire within the city shall file an application in writing with the city clerk for such license, which application shall be made by the person owning the automobile or other vehicle, and the application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Full name and address of owner of the vehicle to be licensed; 
(2)  Engine number and license tag number of the state, and a complete description of the motor vehicle; 
(3)  Principal place of business and address from which the motor vehicle is proposed to be operated; 
(4)  The name and address of the chauffeurs or person who shall actually operate or drive the vehicle, and such person shall not be less than 21 years of age. Two or more persons may be named as the operators of the vehicle. The city manager or the city manager's designee must be satisfied that the persons named as operators of the motor vehicles are careful and competent operators or drivers; 
(5)  Such other information as may be required by the governing body. 
(Code 1974,  22-102; Code 1996,  5-502) 
Sec. 10-111. - Public convenience and necessity; heariessity; hearing of application. 
    Upon the receipt of the application, the governing body shall hold a hearing thereon, and if the governing body finds that public convenience and necessity requires the licensing and operation of the taxicab (in addition to such other taxicabs as may, at the time, be operating under licenses issued by the city), and if it deems the applicant therefor to be of good moral character and financially able to provide the service the public requires, and that the applicant or any person employed by the applicant will operate the taxicab for which a license is desired properly and for the best interest and convenience of the public, and that the applicant will conform to and obey the laws of the city relative to the operation of taxicabs and all other laws of the city, and all laws of the state, the governing body shall by resolution approve such application. The governing body shall not approve or have in effect at any one time licenses for taxicabs in a number in excess of the number which the governing body may reasonably deem necessary for the best interests and convenience of the inhabitants of the city or the general public, or in such number that the owners and operators of the licensed taxicabs and the employees of such owners or operators might, in the opinion of the governing body, be apt to engage in practices which would be detrimental to the best interests of the city and the city's inhabitants and the general public. The governing body shall reject and deny any application in the event it considers the granting of the license would increase the number of taxicabs licensed to operate in the city beyond the number reasonably necessary for the best interest and convenience of the inhabitants of the city and the general public, and/or for any other reason the governing body deems that the granting of such license would be detrimental to the public interest and welfare. 
(Code 1974,  22-103; Code 1996,  5-503) 
Sec. 10-112. - Insurance. 
    Before any license for a taxicab or vehicle carrying passengers for hire within the corporate limits of the city shall be issued under the provisions of this article, the owner or operator thereof shall file with the city clerk an insurance policy approved by the city attorney providing insurance coverage for each and every taxicab or vehicle carrying passengers for hire, owned, operated or leased by such person, with a liability coverage of not less than $50,000.00 for injury or death to any one person and $100,000.00 for the injury or death of any number of persons in any one accident, and with coverage of at least $20,000.00 for property damage in any one accident, and such insurance coverage shall be effective whether the taxicab or vehicle is, at the time of any accident, being driven by the owner, the owner's agent, lessee or licensee; such insurance policy shall contain all the conditions required by the laws of the state, and by the insurance commissioner of the state, and shall carry a uniform endorsement for actual notice to the city of any changes thereon; the policy and endorsement thereon shall be in a form approved by the city attorney, and the insurance policy shall further provide that it cannot be canceled until ten days' written notice shall have been filed with the city clerk. In the event the insurance policy shall be canceled or for any reason become ineffective, the governing body shall cancel the license, or in the event the licensee or any of the licensee's agents or employees operating the motor vehicle may be convicted of a crime or a misdemeanor under the laws of the state or the laws of the city, the governing body of the city may cancel the license. 
(Code 1974,  22-104; Code 1983; Code 1996,  5-504) 
Sec. 10-113. - License to be issued. 
    Upon the adoption of a resolution by the governing body approving the application, as provided in section 10-111, and the filing of the insurance policy as herein provided, and paying the license fee on file in the city clerk's office for each vehicle or taxicab to be used by the applicant, the city clerk shall issue a license to the applicant for a term of one year, commencing on January 1 and terminating on December 31 of each year, and such license may be transferred from one vehicle to another owned by the same person. The number of taxicabs or vehicles owned or operated by the same person at any one time shall not exceed the number of licenses applied and paid for. Upon the substitution or change of motor vehicles by the licensee, the insurance policy shall be endorsed so as to cover the operation of the substituted vehicle. 
(Code 1974,  22-105; Code 1996,  5-505) 
Sec. 10-114. - License may be revoked. 
    Any owner or operator of any taxicab or vehicle operated for hire over the streets, alleys and public places of the city shall keep and maintain each and all motor vehicles in safe and suitable mechanical condition for taxicab service, and upon failure to do so, the governing body may revoke the license as to any unsafe or unsuitable vehicle. 
(Code 1974,  22-106; Code 1996,  5-506) 
Sec. 10-115. - Penalty. 
    Any person convicted of violating any provision of this article shall be punished by a fine which shall be on file in the city clerk's office. The conviction of any such person of violating any of the provisions of this article shall work an immediate revocation of such person's license. 
(Code 1974,  22-107; Code 1996,  5-507) 
Secs. 10-116-10-142. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - GARAGE SALES 

Sec. 10-143. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Garage sale means any sale operated out of a single-family dwelling, or a two-family dwelling, or a multiple-family dwelling being of two hours or more duration. 
    Goods includes any goods, wares, merchandise or any other property capable of being the object of a sale regulated hereunder. 
    Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
(Code 1974,  12-501; Code 1996,  5-701) 
Sec. 10-144. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a public offense and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in a sum not exceeding $100.00 or sentenced to 30 days in jail, or both. 
(Code 1974,  12-506; Code 1996,  5-705) 
Sec. 10-145. - Frequency of sales. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hold more than two garage sales at the same location within a calendar year. 
(Code 1996,  5-702; Ord. No. 3193,  1) 
Sec. 10-146. - Length of sales. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a garage sale lasting longer than three consecutive days. 
(Code 1974,  12-503; Code 1996,  5-703) 
Sec. 10-147. - Advertising signs. 
    No signs advertising the sale or giving directions to its location shall be used, erected or allowed, except one sign shall be allowed in the front yard of the sale location during the time of the sale. 
(Code 1974,  12-504; Code 1996,  5-704) 
Secs. 10-148-10-179. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - TREE TRIMMING 

Sec. 10-180. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of cutting, trimming, pruning, removing, disposing of, spraying, treating or otherwise caring for trees within the city without first making application for and obtaining a license therefor from the office of the city clerk; provided, however, that nothing herein contained shall be construed so as to prohibit owners or occupants of premises within the city from performing the foregoing activities on premises so owned or occupied. 
(Code 1996,  5-801; Ord. No. 3594,  1) 
Sec. 10-181. - Application. 
    A written application for a license shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, business address and telephone number of the applicant. 
(2)  A complete and accurate description of the type and extent of work to be carried on under such license. 
(3)  A statement that the applicant is in full compliance with all laws of the state relating to pest control, if pest control operations are to be licensed; and shall be filed in the office of the city clerk together with a nonrefundable fee of $25.00. 
(Code 1996,  5-802; Ord. No. 3594,  2) 
Sec. 10-182. - Issuance. 
    Upon the approval of the application and the filing by the applicant of sufficient proof of insurance coverage as required in this article together with a surety bond meeting the requirements of this article in the office of the city clerk, the city clerk shall issue to the applicant a license permitting the licensee to perform in the city the specific type and extent of work set forth in the license. The performance by the licensee of work not specified in the license shall be a violation of this article for which the license may be revoked and/or other penalties provided in this article imposed. 
(Code 1996,  5-803; Ord. No. 3594,  3) 
Sec. 10-183. - Bond and insurance. 
    Before any license is issued or renewed under the provision of this article there shall be filed in the office of the city: 
(1)  A certificate of insurance in a form satisfactory to the city clerk showing that the city is an additional named insured and that the applicant is insured by a company authorized to do business in the state and having a current Best's Insurance Guide Rating of B and Class VII or better for public liability in the amount of not less than $300,000.00 for personal injury and property damage. 
(2)  A surety bond of a company authorized to do business in the state and approved by the city in the amount of $5,000.00 in which the city is the named obligee, the applicant is the principal and the surety company is named obligor conditioned upon the compliance by the principal, the principal's agents, servants and employees with the provisions this article and the laws of the state pertaining to the work permitted by the license issued. The policy of liability insurance shall specifically provide that the policy may not be cancelled before the 11th day after written notice of such cancellation has been delivered to the city, and the insurer shall agree to deliver such written notice to the city at least ten days prior to the cancellation of such policy. 
(Code 1996,  5-804; Ord. No. 3594,  4) 
Sec. 10-184. - Termination. 
    Any license issued hereunder shall terminate: 
(1)  On December 31 of the year in which the license is issued; or 
(2)  Upon the cancellation of the insurance policy or the surety bond required by this article within the term for which such license is issued. 
(Code 1996,  5-805; Ord. No. 3594,  5) 
Sec. 10-185. - License revoked; hearing. 
(a)  Any license issued hereunder may be revoked 15 days after written notice of the city's intent to revoke the license is mailed to the licensee at the licensee's last known post office address if the licensee or the licensee's employees or agents: 
(1)  Has made any false statement or furnished false information in obtaining a license hereunder; 
(2)  Has made any false or misleading statement with the intention of defrauding the public; 
(3)  Has used in the licensee's operations any substance in a manner that is harmful to the health, safety and welfare of the public; 
(4)  Has violated any provision of this article or any law of the state pertaining to the operations carried on by the licensee under the license issued hereunder. 
(b)  Any licensee to whom a written notice of the city's intention to revoke such license has been mailed shall be entitled to a hearing before the governing body of the city, if a written request for such hearing is filed in the office of the city clerk within 15 days the written notice of intended revocation is postmarked. 
(Code 1996,  5-806; Ord. No. 3594,  6) 
Sec. 10-186. - Changes; fee. 
    Licenses issued under the provisions of this article shall not be transferable, and any change in the business status of the licensee or in the ownership of the licensee's business shall require the filing of a new application with new insurance and bond coverage and the payment of another nonrefundable license fee of $25.00. 
(Code 1996,  5-807; Ord. No. 3594,  7) 
Sec. 10-187. - Identification of vehicles. 
    All automobiles, trucks, trailers and other vehicles used by the licensee for the transportation of equipment used by such licensee in the business for which such licensee is licensed hereunder shall have the name and address of the license displayed on both sides thereof in plain, legible letters and figures not less than three inches in height and the same shall be kept in such a condition as to permit the same to be easily distinguished and read. 
(Code 1996,  5-808; Ord. No. 3594,  8) 
Sec. 10-188. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating a provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine which shall be on file in the city clerk's office, or by imprisonment of not more than 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each day that any such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1996,  5-809; Ord. No. 3594,  9) 
Chapter 12 - ELECTIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Candidacy for city office. 
    In accordance with K.S.A. 25-205, and amendments thereto, any person may become a candidate for city office election at large, by having filed on their behalf, a nomination petition or a declaration of candidacy, accompanied by any fee required by law. The nomination petition must be signed by 50 of the qualified electors of the City of Wellington. 
(Ord. No. 4202,  I, 12-20-2016) 
Secs. 12-2-12-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - VOTING[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter Ordinance reference- Precincts, Charter Ordinance Number 12 as amended by Charter Ordinance Number 22. 

Sec. 12-19. - Hours of voting. 
    The hours of voting at all general elections, primary elections, city elections and special elections within the city shall be from 7:00 a.m. in the morning until 7:00 p.m. in the evening. 
(Code 1974, 7-101; Code 1996,  6-101) 
State Law reference- Hours of voting, K.S.A. 25-106. 
Secs. 12-20-12-41. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PRECINCTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter Ordinance reference- Precinct boundaries established and may be amended by ordinance, Charter Ordinance Number 12 as amended by Charter Ordinance Number 22. 

Sec. 12-42. - Precinct boundaries. 
    There is hereby adopted as official precincts of the city, those precincts established by the county election officer pursuant to K.S.A. 25-26ao5(a) whose boundaries are described verbatim as follows: 
(1)  First ward. 
a.  First precinct. Beginning at a point of C Street and Highway 160, north to Adams and Madison, southwest to Vandenburgh, north following railroad to corporate limits which are bounded on the north and east. South boundary is west on Highway 160 a.k.a. 16th Street to C Street, which is point of beginning. 
b.  Second precinct is bounded on the west by G Street. Bounded on the south by 10th Street and bounded on the east by C Street, Adams and Madison Streets, then following Vandenburgh southwest to the point of beginning. 
(2)  Second ward. 
a.  First precinct begins at the corner of C Street and Harvey Street, east to the west road of Cemetery, south to Lincoln Street, east to Arthur Street, south to corporate limits, then east and north along corporate limits to Highway 160, west on Highway 160 to C Street, then south to point of beginning. 
b.  Second precinct is bounded on the west by C Street, south to Botkin. It is bounded on the south and east by the corporation limits to Arthur Street, north to Lincoln Street, west to west road of Cemetery, north to Harvey Street, west on Harvey to point of beginning. 
(3)  Third ward. 
a.  First precinct is bounded on the north by 10th Street. The east boundary is C Street to Botkin Street, east to Santa Fe tracks, south following the corporate limits, north following corporation limits, east on Botkin Street to G Street, then north to point of beginning. 
b.  Second precinct. Point of beginning is G and Highway 160 a.k.a. 8th Street. West on Highway 160 to the corporate limits. Following west and south to Botkin, east on Botkin to G Street, then north to the point of beginning. 
(4)  Fourth ward. 
a.  First precinct. Point of beginning is Highway 160 and G Street, west on Highway 160 to Plum Street, north on Plum Street to 22nd Street, east on 22nd Street to H Street, north on H Street to corporate limits. Corporate limits east to railroad tracks, south on tracks to G Street, continuing south to point of beginning. 
b.  Second precinct is beginning at a point on Highway 160 and Plum Street, north on Plum east on 22nd Street to H Street, north on H Street to corporate limits. Precinct is bounded on the north and west by corporate limits to Highway 160, east on Highway 160 to point of beginning. 
(Code 1996,  6-301; Ord. No. 3542,  1) 
Chapter 16 - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4082,  1-3, adopted March 15, 2011, repealed former Ch. 16,  16-19-16-155, and enacted a new Ch. 16 as set out herein. Former Ch. 16 pertained to environment and derived from Code 1987; Code 1990; Code 1996,  8-201-8-211, 8-301-8-314, 8-701, 8-801-8-803; Ord. No. 3584,  1-3; Ord. No. 3726,  1, 2; Ord. No. 3754,  I-VIII, adopted Feb. 4, 1997; Ord. No. 3840,  I, adopted March 5, 2002 and Ord. No. 3841,  I, adopted March 5, 2002. 

Sec. 16-1. - Adoption of the 2009 International Property Maintenance Code. 
    The 2009 International Property Maintenance Code (the "IPMC"), including its Appendix A: Boarding Standard, a uniform code prepared by the International Code Council, Inc., 500 New Jersey Ave., NW, 6th floor, Washington, DC, 20001, is hereby adopted by reference and incorporated as an ordinance of the City of Wellington, Kansas, except as specific provisions thereof are hereby amended or repealed. One or more copies of the IPMC shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy," with all deleted or amended sections or portions thereof clearly marked to show such modification, and to which shall be attached a copy of this ordinance. Such copy or copies shall be filed with the City Clerk and shall be open and available for public inspection at all reasonable hours. 
(Ord. No. 4082,  1, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 16-2. - Amendments. 
    The following sections of the IPMC are hereby subject to all amendments, insertions, deletions, or changes as hereinafter set forth: 
A.  Section 101.1 Insert: "City of Wellington, Kansas". 
B.  Section 102.3 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
102.3 Application of other codes. Repairs, additions or alterations to a structure, or changes of occupancy, shall be done in accordance with the procedures and provisions of the International Building Code, International Fuel Gas Code, International Mechanical Code and NFPA 70. Nothing in this code shall be construed to cancel, modify or set aside any provision of the zoning code of the City of Wellington, Kansas. 
C.  Section 103 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
SECTION 103 ADMINISTRATION 
103.1 Designation. The City Manager shall designate the code officer to exercise the powers of this code and shall be hereinafter referred to as the code officer in this code. 1 [] 
103.2 Fees. The fees for activities and services performed by the department in carrying out its responsibilities under this code shall be as indicated in the fee schedule (Table 1). 
D.  Section 107.1 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
107.1 Notice to person responsible. Whenever the code official determines that there has been a violation of this code or has grounds to believe that a violation has occurred, notice shall be given in the manner prescribed in Sections 107.2 and 107.3 to the person responsible for the violation as specified in this code. Notices for condemnation procedures shall also comply with Section 108.3. 
107.1.1 Annual notice procedure for weed violations. Notices for weed violations shall be given once per calendar year, in the manner prescribed in Sections 107.2 and 107.3, and shall also be published in the official city newspaper one time per calendar year. Such notice shall also include a statement that no further notice shall be given prior to removal of weeds. In the event of a subsequent transfer of ownership, a copy of any standing notice shall be provided to the new owner as prescribed in Section 107.6 and shall serve as notice given in the manner prescribed in this section to the new owner. 2 [] 
E.  Section 107.2 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
107.2 Form. Such notice prescribed in Section 107.1 shall be in accordance with all of the following: 
1.  Be in writing. 
2.  Include a description of the real estate sufficient for identification. 
3.  Include a statement of the violation or violations and why the notice is being issued. 
4.  Include a correction order allowing a reasonable time, not to exceed ten (10) days 3 [], to make the repairs and improvements required to bring the dwelling unit or structure into compliance with the provisions of this code. 
5.  Inform the property owner of the right to request a hearing with the governing body. 
6.  Include a statement of the right to file a lien in accordance with Section 106.3. 
F.  Section 107.3 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
107.3 Method of service. Such notice shall be deemed to be properly served if a copy thereof is: 
1.  Delivered personally; 
2.  Sent by certified mail, return receipt requested to the last known address; or 
3.  If a notice of violation is returned showing that the letter was not delivered during the preceding twenty-four month period, notice may be provided by such methods including, but not limited to, door hangers, conspicuously posting notice of such order on the property, personal notification, telephone communication or first class mail. 4 [] 
G.  Section 108.3 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
108.3 Notice. Whenever the code official has condemned a structure or equipment under the provisions of this section, the code official shall file with the governing body a statement in writing that a premise contains unsafe structures or equipment. The governing body shall by resolution fix a time and place at which the owner, the owner's agent, any lienholder of records, and any occupant may appear and show cause why the structures or equipment should not be condemned and ordered repaired or demolished. Such resolution shall be published in the official city newspaper once each week for two consecutive weeks, on the same day of each week. At least thirty days shall elapse between the last publication and the date set for the hearing. A copy of the resolution shall be mailed by restricted mail within three days after the first publication to each such owner, agent, lienholder of record, and occupant, at the last known address. 
108.3.1 Hearing. At the time and place fixed for the hearing, or any adjournment thereof, the governing body shall hear all evidence submitted by the code official, the owner, agent, lienholder, and occupants. If the governing body determines the structures or equipment to be unsafe, resolution fixing a reasonable time within which repair or removal shall be commenced and the premises made safe shall be passed. If repair, alteration or improvement of a structure or equipment cannot be made at a cost of 50 percent or less than its value, the structure or equipment shall be demolished or removed. Such resolution shall be published in the official city newspaper once and an official copy of the resolution shall be mailed by restricted mail within three days after the publication to each such owner, agent, lienholder of record, and occupant, at the last known address. 5 [] 
H.  Section 110.2 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
110.2 Notices and orders. All notices and orders shall comply with Section 108.3 and 108.3.1, as amended. 
I.  Section 111 is hereby deleted in its entirety. 
J.  Section 112.4 Insert: 100.00, Insert: 500.00. 
K.  Section 201.3 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
201.3 Terms defined in other codes. Where terms are not defined in this code and are defined in the International Building Code, International Fire Code, International Plumbing Code, International Mechanical Code, NFPA 70 or the zoning code of the City of Wellington, Kansas, such terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them as stated in those codes. 
L.  Section 302.4 Weeds. All premises and exterior property shall be maintained free from weeds and plant growth in excess of twelve (12) inches. All noxious weeds including, but not limited to noxious weeds listed in Table 2, shall be prohibited. Weeds shall be defined as all grasses, annual plants and vegetation, other than trees or shrubs provided; however, this term shall not include cultivated flowers and gardens. 
Upon failure of the owner or agent having charge of the property to cut and destroy weeds after service of a notice of violation, they shall be subject to prosecution in accordance with Section 106.3 and as prescribed by the authority having jurisdiction. Upon failure to comply with the notice of violation, any duly authorized employee of the jurisdiction or contractor hired by the jurisdiction shall be authorized to enter upon the property in violation and cut and destroy the weeds growing thereon, and the costs of such removal shall be paid by the owner or agent responsible for the property. Cost is due and payable within thirty days following receipt of notice. If the costs remains unpaid after the thirty day period, the cost may be levied as a special assessment against the premises. Fees incurred by the city will be assessed pursuant to Table 1. 6, 7 [] 
M.  Section 302.8 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
302.8 Motor vehicles. Except as provided for in other regulations, no inoperative or unlicensed motor vehicle shall be parked, kept or stored on any premises for a period greater than thirty consecutive days, and no vehicle shall at any time be in a state of major disassembly, disrepair, or in the process of being stripped or dismantled. Painting of vehicles is prohibited unless conducted inside an approved spray booth. 
Exceptions: 
1.  Any vehicle which is enclosed in a garage or similarly enclosed area designed and approved for such purposes. 
2.  Any person conducting a business enterprise in compliance with existing zoning regulations. 
N.  Section 302 is hereby amended to include the following: 
302.10 Keeping or storing of anhydrous ammonia. Any person who keeps or stores anhydrous ammonia, except in a cylinder under 165 pounds at one location, either permanently or temporarily, in either movable or immovable tanks, bins, or other containers, including, but not limited to, trucks and railroad cars, within the corporate limits of the city, shall, upon conviction thereof be fined not more than $100.00 for each offence. Each day such keeping or storage of anhydrous ammonia continues shall constitute a separate offence. 
O.  Section 304.3 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
[F] 304.3 Premises identification. Buildings shall have approved address numbers placed in a position to be plainly legible and visible from the street or road fronting the property. These numbers shall contrast with their background. Address numbers shall be Arabic numerals or alphabet letters. Numbers shall be a minimum of 4 inches (102 mm) high with a minimum stroke width of 0.5 inch (12.7 mm). 
304.3.1 Numbering method. Numbering shall be determined and made as follows: 
1.  Buildings upon streets and avenues running east and west shall be numbered each way from Washington Avenue, commencing so as to have all odd numbers on the north side of the streets and avenues, adding thereto 100 and allowing 100 for each block and one for each 25 feet front. 
2.  Buildings upon streets and avenues running north and south shall be numbered each way from Harvey Avenue, commencing so as to have all the odd numbers on the east side of the streets and avenues, adding thereto 100 and allowing 100 for each block and one for each 25 feet front. 8 [] 
P.  Section 304.14 Insert: June 1, Insert: October 15. 
Q.  Section 403.3 is hereby amended to read as follows: 
403.3 Cooking facilities. Unless approved through the certification of occupancy, cooking shall not be permitted in any rooming unit or dormitory unit, and a cooking facility or appliance shall not be permitted to be present in the rooming unit or dormitory unit. Portable cooking equipment employing flame shall be prohibited in any dwelling. 9 [] 
Exceptions: 
1.  Where specifically approved in writing by the code official. 
2.  Devices such as coffee pots and microwave ovens shall not be considered cooking appliances. 
R.  Section 602.4 Insert: November 15, Insert: March 31.

Sec. 16-3. - Penalty. 
    Violation penalties as referenced in Section 106 of the International Property Maintenance Code of the City of Wellington are as follows: 
    Upon conviction thereof and for the conviction of any violation of the provisions of Sections 302 except 302.8, 303, 308, and 309 of the International Property Maintenance Code of the City of Wellington, be fined in an amount not to exceed $100.00 or be imprisoned not to exceed 30 days or be both fined and imprisoned. 
    Upon conviction thereof and for the conviction of any violations of the provisions of Section 302.8 of the International Property Maintenance Code of the City of Wellington, be fined in an amount not to exceed $500.00 or be imprisoned not to exceed 30 days or be both fined and imprisoned. 
(Ord. No. 4115,  1, 7-17-2012) 
Chapter 18 - FINANCE AND TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. - SALES TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- City sales tax, K.S.A. 12-187. 

Sec. 18-17. - Levy of the one-half of one percent sales tax. 
    A majority of the electors voting thereon having approved, at a special question election held on November 7, 1978, the levying of a retailers' sales tax in the city as authorized by K.S.A. 12-187, there is hereby levied a city retailers' sales tax in the amount of one-half of one percent to take effect on February 1, 1979. 
(Ord. No. 3216,  I, 11-21-1978) 
Sec. 18-18. - Levy of additional one-half of one percent sales tax. 
    A majority of electors voting thereon having approved, at a special question submitted election held on April 5, 1983, the levying of an additional retailers' sales tax in the amount of one-half of one percent, making a total of one percent, in the city as authorized by K.S.A. 12-187 et seq., there is hereby levied an additional one-half of one percent to take effect on July 1, 1983. 
(Ord. No. 3358,  I, 4-19-1983)
