Sec. 18-19. - Levy of additional one-quarter of one percent sales tax. 
    A majority of the electors of the City of Wellington, Kansas, voting thereon having approved, at a special election held on the 4th day of November, 2014, the levying of a retailers' sales tax at the rate of one percent for the purpose of financing the provision of health care services at St. Luke's Hospital d.b.a. Sumner Regional Medical Center in the City of Wellington, Kansas for a period of ten years commencing on April 1, 2015 and ending April 1, 2025 as well as repealing, effective April 1, 2015, the existing one half percent retailers' sales tax in place for the same purpose. 
(Ord. No. 3883,  I, 9-2-2003; Ord. No. 4111,  I, 4-17-2012; Ord. No. 4170,  I, 11-18-2014) 
Sec. 18-20. - Application of state law. 
    Such tax shall be identical in its application and exemptions there from to the Kansas Retailers' Sales Tax Act and all laws and administrative rules and regulations of the Kansas Department of Revenue relating to the states retailers' sales tax shall apply to such city retailers' sales tax insofar as such laws and regulations may be made applicable. The services of the department of revenue shall be utilized to administer, enforce and collect such tax. 
(Ord. No. 3216,  II, 11-21-1978; Ord. No. 3358,  II, 4-19-1983; Ord. No. 3883,  II, 9-2-2003; Ord. No. 4111,  II, 4-17-2012; Ord. No. 4170,  II, 11-18-2014) 
Chapter 20 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Fire prevention and protection, K.S.A. 31-132 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 20-1-20-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE/EMS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 20-11-20-18. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FIRE/EMS DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 20-19. - Created. 
    There is hereby created in the city a fire/EMS department composed of a chief, assistant chiefs, captains, and such fulltime and parttime firefighters as the governing body may provide. 
(Code 1974,  9-101; Code 1996,  7-101) 
Sec. 20-20. - City manager to appoint. 
    The city manager shall appoint the chief, assistant chiefs, captains and the fulltime and parttime firefighters. 
(Code 1974,  9-102; Code 1996,  7-102) 
State Law reference- Appointment of city officers and employees, K.S.A. 14-1501. 
Sec. 20-21. - Members of the fire/EMS department; physical examination. 
    No person shall be employed as a member of the fire/EMS department of the city until such person shall be examined by a physician designated by the city manager and determined to be physically fit for duty as a firefighter. All fulltime members of the fire/EMS department must pass a psychological examination and be determined to be fit for duty as a firefighter. The city manager of the city may at any time require a physical or psychological examination of any member of the fire/EMS department. 
(Code 1974,  9-103; Code 1996,  7-103) 
Sec. 20-22. - Chief to have control. 
    The chief of the fire/EMS department shall, under the direction of the city manager, have complete control of the fire/EMS department and all the firefighting equipment of the city and shall be responsible for the proper organization, training, discipline and functioning of the personnel of the fire/EMS department and fire apparatus of the city. 
(Code 1974,  9-104; Code 1996,  7-104) 
Sec. 20-23. - Assistant chief to direct in absence of chief. 
    In the absence of the chief, the assistant chiefs shall have all the powers and perform all the duties of the chief. 
(Code 1974,  9-105; Code 1996,  7-105) 
Sec. 20-24. - On duty. 
    The fire chief, assistant fire chiefs, captains and fulltime and parttime firefighters shall be on duty during each and every day and night except as prescribed by rules and regulations which are now or may hereafter be adopted. 
(Code 1974,  9-106; Code 1996,  7-106) 
Sec. 20-25. - Reports and records of chief. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire/EMS department to keep an accurate list of all equipment belonging to the fire/EMS department, to maintain accurate records of fire alarms, EMS responses, training, and the attendance of the same and to make all reports required by law of the chief of the fire/EMS department. 
(Code 1974,  9-108; Code 1996,  7-107) 
Secs. 20-26-20-33. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - AMBULANCE SERVICE 

Sec. 20-34. - Ambulance service trust fund. 
(a)  There is hereby created a fund of the city to be known as the Wellington Ambulance Service Trust Fund into which there shall be deposited all gifts, donations and bequests thereto for the purposes hereinafter set forth. 
(b)  The purpose of the Wellington Ambulance Service Trust Fund is to provide moneys to be used, either alone, or along with moneys from other sources, for the equipment and/or the operation and/or the maintenance of the Wellington Ambulance Service. Fund moneys shall be used solely for the foregoing purposes. 
(Code 1996,  8-501; Ord. No. 3342,  1, 2) 
Secs. 20-35-20-53. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIREFIGHTERS' RELIEF ASSOCIATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Firefighters' Relief Act, K.S.A. 40-1701 et seq. 

Sec. 20-54. - Relief fund. 
    The treasurer of the firefighters' relief association shall receive from the state commissioner of insurance, all money belonging to the firefighters' relief fund of the firefighters' relief association of the city, and all other money collected, and shall deposit the same to the credit of the Wellington firefighters' relief fund. The fund shall be held in trust and used for the relief of members of the fire/EMS department of the city as provided by law. No part of the fund shall be paid out except upon orders of the firefighters' relief association, the association being composed of members of the fire/EMS department of the city and incorporated under the laws of the state. All money so received shall be set apart and be used solely and entirely for the objects and purposes provided by laws of the state. 
(Code 1974,  9-201; Code 1996,  7-201) 
Sec. 20-55. - Treasurer's bond. 
    The treasurer of the firefighters' relief association shall be a member of the fire/EMS department, who before assuming the duties of such office shall give a public official bond in an amount which shall not be less than 100 percent of all property which shall come into the possession of such treasurer, including both cash and investments, which bond shall be approved by the city attorney. 
(Code 1974,  9-202; Code 1996,  7-202) 
Sec. 20-56. - Disbursements. 
    The firefighters' relief association shall have supervision of the disbursement of the firefighters' relief fund for the purposes for which the fund was created by law, for the benefit of the association and its members as provided by law, and shall also have supervision of the investment of such fund as hereinafter provided. The treasurer of the firefighters' relief association shall keep an accurate and detailed account of all warrants drawn on the fund, and the purposes for which same are drawn and provide an annual report to the state commissioner of insurance. 
(Code 1974,  9-203; Code 1996,  7-203) 
Sec. 20-57. - Purpose. 
    The conduct of all business relating to the firefighters' relief association and funds shall be in accordance with the charter, constitution and bylaws, which constitution and bylaws shall be in strict accordance with the laws of the state relating to and governing the firefighters' relief fund and association. 
(Code 1974,  9-204; Code 1996,  7-204) 
Sec. 20-58. - Use of moneys. 
    All moneys collected and received by the firefighters' relief association shall be held in trust and used as a fund for the relief of any member of the fire/EMS department of the city when injured or physically disabled in or by reason of the discharge of the member's duties as such, and for the relief of or the payment of gratuities to the widow or those dependent upon any member of the fire/EMS department who may be killed in the discharge of the member's duties as firefighters, or who may die from the effect of injuries so received, or from disease contracted by reason of the member's duties as such, and for the payment of the necessary funeral expenses of any member of the fire/EMS department when killed in the discharge of the member's duties as firefighters, or in the case of death resulting from the injuries so received or disease so contracted by reason of the member's duties as such, or for the purchase of insurance which would provide for any or all of the foregoing purposes for which such fund is authorized to be expended. The amount of the insurance shall be determined by the Wellington Firefighters' Relief Association, but the total amount of premium to be paid in any one year shall not exceed the amount received from the state commission of insurance plus any amounts received from other sources, less such expenses as may be necessarily incurred for the operating expenses of the relief association In case the amount of money on hand is insufficient to meet all obligations which may be incurred at the same time, the amount paid to injured and disabled firefighters or their widows or dependents shall be prorated and under no circumstances shall any obligations be incurred in excess of the amount of funds on hand. 
(Code 1974,  9-205; Code 1996,  7-205) 
State Law reference- Use of money, K.S.A. 40-1707. 
Sec. 20-59. - Review by city attorney. 
    No payment of $1,500.00 or more shall be made from the firefighters' relief fund until the expenditure by the firefighters' relief association shall have been reviewed and approved by the city attorney. 
(Code 1974,  9-206; Code 1996,  7-206) 
Sec. 20-60. - Funds may be invested. 
    The firefighters' relief association through its officers, may invest any amount, not to exceed 90 percent of all such relief funds, in purchasing bonds of the city. When such bonds are not obtainable, United States government bonds may be purchased. Such bonds shall be purchased so as to yield not less than two percent interest net, and such purchase must be approved by the governing body. It shall be the duty of the city attorney of the city to examine all such bonds as to their validity and report thereon in writing to the governing body and the firefighters' relief association, and no bonds shall be purchased by the firefighters' relief association until they have been approved and found valid by the city attorney. 
(Code 1974,  9-207; Code 1996,  7-207) 
State Law reference- Financial reports, filing, etc., K.S.A. 40-1706. 
Secs. 20-61-20-78. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FIRE PREVENTION STANDARDS 

Sec. 20-79. - Adoption of the 2015 International Fire Code. 
    That a certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the office of the City Clerk of the City of Wellington, being marked and designated as the International Fire Code 2015 edition, including appendix chapters B, C, D, E, F, G, as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the Fire Code of the City of Wellington, in the State of Kansas regulating and governing the safeguarding of life and property from fire and explosion hazards arising from the storage, handling and use of hazardous substances, materials and devices, and from conditions hazardous to life or property in the occupancy of buildings and premises as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said Fire Code on file in the office of the City of Wellington are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this ordinance. 
(Code 1983; Code 1985,  7-301; Code 1990,  7-301-7-303; Code 1996,  7-301; Ord. No. 3458,  1; Ord. No. 3485; Ord. No. 3681,  I; Ord. No. 3739,  I; Ord. No. 3781,  I, 5-19-1998; Ord. No. 3899,  I, 8-3-2004; Ord. No. 4088,  1, 3-15-2011; Ord. No. 4255,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 20-80. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4088,  2, adopted March 15, 2011, repealed  20-80, which pertained to amendments to International Fire Code and derived from Ord. No. 3899,  II, adopted Aug. 3, 2004. 
Sec. 20-81. - Accumulation of rubbish and trash. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to allow to accumulate or to keep in any part of any building or outside of and adjacent to any building or in any alley, sidewalk, street or premises within 30 feet of any building any rubbish, trash, waste paper, excelsior, empty boxes, barrels or other combustibles which shall constitute a fire hazard. 
(Code 1996,  7-305) 
Sec. 20-82. - Stacking of hay or straw. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, stack or store any hay or straw within 500 feet of any building located inside the fire limits of the city. 
(Code 1996,  7-306) 
Sec. 20-83. - Keeping of packing materials. 
    It shall be unlawful to keep excelsior or other packing material in any other than metal or wood metal line boxes or bins having self-closing or automatic covers. All refuse and trash from rooms where packing or unpacking is done shall be removed daily. 
(Code 1996,  7-307) 
Sec. 20-84. - Storage of ashes. 
    It shall be unlawful to store ashes inside of any nonfireproof building unless they are stored in a noncombustible container or receptacle, and a clearance of at least five feet shall be maintained between such container or receptacle and any combustible materials not placed therein. Ashes shall not be stored outside of any building in wooden, plastic, or paper product receptacles or dumped in contact with or in close proximity to any combustible materials. 
(Code 1996,  7-308) 
Sec. 20-85. - Filling gasoline tanks of motor vehicles. 
    The engines of motor vehicles shall be stopped when the gasoline tanks of such vehicles are being filled with gasoline at service stations or other places where gasoline is supplied to motor vehicles. The driver or person in control of such vehicle when the gasoline tank of same is being filled who refuses, neglects or fails to stop the engine of such vehicle shall likewise be guilty of a violation of this Code. 
(Code 1996,  7-309) 
Sec. 20-86. - Fire hazards generally. 
    It is unlawful for any person to cause or create anywhere within the city, or to permit on any premises under such person's control, any situation or condition that is conducive to or likely to cause or permit the outbreak of fire or the spreading of fire. Any situation or condition conducive to the outbreak of or spreading of fire, is declared to be a fire hazard. The violation of or failure to comply with any law pertaining to the storage, handling or use of flammable oils, explosives, liquefied petroleum gases, or fertilizers and all wires and other conductors charged with electricity, is declared to be a fire hazard. The placing of stools, chairs or any other obstruction in the aisles, hallways, doorway, or exit of any theater, public hall, auditorium, church or other place of indoor public assemblage, or the failure to provide any such place of public assemblage with sufficient, accessible and unobstructed fire exits and escapes is also declared to be a fire hazard. The obstruction of any street, avenue, alley, fire hydrant or any other condition that might delay the fire/EMS department in fighting fire is declared to be unlawful. 
(Code 1996,  7-310) 
Sec. 20-87. - Inspections to discover fire hazards. 
    It shall be the duty of the fire chief to inspect or cause to be inspected by fire/EMS department officers or members, as often as may be necessary all buildings, particularly all mercantile buildings, manufacturing plants, warehouses, garages, hotels, boardinghouses, roominghouses, theaters, auditoriums and all places of public assemblage, for the purpose of discovering the violation of any fire preventive law or any fire hazard and ascertaining and causing to be corrected any conditions liable to cause fires and to see that all places of public assemblage, hotels and roominghouses have sufficient and unobstructed facilities for escape therefrom in case of fire. 
(Code 1996,  7-311) 
Sec. 20-88. - Abatement of fire hazards; issuing order. 
    Whenever any officer or member of the fire/EMS department shall find or discover any fire hazard or shall find in any building or upon any premises combustible or explosive material or dangerous accumulation of rubbish or unnecessary accumulation of paper, boxes, shavings or any other flammable material, so situated as to endanger property by the probability of fire, or shall find or discover any violation of this chapter or any other law hazardous to public safety from fires, the fire chief shall order the fire hazard or danger from the fire forthwith abated and remedied and such order shall be complied with immediately by the owner or occupant of such buildings or premises. If the hazard or condition ordered abated and remedied is a violation of, or a failure to comply with any law, the fire chief shall report the matter to the city attorney and the city attorney shall, if the city attorney deems it advisable, prosecute the offender. 
(Code 1996,  7-312) 
Sec. 20-89. - Service of order; records. 
    Any order made under section 20-88 shall be in writing and may be served personally upon the owner or occupant of the premises or by leaving it with any person in charge of the premises or if the premises are unoccupied and the owner is a nonresident of the city, then by mailing a copy to the owner's last known post-office address. One notice to either the occupant or owner shall be sufficient. The fire chief shall keep a record of and copies of all such orders and notices and shall follow up such notices at the expiration of the time for compliance therewith and when complied with make proper entry, and if not complied with, file complaint with the municipal court against the property owner and/or occupant. 
(Code 1996,  7-313) 
Sec. 20-90. - Penalty. 
    Violation of the 2015 edition of the International Fire Code, as adopted by the City of Wellington, Kansas per Ordinance No. 4255, on the 5th day of March, 2019, is punishable by Class B Misdemeanor with a sentence ranging up to six months in jail and/or a fine not to exceed $1,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 4102,  I, 1-17-2012; Ord. No. 4256,  I, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 20-91. - Open burning. 
    It is unlawful for any person to conduct open burning of any type of materials, including, but not limited to, grass, brush, and leaves without a burn permit issued by the fire chief or his/her designee. Restricted items that cannot be burned include plastics, construction material, building, furniture, shingles, vehicles, tires, trash, and clothing. All rules of the burn permit shall be followed in strict adherence. Violation of the burn permit can result in revocation of the burn permit and/or be found in violation of this Code. Exception-portable or stationary outdoor fireplaces can be used without a burn permit and shall not be operated within 15 feet of any structure or combustible materials. Restricted items listed above cannot be burned in a portable or stationary outdoor fireplace. 
(Ord. No. 4149,  I, 12-17-2013) 
Secs. 20-92-20-106. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - NICHOLS TRUST FUND 

Sec. 20-107. - Trust created. 
    There is hereby created a fund of the city to be known as the Nichols Family Trust Fund into which shall be deposited all gifts, donations and bequests made to the city for the purposes set forth in section 20-108. 
(Code 1996,  7-401; Ord. No. 3434,  1) 
Sec. 20-108. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the Nichols Family Trust Fund is to provide moneys to be used, either alone, or along with moneys from other sources, for the purpose of purchasing smoke detectors, batteries and installing the same in dwellings in the city of persons who cannot themselves afford, or are unable to purchase and install smoke detectors in their dwellings. 
(Code 1996,  7-402; Ord. No. 3434,  2) 
Sec. 20-109. - Rules and regulations. 
    In order to carry out the express purposes of the Nichols Family Trust Fund set forth in this article, the city manager shall establish rules and regulations relating to the determination of what persons may be entitled to receive and have installed smoke detectors from the trust fund, and relating to the installation of such smoke detectors in such dwellings. 
(Code 1996,  7-403; Ord. No. 3434,  3) 
Secs. 20-110-20-131. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - FIRE INSURANCE PROCEEDS FUND[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4194,  12, adopted June 19, 2016, repealed the former Art. VI.,  20-132-20-138, and enacted a new Art. VI as set out herein. The former Art. VI pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1996,  7-501-7-507; Ord. No. 3520,  1-7; Ord. No. 3744; Ord. No. 3767,  I, II, 8-19-1997. 
State Law reference- Proceeds of fire insurance policies, K.S.A. 40-3901. 

Sec. 20-132. - Scope and application. 
    The city is hereby authorized to utilize the procedures established by K.S.A. 40-3901 et seq., whereby no insurance company shall pay a claim of a named insured for loss or damage to any building or other structure located within the city, where the amount recoverable for the loss or damage to the building or other structure under all policies is in excess of 75 percent of the face value of the policy covering such building or other insured structure, unless there is compliance with the procedures set out in this article. 
(Ord. No. 4194,  1, 7-19-2016) 
Sec. 20-133. - Lien created. 
    The governing body of the city hereby creates a lien in favor of the city on the proceeds of any insurance policy based upon a covered claim payment made for damage or loss to a building or other structure located within the city, where the amount recoverable for all the loss or damage to the building or other structure under all policies is in excess of 75 percent of the face value of the policy(s) covering such building or other insured structure. The lien arises upon any unpaid tax, special ad valorem levy, or any other charge imposed upon real property by or on behalf of the city which is an encumbrance on real property, whether or not evidenced by written instrument, or such tax, levy, assessment, expense or other charge that has remained undischarged for at least one year prior to the filing of a proof of loss. 
(Ord. No. 4194,  2, 7-19-2016) 
Sec. 20-133. - Same; encumbrances. 
    Prior to final settlement on any claim covered by section 20-133, the insurer or insurers shall contact the county treasurer, Sumner County, Kansas, to determine whether any such encumbrances are presently in existence. If the same are found to exist, the insurer or insurers shall execute and transmit in an amount equal to that owing under the encumbrances a draft payable to the county treasurer, Sumner County, Kansas. 
(Ord. No. 4194,  3, 7-19-2016) 
Sec. 20-135. - Same; pro rata basis. 
    Such transfer of proceeds shall be on a pro rata basis by all insurance companies insuring the building or other structure. 
(Ord. No. 4194,  4, 7-19-2016) 
Sec. 20-136. - Procedure. 
(a)  When final settlement on a covered claim has been agreed to or arrived at between the named insured or insureds and the company or companies, and the final settlement exceeds 75 percent of the face value of the policy covering any building or other insured structure, and when all amounts due the holder of a first real estate mortgage against the building or other structure, pursuant to the terms of the policy and endorsements thereto, shall have been paid, the insurance company or companies shall execute a draft payable to the city treasurer in an amount equal to the sum of 15 percent of the covered claim payment, unless the chief building inspector of the city has issued a certificate to the insurance company or companies that the insured has removed the damaged building or other structure, as well as all associated debris, or repaired, rebuilt, or otherwise made the premises safe and secure. 
(b)  Such transfer of funds shall be on a pro rata basis by all companies insuring the building or other structure. Policy proceeds remaining after the transfer to the city shall be disbursed in accordance with the policy terms. 
(c)  Upon the transfer of the funds as required by subsection (a) of this article, the insurance company shall provide the city with the name and address of the named insured or insureds, the total insurance coverage applicable to said building or other structure, and the amount of the final settlement agreed to or arrived at between the insurance company or companies and the insured or insureds, whereupon the chief building inspector shall contact the named insured or insureds by certified mail, return receipt requested, notifying them that said insurance proceeds have been received by the city and apprise them of the procedures to be followed under this article. 
(Ord. No. 4194,  5, 7-19-2016) 
Sec. 20-137. - Fund created; deposit of moneys. 
    The city treasurer is hereby authorized and shall create a fund to be known as the "Insurance Proceeds Fund." All moneys received by the city treasurer as provided for by this article shall be placed in said fund and deposited in an interest-bearing account. 
(Ord. No. 4194,  6, 7-19-2016) 
Sec. 20-138. - Building inspector; investigation, removal of structure. 
(a)  Upon receipt of moneys as provided for by this article, the city treasurer shall immediately notify the chief building inspector of said receipt, and transmit all documentation received from the insurance company or companies to the chief building inspector. 
(b)  Within 30 days of the receipt of said moneys, the chief building inspector shall determine, after prior investigation, whether the city shall instigate proceedings under the provisions of K.S.A. 12-1750 et seq., as amended. 
(c)  Prior to the expiration of the 30 days established by subsection (b) of this article, the chief building inspector shall notify the city treasurer whether he or she intends to initiate proceedings under K.S.A. 12-1750 et seq., as amended. 
(d)  If the chief building inspector has determined that proceedings under K.S.A. 12-1750 et seq., as amended shall be initiated, he or she will do so immediately but no later than 45 days after receipt of the moneys by the city treasurer. 
(e)  Upon notification to the city treasurer by the chief building inspector that no proceedings shall be initiated under K.S.A. 12-1750 et seq., as amended, the city treasurer shall return all such moneys received, plus accrued interest, to the insured or insureds as identified in the communication from the insurance company or companies. Such return shall be accomplished within 45 days of the receipt of the moneys from the insurance company or companies. 
(Ord. No. 4194,  8, 7-19-2016) 
Sec. 20-139. - Removal of structure; excess moneys. 
    If the chief building inspector has proceeded under the provisions of K.S.A. 12-1750 et seq., as amended, all moneys in excess of that which is ultimately necessary to comply with the provisions for the removal of the building or structure, less salvage value, if any, shall be paid to the insured. 
(Ord. No. 4194,  8, 7-19-2016) 
Sec. 20-140. - Same; disposition of funds. 
    If the chief building inspector, with regard to a building or other structure damaged, determines that it is necessary to act under K.S.A. 12-1756, any proceeds received by the city treasurer under the authority of section 20-136(a) relating to that building or other structure shall be used to reimburse the city for any expenses incurred by the city in proceeding under K.S.A. 12-1756. Upon reimbursement from the insurance proceeds, the chief building inspector shall immediately effect the release of the lien resulting therefrom. Should the expenses incurred by the city exceed the insurance proceeds paid over to the city treasurer under Section 5(a), the chief building inspector shall publish a new lien as authorized by K.S.A. 12-1756, in an amount equal to such excess expenses incurred. 
(Ord. No. 4194,  9, 7-19-2016) 
Sec. 20-141. - Effect upon insurance policies. 
    This article shall not make the city a party to any insurance contract, nor is the insurer liable to any party for any amount in excess of the proceeds otherwise payable under its insurance policy. 
(Ord. No. 4194,  10, 7-19-2016) 
Sec. 20-142. - Insurers; liability. 
    Insurers complying with this article or attempting in good faith to comply with this article shall be immune from civil and criminal liability and such action shall not be deemed in violation of K.S.A. 40-2404 and any amendments thereto, including withholding payment of any insurance proceeds pursuant to this article, or releasing or disclosing any information pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 4194,  11, 7-19-2016) 
Secs. 20-143-20-159. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - FIREWORKS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of fireworks, K.S.A. 31-134; bottle rockets prohibited, K.S.A. 31-155, 31-156. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 20-160. - Kansas Administrative Regulations and certain Kansas Statutes adopted by reference. 
    There is hereby incorporated by reference for the purpose of regulating fireworks within the corporate limits of the city, article 6 of Agency 22 of the Kansas Administrative Regulations of 1994 (K.A.R. 22-6-1-22-6-17), compiled and published by the Office of the Secretary of the State of Kansas, Topeka, Kansas, and K.S.A. 31-155 and 31-156, compiled and edited by the Office of the Revisor of Statutes of the State of Kansas, Topeka, Kansas, save and except such articles, sections, parts or portions as are hereafter modified or changed. No fewer than three copies of the aforesaid portions of the Kansas Administrative Regulations and Kansas Statutes Annotated shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy as Adopted by Ordinance No. 3812," with all sections or portions thereof intended to be changed clearly marked to show any such change and to which shall be attached a copy of this article, and filed with the city clerk to be open for inspection and available to the public at all reasonable hours. The police department, municipal judge and all administrative departments of the city charged with enforcement of this article shall be supplied, at the cost of the city, such number of official copies of such regulations and statutes similarly marked, as may be deemed expedient. 
(Ord. No. 3812,  I, 6-6-2000) 
Sec. 20-161. - Amendment of regulations adopted in section 20-160. 
    Section 22-6-5 of Kansas Administrative Regulations of 1994 incorporated in section 20-160 shall be amended to read as follows: 
    22-6-5. Storage; Sale; Possession; Discharge; or Delivery; Days Permitted. 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation shall store, sell possess or discharge fireworks at temporary retail stands or other locations, or deliver within the City of Wellington, Kansas, retail fireworks before 12:00 o'clock p.m. June 30 and after 12:00 o'clock p.m. on July 5. 
(b)  Retail sales hours shall be from 10:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. on July 1 thru July 4. 
(c)  Legal discharge hours shall be from 10:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. on July 1 thru July 3 and 10:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight July 4. Any other times must be approved and authorized by the city council. 
(d)  Except for public displays approved by the city, no fireworks shall at any time be stored, sold, possessed or discharged on the city property known as the Wellington Lake Recreation Area, and/or Hargis Creek Watershed Park. 
(Ord. No. 3812,  II, 6-6-2000; Ord. No. 3991,  I, 5-18-2007; Ord. No. 4223,  I, 4-3-2018) 
Secs. 20-162-20-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 20-191. - Storage and sale permits required. 
(a)  No person shall store or sell fireworks within the city without first obtaining from the office of the city clerk a permit to store and sell the same. 
(b)  An application for the storage and/or sale of fireworks shall be made at the office of the city clerk and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  Whether such application is for the storage or sale of fireworks, or both. 
(3)  The street address or location at which the fireworks are to be located. 
(4)  The days the applicant intends to store or sell the fireworks. 
(5)  A description of the structure in which the fireworks are to be located. 
(6)  The applicant's state sales tax number. 
(7)  If fireworks are to be stored or sold on land not owned by the applicant, he must furnish a consent letter from the landowner. The letter shall containing the landowner's name and address and consent to the applicant's use of the land to store and/or sell fireworks. 
(8)  A statement that the applicant, if issued a permit, will at all times comply with the laws of the state and ordinances of the city relating to the storage and sales of fireworks. 
(c)  Before a permit is issued hereunder the applicant shall: 
(1)  Furnish a sufficient bond or certificate of insurance showing public liability coverage in an amount not less than $500,000.00; 
(2)  Furnish a written certificate from the fire chief or the fire chief's duly authorized agent stating that the location for which the permit is applied for has been duly inspected and found to be in compliance with the laws of the state and city ordinances; and 
(3)  Pay a fee in accordance with the following schedule: 
a.  For storage of fireworks, the sum of $5,000.00. 
b.  For the sale of fireworks from a stand of 1,000 square feet or less, the sum of $500.00. 
c.  For the sale of fireworks from a stand of more than 1,000 square feet, the sum of $5,000.00. 
(d)  For purpose of this article the terms "storage" and "stored" shall mean fireworks kept or held by wholesalers or distributors for sale or delivery to retailers who take or purchase said fireworks for resale, said terms shall not apply to any fireworks held by retailers for immediate resale to customers for the customers use. 
(e)  Permits for the storage and, or sale of fireworks shall be issued only for locations in the city that are zoned for commercial and industrial uses, and no permits shall be issued for locations in the city that are zoned for uses other than commercial and industrial. 
(Ord. No. 3812,  III, 6-6-2000; Ord. No. 3847,  II, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 20-192. - Inspections; compliance; revocation of permit. 
    Inspections of the locations for which permits for the storage and, or sale of fireworks have been issued under this article may be conducted by duly authorized fire/EMS department personnel at any time. If, upon any such inspection, the location is found not to be in compliance with the provisions of this article, the location shall immediately be made to comply with such provisions, or the permit issued for such location shall be immediately revoked, and any fireworks then held or kept on such location for storage, and, or sale shall be immediately removed from such location. In the event a permit is revoked pursuant to this section, no part of the permit fee paid shall be refunded. 
(Ord. No. 3812,  IV, 6-6-2000) 
Sec. 20-193. - Suspension or discharge of fireworks; emergency conditions. 
    The discharge of fireworks permitted by the provisions of this article may be suspended or limited upon a determination by the mayor of the city, or in the mayor's absence the president of the city council or the city manager, that emergency conditions exist which would make the discharge of fireworks an immediate hazard to persons and property in the city. Upon such a determination a written proclamation setting forth the reason for the suspension or limitation and describing in detail the extent of such suspension or limitation shall be signed by the official making such determination. The proclamation shall be posted on the front door of the city administration center at 317 South Washington Avenue in the city, at such other locations throughout the city as may be appropriate, published in the official city newspaper and disseminated over the local channel of Sumner Cable TV. Such proclamation may be modified or revoked at any time the official who signed said proclamation may deem proper. Notice of any modification or revocation of such proclamation shall be given in the same manner as notice of the proclamation was given. 
(Ord. No. 3812,  V, 6-6-2000) 
Chapter 22 - HUMAN RELATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 22-1-22-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FAIR HOUSING[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Discrimination in housing, K.S.A. 44-1015-44-1029. 

Sec. 22-19. - Purpose. 
    It is hereby declared to be the public policy of the city to eliminate discrimination and safeguard the right of any person to sell, purchase, lease, rent or obtain financing of real property without regard to race, color, sex, national origin, ancestry or religion. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  8-601) 
Sec. 22-20. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Disability has the meaning provided by K.S.A. 44-1002 and amendments thereto. 
    Familial status means having one or more individuals less than 18 years of age domiciled with: 
(1)  A parent or another person having legal custody of such individual; or 
(2)  The designee of such parent or other person having such custody, with the written permission of such parent or other person. 
    Family includes a single individual. 
    Financial institution means any person regularly engaged in the business of lending money or guaranteeing loans on housing accommodations or real property. 
    Owner means any person, lessee, sublessee, assignee, manager, agent having the right to sell, rent or lease any housing accommodation or real property with the corporate limits of the city. 
    Person aggrieved means any person who claims to have been injured by a discriminatory housing practice or believes that such person will be injured by a discriminatory housing practice that is about to occur. 
    Real estate broker means any person who, for a fee or other valuable consideration, sells, purchases, exchanges, rents, negotiates, offers or attempts to negotiate the sale, purchase, exchange or rental of housing accommodations or real property of another person. 
    Real estate salesman or agent means any person employed by a real estate broker to perform or to assist in the performance of any or all of the functions of a real estate broker. 
    Real property means and includes: 
(1)  All vacant or unimproved land; and 
(2)  Any building or structure which is occupied or designed or intended for occupancy, or any building or structure having a portion thereof which is occupied or designed or intended for occupancy. 
    To rent means to lease, to sublease, to let and otherwise to grant for a consideration the right to occupy premises not owned by the occupant. 
    Unlawful discriminatory housing practice means any discrimination or segregation or separation against any person or group of persons because of race, color, sex, national origin, or ancestry and religion, and shall include only those unlawful practices as set forth in sections 22-21 through 22-23. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  8-602) 
State Law reference- Definitions, K.S.A. 44-105 
Sec. 22-21. - Unlawful practices. 
    Subject to the provisions of K.S.A. 44-1018 and amendments thereto, it shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Refuse to sell or rent after the making of a bona fide offer, to fail to transmit a bona fide offer or refuse to negotiate in good faith for the sale or rental of, or otherwise make unavailable or deny, real property to any person because of race, religion, color, sex, disability, familial status, national origin or ancestry. 
(2)  Discriminate against any person in the terms, conditions or privileges of sale or rental of real property, or in the provision of services or facilities in connection therewith, because of race, religion, color, sex, disability, familial status, national origin or ancestry. 
(3)  Make, print, publish, disseminate or use, or cause to be made, printed, published, disseminated or used, any notice, statement, advertisement or application, with respect to the sale or rental of real property that indicates any preference, limitation, specification or discrimination based on race, religion, color, sex, disability, familial status, national origin or ancestry, or an intention to make any such preference, limitation, specification or discrimination. 
(4)  Represent to any person because of race, religion, color, sex, disability, familial status, national origin or ancestry that any real property is not available for inspection, sale or rental when such real property is in fact so available. 
(5)  For profit, induce or attempt to induce any person to sell or rent any real property by representation regarding the entry or prospective entry into the neighborhood of a person of a particular race, religion, color, sex, disability, familial status, national origin or ancestry. 
(6)  Deny any person access to or membership or participation in any multiple-listing service, real estate brokers' organization or other service, organization or facility relating to the business of selling or renting real property, or to discriminate against such person in the terms or conditions of such access, membership or participation, because of race, religion, color, sex, disability, familial status, national origin or ancestry. 
(7)  Discriminate against any person in such person's use or occupancy of real property because of the race, religion, color, sex, disability, familial status, national origin or ancestry of the people with whom such person associates. 
(8)  Other discriminatory practices. 
a.  Discriminate in the sale or rental, or to otherwise make unavailable or deny, residential real property to any buyer or renter because of a disability of: 
1.  That buyer or renter; 
2.  A person residing in or intending to reside in such real property after it is sold, rented or made available; or 
3.  Any person associated with that buyer or renter. 
b.  Discriminate against any person in the terms, conditions or privileges of sale or rental of residential real property or in the provision of services or facilities in connection with such real property because of a disability of: 
1.  That person; 
2.  A person residing in or intending to reside in that real property after it is so sold, rented or made available; or 
3.  Any person associated with that person. 
c.  For purposes of this subsection (8), discrimination includes: 
1.  A refusal to permit, at the expense of the person with a disability, reasonable modifications of existing premises occupied or to be occupied by such person if such modifications may be necessary to afford such person full enjoyment of the premises; 
2.  A refusal to make reasonable accommodations in rules, policies, practices or services, when such accommodations may be necessary to afford such person equal opportunity to use and enjoy residential real property; or 
3.  In connection with the design and construction of covered multifamily residential real property for first occupancy on and after January 1, 1992, a failure to design and construct such residential real property in such a manner that: 
(i)  The public use and common use portions of such residential real property are readily accessible to and usable by persons with disabilities; 
(ii)  All the doors designed to allow passage into and within all premises within such residential real property are sufficiently wide to allow passage by persons with disabilities who are in wheelchairs; and 
(iii)  All premises within such residential real property contain the following features of adaptive design: An accessible route into and through the residential real property; light switches, electrical outlets, thermostats and other environmental controls in accessible locations; reinforcements in bathroom walls to allow later installation of grab bars; and usable kitchens and bathrooms such that an individual in a wheelchair can maneuver about the space. 
d.  Compliance with the appropriate requirements of the American National Standard for Buildings and Facilities providing accessibility and usability for physically handicapped people, commonly cited as "ANSI A 117.1," suffices to satisfy the requirements of subsection (8)c.3(iii) of this section. 
e.  As used in this subsection (8), the term "covered multifamily residential real property" means: 
1.  Buildings consisting of four or more units if such buildings have one or more elevators; and 
2.  Ground floor units in other buildings consisting of four or more units. 
f.  Nothing in this section shall be construed to invalidate or limit any state law or ordinance that requires residential real property to be designed and constructed in a manner that affords persons with disabilities greater access than is required by this section. 
g.  Nothing in this subsection (8) requires that residential real property be made available to an individual whose tenancy would constitute a direct threat to the health or safety of other individuals or whose tenancy would result in substantial physical damage to the property of others. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  8-603) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, K.S.A. 44-1016. 
Sec. 22-22. - Discrimination in financial assistance. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or other entity whose business includes engaging in real estate related transactions to discriminate against any person in making available such a transaction, or in the terms or conditions of such a transaction, because of the race, religion, color, sex, disability, familial status, national origin or ancestry of such person or of any person associated with such person in connection with any real estate related transaction. 
(b)  As used in this section, the term "real estate related transaction" means any of the following: 
(1)  The making or purchasing of loans or providing other financial assistance: 
a.  For purchasing, constructing, improving, repairing or maintaining a dwelling; or 
b.  Secured by real property. 
(2)  The selling, brokering or appraising of real property. 
(c)  Nothing in this section prohibits a person engaged in the business of furnishing appraisals of real property to take into consideration factors other than race, religion, color, sex, disability, familial status, national origin or ancestry. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  8-604) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 44-1017. 
Sec. 22-23. - Reprisal. 
    It shall be an unlawful discriminatory housing practice for any person, owner, real estate broker, salesman or agent thereof: 
(1)  To discriminate or to engage in economic or other reprisals against any person because the person complies with the provisions of this article, or has opposed any practice forbidden under this article, or has filed a complaint, testified or assisted in any proceedings under this article. 
(2)  To aid, abet, incite, compel, coerce, cooperate or participate in the doing of any act declared to be a discriminatory practice under the provisions of this article; or to obstruct or prevent compliance with the provisions of this article, or to attempt directly or indirectly to commit any act declared by this article to be a discriminatory practice. 
(3)  To induce or attempt to induce the sale or listing for sale of any dwelling unit, commercial unit, or real property or any part or portion thereof by representing that a change has occurred or will or may occur with respect to the racial, religious, or ethnic composition of the block, neighborhood, or area in which the property is located; or to induce or attempt to induce such sale by representing that the presence or anticipated presence of persons of any particular race, religion, sex, or national origin or color in the area will or may result in: 
a.  The lowering of property values; 
b.  A change in the racial religious, or ethnic composition of the block, neighborhood, or area in which the property is located; 
c.  An increase in criminal or anti-social behavior in the area; 
d.  A decline in the quality of the schools serving the area. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  8-605) 
Sec. 22-24. - Exception. 
(a)  Nothing in this article shall prohibit a religious organization, association or society, or any nonprofit institution or organization operated, supervised or controlled by or in conjunction with a religious organization, association or society, from limiting the sale, rental or occupancy of real property which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose to persons of the same religion, or from giving preference to such persons, unless membership in such religion is restricted on account of race, color, national origin or ancestry. Nor shall anything in this article prohibit a nonprofit private club in fact not open to the public, which as an incident to its primary purpose or purposes provides lodgings which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose, from limiting the rental or occupancy of such lodgings to its members or from giving preference to its members. 
(b)  Nothing in this article, other than the prohibitions against discriminatory advertising as provided in K.S.A. 44-1016(c) and amendments thereto, shall apply to: 
(1)  The sale or rental of any single-family house by an owner, provided the following conditions are met: 
a.  The owner does not own or have any interest in more than three single-family houses at any one time; and 
b.  The house is sold or rented without the use of a real estate broker, agent or salesperson or the facilities of any person in the business of selling or renting dwellings. If the owner selling the house does not reside in it at the time of the sale or was not the most recent resident of the house prior to such sale, the exemption in this subsection applies to only one such sale in any 24-month period; or 
(2)  Rooms or units in buildings containing living quarters occupied or intended to be occupied by no more than four families living independently of each other, if the owner actually maintains and occupies one of such living quarters as the owner's residence. 
(c)  Applicability regarding maximum number of occupants. 
(1)  Nothing in this article limits the applicability of any reasonable local, state or federal restrictions regarding the maximum number of occupants permitted to occupy a dwelling. Nor does any provision in this article regarding familial status apply with respect to dwellings provided under any state or federal program specifically designed and operated to assist elderly persons, as defined in the state or federal program, or to housing for older persons. 
(2)  As used in this subsection (c), the term "housing for older persons" means housing communities: 
a.  Intended for, and at least 80 percent occupied by, at least one person 55 years of age or older per unit and providing significant facilities and services specifically designed to meet the physical or social needs of such persons; or 
b.  Intended for and occupied solely by persons 62 years of age or older. 
(d)  Nothing in this article prohibits conduct against a person because such person has been convicted two or more times by any court of competent jurisdiction of the illegal manufacture or distribution of a controlled substance as defined in section 102 of the Federal Controlled Substances Act (21 USC 802). 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  8-606) 
Sec. 22-25. - Complaint. 
(a)  Any person claiming to be aggrieved by an unlawful discriminatory housing practice, may on such person's own behalf or by such person's attorney make, sign and file with the city clerk a complaint in writing, under oath. The complaint shall state the name and address of the person alleged to have committed an unlawful discriminatory house practice. Further, the compliant shall state the time, place and the specific unlawful discriminatory acts complained of. 
(b)  Any complaint filed under this article must be filed within 30 days following the commission of the alleged discriminatory act complained of. 
(c)  The complaint shall be filed with the city clerk who shall forward the same to the governing body at its next meeting. 
(d)  A certified copy of the complaint shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested addressed to the person complained against. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  8-607) 
Sec. 22-26. - Investigation of complaint; conciliation. 
(a)  Upon receipt of the complaint the governing body immediately shall cause an investigation to be made. If the investigation reveals there is no merit for the complaint, the complaint shall be dismissed. 
(b)  If the investigation discloses reason to believe the complaint justified, the governing body, or the governing body's appointed agent, shall attempt to conciliate the complaint and eliminate the discriminatory practice. 
(c)  If attempts to conciliate the complaint prove unsuccessful within 30 days following receipt by the governing body, the complaint shall be forwarded to the city attorney to begin legal action. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  8-608) 
Chapter 24 - LAW ENFORCEMENT 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 24-1-24-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Law enforcement officers, K.S.A. 12-4111. 

Sec. 24-19. - Appointments. 
    The city manager shall appoint a chief of police and such number of regular and special police officers as the governing body may deem necessary for the best interest, welfare and protection of the city. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  10-101) 
Sec. 24-20. - Duties of city chief of police and assistants. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police and the assistant chief of police and other police officers, to see that the laws of the state and all ordinances of the city and all resolutions of the governing body are properly enforced and obeyed within the police jurisdiction of the city. Whenever arrest is made they shall attend all trials in municipal court unless excused by the municipal judge. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  10-102) 
Sec. 24-21. - Police chief: powers; duties. 
    The chief of the police department shall, under the direction of the city manager, have complete control of the police department and shall be responsible for the proper organization, training, discipline and functioning of the police department, and for the proper care, use and safety of all property used in connection with such department. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  10-103) 
Sec. 24-22. - Arrests by law enforcement personnel. 
    The law enforcement personnel shall have power to arrest all offenders against the laws of the state, or of the city, by day or night, and house them in a suitable facility to prevent their escape, until an appearance before the proper authority having jurisdiction. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  10-104) 
Sec. 24-23. - Rules of conduct. 
(a)  All members of the police department, including the chief of police, shall be subject to the following rules of conduct: 
(1)  No proposed action or the contents of any order of the police department or case pending before the municipal court shall be made known to any person except those directly concerned with its execution and all police department business shall be treated as confidential. 
(2)  No public criticism or ridicule of any official action of this department or of the municipal court shall be made. 
(3)  Members shall at all times be polite and considerate when dealing with the public and shall maintain proper decorum, command of temper, patience and discretion. This subsection shall not, however, prevent the use of reasonable force to effect necessary action in enforcing the law. 
(4)  No member shall accept any bribes or use such member's office to obtain money, misuse police department property, allow another person to use such member's badge or identification, drink intoxicating liquor while on duty or become drunk or conspicuously disorderly in any public place at any time. 
(5)  No member shall engage in political activity of any nature while on duty nor shall any member accept pay for any service performed during the member's hours of duty. 
(6)  Under no circumstances shall any member use the patrol car for other than official business or permit any person other than city officials to ride in the car, except in the case of emergency or where necessary in order to conduct official city business. 
(b)  Conduct shall also be as defined by department policy. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  10-105) 
Sec. 24-24. - Reward moneys; disposition. 
    All money due to, or received by, the chief of police or any law enforcement personnel on account of any reward accruing to the chief of police or any law enforcement personnel in consequence of any action in the line of duty shall be turned over to the credit of a fund for aid of law enforcement personnel of the city in payment of benefits for sickness and injury and allied uses. If no such fund has been established by the police department, the moneys shall be deposited with the city treasurer and shall become general funds of the city. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  10-106) 
Sec. 24-25. - Reserve police force. 
(a)  A reserve police force is hereby established for the city, for better and more efficient police protection of the city. 
(b)  The members of the reserve police force shall be appointed by the chief of police with the approval of the city manager and shall hold their office for a term of one year or until their successors are appointed and qualified. 
(c)  The reserve police force shall be under the general supervision of the chief of police and shall not draw any compensation for their services. 
(d)  The city shall endeavor to secure insurance coverage for members of the reserve police force comparable to that applicable to members of the police department. In the absence of such insurance coverage the city shall not be liable for any injuries occurring to members of the reserve police force whether the injuries occur while the members are acting as reserve police officers or otherwise. 
(e)  The members of the reserve police force shall not have police powers except when actually called on active duty by the chief of police. 
(f)  No reserve police force member shall carry any firearm while on duty, except on the expressed order of the chief of police. 
(g)  The chief of police shall formulate all necessary rules of the reserve police force relating to training, conduct and duties to be performed by the reserve police force. 
(h)  The chief of police, upon approval by the city manager, may at any time, without cause suspend or remove any member of the reserve police force in accordance with the provisions of the departmental personnel rules and regulations. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  10-107) 
Chapter 26 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Code for municipal courts, K.S.A. 12-4109. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a municipal court for the city. The municipal court shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine cases involving violations of the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  9-101) 
Sec. 26-2. - Practice and procedure. 
    The state code of procedure for municipal courts, as set forth in K.S.A. 12-4101 et seq., and all acts amendatory or supplemental thereto shall govern the practice and procedure in all cases in the municipal court. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  9-102) 
Sec. 26-3. - Times. 
    The municipal court of the city shall be held between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 12:00 noon and between the hours of 1:00 p.m. and 5:00 p.m. each day, Monday through Friday, except on legal holidays, and at such other hours as the municipal judge may designate, at the city administration center, 317 South Washington Avenue, Wellington, or at such other place as may be designated by the municipal judge. 
(Code 1996,  9-103; Ord. No. 3367,  1) 
Secs. 26-4-26-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL JUDGE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal judge, K.S.A. 12-4114. 

Sec. 26-25. - Appointment. 
    The municipal court shall be presided over by a municipal judge. The city manager shall appoint the judge of the municipal court. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  9-104) 
Sec. 26-26. - Powers and duties. 
    The municipal judge shall have such powers and duties as set forth in the state code of procedure for municipal courts, K.S.A. 12-4101 et seq. and all acts amendatory or supplemental thereto. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  9-105) 
Sec. 26-27. - Salary. 
    The municipal judge shall receive a salary as shall be fixed by ordinance. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  9-106) 
Secs. 26-28-26-57. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MUNICIPAL COURT CLERK[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Clerk of the municipal court, K.S.A. 12-4108. 

Sec. 26-58. - Office established; acting clerk. 
(a)  There is hereby established the office of the clerk of the municipal court of the city, which office shall be filled by appointment by the municipal judge of the municipal court. The duties of the office shall be those prescribed by the Code for Municipal Courts set forth in K.S.A. 12-4101 et seq. In the event the duties of the office do not occupy the full period of eight hours on each work day, the person appointed as clerk of the municipal court shall perform other duties for the city as may be prescribed by the city manager. 
(b)  During the temporary absence, sickness or disability of the clerk of the municipal court, the municipal judge shall appoint an acting clerk of the municipal court who shall act as clerk until the absence, sickness or disability of the clerk shall end. 
(Code 1996,  9-107; Ord. No. 3370,  1, 2) 
Secs. 26-59-26-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - COURT PROCEDURE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Code of procedure for municipal courts, K.S.A. 12-4101 et seq. 

Sec. 26-90. - Failure to appear. 
    Any person charged with a violation of the ordinances of the city, released from custody upon such person's own recognizance, without surety, or issued a notice to appear who fails to appear before the municipal court of the city at the time and place set forth in the recognizance or notice to appear shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not more than $100.00 or by imprisonment of not more than three months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Code 1996,  9-108; Ord. No. 3322,  1) 
State Law reference- Failure to appear, K.S.A. 12-4303. 
Sec. 26-91. - Court and administration fees. 
    Each case filed in the municipal court, except for violations with penalty provisions providing within the penalty provision that the fine shall include the court costs, where there is a finding of guilt, either after trial or upon the court accepting a plea of guilty or no contest, or upon a forfeiture of bond or the entry of a diversion agreement, the following court costs shall be imposed: 
(1)  A law enforcement fee as required by K.S.A. 12-4117, except for cases involving nonmoving traffic violations and parking tickets, in which this fee shall not be assessed. 
(2)  A docket fee of $62.50 for all cases, except an offense that is assessed a fee pursuant to paragraph (1) and parking tickets shall only have a docket fee of $40.00. 
(3)  Witness fee of $10.00 for each witness, plus mileage, shall be assessed for all witnesses signing up for a witness fee after being subpoenaed to testify, except for Wellington Police Officers. 
(4)  A bench warrant fee of $50.00 shall be assessed when a bench warrant has been served upon the defendant. There shall be no more than one bench warrant fee in any case even though multiple bench warrants may be served upon the defendant. When the court recalls the bench warrant without the defendant being arrested, the bench warrant fee shall not be assessed, such as when the defendant appears in court to turn his/herself in and the court exercises its discretion to recall the warrant. 
(5)  A KBI laboratory fee as required by K.S.A. 28-176 shall be assessed in each case in which the KBI provided forensic science, laboratory services, or forensic computer examination services in connection with the investigation of such case, provided that such services were provided prior to defendant being granted diversion or adjudicated guilty of the crime pertaining thereto. 
(6)  An incarceration fee of $35.00 per day for each day or portion of a day that the defendant is committed by the court to serve time in the county jail. This incarceration fee only applies to jail time served pursuant to court order and shall not apply to jail time served prior to defendant being initially sentenced by the court. 
(7)  A notice fee of $30.00 shall be assessed no more than once in each case in which the court clerk either sends notice to the defendant or summons that the defendant has failed to pay or appear in court as required. Such notice may be the notice required to be sent prior to suspension of the defendant's driver's license for a traffic offense or it may be such other notice that the clerk uses to notify defendant of missing a required court appearance. 
(8)  A judicial education fund assessment fee shall be assessed as required by K.S.A. 12-4116. 
(9)  A probation supervision fee of $50.00 may be assessed against any defendant that the court places on a reporting probation. 
(10)  An expungement fee of $75.00 shall be paid by the defendant upon the defendant filing a motion for expungement. 
(11)  The fees in subsections (1), (2), (3), (8), and (10) noted above are mandatory and may not be waived by the court. 
(12)  The fees provided for in subsections (4), (5), (6), (7), and (9), may be waived or partially waived by the court upon the court making a finding that the defendant is indigent and is therefore either incapable of paying such fees or would suffer significant financial hardship if required to pay such fees. The basis for such findings shall be documented by the court. 
(Ord. No. 4081,  1, II, 3-1-2011; Ord. No. 4129,  I, 2-19-2013; Ord. No. 4192,  1, 6-7-2016; Ord. No. 4228,  I, 8-7-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4081,  1, II, adopted March 1, 2011, repealed former  26-91, and enacted a new  26-91 as set out herein. Former  26-91 pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Code 1994,  9-109; Ord. No. 3764,  I, adopted Aug. 5, 1994 and Ord. No. 3952, adopted July 5, 2006. 
State Law reference- Municipal court assessment, K.S.A. 12-4117. 
Sec. 26-92. - Maximum court and administration fee. 
    Only one docket and administration fee per defendant will be assessed regardless of the number of violations. If a defendant is charged with violations for which two different docket and administration fees could be assessed, the highest docket and administration fee will be assessed. 
(Code 1996,  9-110) 
Charter Ordinance reference- Administration and court fees, Charter Ordinance No. 15. 
Chapter 28 - OFFENSES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 28-1-28-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - UNIFORM OFFENSE CODE 

Sec. 28-19. - Incorporating Uniform Public Offense Code. 
    There is hereby incorporated by reference for the purpose of regulating public offenses within the corporation limits of the City of Wellington, Kansas, that certain code known as the "2018 Uniform Public Offense Code for Kansas Cities, 34th Edition," prepared and published in book form by the League of Kansas Municipalities, Topeka, Kansas, save and except such articles, sections, parts or portions as are hereinafter modified or changed. No fewer than three copies of said Uniform Public Offense Code shall be marked or stamped, "Official Copy as Adopted by Ordinance No. 4225," with all sections or portions thereof intended to be changed clearly marked to show any such change and to which shall be attached a copy of this article, and filed with the city clerk to be open to inspection and available to the public at all reasonable hours. 
(Ord. No. 4225,  I, 8-7-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4225,  I, IV, adopted Aug. 7, 2018, repealed  28-19 in its entirety and enacted a new  28-19 to read as set out herein. Former  28-19 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 4210,  I, V, adopted Aug. 1, 2017. 
Sec. 28-20. - Same-Amendment. 
    Section 6.8 of the 2018 Uniform Public Offense Code for the Kansas Cities, 34th Edition, is amended to read as follows: 
"6.8. Littering. 
(a)  No person shall intentionally or recklessly deposit or cause to be deposited any litter upon any public street, highway, alley, road, right-of-way, park, or other public place, or any lake, stream, water-course, or other body of water, except by direction of some public official, city employee, or law enforcement officer, authorized by law to direct or permit such acts. No person shall intentionally or recklessly deposit or cause to be deposited litter upon any private property without the consent of the owner of said property. When litter is deposited upon public or private property, there shall be a rebuttable presumption that the owner of said property had not consented thereto. 
(b)  Litter shall include, but is not necessarily limited to, rubbish, garbage, and trash, including tree limbs, yard clippings, paper, metal, plastic, glass, eggs, tomatoes, and similar items. 
(c)  Violation of this section is a Class C misdemeanor which is punishable up to 30 days in jail and/or a fine not to exceed $500.00." 
    Section 10.6 of the 2018 Uniform Public Offense Code for Kansas Cities, 34th Edition, is amended to read as follows: 
"10.6 Air Gun, Air Rifle, Slingshot, BB Gun, Paint Ball Gun or Bow and Arrow. 
(a)  The unlawful operation of an air gun, air rifle, BB gun or paint ball gun is the shooting, discharging or operating of any air gun, air rifle, slingshot, BB gun, or paint ball gun within the city, except within the confines of a building or other structure from which projectiles cannot escape, and except for special events sponsored by established and recognized organizations held in those areas of the city's public park system that are not frequently frequented by persons, if such event is (1) conducted in such a manner as to guard against and prevent injury to persons participating in the event as well as any other person or persons and damage to property; (2) approved in writing prior to the event by the Park Board and the Police Department of the city; (3) supervised by a person over the age of twenty-one (21) years; and (4) a certificate of insurance in a form satisfactory to the city, showing that the city is properly insured for all claims for injuries to persons and damage to property resulting from the special event, is filed with the city. 
(b)  The operation of a bow and arrow is the shooting, discharging or operating any bow and arrow within the city, except when shot, discharged or operated as a part of a physical education program in the regular curriculum of a public school, if said program is supervised by a qualified archer who a member of the school faculty, is conducted on school-owned property in areas not commonly frequented by people in the presence of the supervisor and in a manner as to guard against and prevent injury to persons participating in the program and to others, or except in the confines of a building or other structure from which arrows cannot escape, or except for special events sponsored by established and recognized organizations held in those areas of the city's public park system that are not frequently frequented by persons, if such event is (1) conducted in such a manner as to guard against and prevent injury to persons participating in the event as well as any other person or persons and damage to property; (2) approved in writing prior to the event by the Park Board and the Police Department of the city; (3) supervised by a person over the age of twenty-one (21) years; and (4) a certificate of insurance in a form satisfactory to the city, showing that the city is properly insured for all claims for injuries to persons and damage to property resulting from the special event, is filed with the city. 
(c)  Violation of this section is a Class C misdemeanor punishable of a fine upto $ 500.00 and/or 30 days in jail." 
(Ord. No. 4225,  II, III, 8-7-2018; Ord. No. 4260,  I, 4-2-2019) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4225,  II-IV, adopted Aug. 7, 2018, repealed  28-20 in its entirety and enacted a new  28-20 to read as set out herein. Former  28-20 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 4210,  II-IV, adopted Aug. 1, 2017. 
Secs. 28-21-28-43. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CITY OFFENSES 

Sec. 28-44. - Penalties. 
    Unless otherwise specified, the penalties for violation of any of the sections in this article will be classed in the manner set out in article 12 of the Uniform Public Offense Ordinance for Kansas Cities, as incorporated by reference by section 28-19. 
(Code 1988; Code 1996,  11-201) 
Sec. 28-45. - Theft, destruction of fruit or vegetables. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maliciously or mischievously enter the enclosure of any person and pick, destroy or carry away any fruit or vegetables of any tree, shrub, bush or vine. 
(Code 1974,  18-203; Code 1996,  11-202) 
Sec. 28-46. - Loitering; communicating with prisoners. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to loiter around or about the city jail or communicate with any prisoner detained therein, or deliver any parcel or thing to any prisoner without first having obtained permission from the officer in charge of the jail. 
(b)  Violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation. 
(Code 1974,  18-707; Code 1996,  11-203) 
Sec. 28-47. - Blasting. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to blast or cause to be blasted rocks, stumps or other material without having the same covered in such good and sufficient manner so as to prevent any fragment or rock or other material from ascending into the air, and having first obtained permission from the governing body, and placed sufficient guards so as to prevent damage or injury to person or property. 
(b)  Violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation. 
(Code 1974,  18-714; Code 1996,  11-204) 
Sec. 28-48. - Bill posting. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to place or cause to be placed any posters, signs or advertising matter on any telephone, telegraph or light poles or posts, or place or post any bills, advertisements or posters on any building or public place without the consent of the owner or person in control of such building, or the governing body in the case of public buildings. 
(b)  Violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation. 
(Code 1974,  18-715; Code 1996,  11-205) 
Sec. 28-49. - Taking public property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to take possession of any property, real or personal, belonging to the city or to the possession of which the city is entitled or to commit any willful trespass thereon or to unlawfully withhold the possession thereof from the city. 
(b)  The unlawful withholding of the same after due demand shall constitute a new and separate offense and shall be punished in like manner as herein provided for unlawfully taking possession thereof. 
(c)  Taking public property shall be punishable as a Class C violation. 
(Code 1974,  18-213; Code 1996,  11-206) 
Sec. 28-50. - Indecent exposure. 
(a)  Indecent exposure of person is appearing in any public place in a state of nudity. 
(b)  Indecent exposure is a Class B violation, and any person appearing in a public place in a state of nudity shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished in accordance with the Uniform Public Offenses Ordinances for Kansas Cities, as adopted in section 28-19. 
(Code 1996,  11-207; Ord. No. 3397,  1) 
Sec. 28-51. - Public defecation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to urinate or defecate in or upon any public street, highway, alley, roadway or other public place. 
(b)  Violation of this article shall be punishable as a Class B violation under article 12 of the Uniform Public Offense Code for Kansas Cities. 
(Code 1996,  11-208; Ord. No. 3445,  1) 
Sec. 28-52. - Disturbing the peace. 
(a)  Statement of purpose. It is the purpose of this section to protect individuals in the city from unreasonable intrusions caused by excessive, unnecessary, unreasonable or unusually loud noises; it is not the intent or purpose of this section to limit or abridge the rights of any person to peacefully assemble and express opinions, and no provision of this section shall be so construed. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue, maintain or cause to be made or continued any excessive, unnecessary, unreasonable or unusually loud noise or any noise, which either annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others within the city. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use, operate or permit the use or operation of any electronic device, radio receiving set, television, musical instrument, phonograph, or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants or at any time with louder volume than is necessary for convenient hearing of the person who are in the room, vehicle or chamber in which such machine or device is operated and who are voluntary listeners thereto. Neighboring inhabitants shall include persons living within or occupying residential districts of single or multifamily dwellings and shall include areas where multiple-unit dwellings and high-density residential districts are located. 
(d)  No person shall congregate with other persons because of, participate in, or being any part or gathering of people from which sound emanates of a sufficient volume so as to disturb the peace, quiet or repose of persons residing in any residential area. No person shall visit or remain within any residential dwelling unit or within the vicinity of a residential dwelling unit wherein such party or gathering of people is taking place except persons who have gone there for the sole purpose of abating the disturbance. A police officer may order all person present in any group or gathering from which such sound emanates, other than the owners or tenants of the dwelling unit, to immediately disperse in lieu of being charged under this section. Owners or tenants of the dwelling unit shall immediately abate the disturbance and, failing to do so, shall be in violation of this section. 
(e)  Any person who shall violate the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not more than $100.00, or be imprisoned for not more than 30 days, or be both so fined and imprisoned. 
(Code 1996,  11-209; Ord. No. 3566,  1, 2) 
Sec. 28-53. - Curfew hours declared; exception.
