    It shall be unlawful for any minor under the age of 16 years of age to loiter, idle, wander, stroll, or play in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds, or other public grounds, public places and public buildings, places of amusement and entertainment, vacant lots or other unsupervised places between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the following day, except on Fridays and Saturdays, when the hours shall be 12:00 midnight to 6:00 a.m.; provided however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to a minor accompanied by the minor's parent, guardian, or other adult person having the care and custody of the minor, or where the minor is upon an emergency errand of legitimate business directed by the minor's parent, guardian or other person having the care and custody of the minor. 
(Code 1996,  11-210; Ord. No. 3549,  1) 
Sec. 28-54. - Responsibility of parent, or person having custody. 
    It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of a minor under the age of 16 years to permit such minor to loiter, idle, wander, stroll or play in or upon the public street, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public grounds, public places and public building, places of amusement and entertainment, vacant lots or other unsupervised places, between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the following day; provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply when the minor is accompanied by the minor's parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of the minor, or where the minor is upon an emergency errand or legitimate business directed by the minor's parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of the minor. 
(Code 1996,  11-211; Ord. No. 3549,  2) 
Sec. 28-55. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any minor violating the provisions of sections 28-53 and 28-54 shall be dealt with in accordance with the provisions of the Kansas Juvenile Justice Code (K.S.A. ch. 38, art. 16). 
(b)  Any parent, guardian or person in charge of a minor, who shall permit such minor to violate the provisions of sections 28-53 and 28-54 after having been notified of a prior violation by such minor, shall be fined in an amount not less than $5.00 and not more than $100.00. 
(Code 1996,  11-212; Ord. No. 3549,  3) 
Sec. 28-56. - Loitering. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Loitering means remaining idle in essentially one location and includes the concept of spending time idly; to be dilatory; to linger; to stay; to saunter; to delay; to stand around; and shall also include the colloquial expression hanging around. 
    Public place means any place to which the general public has access and a right to resort for business, entertainment or other lawful purpose, but does not necessarily mean a place devoted solely to the uses of the public. It shall also include the front or immediate area of any store, shop, restaurant, tavern or other place of business and also public ground, areas or parks. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter, loaf, wander, stand or remain idle either alone and, or in consort with others in a public place in such a manner so as to: 
(1)  Obstruct any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building or hindering or impeding to tending to hinder or impede the free and uninterrupted passage of vehicles, traffic or pedestrians; 
(2)  Commit in or upon any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building any act or thing which is an obstruction or interference to the free and uninterrupted use of property or with any business lawfully conducted by anyone in or upon or facing or fronting on any such public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building, all of which prevents the free and uninterrupted ingress, egress and regress therein, thereon and thereto. 
(c)  When any person causes or commits any of the conditions enumerated in subsection (a) of this section, a police officer or any law enforcement officer shall order that person at stop causing or committing such conditions and to move on or disperse. Any person who fails or refuses to obey such orders shall be guilty of a violation of the provisions of this section. 
(d)  Any person who shall violate the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not more than $100.00, or imprisoned for not more than 30 days, or be both so fined and imprisoned. 
(Code 1996,  11-213; Ord. No. 3634,  1, 2) 
Sec. 28-57. - Smoking in public places. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Public meeting includes all meetings open to the public. 
    Public place means enclosed indoor areas open to the public or used by the general public including, but not limited to: restaurants, retail stores, public means of mass transportation, passenger elevators, health care institutions or any other place where health care services are provided to the public, educational facilities, libraries, courtrooms, state, county or municipal buildings, restrooms, grocery stores, school buses, museums, theaters, auditoriums, arenas and recreational facilities. 
    Smoking means possession of a lighted cigarette, cigar, pipe or any other lighted smoking equipment. 
(b)  Prohibited; exceptions, designation smoking areas. 
(1)  No person shall smoke in a public place or at a public meeting except in designated smoking areas. 
(2)  Smoking areas may be designated by proprietors or other person in charge of public places, except in passenger elevators, school buses, public means of mass transportation and any other place in which smoking is prohibited by the fire marshal or by other law, ordinance or regulation. 
(3)  Where smoking areas are designated, existing physical barriers and ventilation shall be used to minimize the toxic effect of smoke in adjacent nonsmoking areas. 
(c)  Signs and designated smoking areas; authorizing proprietor or person in charge of public place to establish designated smoking areas. The proprietor or other person in charge of the premises of a public place shall post or cause to be posted in a conspicuous place signs clearly stating that smoking is prohibited by state law and by ordinances of the city. The person in charge of the premises shall also post or cause to be posted in any designated smoking area, signs stating that smoking is permitted in such room or area. The proprietor or person in charge of the public place shall have the authority to establish the percentage of area in the public place which shall be posted and designated as a smoking area. 
(Code 1996,  11-214-11-216; Ord. No. 3647,  1-3) 
Sec. 28-58. - Parades throwing objects. 
    It shall be unlawful for any participant in any parade in the city at any time during a parade in the city: 
(1)  To throw, toss, drop, deposit or in any way place, or permit to be thrown, tossed, dropped, deposited or placed in or on the path of floats, vehicles or other units or entries in such parade any candy, gum, foodstuff of any kind whatsoever, or any other object of value that would be likely to entice children into the path of a float, vehicle or other units or entries in the parade; or 
(2)  To throw or toss or permit to be thrown or tossed into the crowd of spectators assembled along the route of the parade any thing or object which might reasonably be anticipated to cause personal injury if such thing or object struck a person. Violators of this section may be forthwith removed from the parade. 
(Code 1996,  11-217; Ord. No. 3699,  1) 
Sec. 28-59. - Window peeping. 
    Any person who shall enter upon private property without the express permission of the owner or person in lawful possession thereof and while thereon, or from adjacent or nearby public or private property, with or without the use of ocular aids, look or peep into any window, door, skylight or other opening in a dwelling house, or apartment or roominghouse, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00, or not to exceed six months in jail, or be both so fined and imprisoned. 
(Code 1996,  11-218; Ord. No. 3740,  1) 
Chapter 30 - PUBLIC PROPERTY 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 30-1-30-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKS AND RECREATION AREAS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- City parks, K.S.A. 12-1301 et seq.; recreation systems, K.S.A. 12-1922 et seq.; park commission, K.S.A. 14-537; maintenance of parks, K.S.A. 14-538. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 30-19-30-39. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PARK BOARD 

Sec. 30-40. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a city park board to be comprised of five members. 
(Code 1996,  12-101; Ord. No. 3094,  1; Ord. No. 4077,  I, 3-1-2011) 
Sec. 30-41. - Members. 
    One of the members of said board shall be either the mayor or a city councilmember who shall serve as chairperson of the board. The remaining four members of the board shall be appointed by the governing body and shall be residents and taxpayers of the city. No member of the board shall be related by blood or marriage to a member of the governing body of the city or to any officer of the city government. 
(Code 1974,  15-102, 15-103; Code 1996,  12-102, 12-103; Ord. No. 3887,  V, 11-18-2003; Ord. No. 3982,  V, 12-5-2006; Ord. No. 4077,  I, 3-1-2011) 
Sec. 30-42. - Term of office. 
(a)  Commencing no later than at the last regular meeting of the governing body in April 2011, the governing body shall appoint either the mayor or city council member to serve an unlimited term commencing April 19, 2011, subject to resignation, retirement, or not being reelected to the governing body. The governing body shall appoint members to three positions to serve commencing April 19, 2011 through April 30, 2013. Thereafter, one of these positions shall be allowed to expire. In the future, as each of these terms expires for the remaining two positions, the governing body shall appoint members to these positions to serve a term of four years commencing May 1st. Any member appointed to serve a four-year term after January 1, 2013, shall not serve more than two consecutive four-year terms. 
(b)  Also commencing no later than at the last regular meeting of the governing body in April 2011, the governing body shall appoint members to three positions to serve a term commencing April 19, 2011 through April 30, 2015. Thereafter, one of these positions shall be allowed to expire. In the future, as each of these terms expires for the remaining two positions, the governing body shall appoint members to these positions to serve a term of four years commencing May 1st. Any member appointed to serve a four-year term after January 1, 2013, shall not serve more than two consecutive four-year terms. 
(c)  Any member of the board may be removed by the city manager, at his discretion, for misfeasance, nonfeasance, or malfeasance, but only after he conducts an inquiry into any complaint about a member. Furthermore, if any member fails to attend three consecutive regularly scheduled or special meetings where an official vote is required, then the position shall be considered vacated, and the member shall not be eligible to reapply for a board or commission position for a period of one year. The board chairman shall submit an attendance report to the city clerk within ten business days after each meeting. 
(d)  Vacancies shall be filled by the governing body for the unexpired term. All members of said board will serve without compensation. 
(Code 1974,  15-104; Code 1996,  12-104; Ord. No. 3887,  VI, 11-18-2003; Ord. No. 3982,  VI, 12-5-2006; Ord. No. 4077,  I, 3-1-2011; Ord. No. 4160,  V, 7-1-2014) 
Editor's note- See  2-86 editor's note. 
Sec. 30-43. - Powers and duties. 
    The parks of the city shall be under control and management of the park board and they shall make suitable rules and regulations for the care and government of such parks, and are hereby authorized to recommend to the governing body penalties for violation by any person of the rules and regulations so made. The park board is directed to make recommendations each year to the city governing body for the support and maintenance of the parks of the city. 
(Code 1974,  15-105; Code 1996,  12-105) 
Secs. 30-44-30-74. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PARK REGULATIONS 

Sec. 30-75. - City laws extended to parks. 
    The laws of the city shall extend to and over the area of all municipal parks and cemeteries. 
(Code 1996,  12-201; Ord. No. 3095,  3) 
Sec. 30-76. - Acts prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful within the public parks and park nursery of the city and upon the land acquired by the city in the east half of section 11 south, Township 32 south, Range 1 west of the 6th Principal Meridian in Sumner County, Kansas, for flood control purposes in the Hargis Creek Watershed: 
(1)  To drive, park, ride, lead or otherwise permit any automobile, bicycle, whether motorized or not, or horses or other livestock, or any means of conveyance whatsoever other than by a person walking under the person's own muscular power elsewhere in any park of the city or on the land in the Hargis Creek Watershed described in this section other than upon improved roadways and parking areas therein. This provision shall not prohibit the use of golf carts on the Wellington Municipal Golf Course, except as hereinafter set forth. The governing body may, by resolution, designate parts of the Hargis Creek Watershed land for specific uses and may exempt the land so designated from the provision of this subsection. This provision shall not prohibit parking on the grass immediately to the right of the improved roadway in city parks unless it is otherwise posted as a no parking area, nor shall it apply to occasions where permission has been granted by the City of Wellington for a location within any park of the city. 
(2)  To go upon the greens and aprons thereof on the Wellington Municipal Golf Course other than by a person walking under the person's own muscular power or to drive or take golf carts or other vehicles upon the greens or the aprons thereof; 
(3)  To ride or drive any automobile or other vehicle including golf cart, work site utility vehicle, micro-utility truck, or all-terrain vehicle, over or along the roadways in any park in said city or on the land above described in the Hargis Creek Watershed, except areas designated by resolution under subsection (1) of this section, at a speed exceeding 20 miles per hour. 
(4)  To enter, move, interfere with or disturb any boat, canoe, or other kind of watercraft, the same being the property of another; 
(5)  To drop or throw into any grass or timber, which is sufficiently dry to be flammable, any lighted match, cigar, cigarette or other thing which will cause such dry grass or trees or other inflammable material to become ignited and burn; 
(6)  To make a fire for any purpose on the grounds of the parks or the land in the Hargis Creek Watershed described in this section, except by city employees acting under the direction of their duly constituted foreman, and except at the places provided for the cooking of food; 
(7)  To camp without the written permission of the city manager or the city manager's duly authorized agent; 
(8)  To go upon the dam, the emergency spillway, or any part thereof, located on the land in the Hargis Creek Watershed described in this section, except by a person walking under the person's own muscular power; 
(9)  To dive, jump, or enter the waters of Slate Creek from the dam located on the Slate Creek south of Doughnut Bay in Wood's Park; 
(10)  No such person may take more than three black bass per day, each of which must be at least 15 inches in length and no person may take more than five channel catfish per day, each of which must be at least 16 inches in length; or other fish species as posted by the park board or in accordance with Kansas Fish and Game Commission creel limits and regulations; 
(11)  Swimming in Wood's Park is prohibited. 
(Code 1996,  12-202; Ord. No. 3535,  1; Ord. No. 4050,  XI, 9-1-2009; Ord. No. 4091,  I, 7-5-2011; Ord. No. 4122,  I, 9-18-2012; Ord. No. 4123,  7, 11-20-2012) 
Sec. 30-77. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate section 30-76(1), (3), (4), (5), (6), (7), (8), (10), (11) or (12) shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not more than $100.00, or be imprisoned for not more than 60 days, or be both so fined and imprisoned. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate section 30-76(2) or (9) shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined $250.00, or be imprisoned for not more than 30 days, or be both so fined and imprisoned. 
(Code 1996,  12-203; Ord. No. 3593,  1) 
Sec. 30-78. - Hargis Creek Watershed Park-Rules and requirements. 
    The following rules, regulations, provisions and licensing requirements are hereby established for the area known as Hargis Creek Watershed Park in the city: 
(1)  Canoes, sailboats, rowboats, and boats powered by electric trolling motors shall be permitted on the waters of Hargis Creek Watershed Park, and all other boats, including boats powered by gasoline motors, are prohibited on the waters. 
(2)  Camping in Hargis Creek Watershed Park is prohibited. 
(3)  The parking of vehicles, boats, trailers, or other equipment of any nature whatsoever on boat ramps in Hargis Creek Watershed Park is prohibited. 
(4)  Pole fishing only shall be permitted in the waters of Hargis Creek Watershed Park. Only two poles per person may be set in the waters of the park, and all fishing lines of whatsoever kind shall be attended at all times. No person shall take any fish from the waters of the park by use of a seine. 
(5)  Hunting in Hargis Creek Watershed Park is prohibited. Dogs shall be permitted to run at-large in the park when under the direct supervision and control of the owner, keeper or harborer of the dog. 
(6)  Swimming in Hargis Creek Watershed Park is prohibited. 
(Code 1996,  12-204; Ord. No. 3735,  1; Ord. No. 3770,  1, 10-21-1997; Ord. No. 3926, 4-5-2005) 
Sec. 30-79. - Same-Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the rules, regulations, provisions and licensing requirements made and established by section 30-78, shall upon conviction thereof be fined not more than $100.00, or be imprisoned for not more than 30 days, or be both so fined and imprisoned, and, in the discretion of the judge of the municipal court, any license issued under such rules, regulations, provisions and licensing requirements may be revoked. 
(Code 1996,  12-205; Ord. No. 3495,  2) 
Secs. 30-80-30-101. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WELLINGTON LAKE 

Sec. 30-102. - Establishment. 
    There is hereby established an area to be known as the Wellington Lake Recreation Area located on real estate owned by the City of Wellington, Kansas, in Sumner County, Kansas. 
(Code 1996,  12-301; Ord. No. 3660,  1) 
Sec. 30-103. - Declaration of policy. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy of the city to provide to the residents of the city and its environs as well as the present water customers of the city a supply of potable water from the waters of Wellington Lake and at the same time promote the safe and prudent use by the public of The Wellington Lake Recreation Area for recreational purposes in a manner compatible with the maintenance of the waters of Wellington Lake as a municipal water supply. 
(Code 1996,  12-302; Ord. No. 3660,  3) 
Sec. 30-104. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alcoholic liquor means alcohol, spirits, wine, beer and every liquid or solid, patented or not, containing alcohol, spirits, wine or beer and capable of being consumed as a beverage by a human being, but shall not include any cereal malt beverage. 
    Bicycle means every device propelled by human power upon which any person may ride, having two tandem wheels either of which is more than 14 inches in diameter. 
    Cereal malt beverage means any fermented but undistilled liquor brewed or made from malt or from a mixture of malt or malt substitute, but does not include any such liquor which is more than 3.2 percent alcohol by weight. 
    City means the City of Wellington, Kansas. 
    Commercial activity means any activity which involves the buying and selling of any goods, wares and merchandise or the providing of any service of any nature whatsoever, or the renting or leasing boats or other recreational equipment or sporting goods of any sort for a valuable consideration. 
    Concessionaire means any person, firm, association or corporation that by written contract with the governing body of the city has been granted the right to conduct a commercial activity in the Wellington Lake Recreation Area. 
    Craft means any boat or vessel designed for use on water. 
    Household means all members of one family living together at a single residence. 
    Lake means all waters impounded by the dam located in the Wellington Lake Recreation Area. 
    Motor vehicle means every vehicle, other than a motorized bicycle which is self-propelled. 
    Motorcycle means every motor vehicle having a seat or saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor. 
    Motor-driven cycle means every motorcycle, including every motor scooter, with a motor which produces not to exceed five brake horsepower, and every bicycle with motor attached. 
    Nonresident means any person who does not maintain a permanent resident within Sumner County, Kansas. 
    Officer means any person authorized or designated by the city to enforce all rules and regulations set forth in this article, including members of the city police department, the county sheriff's department and the state highway patrol as well as any person authorized or designated by the state or the United States government or any agency thereof to enforce any state or federal laws, rules or regulations applicable to the Wellington Lake Recreation Area or any activities permitted or carried on in the recreation area. 
    Recreation area supervisor means the person appointed by the city manager to oversee the operation and maintenance of the recreational facilities in the area and the use of the area, including the use of the waters of Wellington Lake for recreational purposes, by the public. 
    Resident means any person who maintains a permanent residence within Sumner County, Kansas. 
    Roadway means those areas in the recreation area which are specifically designed and improved for vehicular travel. 
    Vehicle means every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon an highway, except devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Code 1996,  12-303; Ord. No. 3660,  4) 
Sec. 30-105. - Recreation permit. 
(a)  All persons desiring to use the Wellington Recreation Area for any purpose other than for sightseeing and fishing shall first obtain a recreation permit for the person's vehicle from the recreation area supervisor or the recreation area supervisor's duly authorized agent and pay the fees established therefore. Additional permits may be purchased for vehicles owned by members of the same household for the prescribed fees. The permit shall be issued for the vehicle owned by the person requesting the permit and stickers showing that a permit has been issued shall be provided for attachment to the vehicle for which the same was issued. The permit shall entitle the owner of the vehicle to use the facilities of the recreation area for recreational purposes. Vehicles entering the recreation area without a permit for any purpose other than sightseeing and fishing shall be in violation of this section and shall be subject to penalties set forth in section 30-118. 
(b)  Fees for recreation permits and additional permits are as as set by the governing body and on file in the city clerk's office. 
(c)  The fees for permits shall be in addition to fees established in sections 30-106, 30-107(h), and 30-109 for specific activities. 
(Code 1996,  12-304; Ord. No. 3681,  1; Ord. No. 3926, 4-5-2005; Ord. No. 4172,  I, 12-16-2014) 
Sec. 30-106. - Boating; rules and regulations; fees. 
(a)  Boat operation permitted; exceptions. Subject to the rules and regulations and upon the payment of boating fees hereinafter set forth, the operation of boats on the waters of Wellington Lake shall be permitted at all times except during those periods of time designated by the state department of wildlife and parks as seasons for the hunting of water fowl and game birds and animals in the county, provided however, that during such hunting seasons boats propelled only by human power and boats with trolling motors may be used with extreme caution for the purpose of placing or removing decoys and blinds. Hydroplanes, aero propellers, and houseboats shall not be permitted on the waters of Wellington Lake. 
(b)  Licenses. Before any boat shall be operated on the waters of Wellington Lake a license for such boat shall be obtained from the lake supervisor. If the boat to be licensed is a motor boat or a sail powered boat satisfactory evidence that the boat is insured for public liability and property damage with a single limit coverage of not less than $25,000.00 shall be furnished the lake supervisor before a license is issued. No license shall be issued unless the appropriate fee as hereinafter set forth has been collected by the lake supervisor. 
(c)  Hours. No boats, except fishing boats being operated at a speed that produces no visible wake, shall be operated on the waters of Wellington Lake between one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise. 
(d)  Launching. Motorboats shall be launched on and removed from the waters of Wellington Lake only at designated launching areas. Small human powered boats may be launched where convenient. 
(e)  Life jackets. Approved life jackets sufficient in number to supply one jacket to each occupant of the boat shall be carried on all boats. Persons 12 years of age and under shall actually wear an approved life jacket at all times such person is on a boat. 
(f)  Traffic. Boats shall travel in a generally counterclockwise direction on the waters of Wellington Lake; boats shall turn to the right when meeting another boat; when overtaking another boat the overtaking boats shall turn to the left; boats approaching each other at right angles shall give the right-of-way to the boat on the right; motor powered boats shall at all times give the right-of-way to sailboats and human powered boats. 
(g)  Rough waters. Notwithstanding contrary language in this article, no person shall operate a boat on the waters of Wellington Lake when the waters of the lake are sufficiently rough to be considered dangerous. 
(h)  Swimming. No boat shall proceed into any area of the waters of Wellington Lake, which is designated and marked as a swimming area. 
(i)  Boat trailers. Boat trailers shall be parked only in this area of the Wellington Lake recreation area as are specifically designated and marked for boat trailer parking. 
(j)  Transporation for hire. No person, other than a duly authorized concessionaire, shall carry or transport any person upon the waters of Wellington Lake for hire, or for any valuable consideration whatsoever. 
(k)  Duty to render assistance. All owners and/or operators of boats on the waters Wellington Lake shall render assistance at times of emergency and in the enforcement of these rules and regulations when called upon by the recreation area supervisor or the recreation area supervisor's duly authorized representative. 
(l)  Boat docks. Boat docks are provided on Wellington Lake for the purpose of loading and unloading onto and from boats, and no privately owned boat docks shall be constructed or maintained on the waters of Wellington Lake. 
(m)  Water skiing. Water skiing shall be permitted on the waters of Wellington Lake in those areas designated for water skiing; when meeting or passing other boats, skiers shall take and maintain a position behind the skiers towing boat until the other boat is safely passed; skiers shall be retrieved from the water as soon as possible after the skier falls from the skis into the water; no boat shall be operated with ski lines behind the boat unless a skier is being towed or retrieved from the water. Water skiers shall wear approved ski vests. 
(n)  Boat fees. Boat fees shall be as set by the governing body and on file in the city clerk's office. Such fees which shall be in addition to fees charged for a recreation permit, shall be charged for boating on the waters of Wellington Lake except for boats used only for fishing purposes. 
(Code 1996,  12-305; Ord. No. 3660,  6; Ord. No. 3926, 4-5-2005; Ord. No. 4172,  I, 12-16-2014) 
Sec. 30-107. - Camping; rules and regulations; fees. 
(a)  Camping shall be permitted in those parts of the Wellington Lake Recreation Area which are designed, marked and posted for camping and in no other parts of the recreation area by any person who holds a valid recreation permit for the Wellington Recreation Area. Primitive camping will be permitted in areas designated therefore, but will not be permitted in camping areas served by electricity. Such camping shall be in conformity with the camping fees hereinafter specified. No advance reservations will be made for the utilization of any camping area provided with electrical drops or hook-ups. 
(b)  Any person desiring to set up camp shall first pay the lake supervisor the appropriate camping fee in accordance with the schedule of fees hereinafter set forth and obtain from the supervisor the assignment of a camp site location and number, and the camper shall use the assigned site and no other site. 
(c)  No camper or other person shall make any connection to water outlets in the Wellington Recreation Area for a period longer than necessary to fill water tanks or storage facilities on a trailer, mobile home, camper or recreational vehicle. 
(d)  Only vehicles using electrical outlets provided for campers shall be parked near such outlets. Any other vehicles parked near said electric outlets will be required to pay camping fees for the additional vehicle. No 30 amp electrical adapters shall be plugged into or used in 15 amp outlets. 
(e)  Shelter houses in the Wellington Lake Recreation Area shall not be used for camping, nor shall any electric outlets in said shelter houses be used to supply electrical power to trailers, mobile homes, campers, trailers or other recreational vehicles. 
(f)  No trailer, mobile home, camper or other recreation vehicle shall be parked in boat ramp areas in the Wellington Lake Recreation Area. 
(g)  During cold weather, public restrooms in the recreation area will be closed and will not be available for use by campers; campers using the recreation area during time when the public restrooms are closed must provide or make provision for their own restroom facilities. 
(h)  Camping fees. The fees shall be as set by the governing body and on file in the city clerk's office. Such fees which shall be, in addition to fees charged for a Recreation Permit, shall be charged for camping in the Wellington Lake Recreation Area: 
(i)  Camping in the Wellington Lake Recreation Area between the first day of waterfowl season each year and the following March 1 shall be allowed only in the area designated as "Old West". 
(Code 1996,  12-306; Ord. No. 3660,  7; Ord. No. 3775,  1, 2-4-1997; Ord. No. 3834,  I, 12-18-2001; Ord. No. 4172,  I, 12-16-2014; Ord. No. 4189,  I, 12-1-2015) 
Sec. 30-108. - Fishing; rules and regulations. 
(a)  Fishing shall be permitted in the waters of Wellington Lake by all persons. Those who are required to hold a valid fishing license issued by the state must do so. No unattended fishing lines, including drop lines, may be used between sunrise and sunset, and no trout lines or link lines may be used at any time. 
(b)  To ensure quality fishing in the waters of Wellington Lake in the future the size and possession limits of fish taken shall be as provided by state law. 
(Code 1996,  12-307(c); Ord. No. 3681,  2; Ord. No. 3801,  I, 5-4-1999; Ord. No. 3926, 4-5-2005) 
Sec. 30-109. - Hunting; rules and regulations; fees. 
(a)  The hunting of water fowl in the Wellington Lake Recreation Area shall be permitted during seasons established by the state for the hunting of waterfowl in the county, and at no other time. The hunting of upland game birds, fur-bearing animals, deer and predatory animals, as well as the trapping of fur-bearing animals in the recreation area is at all times prohibited. 
(b)  The display or discharge of firearms in the Wellington Lake Recreation Area, except during a state-established waterfowl season is prohibited. 
(c)  Those persons who are required to hold a valid hunting license issued by the state, must also hold a valid Wellington Recreation Area waterfowl hunting permit and all persons must hold a valid recreation permit for the Wellington Lake Recreation Area. 
(d)  The fees shall be as set by the governing body and on file in the city clerk's office. Upon the payment of the fees and the showing by the hunter that, if required, holds a valid hunting license issued by the state and such waterfowl stamps as are required by the state and the government of the United States, the recreation area supervisor, or the recreation area supervisor's duly authorized agent shall issue to the hunter a license to hunt waterfowl in the recreation area in accordance with the rules and regulations in this article. 
(Code 1996,  12-308; Ord. No. 3681,  9; Ord. No. 4172,  I, 12-16-2014) 
Sec. 30-110. - Picnicking; use of shelter houses. 
(a)  Picnicking shall be permitted in all areas of the Wellington Lake Recreation Area with purchase of the recreation permit which are safe and suitable for that purpose and in shelter houses therein located; picnic tables and shelter houses in the area are available for use on a first come first served basis, and no advance reservations shall be made for the utilization of the same except large rock shelter located at Eagle Cove. All picnickers shall be responsible for the policing of the picnic area or shelter they have used to see that all food, waste paper, paper cups, dishes and other utensils and containers used is property disposed of and the area left in a neat and orderly condition for the next user. 
(b)  Shelter houses are not to be used for camping of any kind whatsoever, nor shall campers use electrical outlets at shelter houses in connection with camping activities. 
(Code 1996,  12-309; Ord. No. 3660,  10) 
Sec. 30-111. - Swimming. 
(a)  Swimming will be permitted in the swimming beach area of the waters of Wellington Lake located in the southwest corner of the lake and marked by buoys establishing in the limits of the swimming area; when buoys are not in place no swimming will be permitted; swimming may be restricted when, in the opinion of the recreation area supervisor, the waters of Lake Wellington are, for any reason unsafe for swimmers; a recreation permit shall be required for swimming. 
(b)  No lifeguards will be provided in the swimming area and swimmer will assume all risks of injury which may result from such swimming; children under the age of 12 years must be accompanied by an adult; no glass, alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverages, or dogs will be permitted in the swimming beach area; the area shall be closed from one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise. 
(Code 1996,  12-310; Ord. No. 3660,  11) 
Sec. 30-112. - Archery. 
    The sport of archery, whether for purposes of practice, or archery competition or otherwise, shall not be permitted in the Wellington Lake Recreation Area without specific written authority from the city. Such authority shall not be granted unless adequate insurance coverage is provided to protect the city as well as others using the recreation area and surrounding territory against personal injury and property damage resulting from shooting bows and arrows, each participant in the sport agrees in writing to abide by and comply with all rules, regulations and requirements set forth in this article and in the written document granting such authority, and unless the city park board recommends that such authority be granted. 
(Code 1996,  12-311; Ord. No. 3660,  12) 
Sec. 30-113. - Commercial activities. 
    Commercial activities may be carried on in the Wellington Lake Recreation Area only by persons who have by written agreement with the city obtained approval to carry on such activity. 
(Code 1996,  12-312; Ord. No. 3660,  13) 
Sec. 30-114. - Special events. 
    The governing body of the city may at any time permit especial events at the Wellington Lake Recreation Area by large groups or by the community as a whole and to close such parts of the recreation area for such period of time as deemed necessary to accommodate such special event. A special event, for purposes of this section, shall be deemed to be an event which occurs or is held not more frequently than once a year and which extends for no longer than two consecutive days and in which an unusually large number of persons would participate. 
(Code 1996,  12-313; Ord. No. 3660,  14) 
Sec. 30-115. - Rights reserved by city. 
    Because the waters of Wellington Lake serve as the water supply for residents of the city and its environs as well as for several rural water districts, the city shall have the right, notwithstanding any language herein that may be construed to the contrary, at any time to change, amend, repeal or suspend for any period of time recreational privileges granted by this article in order to protect such water supply for human consumption, and such action by the city may be taken without any requirement that permit and license fees collected under the provisions of this article be refunded to the person from whom such fees were collected. 
(Code 1996,  12-314; Ord. No. 3660,  15) 
Sec. 30-116. - Acts prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to do any of the following acts in the Wellington Lake Recreation area: 
(1)  To sell, possess or consume alcohol liquor unless the governing body agrees to enter into an agreement for the purpose of providing live entertainment on specific dates and times within a designated area to be agreed upon between the contracting parties located within the Wellington Lake Recreation area. 
(2)  To drive any vehicles at a speed greater than as posted. 
(3)  To drive any vehicle, including dune buggies, at any place except on roadways. 
(4)  To park or leave unattended any vehicle on any roadway in such a manner as to block or impede traffic. 
(5)  To violate any traffic laws of the state. 
(6)  To permit domestic pets or farm animals to run at large, except that hunting dogs shall be permitted to run at large during hunting seasons if kept under the control of the owner. 
(7)  To transport any person on the waters of Wellington Lake for hire or for any valuable consideration without a valid concessionaires written agreement from the city. 
(8)  To building, start, or maintain a fire in or about the Wellington Lake Recreation Area except in permanent fireplaces, grills or other facilities provided in the area. 
(9)  To engage in or solicit any business in any manner whatsoever, including the dissemination or posting of handbills and notices without a valid concessionaire's agreement or specific permission granted by resolution of the governing body of the city. 
(10)  To throw or leave along any roadway or on the ground in any picnic, camping, any refuse, garbage, rubbish, sewage, gray water or waste of any kind. 
(11)  To dispose of any refuse, garbage, rubbish, sewage, gray water and water of any kind whatsoever except in depositaries provided therefore. 
(12)  To in any manner pollute the waters of Wellington Lake. 
(13)  It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to go upon the dam, the emergency spillway, or any part thereof, located at Lake Wellington which is within the city limits except by a person under the person's own muscular power. 
(14)  To make a false statement or representation in order to secure a permit, license or agreement provided for therein. 
(15)  Any non-licensed vehicles, including, but not limited to, ATVs, go-carts and dirt bikes are not permitted on lake property or roadways. 
(Code 1996,  12-315; Ord. No. 3628,  1; Ord. No. 3660,  16; Ord. No. 3926, 4-5-2005; Ord. No. 4037,  I, 4-7-2009) 
Sec. 30-117. - Enforcing officer. 
    The city manager or the city manager's duly authorized agency shall have the duty to enforce ordinances of the city pertaining to the Wellington Lake Recreation Area. 
(Code 1996,  12-316; Ord. No. 3660,  17) 
Sec. 30-118. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate section 30-106(a) shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not more than $200.00, or be imprisoned for not more than 30 days, or be both so fined and imprisoned. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate section 30-116(12) and (13) shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not more than $500.00, or be imprisoned for not more than 30 days, and in addition thereto may be ordered by the municipal court to make restitution to the city for damages resulting from such violation. 
(c)  Any person who shall violate any provision of this article relating to traffic or to alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverage shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished in the manner provided for in other ordinances of the city relating to such conduct. 
(d)  Any person who shall violate any provisions, section and subsections of this article not specifically set forth in section 30-116(1), (2) and (3) shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not more than $100.00, or be imprisoned for not more than 30 days, or be both so fined and imprisoned. 
(e)  In addition to the foregoing penalties nay violator of the provisions of this article or the applicable laws of the state may be removed from the Wellington Lake Recreation Area and barred from further use of such recreation area until the violator complies with or demonstrates to the governing body that the violator can comply with this article and the laws of the state in the future. 
(f)  In addition to the foregoing penalties the boating privileges of any person who habitually operates a boat on the waters of Wellington Lake in a wanton and reckless manner may be forfeited or terminated. 
(Code 1996,  12-318; Ord. No. 3660,  18) 
Secs. 30-119-30-149. - Reserved.

    There is hereby created a fund of the city, to be known as the Wellington Golf Course Trust Fund, into which there shall be deposited all gifts, donations and bequests for the purposes set out in section 30-195. 
(Code 1996,  12-403(a); Ord. No. 3254,  1, 2) 
Sec. 30-195. - Purpose.

Secs. 30-196-30-211. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Golf Course Reserve Fund 

Sec. 30-212. - Created. 
    There is hereby created and established, pursuant to K.S.A. Supp. 12-1,118, a fund of the city to be known as the Golf Course Capital Improvement Reserve Fund which fund shall be used for the purpose of financing in whole or in part, any public improvement need for the golf course, including the repair, restoration and rehabilitation of existing facilities. 
(Code 1996,  12-404; Ord. No. 3599,  1) 
Sec. 30-213. - Use. 
    It is declared to be the policy of the governing body of the city that the golf course capital improvement reserve fund shall be used as a financing mechanism for repair, reconstruction and rehabilitation of public facilities for the improvement of the golf course department of the city. The amount to be annually reserved shall be to the maximum extent possible to meet the city's present and future public infrastructure needs in the golf course and to avoid cost of unnecessary indebtedness and to annually approve in the future of the budgeting of an amount sufficient to finance repairs, maintenance or construction of facilities. 
(Code 1996,  12-405; Ord. No. 3599,  2) 
Sec. 30-214. - Plan. 
    The city manager shall submit a plan for the implementation of this article and for the achievement of the policy objectives expressed in section 30-213, and shall, beginning in 1991, annually submit, with the proposed annual budget, a proposed golf course capital improvement program for each of the following five years. The budget proposed shall include an amount sufficient to finance proposed improvements for the following year, as well as an additional amount to be reserved as set forth in the currently submitted acquisition program. 
(Code 1996,  12-406; Ord. No. 3599,  3) 
Sec. 30-215. - Investment. 
    Moneys in the golf course capital improvement reserve fund may be invested in accordance with the provisions of K.S.A. 10-131, and the interest earned on such investments shall be credited to such fund. 
(Code 1996,  12-407; Ord. No. 3599,  4) 
Secs. 30-216-30-238. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MUNICIPAL AIRPORT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 30-239. - Operation and control. 
    The management and operation of the Wellington Municipal Airport will be under the control of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3963,  1-3, 7-18-2006) 
Sec. 30-240. - City laws extended. 
    The lands included in the area known as the Wellington Municipal Airport shall be deemed to be a part of the corporate limits of the city. The police power of the city is hereby extended to include all territory of the airport. All provisions of this Code are hereby declared to be applicable to the Wellington Municipal Airport. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  12-506) 
Secs. 30-241-30-258. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - AIRPORT ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 30-259. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a board, hereinafter to be known as the Wellington Airport Advisory Board. 
(Ord. No. 3964,  1, 8-1-2006) 
Sec. 30-260. - Appointment; terms; compensation; removal. 
(a)  The Wellington Airport Advisory Board shall consist of five members who shall be appointed by the governing body one of whom shall be a city councilmember who shall serve as chairman of said board. Of the remaining four members, three shall be residents of the city. 
1.  Commencing no later than at the last regular meeting of the governing body in April 2011, the governing body shall appoint members to two positions to serve a term commencing August 2, 2011 through April 30, 2016. In the future, as each of these terms expire, the governing body shall appoint members to these positions to serve a term of four years commencing May 1st. Any member appointed to serve a four-year term after January 1, 2013, shall not serve more than two consecutive four-year terms. 
2.  Commencing no later than at the last regular meeting of the governing body in April 2012, the governing body shall appoint a member to one position to serve a term commencing August 2, 2012 through April 30, 2017. In the future, as this term expires, the governing body shall appoint a member to this position to serve a term of four years commencing May 1st. Any member appointed to serve a four-year term after January 1, 2013, shall not serve more than two consecutive four-year terms. 
3.  Commencing no later than at the last regular meeting of the governing body in April 2013, the governing body shall appoint a member to one position to serve a term commencing August 2, 2013 through April 30, 2018. In the future, as this term expires, the governing body shall appoint a member to this position to serve a term of four years commencing May 1st. Any member appointed to serve a four-year term after January 1, 2013, shall not serve more than two consecutive four-year terms. 
4.  Commencing no later than at the last regular meeting of the governing body in April 2011, the governing body shall appoint either the mayor or a city councilmember to serve an unlimited term commencing August 2, 2011, subject to resignation, retirement or not being reelected to the governing body. 
(b)  Any member of the board may be removed by the city manager, at his discretion, for misfeasance, nonfeasance, or malfeasance, but only after he conducts an inquiry into any complaint about a member. Furthermore, if any member fails to attend three consecutive regularly scheduled or special meetings where an official vote is required, then the position shall be considered vacated, and the member shall not be eligible to reapply for a board or commission position for a period of one year. The board chairman shall submit an attendance report to the city clerk within ten business days after each meeting. 
(Ord. No. 3964,  2, 8-1-2006; Ord. No. 3982,  XI, 12-5-2006; Ord. No. 4076,  I, 3-1-2011; Ord. No. 4160,  III, 7-1-2014) 
Editor's note- See  2-86 editor's note. 
Sec. 30-261. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies shall be filled by the governing body for the unexpired term. All members of said board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 3964,  3, 8-1-2006; Ord. No. 4076,  I, 3-1-2011) 
Sec. 30-262. - Rules and regulations. 
    The airport advisory board shall adopt a set of rules to govern its own meetings and procedures. The rules may be amended from time to time, but only upon notice to all members that said proposed amendments shall be acted upon at specified meetings. Any amendments will need to be approved by a majority vote of the city council. The city council will accept the current set of rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 3964,  4, 8-1-2006) 
Sec. 30-263. - Officers. 
    The airport advisory board shall organize annually by electing one of its members as chairperson and one as vice-chairperson. 
(Ord. No. 3964,  5, 8-1-2006) 
Sec. 30-264. - Meetings. 
    Regular meetings of the airport advisory board shall be at least once each month and special meetings of the board shall be called by the chairperson. Written notice of special meetings shall be given to all members. A quorum of the board shall consist of four members. 
(Ord. No. 3964,  6, 8-1-2006) 
Sec. 30-265. - Open to public. 
    Meetings of the airport advisory board shall be open to the public. The board shall keep records and minutes of its business and official actions, which shall be filed with the city clerk and be open to public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 3964,  7, 8-1-2006) 
Sec. 30-266. - Power and duties. 
    That the powers and duties of the airport advisory board shall be to advise the governing body on all matters relating to the operation and maintenance of the Wellington Municipal Airport. The board shall suggest rules and regulations governing the operation and maintenance of the Wellington Airport but said rules and regulations shall not be in effect unless approved and promulgated by the governing body. The board shall pay particular attention to matters relating to the safety of users and visitors at the Wellington Airport and to the cleanliness and sanitation of the premises. The board shall make recommendations to the city council during the preparation of the annual budget. 
(Ord. No. 3964,  8, 8-1-2006) 
Secs. 30-267-30-295. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - MINIMUM STANDARDS 

Sec. 30-296. - Incorporated.

No fewer than three copies of the minimum standards shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy as Incorporated by Ordinance No. 3362," and filed with the city clerk to be open to inspection and available to the public at all reasonable hours. The municipal judge and all administrative departments of the city charged with the enforcement of the minimum standards shall be supplied, at the cost of the city, such number of official copies of such minimum standards as may be deemed expedient. 
(Code 1996,  12-503; Ord. No. 3362,  1) 
Sec. 30-297. - Penalty.

Of the remaining four members, one may be a non-resident of the City of Wellington, Kansas, but must be a resident within the boundaries of Unified School District No. 353. 
1.  Commencing no later than at the last regular meeting of the governing body in April 2011, the governing body shall appoint either the mayor or city councilmember to serve an unlimited term commencing April 19, 2011, subject to resignation, retirement, or not being reelected to the governing body.

(b)  Any member of the board may be removed by the city manager, at his discretion, for misfeasance, nonfeasance, or malfeasance, but only after he conducts an inquiry into any complaint about a member. Editor's note- See  2-86 editor's note. 
Sec. 30-378. - Rules and regulations. 
    The governing body shall, by resolution, which shall be filed with the city clerk, make rules and regulations for the operation and use of the Wellington Municipal Auditorium, including fees for such use. Such rules and regulations may be amended, modified or changed at any time by resolution of the governing body which shall seek the advice of the municipal auditorium board. 
(Code 1996,  12-602; Ord. No. 3379,  II) 
Sec. 30-379. - Duties. 
    The care and operation of the Municipal Auditorium and Heritage Park shall be under the control and management of the municipal auditorium board. The board shall present annual budget requests to the governing body, approve in advance the booking and promotion of activities and events in the auditorium. In addition to the foregoing the auditorium board shall submit to the governing body quarterly projected budgets showing anticipated revenues and expenses of the auditorium and a statement of projected public relations and other efforts to be made by the auditorium board and the auditorium director to increase revenues in the ensuing three month period together with a report setting forth actual revenues and expenditures of the auditorium and public relations and other efforts to increase revenues in the preceding three month period. The board shall establish dates for regular meetings of the board and shall furnish copies of the minutes of all meetings to the governing body. 
(Code 1996,  12-603; Ord. No. 3379,  III) 
Sec. 30-380. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate or fail to comply with the rules and regulations made by the governing body under the authority of section 30-378 shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not more than $100.00, or imprisoned not more than 30 days, or be both so fined and imprisoned. 
(Code 1996,  12-605; Ord. No. 3311,  5) 
Sec. 30-381. - Consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
    Alcoholic beverages, including cereal malt beverages, beer, wine, and/or alcoholic liquor, may be sold and/or consumed only on the premises comprising the Wellington Memorial Auditorium, but only after permission to do so is first obtained in writing from the City Manager of the City of Wellington, Kansas, by the person, group, or entity desiring to host an event which involves the sale and/or consumption of said alcoholic beverages. The sale of alcoholic liquor or cereal malt beverages is only allowed if by properly licensed and/or permitted individuals or businesses. Proof of license and/or permit is required to be provided to the City Manager if alcoholic beverages are to be sold in the Auditorium. 
    In conjunction with events being hosted at the Wellington Memorial Auditorium, consumption of alcoholic beverages as set forth above, may occur within Heritage Park. Separate permission is required for consumption of alcoholic beverages in Heritage Park, and may only be granted in conjunction with said events at Memorial Auditorium when similar permission has been granted. Heritage Park does not include the sidewalks on the East or South side of the park, or the parking area on the West side of the Park. The park is the area within those boundaries. 
(Ord. No. 4070,  I, 11-2-2010; Ord. No. 4130,  I, 3-19-2013; Ord. No. 4215,  I, 10-17-2017) 
Secs. 30-382-30-403. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VIII. - CEMETERIES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4261,  I, adopted May 21, 2019, repealed the former Art. VIII,  30-479, 30-480, 30-499, 30-500, 30-524, 30-542-30-550, 30-579-30-589, 30-612, 30-613, 30-645-30-647, 30-666-30-668, 30-695-30-697, 30-723-30-725, and enacted a new Art. VIII as set out herein. The former Art. VIII pertained to similar subject. 

Sec. 30-456. - Definitions. 
    Definitions in this section shall only apply in Article VIII. 
    Burial or interment shall be defined as the interring of a body or cremated remains of a single person in the ground or above ground in a mausoleum or columbarium. This shall also include synonyms or similar words describing the placing of human cremains in a columbarium niche. 
    Disinterment shall be defined as the removing of a body or cremated remains of a single person from the ground or above ground in a mausoleum or columbarium. This shall also include synonyms or similar words describing the removal of human cremains in a columbarium niche. 
    Disurnment shall be defined as the removal of cremated remains from a niche. 
    Foot marker shall be defined as any permanent monuments or marker placed at the foot of the grave. 
    Headstone shall be defined as any permanent monuments or markers placed at the head of a grave. 
    Inurnment shall be defined as the placing of cremated remains into a niche. 
    Lot owner shall be defined as the person or persons owning the right of interment of a lot. 
    Niche owner shall be defined as the person or persons owning the right of inurnment of a columbarium niche. 
    Resident shall be defined as a resident of the city of Wellington, Kansas. 
    The Cemetery shall apply to Prairie Lawn and Pioneer Cemeteries collectively. 
    Urn shall be defined as any container containing cremated human remains. 
(Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-457. - Office of sexton. 
    The office of sexton of the cemetery is hereby created, to be under the direct supervision of the public works director. The officer shall be appointed by the city manager, and the sexton's duties, powers, term of office, compensation and qualifications shall be such as prescribed by law and as provided by the laws of the city. 
(Code 1996,  12-829; Ord. No. 3329,  37; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-458. - Duties. 
(a)  The cemetery sexton shall: 
(1)  Have general charge and exercise immediate control of the cemetery, under the supervision and direction of the public works director; 
(2)  Attend to the digging and filling of all graves; 
(3)  Superintend and carry out all laws of the city relating to the cemetery, and all rules and orders of the governing body for the regulation, protection, government and improvement of the cemetery, and to do and perform such work and labor therein as may from time to time be ordered by the public works director; 
(4)  Give all time and attention in keeping in good condition all cemetery property, including all lots sold or to be sold by the city, and all lots retained by the city for cemetery purposes; 
(5)  Have exclusive use, control, and management of all water hydrants and all hose used for watering purposes in the cemetery. 
(b)  The sexton or designee shall be at the cemetery to give information and/or render assistance to lot owners and visitors from 8:00 a.m. until 12:00 noon, and from 1:00 p.m. until 5:00 p.m. weekdays and on Memorial Day, but on no other holidays. Special arrangements may be made however, to have someone in attendance on weekends and holidays other than Memorial Day. 
(Code 1996,  12-830; Ord. No. 3329,  38; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-459. - The cemetery. 
(a)  Prairie Lawn Cemetery is hereby located and established on tracts of land situated in the west half of section 13, Township 32 South, Range 1 west of the 6th Principal Meridian in Sumner County, Kansas, bounded as follows, to wit: 
Beginning at the center point of said section, then north 495 feet, then west 660 feet, then south 495 feet, then west 668.5 feet, then south 1,109.7 feet, then east 1,322.08 feet, then north 1,109.7 feet to the place of beginning, and 
Beginning at a point 100 feet east of the southeast corner of lot 5 block 1 of the Martin & Gentry Addition, then north 140 feet, then east 225 feet, then south 140 feet, then west 225 feet to the place of beginning, and 
Lots 1-10 of Block 1 of the Highland Park Addition. 
All of the real estate described in this section is hereby set apart and dedicated as and for the public cemetery and burial ground of the City, under the name of "Prairie Lawn Cemetery." A part of the cemetery consisting of a tract of ground 60 feet wide, east and west, and 303 feet long, north and south, the northeast corner of which is the beginning point of the tract of land above described in the southwest quarter of said section 13, is hereby set off and reserved for and to be known as "The Potter's Field," and the remainder of such cemetery ground as above described shall be used for general cemetery purposes, except as otherwise provided by law. 
(b)  Wellington Pioneer Cemetery is hereby located and established on a tract of land situated in the northeast corner of the Northeast Quarter of Section 14, Township 32, Range 1 West of the 6th Principal Meridian in Sumner County, Kansas, bounded as follows, to wit: 
Beginning 30 feet south and 30 feet west of the northeast corner of the Northeast Quarter section, then south 298 feet, then west 395 feet, then north 298 feet, then east 395 feet to the place of beginning. 
(Code 1996,  12-801; Ord. No. 3329,  1; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-460. - Official plats. 
(a)  The plats of the cemetery as set out in section 30-459 are hereby declared to be the official plats of the cemetery and shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  Further platting, replatting, subdividing and improvement of such cemetery grounds shall conform as nearly as may be possible to the general plan established in the aforesaid plats, and any change in the same or in the grade of the cemetery, as heretofore established, or the improvement of the cemetery shall be made only after approval by the governing body and then only under the supervision and direction of the public works director or designee. The cemetery shall be regulated and governed as provided by law and the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1996,  12-802; Ord. No. 3329,  2; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Secs. 30-461-30-465. - Reserved. 
Sec. 30-466. - City mausoleum. 
    The Wellington City Mausoleum created and located in the cemetery of the City of Wellington is hereby made a part of the cemetery, and the mausoleum shall be under the control and supervision of the governing body. It shall be maintained under such rules as shall be, from time to time, made and adopted by the governing body. The cemetery sexton shall have charge of the mausoleum in conjunction with The cemetery sexton's other duties. The mausoleum shall be maintained, improved and cared for from and by funds as procured through rules and regulations promulgated and adopted by the governing body. The management and regulation of the mausoleum shall be subject to the rules of the cemetery as far as the same are applicable. 
(Code 1996,  12-803; Ord. No. 3329,  36; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Secs. 30-467-30-470. - Reserved. 
Sec. 30-471. - Lots to be sold. 
(a)  Lots or columbarium niches individually or by sections or blocks may be sold for purposes of interment only, and certificates of sale signed by the mayor and countersigned by the city clerk, under the seal of the city, issued therefor at prices fixed by resolution of the governing body. 
(b)  The purchasing of lots or columbarium niches shall be subject to the following rules: 
(1)  The city reserves the right to limit the number of lots or columbarium niches that any private entity shall have title to at any one time. 
(2)  All transfer of ownership from one individual or entity to another shall comply with section 30-477. No lot or niche shall be resold in a private transaction. Any transaction involving transferring any interest in a lot or columbarium niches not complying with section 30-477 shall be void. 
(c)  Lots in blocks numbered 143, 144, 145, 155, 156, 157, 171, 172 and 173, henceforth referred to as the Veteran's Section, heretofore granted and conveyed to James Shields Post No. 57, Department of Kansas, shall not be sold, but any such lots that are unused shall be available, without cost for the lot, for the burial of any deceased person honorably discharged from the Armed Forces of the United States of America, all as provided by K.S.A. Ch. 73, Art. 3, and any acts amendatory or supplementary thereto, except for any plot allowance made available under any public law of the federal government; 
(d)  Burial lots located in "The Potter's Field" shall not be sold, but any such unused lot shall be available without cost for the burial of all deceased persons who are public charges, or who are unknown, or who have no persons responsible for the decedent's debts who cannot afford to purchase a cemetery lot, or where no other provision is made for their interment. 
(e)  Before issuing a burial permit for the burial of any deceased person on the lots described as being owned by James Shields Post No. 57, Department of Kansas, or on lots in "The Potter's Field," the city clerk shall collect the prevailing fee for the opening and closing of a grave and shall receive information required for the cemetery lot record. 
(f)  It shall be the responsibility of the lot/niche owner to keep the city advised at all times of the current mailing addresses of themselves, the person for whom the lot/niche is purchased for, and of the next of kin of the designee. The lot/niche owner will normally be the individual that the city would contact for any reason. 
(Code 1996,  12-804; Ord. No. 3329,  3; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
State Law reference- Sale of cemetery lot regulations, K.S.A. 14-1008. 
Sec. 30-472. - Former sales ratified. 
    All sales of lots, sections or blocks which have heretofore been made by the city are hereby ratified and confirmed, and in all cases where certificates of sale issued therefore shall not correctly describe such property as indicated on the plats declared by this article to be official plats, the city clerk is hereby authorized to take up such old certificates of sale and issue a correct certificate of sale for the property as sold. In all cases where new certificates of sale shall be issued in lieu of such outstanding certificates, and in all other cases where, from any existing record or memoranda, the city clerk can supply information not shown in the cemetery lot record such information shall then be shown in such lot record. 
(Code 1996,  12-805; Ord. No. 3329,  10; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-473. - Prices. 
    Prices for lots, and columbarium niches to be sold in the cemetery shall be fixed and established by the governing body, and the same may be changed from time to time by resolution of the governing body. 
(Code 1996,  12-806; Ord. No. 3329,  12; Ord. No. 4173,  IV, V, 2-3-2015; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-474. - Columbarium niches. 
(a)  The purchase price of a city owned columbarium niche shall include the right of inurnment of the selected niche, inurnment, recording of the deceased's information into cemetery records, burial permit fee, and a one-time engraving of the niche cover. Any additional engraving, i.e. addition of date of death, shall incur an additional fee as outlined in the fee schedule on file in the city clerk's office. Any inurnment done on a Saturday shall incur an additional fee as outlined in the fee schedule on file in the city clerk's office. 
(b)  The city shall engrave the niche cover and such engraving shall be in a uniform size and style of the city's choosing and shall be limited to name of deceased (first, middle initial, last), DOB, DOD and not more than one line describing military service. 
(c)  The city shall retain ownership of any city purchased columbarium and shall only sell the right of inurnment of niches. 
(Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-475. - Repurchase by city. 
    The city may repurchase lots, and columbarium niches in the cemetery, subject to the availability of funds and budget. The price to be paid by the city for such repurchases shall be as follows: 
(1)  For lots purchased prior to November 17, 1969, the original sale price of the lots, but in no event less than $40.00; per lot. 
(2)  For lots purchased after November 17, 1969, the original sale price of the lots less ten percent for administrative costs. 
(3)  For columbarium niches the original sale price of the niche less ten percent, if the niche cover has been engraved the City will also deduct the cost to replace said niche cover from the repurchase price. 
(Code 1996,  12-808; Ord. No. 3329,  13; Ord. No. 4173,  IV, V, 2-3-2015; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-476. - Lot/niche record. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the city clerk to keep a cemetery lot/niche record for the the cemetery containing the following information: 
(1)  The names of all persons who have in the past purchased or may in the future purchase lots/niches in the cemetery; 
(2)  The description of the property purchased by lot and block number or niche description; 
(3)  The date of purchase; 
(4)  The amount of money paid therefor; 
(5)  The number of the burial permit issued for the interment on each separate lot/niche; 
(6)  The date of the burial permit was issued; 
(7)  The name, age, sex and place of residence at the time of death of the person interred on each separate lot/niche; 
(8)  The date of the death of such person; 
(9)  The cause of death, as nearly as the same can be ascertained; 
(10)  The amount of the fee paid for the burial permit; and 
(11)  Any other information that the clerk may deem necessary to keep a complete and accurate cemetery lot/niche record for such cemetery. 
(b)  For lots in the cemetery located in "The Potter's Field" and for those lots owned by the James Shields Post No. 57, Department of Kansas, as much of the foregoing information as can be obtained shall be kept in the cemetery lot record. 
(Code 1996,  12-809; Ord. No. 3329,  8; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-477. - Transfer of ownership. 
    Ownership of lots, and columbarium niches in the cemetery shall be transferred only in the manner provided in this article and only on forms provided by the city. To transfer such ownership the owner shall complete in all particulars and deliver to the office of the city clerk a form to be provided by the city entitled, "Transfer of Ownership," showing the name of the owner of the lot or niche, the name and address of the person to whom ownership is transferred and a complete and accurate description of the lot or niche transferred together with a transfer fee, which shall be on file in the city clerk's office. Upon receipt of the transfer fee and a properly completed transfer of ownership form, the city clerk shall record the change of ownership indicated by the completed form in the records of the cemetery in the city clerk's office, complete the endorsement at the bottom of the form showing that the change of ownership has been recorded in the cemetery records and deliver or mail the form to the person to whom the lot or niche is transferred. The city shall charge an additional fee to cover the cost to replace an engraved niche cover upon transfer. 
(Code 1996,  12-810; Ord. No. 3329,  14; Ord. No. 4173,  II, V, 2-3-2015; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Secs. 30-478-30-499. - Reserved. 
Sec. 30-500. - Burials. 
(a)  Only one size B burial or two size A burials shall be permitted on each lot. One size A and one size B burial may be located on the same lot. 
(1)  Size A opening shall be defined as an urn/casket/vault with dimensions equal to or less than 24"W or 54"L 
(2)  Size B opening shall be defined as an urn/casket/vault with dimensions larger than 24"W or 54"L. 
(b)  For any burial in which the city provides the lot (i.e., paupers), the marker shall be limited to an 18-inch grass marker or government marker for veterans, the markers shall be flush with the surrounding ground. 
(c)  Burials in the cemetery are limited to human remains only. 
(d)  Scattering of cremated remains shall be prohibited. 
(e)  No more than two human cremains per niche will be allowed in any city owned columbarium. 
(Code 1996,  12-811; Ord. No. 3494,  1; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-501. - Burial permit-Information. 
    The city clerk shall, when furnished a death certificate or a certificate of stillbirth, issue to any person applying for the same a burial permit which shall set forth the following information, to wit: 
(1)  The name, age, sex and place of residence at the time of death of the deceased person to be buried; 
(2)  The number of the lot and block or columbarium niche location in the cemetery on which the interment is to be made; and 
(3)  The name of the owner of such lot or niche and the name of the person or person requesting the issuance of such permit. 
(4)  The branch of service and the war in which the deceased individual served. 
(Code 1996,  12-813; Ord. No. 3329,  5; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-502. - Same-Fee. 
    There shall be burial permit fees in the amounts which are on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1996,  12-814; Ord. No. 3674,  1; Ord. No. 4173,  IV, V, 2-3-2015; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-503. - Same-Records. 
    Burial permit records shall consist of a permit and a corresponding stub numbered with identical numbers. Each permit and the corresponding stub shall be numbered consecutively with identical numbers and shall be bound in book form. Upon completion of the permit and the corresponding stub by the city clerk, the permit shall be delivered to the sexton who shall note the interment thereon and return the same to the clerk. All permits and stubs shall be retained by the clerk as part of the records of the cemetery. 
(Code 1996,  12-815; Ord. No. 3329,  9; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-504. - Permit to open grave. 
    Any person who desires to open any grave or niche and, or disinter and remove, or disinter and reinter any remains now buried or that may hereafter be buried in the cemetery shall pay a permit fee which is on file in the city clerk's office prior to said interment or disinterment. 
(Code 1996,  12-816; Ord. No. 3674,  2; Ord. No. 4173,  IV, V, 2-3-2015; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-505. - Holidays. 
    No interment, disinterment, cremation or interment services shall be permitted on the date established by the governing body of the city for the observance of the following holidays by city employees: New Year's Day, Martin Luther King, Jr. Day, Independence Day, Christmas Day, Veterans Day, Memorial Day, Labor Day and Thanksgiving Day and the Friday following. Interment services on the Saturday preceding Memorial Day shall be allowed prior to 12:00 p.m. only. 
(Code 1996,  12-817; Ord. No. 3329,  18; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-506. - Grave to be dug by sexton. 
(a)  No grave, or columbarium niche shall be dug or opened in the cemetery except by the sexton, or under the sexton's supervision, and then only after a permit therefore has been issued as provided in this article, and no grave, or columbarium niche shall be dug or opened on any lot or niche other than the lot or niche described in the permit. No grave or niche shall be dug or opened or closed at any time on Sunday, nor shall any grave or niche be dug or opened at any time after 12:00 noon on Saturday. 
(b)  The urn for cremated remains to be inurned in a city owned columbarium shall be of a material approved by the city (non-biodegradable) and shall be of a size suitable for the niche. The city shall have the right to refuse to accept for inurnment any urn deemed unsuitable due to its size, durability, construction, etc. 
(c)  The city will not reopen any niche after an inurnment has taken place to add anything to said niche, with the exception of an additional set of cremains where double inurnment is allowed. 
(Code 1996,  12-818; Ord. No. 3329,  6; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-507. - Types of vaults or boxes. 
    In every earth interment in the cemetery, excluding cremains, the casket shall be closed in a vault or box constructed of concrete, cement, steel or fiberglass. The use of wooden boxes is prohibited. 
(Code 1996,  12-819; Ord. No. 3329,  17; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Secs. 30-508-30-531. - Reserved. 
Sec. 30-532. - Memorial monuments and markers; permit required. 
    All memorial monument and marker installation and maintenance shall be done by a private company in business for that type of work. Before any memorial work is commenced a permit approving such work shall be obtained from the sexton of the cemetery. The permit shall state the name of the company proposing to do the work, the location of the work, the type of memorial work to be done, and such other information necessary to determine that the proposed work will comply with the cemetery rules and regulations. Permit fees, which shall be on file in the city clerk's office, will be charged to cover the cost of issuing the permit and inspecting the work described in the permit. No permit fee shall be charged for Veterans Administration markers set in the cemetery. The funds derived from this fee shall be used for the cemetery beautification trust fund to correct those monuments or markers that are unsightly or unsafe. The sexton shall be notified no less than two business days prior to setting of a monument. 
(Code 1996,  12-820; Ord. No. 3436,  1; Ord. No. 4173,  IV, V, 2-3-2015; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-533. - Supervision. 
    All memorial work shall be done under the general supervision of the sexton of the cemetery. 
(Code 1996,  12-821; Ord. No. 3329,  33; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-534. - Specifications. 
(a)  Headstones on lots 1 to 8, inclusive, in blocks 1066-1077; 1111-1122; 1156-1167; inclusive, Prairie Lawn Cemetery shall not project more than six inches above the surface of the ground and all other permanent monuments or markers on lots 1 to 8, inclusive, shall be flush with the ground surface. 
(b)  Headstones on lots 9 to 16, inclusive, in blocks 1066-1077; 1111-1122; 1156-1167; inclusive, in Prairie Lawn Cemetery may project more than six inches above the surface of the ground and all other permanent monuments or markers on said lots 9 to 16, inclusive, shall be flush with the ground surface. 
(c)  All headstones shall have a concrete foundation extending at least six inches beyond the sides and ends of the monument or marker.
