The foundation shall be reinforced with not less than three-eighths inch reinforcing bars spaced not less than six inches apart on center and extending the full length of the foundation to a point three inches from each end of the foundation and be set in conformity with the following rules: 
(1)  Headstones up to 12 inches in height not including the base shall have a concrete foundation six inches deep. Precast foundations may be used providing they meet or exceed specifications, and must have a smooth finish. 
(2)  Headstones up to 24 inches in height not including the base shall have a concrete foundation six inches deep with not less than four concrete piers of a diameter of not less than six inches extending twelve inches below the bottom of the concrete foundation. Precast foundations may be used providing they meet or exceed specifications, and must have a smooth finish. 
(3)  Headstones up to 36 inches in height not including the base shall have a concrete foundation eight inches deep with not less than six concrete piers of a diameter of not less than six inches extending 12 inches below the bottom on the concrete foundation. 
(4)  Headstones up to 48 inches in height not including the base shall have a concrete foundation 12 inches deep with not less than six concrete piers of a diameter of not less than six inches extending 24 inches below the bottom of the concrete foundation. 
(5)  The foundation of any monument or marker exceeding 48 inches in height not including the base shall be determined on an individual basis. 
(6)  The top surface of all concrete foundations shall be flush with the ground surface adjacent to the foundation. 
(7)  Foot markers shall be set flush with the ground and shall have a concrete foundation not less than six-inches deep which shall extend at least six-inches beyond the sides and ends of the foot marker, reinforced with not less than three-eighths inch reinforcing bars set around the perimeter of the foot marker and may be precast. 
(8)  Foundations for above-ground mausoleums will be determined for each individual situation. 
(9)  If it is necessary to move and reset a stone to accommodate an individual burial on a grave, the funeral home shall be responsible therefor. 
(10)  No dry mix shall be allowed in the pouring of foundations. All foundations must be wet poured, unless otherwise noted. 
(11)  All vases set at ground level must have concrete extending six inches beyond the vase on all sides. 
(12)  Vases will not be allowed on flush footmarkers. 
(d)  All monuments and markers shall be constructed of marble, bronze, or granite. 
(e)  All monuments or markers in block 1090 "Baby Land" shall be set flush with the ground and shall have a concrete foundation six inches deep and shall have a monument or marker measuring no longer than 17 by nine inches with a concrete foundation measuring 24 by 15 inches and must be precast. 
(f)  All monuments and decorations that are above ground level must go at the head of the grave. 
(g)  No monuments or markers may be set one week before Memorial Day. 
(h)  Temporary markers shall be left for a period of no longer than one year after the date of the burial or until they are no longer legible or until a permanent marker is set, whichever comes first, whereupon the sexton shall remove the temporary marker and dispose of it accordingly. 
(i)  The placement of memorial benches, statues, private columbariums or private mausoleums must be authorized by the public works director and sexton before installation will be allowed. 
(j)  Any company setting a monument or marker shall have 14 days from the date the monument or marker foundation was installed to pull forms and backfill. 
(k)  For any burials in the area designated as the Veteran's Section the monument or marker shall be limited to a Veterans Administration marker, and be limited to a single marker placed at the head of the grave. 
(l)  Lot owners may have the corners of the lots they own marked with a granite, bronze or marble corner marker no larger than six inches square at the surface and which shall in all cases be set in the ground inside the lot boundaries under the supervision of the Sexton so that the same may be flush with the surface of the lot and surrounded by a three-inch concrete apron, extending at least two inches below the bottom of the corner marker but not less than four inches in depth. 
(m)  The city reserves the right to require a wet poured foundation. 
(Code 1996,  12-822; Ord. No. 3674,  3; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-535. - Placement of mausoleums. 
(a)  No mausoleums, either surface or above surface, may be placed in the new high density section of Prairie Lawn Cemetery. Mausoleums hereby prohibited in the new high density section of the cemetery may, however, be placed in all sections of the cemetery other than the high density section thereof. Before an above ground mausoleum is constructed a trust fund shall be established with the city to provide funds for future upkeep of the mausoleum. Said trust fund shall be not less than 25 percent of the total purchase price of the mausoleum. 
(b)  For purposes of this section the new high density section of Prairie Lawn Cemetery shall be that part of the cemetery described as follows, to wit: 
Beginning at the center point of section 13, Township 32 South, Range 1 West of the 6th Principal Meridian in Sumner County, Kansas, thence west along the quarter section line between the northwest quarter and the southwest quarter of section 660 feet, thence north 495 feet to a point 660 feet west of the east line of northwest quarter of section, thence east 660 feet to the east line of northwest quarter, thence south along the east line of said northwest quarter, a distance of 495 feet, to the place beginning, all in the northwest quarter (NW 1/4) of section 13. 
(Code 1996,  12-823; Ord. No. 3372,  1; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Secs. 30-536-30-560. - Reserved. 
Sec. 30-561. - Improvement of lots and graves. 
(a)  Seasonal, artificial or cut flowers and wreaths shall be permitted in the cemetery, subject, however, to other provisions of this section and section 30-562. 
(b)  Seasonal flowers, cut flowers, artificial plants or flowers and wreaths shall be permitted on the entire grave space area for up to ten days immediately following the date of interment on said grave and for a period commencing five days before and ending ten days after Memorial Day. 
(c)  Any unauthorized plantings or objects on graves or lots may be removed by the sexton and disposed of. Such objects as floral frames, vases, benches, statues, etc., may be disposed of if not claimed after seven days. 
(d)  All retaining walls, fences and curbing of lots and grave spaces in the cemetery are prohibited, except as may be constructed by the city. A retaining wall, fence or curbing which is presently in place may be removed by the city when the sexton of the cemetery determines that the improvement is in poor condition that it is detrimental to the appearance and maintenance of the cemetery if the owner of such improvement, after notice to repair the same, fails to repair such improvement. If reasonable efforts to locate the owner of such improvement for purposes of giving such notice have failed, the city may proceed to remove such improvement. 
(e)  All graves shall be flush with the surrounding ground level after they have settled, and they shall not be mounded or maintained without turf. 
(f)  Nothing shall be affixed to, or left in the area of any city owned columbarium, unless provided by the city. The city reserves the right to remove any such ornamentation or correct any such alteration or damage at the expense of the niche owner. Exception, one small veteran's medallion provided by the Veteran's Administration shall be permitted on a niche cover. 
(Code 1996,  12-824; Ord. No. 3329,  25, 26, 28-31; Ord. No. 3798,  II, 3-2-1999; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-562. - Installation or planting regulations. 
    Any plantings or installations permitted in the cemetery by other provisions of this article shall conform to the following regulations: 
(1)  The planting of trees, shrubs bushes, plants or perennial flowers of any kind are prohibited. All permanent plantings of any kind will be done by the city. 
(2)  Placement of seasonal, artificial or cut flowers shall be limited to the area allowed for the marker or monument and shall not extend onto the grave, adjoining graves or alley ways. 
(3)  No placement of plantings shall be permitted around foot markers. 
(4)  Artificial flowers, wreaths and cut flowers shall be placed and secured in a manner that they will not become dislodged or scattered by the wind. 
(5)  Damaged or faded artificial flowers or wreaths, and neglected, misplaced, dead, unkempt, unauthorized or hazardous plantings, including trees, may be removed by the sexton of the cemetery as necessary to maintain the attractive, safe and neat appearance of the cemetery. 
(6)  Nothing shall be allowed around the foundation, monument, marker, or on the grave that will impair the sexton's ability to maintain the attractive, safe and neat appearance of the cemetery. 
(7)  Glass of any kind is a safety hazard and as such is strictly forbidden in the cemetery and any glass that is found will be promptly removed and disposed of. 
(Code 1996,  12-825; Ord. No. 3372,  2; Ord. No. 3798,  II, 3-2-1999; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Secs. 30-563-30-599. - Reserved. 
Sec. 30-600. - Liability. 
(a)  The cemetery department shall not be held responsible for any order given verbally, by telephone, email or for any mistake occurring from the want of precise and proper instructions as to the particular space, size and location in a lot where interment is desired. 
(b)  The cemetery department shall have the right to correct any errors that may be made by the department either on making interments, disinterment or removals, or in the description, transfer or conveyance of any interment property either by cancelling such conveyance and substituting and conveying in lieu thereof other interment property of equal value and similar location as far as possible as may be selected by the cemetery department, or, in the sole discretion of the governing body, by refunding the amount of money paid on account of said purchase. In the event the error shall involve the interment of the remains of any persons in such property, the cemetery department shall have the right to remove and reinter the remains on such other property of equal value and similar location as may be substituted and agreed upon. 
(c)  The cemetery will not be held responsible for any article left on cemetery property or for any monuments, foot markers, anything on any lot, or inside any niche damaged or destroyed by fires, acts of God, acts of nature, acts of war, vandalism, theft or other damages occurring to private property. 
(d)  By its design and construction, the niche may not be weatherproof nor corrosion proof. No warranty, representation or agreement is or can be made concerning the effects of weather, exposure, or time upon cremains inurned in a niche. 
(e)  The city reserves the right to temporarily move cremains for the purpose of maintaining a columbarium. 
(Code 1996,  12-826; Ord. No. 3329,  36; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-601. - Unlawful acts. 
(a)  No person shall be allowed to ride or drive over or across any grave or occupied or improved or unimproved lot, block or section in the cemetery. This section shall not apply to the Sexton or his designee while in the discharge of the sexton's duties. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, without authority, to willfully remove, cut, carve, mark, break, or otherwise deface or injure any monument, stone, grave, slab, corner post, building, fence, railing, tree, shrub, or flower in the cemetery or used for the protection, beautification or improvement of the cemetery, or of any grave, lot, section or block therein. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person other than the owners of lots or graves to go into the cemetery, except when accompanied by the sexton, at any time between sundown and sunrise, or to remain loitering in the cemetery without any apparent errand or object. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to divert, or attempt to divert the cemetery, or any block, section lot, street, alley, common or other part thereof from the usual and proper use and occupancy thereof for cemetery purposes and purposes of interment, and each day that such diversion or unlawful use thereof shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dig or excavate in any street, lane, alley, walk or common, in the cemetery, except in grading or otherwise improving the same under the direction of the city manager or designee, or in any way occupy, blockade or obstruct any such street, lane, alley, walk or common. 
(f)  Any monument or vault company, or employee thereof, found to be in violation of the rules of the cemetery shall be given two warnings, one verbal and one written, after which if the company is still found to be violating the rules, they may be barred from doing any work in the cemetery for a period of time as determined by the city manager. 
(Code 1996,  12-827; Ord. No. 3329,  19-23; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-602. - Private burials. 
    No burial of human remains shall be conducted nor headstones or mausoleums maintained on private property other than in designated cemeteries within the city limits of the City of Wellington, Kansas. Headstones may be allowed on the property of bonafide monument companies, funeral homes, and/or mortuaries for the purpose of sales displays only. 
(Ord. No. 4108,  I, 2-21-2012; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Secs. 30-603-30-733. - Reserved. 
Sec. 30-734. - Cemetery Endowment Fund created. 
    There is hereby created an endowment fund for the purpose of permanently maintaining and caring for Prairie Lawn Cemetery and other cemeteries belonging to the city, to be known as the Permanent Cemetery Endowment Fund. 
State Law reference- Endowment Fund, K.S.A. 12-1408 et seq. 
(Code 1974,  5-301; Code 1996,  12-832; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-735. - Governing body; powers. 
    The governing body is hereby empowered to set aside at any time any moneys on hand in any cemetery fund not otherwise appropriated, or any gifts, donations and contributions or subscriptions for the purpose, or profits derived from the sale of lots, or other property belonging to the cemetery for the purpose of said Permanent Cemetery Endowment Fund. 
(Code 1974,  5-302; Code 1996,  12-833; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-736. - Investments. 
    All funds raised by popular subscription or profits or surplus set aside for the endowment fund as provided in this article shall be invested in investments authorized by K.S.A. 12-1675, and amendments thereto, in the manner prescribed therein or in state, county or municipal bonds, bonds of the United States of America or any bonds guaranteed, both as to principal and interest, by the United States of America, and the interest accruing therefrom, from the investment shall annually be expended for caring for graves, beautifying and improving the cemetery. In no case shall the fund be depleted or lessened, and nothing but its earnings, as they accumulate annually, shall be expended for any purpose whatsoever, except as specified in this section, and the endowment fund shall be for the purpose prescribed in this act and its earnings expended in the manner prescribed forever. 
(Code 1996,  12-834; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Secs. 30-737-30-738. - Reserved. 
Sec. 30-739. - Beautification Trust Fund created. 
    There is hereby created a fund of the city to be known as the Cemetery Beautification Trust Fund into which shall be deposited all monument and marker permit fees, gifts, donations and bequests made to the city for the purposes hereinafter set forth. 
(Code 1996,  12-835; Ord. No. 3435,  1; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-740. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the Cemetery Beautification Trust Fund is to provide moneys to be used, either along or along with moneys from other sources for the purpose of correcting monuments or markings in unsightly or hazardous condition in the cemetery of persons deceased or where next of kin or heirs are unknown or who cannot themselves afford to correct the monuments or markers. The trust fund can also be used for landscaping improvements at the cemetery; which includes the planting of trees, bushes, shrubs, flowers and grass that would further enhance and beautify the cemetery. 
(Code 1996,  12-836; Ord. No. 3435,  2; Ord. No. 3798,  III, 3-2-1999; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-741. - Regulations. 
    In order to carry out the express purposes of the Cemetery Beautification Trust Fund set forth in this article, the city manager shall establish rules and regulations relating to the determination of which monuments or markers are to be corrected by proceeds from the fund, and for the method and procedure of such correction. 
(Code 1996,  12-837; Ord. No. 3435,  3; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Secs. 30-742-30-743. - Reserved. 
Sec. 30-744. - Cemetery Capital Improvement Fund created. 
    There is hereby created and established, pursuant to K.S.A. Supp. 12-1,118, a fund of the city to be known as the Cemetery Capital Improvement Reserve Fund which fund shall be used for the purpose of financing the acquisition of additional land for future operational needs of the cemetery, and for financing, in whole or in part, any public improvement need for the department, including the repair, restoration and rehabilitation of existing facilities. 
(Code 1996,  12-838; Ord. No. 3578,  1; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-745. - Policy. 
    It is declared to be the policy of the governing body of the city that the Cemetery Capital Improvement Reserve Fund shall be used as a financing mechanism to secure the planned and orderly acquisition of additional land for future expansion and operational needs of the cemetery and for repair, reconstruction and rehabilitation of public facilities for the improvement of the cemetery department of the city. The amount to be annually reserved shall be to the maximum extent possible to meet the city's present and future public infrastructure needs in the cemetery and to avoid cost of unnecessary indebtedness and to annually approve in the future the budgeting of an amount sufficient to finance the acquisition of additional land for future use and for needed repairs, maintenance or construction of facilities. 
(Code 1996,  12-839; Ord. No. 3578,  2; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Sec. 30-746. - Plan. 
    The city manager shall submit a plan for the implementation of this article and for the achievement of the policy objectives expressed in section 30-745, and shall, beginning in 1990, annually submit, with the proposed annual budget, a proposed cemetery capital improvement program for each of the following five years. The budget proposed shall include an amount sufficient to finance proposed cemetery land acquisition or improvements for the following year, as well as an additional amount to be reserved as set forth in the currently submitted acquisition program. 
(Code 1996,  12-840; Ord. No. 3578,  3; Ord. No. 4261,  II, 5-21-2019) 
Secs. 30-747-30-748. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - REGIONAL PARK TRUST FUND 

Sec. 30-749. - Established. 
    There is hereby established and created a fund of the city to be known as the Wellington Regional Park Trust Fund, into which there shall be deposited all grants, gifts, donations, bequests and moneys from any other source whatsoever to be used, either alone, or along with moneys from other sources, for the purposes of maintaining, operating and improving land owned by the city located in the northeast quarter of section 10, Township 32 South, Range 1 West of the 6th Principal Meridian in Sumner County, Kansas, known as the Wellington Regional Park, and for no other purposes. 
(Code 1996,  12-901; Ord. No. 3537,  1) 
Secs. 30-750-30-766. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - SENIOR CITIZEN CENTER TRUST FUND 

Sec. 30-767. - Established. 
    There is hereby established and created a fund of the city to be known as the Wellington Senior Citizen Center Trust Fund, into which there shall be deposited all grants, gifts, donations, bequests and moneys from any other source whatsoever to be used, either alone, or along with moneys from other sources, for the purposes of acquiring, purchasing, constructing, maintaining, operating, and improving buildings and/or land that may hereafter be acquired by the city for the purpose of the Wellington Senior Citizens Center, and for no other purposes. 
(Code 1996,  12-1001; Ord. No. 3545,  1) 
Chapter 32 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Streets, K.S.A. 12-601 et seq.; buildings, structures and grounds, K.S.A. 12-1708 et seq.; sidewalks, K.S.A. 12-1801 et seq.; roads and bridges, K.S.A. 68-101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 32-1. - Land resources and mitigation measures. 
    City of Wellington shall hence forth comply with the following five items in conjunction with the street and drainage improvements: 
(1)  City will maintain compliance with all local, state, and federal environmental requirements. 
(2)  City will comply with all applicable local zoning requirements and obtain any required building permits. 
(3)  An approved asbestos contractor will be contracted and used to properly address and/or dispose of any ACM. Contact KDHE if any questions arise related to ACM. 
(4)  If sufficient area will be disturbed, a National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit for storm water runoff resulting from construction activities will be obtained from the Kansas Department of Health and Environment prior to starting construction. 
(5)  The State Historic Preservation Officer and appropriate Native American Tribe(s) will be contacted immediately and construction halted if any buried archeological materials are encountered. 
(Ord. No. 4097,  1, 9-6-2011) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4097,  1, adopted Sept. 6, 2011, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore these provisions have been included as  32-1, at the editor's discretion. 
Secs. 32-2-32-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Sidewalks, K.S.A. 12-1801 et seq. 

Sec. 32-19. - Construction approval required. 
    It shall be unlawful to construct, reconstruct or repair any sidewalk within the city until the plans for such work have been approved, in writing, by the city engineer. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-101) 
Sec. 32-20. - Petition. 
    When a petition signed by not less than ten citizens owning real estate in the city requesting construction of a sidewalk is filed with the city clerk, the governing body may in its discretion, by a resolution, order such sidewalk constructed as herein provided. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-104) 
State Law reference- Petition for construction of sidewalk, K.S.A. 12-1803. 
Sec. 32-21. - Presumption. 
    Any sidewalk in the city which has an abrupt change in elevation of one inch or more, or which has a cross sectional slope greater than two inches in 12 inches shall be deemed inadequate and unsafe for travel and shall be repaired as provided in the codes and ordinances of the city. Nothing herein contained shall in any way limit or impinge upon the power of the governing body of the city to determine, in its opinion, what other conditions in a sidewalk in the city would render the same inadequate or unsafe for travel. 
(Code 1996,  13-105; Ord. No. 3473,  1) 
Sec. 32-22. - Condemnation; reconstruction. 
    When any sidewalk, in the opinion of the governing body, becomes inadequate or unsafe for travel thereon, the governing body may adopt a resolution condemning such walk and providing for the construction of a new walk in the place of the walk condemned. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-106) 
State Law reference- Condemnation and reconstruction of sidewalk, K.S.A. 12-1804. 
Sec. 32-23. - Notice; publication. 
    The resolution providing for the construction or reconstruction of a sidewalk, as the case may be, shall give the owner of the abutting property not less than 30 days nor more than 60 days after its publication one time in the official city paper in which to construct or cause to be constructed or reconstructed the sidewalk at the abutting property owner's own expense. If the sidewalk is not constructed by the property owner within the time specified, the governing body shall cause the work to be done by contract. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-107) 
State Law reference- Notice to abutting owner, K.S.A. 12-1805. 
Sec. 32-24. - Right of abutting owner. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to prohibit the owner of property abutting on a street, who desires to construct or reconstruct a sidewalk at the abutting property owner's own expense and in accordance with official plans and specifications for the purpose and which meet such other requirements as would have to be met if the sidewalk were constructed or reconstructed by the city, to construct or reconstruct a sidewalk without any petition or a condemning resolution by the governing body. If such property owner desires the sidewalk to be constructed and reconstructed by the city and an assessment levied as provided by law in other cases, the property owner shall file a request with the governing body. The governing body, in its discretion, may provide for the construction or reconstruction of the sidewalk requested in the same manner as in other cases where citizens or taxpayers petition the governing body. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-108) 
State Law reference- Construction by abutting owner, K.S.A. 12-1806. 
Sec. 32-25. - Repairs by owner or city. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner of the abutting property to keep the sidewalk in repair, but the city may, after giving five days' notice to the owner or the owner's agent, if known, of the necessity for making repairs or without notice if the lot or piece of land is unoccupied, make all necessary repairs at any time. The repairs shall be done and the cost thereof assessed against the lot or piece of land abutting on the sidewalk so repaired as may be provided by law. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-109) 
State Law reference- Repairs by owner or city, K.S.A. 12-1808. 
Sec. 32-26. - Work according to specifications. 
    Any person who shall construct or assist in constructing any sidewalk or crosswalk, or rebuild or assist in rebuilding any sidewalk or crosswalk, or make or assist in making any improvement whatever upon the streets, avenues or alleys of the city shall do so in accordance with the maps, plans, specifications and profiles of the city engineer mentioned in this article, and the rules and directions herein contained. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-111) 
Sec. 32-27. - Obstructing sidewalks. 
(a)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to build or construct any step or other obstruction, whether temporary or permanent, or to store, leave or allow to be left any implements, tools, merchandise, goods, containers, benches, display or show cases, on any sidewalks or other public ways in the city or to obstruct the same longer than is necessary for loading or unloading any such article or object. 
(b)  Special authorization. The city manager may authorize the granting of temporary permits in connection with a building or moving permit for limited times only to the owner of property abutting on any sidewalk to use or encumber such sidewalk or public way of the city during the construction of any building or improvement thereon. No permit shall be issued for such purpose until plans for warning and safeguarding the public during such use of sidewalks shall have been submitted by the owner or the owner's contractor and approved by the city manager. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-112, 13-113) 
Sec. 32-28. - Sidewalks covered with earth. 
    No lot or piece of land abutting on any sidewalk shall be allowed to become or remain in such condition that earth or other substance shall accumulate on the sidewalk and it shall be the duty of the owner of such lot or piece of land to place the same in such condition as to prevent the accumulation of such earth or other substance on such sidewalk. 
(Code 1974,  21-403; Code 1996,  13-114) 
Sec. 32-29. - Violation. 
    For the violation of section 32-26, 32-27(a), or 32-28, each day that the work is left in a condition unsatisfactory to the city inspector shall be considered a separate violation under this article with the exception that each such day shall not be considered a separate violation where repair work in accordance with city specifications and requirements has been commenced. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-115) 
Sec. 32-30. - Snow and ice to be removed. 
    It is hereby made the duty of the owner and of the occupant of any lots abutting upon any sidewalks to cause all snow and ice to be removed from such sidewalks within five hours from the time that said snow has fallen or ice has accumulated. If the snow falls or ice accumulated upon said sidewalks in the nighttime, removal of the snow or ice shall be made within five hours after sunrise on the following day. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-116) 
Secs. 32-31-32-48. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STREETS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 32-49-32-69. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - EXCAVATION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Notice of intent to excavate, K.S.A. 66-1804. 

Sec. 32-70. - Permit. 
    No person, other than authorized city employees, shall dig or excavate any hole, ditch, trench or tunnel in or under any street, alley, sidewalk, park or other public property or public easement through private property without first having secured a permit for such excavation. Application shall be made to the city engineer. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-201) 
Sec. 32-71. - Surety bond or insurance required. 
(a)  No permit shall be issued until the applicant has submitted to the city engineer either: 
(1)  A good and sufficient bond by the applicant in the sum of $5,000.00 conditioned that the applicant will comply with all laws and regulations of the city and with any lawful orders of the city engineer and conditioned further that the city or any other person who may deem himself injured or damaged by the applicant's failure to comply with the provisions of this Code may sue on the bond to recover damages. All such bonds shall be approved by the city manager before a license is issued; or 
(2)  A certificate of liability insurance covering the work in which the applicant is engaged. The certificate shall show that the applicant is covered by a liability insurance policy issued by a corporation authorized to do business in the state and that the applicant has a policy with a $300,000.00 minimum for bodily damage and $100,000.00 for property damage. 
(b)  Whether the holding of a bond or a liability insurance policy shall be required of any given applicant shall be wholly within the discretion of the city manager. 
(c)  No bond or liability insurance policy required under this section shall be cancelled or terminated until at least ten days after a notice of cancellation of the bond or insurance is received by the city clerk. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-202) 
Sec. 32-72. - Field. 
    If the application is approved by the city, the city engineer shall issue a permit upon payment of a fee which shall be on file in the city clerk's office. Each permit issued under the provisions of this section shall cover only one specified excavation. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-203) 
Sec. 32-73. - Barricades. 
    Any person to whom an excavation permit is issued shall enclose all excavations which they make with sufficient barricades and danger signs at all times, and shall maintain sufficient warning lights or flares at nighttime. The holder of an excavation permit shall take all necessary precautions to guard the public against all accidents from the beginning of the work to the completion of the same. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-204) 
Sec. 32-74. - Interference with barricades. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, except those having authority from the city or an official thereof, to throw down, interfere with or remove any barriers, barricades, or lights placed in any street to guard and warn the traveling public of any construction work thereon or adjacent thereto, or placed in any street or alley by the city or its agents to close a street or alley, or to warn the public of a danger in the street or alley. 
(b)  No vehicle, except those of city, state, or federal government authorities and their franchisees, shall at any time be driven past any barrier, barricade or lights placed in a street or alley for the purpose of guarding and warning the traveling public of construction work, or for the purpose of closing a street or alley, or for the purpose of warning of a danger therein and into that portion of the street so barricaded 
(Code 1996,  13-205; Ord. No. 3675,  1, 2) 
Sec. 32-75. - Backfilling excavation. 
    Any person making excavations in any of the streets, alleys or public grounds in the city shall backfill all trenches or ditches or excavations made by such person whenever deemed necessary by the street department and any person shall remove all surplus material in all cases of excavation from the streets, alleys or other public grounds, and it shall be the duty of such person, firm or corporation making such excavation to follow the directions of any person directed by the city to supervise said work. 
(Code 1974,  21-205; Code 1996,  13-206) 
Sec. 32-76. - Cutting curbs; pavement. 
(a)  No person shall cut any curb, gutter, pavement, blacktop, sidewalk or excavate any street, alley or other public grounds of the city for any purpose without first obtaining a permit authorizing the same from the city engineer. 
(b)  Once the work for which the excavation was made has been completed the city shall restore the pavement, blacktop, sidewalk or other surfacing at the expense of the person from whom the excavation was made. 
(c)  In lieu of the city replacing pavement, it may elect to authorize utility companies or contractors to resurface streets or sidewalks with like materials, subject to approval of the street superintendent. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-207) 
Sec. 32-77. - Altering drainage. 
    No person shall change or alter any gutter, storm sewer, drain or drainage structure which has been constructed, or is being lawfully maintained or controlled by the city unless such change or alteration has been authorized or directed by the city manager. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-208) 
Sec. 32-78. - Unfinished pavement. 
    No person shall walk upon, drive or ride over or across any pavement, sidewalk or incomplete grading which has not been opened for traffic. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-209) 
Secs. 32-79-32-99. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ENCROACHMENTS 

Sec. 32-100. - Building materials in street. 
    Any person desiring to use the sidewalk or any part of the street for the temporary deposit of building material, including the use of movable storage containers, during the construction or repair of any building, or during the temporary use of any sidewalk while excavating any cellar, shall apply to the city manager for permission to use the same and upon such application, the city manager may grant permission to use the same temporarily for the purpose to be named. Not more than one-third of the width of the street shall be used, and in case the sidewalk be obstructed, a temporary walkway shall be provided around such obstruction, and the gutter shall be kept open for flow of water and no person shall use or temporarily appropriate any sidewalk or street or any material part thereof including a moveable storage container without the consent of the city manager. Upon the completion of any building, the material in the street shall be removed within ten days. Any such obstruction shall be adequately marked to give warning to the drivers of vehicles. Adequate markings shall include, but not be limited to, cones, barricades and/or flashers. 
(Code 1974,  21-407; Code 1996,  13-211; Ord. No. 4200,  I, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 32-101. - Commercial use of street. 
    No person may use any portion of any sidewalk or street right-of-way for the purpose of displaying or offering for sale wares, goods, merchandise or other items. Nothing in this article, however, shall be construed as prohibiting the city manager from waiving the prohibition of this section in connection with community promotions or community-wide celebrations when such waiver is considered to be in the best interest of the city. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-212) 
Sec. 32-102. - Dangerous objects. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, throw or cause to be placed or thrown in or on any street, alley, sidewalk or other public grounds of the city, any glass, tacks, nails, bottles, wire or other dangerous objects that might wound any person or animal, or cut or puncture any pneumatic tire while passing over the same. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-213) 
Sec. 32-103. - Petroleum products in streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or throw any waste oil, fuel oil, kerosene, gasoline or other products of petroleum or any acids into or upon any street or public grounds of the city, or willfully to permit the same to be spilled, dripped or otherwise to come into contact with the surface of any street, alley, or sidewalk within the city. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-214) 
Sec. 32-104. - Burning in streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make or cause to be made, any fire upon any of the paved streets, alleys, or street intersections within the city. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-215) 
Sec. 32-105. - Throwing in streets. 
    It shall be unlawful to throw or bat any ball, stone, or other hard substance into, on or across any street or alley or at or against any building or vehicle. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-216) 
Sec. 32-106. - Hauling loose material. 
    It shall be unlawful to haul over the streets or alleys of the city any loose material of any kind unless it is covered or tied down and except in a vehicle having a tight box so constructed as to prevent the splashing or spilling of any of the substances therein contained upon the streets or alleys. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-217) 
Sec. 32-107. - Obstructing rail crossing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any railroad company or any person operating a railroad in the city, to allow its trains, engines or cars to stand upon any crossing or street in excess of 15 minutes at any one time without leaving an opening in the traveled portion of the street or crossing of at least 30 feet wide. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-218) 
Sec. 32-108. - Train crew; warning. 
    It shall be unlawful for the conductor or engineer of any train, engine or moving cars not preceded by an engine to cross any street, alley or public place without causing a person to be stationed upon the end of the first car or at the crossing to warn of the approaching cars. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-219) 
Sec. 32-109. - Signals required. 
(a)  Every railroad company owning or operating a railroad through the city shall erect and maintain warning devices for the safety of persons crossing the railroad. 
(b)  Safety devices of the type indicated shall be located at the point where the railroad crosses the following streets or avenues in the city: gates and flashing signal devices. 
(1)  Washington Avenue; 
(2)  C Street; 
(3)  Jefferson Avenue; 
(4)  G Street; 
(5)  16th Street; 
(6)  Harvey Avenue; 
(7)  H Street; 
(8)  12th Street; 
(9)  Hillside Avenue. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any railroad company to fail to erect and maintain in proper working condition, safety warning devices of the type and at the locations set out herein. 
(Code 1974,  12-601; Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-220) 
Sec. 32-110. - Duties of railroad companies; improvements. 
    All railroad companies operating within the corporate limits of the city are hereby required to keep the streets and alleys over which they run properly drained, and to light the same whenever directed by the governing body, to construct, maintain and keep in repair to their full width all crossings over all streets, alleys and ditches used by them, to construct and maintain drains and culverts where crossed by any line of the railroad over all streets or alleys over which they run, and to comply with orders of the governing body of the city directing the laying and construction of railroad tracks, turnouts or switches and to regulate the grade of the same and requiring all such companies to conform to the grade of the streets and alleys of the city as they are now, or hereafter may be established. Such crossing shall be constructed, maintained and repaired in accordance with specifications now on file in the department of engineering. 
(Code 1996,  13-222; Ord. No. 3516,  1) 
Sec. 32-111. - Service of notice to comply. 
    A railroad company that has constructed or is not maintaining a railroad crossing in a manner that is in compliance with the requirements set forth in section 32-110 or is not otherwise complying with the requirements therein contained may be served with notice to comply by the city serving written notice of such noncompliance upon the resident agent of the railroad company. Such written notice shall identify the location of the crossing or other condition that does not comply with the requirements, and such notice shall specify the condition that needs to be corrected to bring such crossing or condition into compliance. 
(Code 1996,  13-223; Ord. No. 3516,  2) 
Sec. 32-112. - Penalty. 
    Any railroad company, after it has been served with a notice as provided in section 32-111 to construct or maintain suitable grade crossings or other improvements in compliance with section 32-111 at or over its tracks at a public grade crossing or to correct any other condition that is not in compliance with the requirements of section 32-110 and has failed, neglected or refused to commence such construction, maintenance or correction within 90 days, after the service of such notice upon said railroad company, or thereafter fails, neglects or refuses to complete the same within 180 days after service of such notice upon said railroad company, shall, upon conviction thereof be fined $100.00. Each day that any violation of section 32-111, this section, or both, continues shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as a separate violation. 
(Code 1996,  13-224; Ord. No. 3516,  3) 
Secs. 32-113-32-139. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PUBLIC TREES AND SHRUBS 

Sec. 32-140. - Care. 
    The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares and public grounds, as may be necessary to ensure safety when servicing city utilities or to preserve the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. The city may remove or cause or order to be removed, any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-401) 
Sec. 32-141. - Prevent spread of disease. 
    No tree, tree materials or shrubs as mentioned herein which have been cut down, either by the property owner or by the city shall be permitted to remain on the premises, but shall immediately be removed and burned, so as to prevent the spread of the tree disease. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-402) 
Sec. 32-142. - Trees on private property. 
    Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of eight feet above the surface of the street or right-of-way. The owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a street light, or interferes with visibility of any traffic control device or sign. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-403) 
Sec. 32-143. - Trees on public property; cost borne by city. 
    The city shall have the authority to treat or to remove any tree as defined in section 32-140, or to remove any dead tree as mentioned herein, which is located within the limits of any public right-of-way within the city. The adjacent property owners shall not be responsible for the cost of treatment or removal of any such trees within the public right-of-way and this expense shall be borne by the city at large. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-404) 
Sec. 32-144. - Trees in street parking. 
    No person shall plant or cultivate any tree, shrubbery, hedge or other plants in the parking of any street, or on land adjacent to any sidewalk or street parking unless the same are trimmed and maintained to prevent obstruction of the passage of vehicles and pedestrians over and along the roadway of any street or sidewalk of the city, as the case may be. All trees extending over any portion of a street shall be so trimmed that the branches or any portion thereof shall not overhang any sidewalk lower than eight feet from the surface thereof, nor lower than 14 feet from the roadway of any street or public way. It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of the property adjacent to any parking in which trees are cultivated to remove any dead trees or any dead or decayed limb or branch thereof constituting a hazard to the traveling public. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  13-221) 
Secs. 32-145-32-169. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MINOR STREET PRIVILEGES 

Sec. 32-170. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Minor street privilege means any authorized or permitted private right in, on, under or over public streets, alleys or ways, separate and distinct from the general public use of streets, alleys and ways, provided, however, that the term minor street privilege shall not apply to the short time use of public space in connection with building construction which is regulated by the building code adopted by the city, nor shall it apply to a public utility operating under a franchise granted by the city, nor shall it apply to hitching posts that are in existence and in place prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, and where the hitching post is specifically designed for the purpose of hitching horses thereto. 
    Permittee means a person in possession of a minor street privilege. The term includes the grantee of a minor street privilege who, in such grant, shall be the owner or lessee of the private property abutting the land on which the minor street privilege is granted. 
(Code 1996,  13-501; Ord. No. 3427,  1) 
Sec. 32-171. - Subject to regulations and permits as contained in article. 
    The enjoyment and use of minor street privileges by the permittee for private purposes, as hereinafter set forth in this article, shall be subject to regulations and permits as set forth in this article. 
(Code 1996,  13-502; Ord. No. 3427,  2) 
Sec. 32-172. - Permits for new privileges; application. 
    Application for any new minor street privileges shall be submitted to the city engineer by letter with appropriate drawings, plans or photographs attached. The application shall be made by the owner or lessee of abutting land, provided that a minor street privilege permit issued to a lessee shall in no event extend beyond the termination date of the lease under which the abutting property is being leased and provided further that the minor street privilege permit shall be automatically cancelled if the lessee's lease is terminated prior to the termination date set forth in the permit. 
(Code 1996,  13-504; Ord. No. 3427,  4) 
Sec. 32-173. - Approval of permit application; issuance. 
    On approval of the application referred to in section 32-172 by the city engineer, and the payment of the required fee, the permit shall be issued by the city engineer. 
(Code 1996,  13-505; Ord. No. 3427,  5) 
Sec. 32-174. - Authority of city engineer to grant renewal of permits previously issued. 
    The city engineer may grant renewals of permits previously granted under the provisions of this article upon the payment of annual permit fees to the city clerk and continuation in force of surety bond and/or liability insurance for such renewals unless the governing body of the city shall direct that no such renewals shall be issued. 
(Code 1996,  13-506; Ord. No. 3427,  6) 
Sec. 32-175. - Liability of permittee; to save and hold city harmless. 
    It shall be a condition of the use or enjoyment of any minor street privilege that the permittee shall save and hold the city harmless of any and all liability, claims or expenses of any kind whatsoever caused by, or growing out of the construction, maintenance, operation, use, relocation, discontinuance or abandonment of such minor street privileges; whether such claims are for damages or for injunctive relief. 
(Code 1996,  13-507; Ord. No. 3427,  7) 
Sec. 32-176. - Bond or liability insurance requirements. 
    Whenever, in the opinion of the city engineer, the construction, maintenance or abandonment of a minor street privilege permit is attended with the possibility of substantial damage or loss to the city, to other property owners, or to members of the public, the applicant for such minor street privilege shall furnish and file with the city clerk a surety bond or provide proof of liability insurance that names the city as an additional insured and provides that the city will be given ten days prior notice of cancellation in an amount determined by the city engineer to be sufficient to protect against such damage or loss; provided, however, that in all cases where previous special privileges for the use of streets and public places as provided for in this article have been granted by the governing body and bond has been posted or proof of insurance provided under such article, such bond shall continue in effect under the provisions of this article unless cancelled by the surety upon such bond. 
(Code 1996,  13-508; Ord. No. 3427,  8) 
Sec. 32-177. - Restoration of streets, etc.; cost. 
    The cost of all restoration, all adjustments in connection with all utilities and all other adjustments made necessary by the construction, maintenance, operation, relocation, discontinuance or abandonment of any minor street privilege shall be paid by the permittee. All such restoration and other necessary work of adjustment shall be performed in accordance with the provisions of this article and other articles, or in the absence of a regulatory article, shall, at the option of the city engineer, be performed by the permittee or by the city at the permittee's expense from funds deposited with the city by the permittee as provided for under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1996,  13-509; Ord. No. 3427,  9) 
Sec. 32-178. - Termination by the city for failure to pay permit fee; notice to permittee. 
    In case a permittee shall fail to pay the annual permit fee, with accrued penalties, for any minor street privilege within 30 days after the same shall be due and payable, the city engineer shall declare the privilege and permission terminated and shall immediately cause a notice of termination to be given the permittee. 
(Code 1996,  13-510; Ord. No. 3427,  10) 
Sec. 32-179. - Permittee to arrange for discontinuance and make restoration of property. 
    Upon termination of a privilege, under the provisions of this article, the city engineer shall notify the permittee to make all necessary arrangements for the discontinuance and abandonment of the privilege and make or cause restoration of the public property, all in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1996,  13-511; Ord. No. 3427,  11) 
Sec. 32-180. - Failure of permittee to make restoration; work to be done by city; cost. 
    If the permittee shall fail to make arrangements promptly, as required by the preceding section, the city engineer is authorized to perform the necessary work and charge the expense thereof to the permittee. In addition to the cost in section 32-177, the permittee shall be charged with proportionate permit fees for the period up to the date on which the work of restoration is completed. 
(Code 1996,  13-512; Ord. No. 3427,  12) 
Sec. 32-181. - Unlawful use of privileges. 
    It is unlawful for any person to make any use of a minor street privilege unless permission for such use has been authorized in accordance with the provisions of this article, and the use of any minor street privilege is prohibited unless the permit fee is paid as herein provided. 
(Code 1996,  13-513; Ord. No. 3427,  13) 
Sec. 32-182. - Control and supervision by city manager; generally. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, the city manager shall have full control of the supervision, inspection and regulation of minor street privileges. When the public safety or welfare shall require the temporary or permanent discontinuance or modification of a minor street privilege, the city manager shall take all action necessary for the public interest. If action by the governing body shall be required, the city manager shall advise the governing body who shall cause the necessary legislation to be prepared. 
(Code 1996,  13-514; Ord. No. 3427,  14) 
Sec. 32-183. - Rules and regulations. 
    The city manager is authorized to prepare and enforce reasonable rules and regulations to govern the carrying out of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1996,  13-515; Ord. No. 3427,  15) 
Sec. 32-184. - Revocation of privilege and proration of permit fees. 
    All minor street privileges provided for in this article are revocable. Upon any such minor street privilege being revoked during a period of time for which a permit fee has been paid, the city shall tender to the owner the annual fee paid on a prorata basis as determined by the city engineer. 
(Code 1996,  13-516; Ord. No. 3427,  16) 
Sec. 32-185. - Annual permit fees; established. 
    The annual permit fees for minor street privileges shall be on file in the city clerk's office. Any permittee desiring a minor street privilege permit approved under the provisions of this article shall upon approval of application pay the fee which is on file in the city clerk's office for the following; 
(1)  Scales for vehicles, docks or loading platforms, including steps and ramps, bridges from one building to another, buildings extended over or across and not supported by public property, ventilating and other ducts, roofs from one building to another, sidewalks elevators, coal holes, manholes and similar openings in, or structures on, under or over public property, per square foot of area occupied. 
(2)  Clock supported by public property, each, without advertising. 
(3)  Overhead hoist beams and cranes, each. 
(4)  Permanent flag poles supported by public property, each. 
(5)  Steps or landings on, under or over public property, per square foot. 
(6)  Tunnels for private use, per cubic foot. 
(7)  Tanks under public property, including necessary connection pipes and other appurtenances, per gallon capacity. All tank installations shall be regulated by the provisions of the fire code, building code and the zoning ordinance of the city as adopted by the governing body. No new tank installation shall be made, nor shall any tank now installed on, above or below public property be used for the storage of a commodity with a flash point below 100 degrees Fahrenheit, closed cup tester. 
(8)  Vaults or subsurface spaces other than tunnels. The space shall be measured from the private property line to the outside of the wall enclosing the space and from the floor of the space to the traffic surface. 
(9)  Car tracks (private, not operated by common carrier), per lineal foot of track. 
(10)  Pipe lines and conduits of one continuous length not exceeding 500 feet in length and two feet in diameter (not public utilities), per lineal foot for each additional lineal foot. (Over two feet in diameter not permitted except by special permission of the governing body, who shall determine the annual permit fee.) 
(11)  Wires (not public utilities), per lineal foot. 
(12)  Use of street, alley or other public space including public space upon which buildings are located, not used in connection with building construction, per square foot for grants of a minor street privilege permit that will involve the use of 5,000 square feet of land or less and a fee negotiated by the city manager, subject to the approval of the governing body, for grants of a minor street privilege permit that will involve the use of more than 5,000 square feet of land. 
(13)  Wells, either supply or discharge, on public property, including necessary connecting pipes and appurtenances. 
(Code 1996,  13-517; Ord. No. 3427,  17) 
Sec. 32-186. - Administrative charge; designated. 
    Any minor street privilege permit authorized under this article which does not require an annual fee as on file in the city clerk's office shall be required to pay an administrative fee which is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1996,  13-518; Ord. No. 3427,  18) 
Sec. 32-187. - Charge in addition to inspection, construction and other permit fees. 
    All permit fees established for the enjoyment of minor street privileges shall be separate from and in addition to inspection, construction and other permit fees. 
(Code 1996,  13-519; Ord. No. 3427,  19) 
Sec. 32-188. - Fees; payment and disposition. 
    Permit fees and administrative charge, except for existing uses, shall be payable in advance prior to the issuance of the annual permit, and shall be for a term of one year from the date of its issuance. The receipt for payment of such fee in each successive year shall constitute a renewal of the annual permit. All permit fees received under the provisions of this article shall be at once transmitted to the city clerk, and the permit shall serve as a receipt. 
(Code 1996,  13-520; Ord. No. 3427,  20) 
Sec. 32-189. - Exception. 
(a)  With the exception of the administrative charge as set forth in section 32-186, no annual permit fee shall be paid for a minor street privilege when the granting of such privilege is coupled with and is a part of the public requirement or consideration for the taking of land by the city in connection with the city's approval of a plat or lot split. 
(b)  The administrative charge shall accompany the application when a waiver of annual permit fee is requested. The application for a minor street privilege shall state the reasons for the waiver, and shall be accompanied by drawings, plans or photographs showing all encroachments and describing their nature and specifications. Upon the approval of the minor street privilege by the city engineer the appropriate drawings, plans or photographs shall be made a part of the permit, and the recipient of the minor street privilege, by its acceptance of the minor street privilege, shall be obligated to indemnify the city for any and all costs of removal of any unauthorized improvements not constructed according to the documents submitted and approved or not included in the minor street privilege. 
(c)  The permit fee for minor street privilege, with the exception of the administrative charge as set forth in section 32-186, may be waived by the city engineer when the city engineer determines the project to be one involving public safety, handicap accessibility, beautification or improvement of public property for public purposes, or when the project involves a door not more than 36 inches in width which opens onto a public sidewalk and is used only as an emergency exit from a building and for no other purpose, is equipped on the inside with an approved panic bar and remains locked from the outside at all times except in cases of an emergency. 
(d)  No permit fee for the issuance of a minor street privilege shall be required to be paid for use of public right-of-way that has been fenced for private use prior to annexation by the city for a period of ten years from the date of enactment of the ordinance from which this article is derived or for a period of ten years from the date of annexation of land wherein fence is located prior to annexation that is subsequent in time to the enactment of this article. A person making application for such minor street privilege shall comply with all other provisions of this article in obtaining a minor street privilege permit including the requirement to post a surety bond and/or provide proof of liability insurance that names the city as an additional insured. A person to be eligible to waiver of payment of fees herein must make application for a minor street privilege within six months of the date of enactment of the ordinance from which this article is derived or within six months of subsequent annexation of land wherein fence is located prior to annexation. 
(e)  Any person aggrieved by the action of the city engineer may appeal the city engineer's ruling on the waiver to the governing body by requesting a hearing before the governing body within 30 days of notification of the decision of the city engineer. 
(Code 1996,  13-521; Ord. No. 3632,  1) 
Sec. 32-190. - Penalty for failure to pay fees when due. 
    All permits not paid within 30 days after the due date shall be subject to a penalty of ten percent of the amount of permit fee, and ten percent of the amount of the permit fee shall be added for each additional 30 days from the due date. 
(Code 1996,  13-522; Ord. No. 3427,  22) 
Sec. 32-191. - Limitations on new encroachments. 
    All encroachments on public streets, alleys or ways shall continue to be regulated in accordance with all applicable laws, provisions of this article and other articles and rules. Nothing in this article shall be construed to mean that permits for new encroachments will be issued when such encroachments conflict with such regulations. 
(Code 1996,  13-523; Ord. No. 3427,  23) 
Sec. 32-192. - Right of city in civil action to recover permit fees and cost of restoration. 
    In addition to the penalty prescribed in section 32-190, the city may recover in a civil action in any court of competent jurisdiction, the amount of the permit fees imposed and/or the actual cost of restoration. No property of such debtor shall be exempt from forced sale under any process of law for such indebtedness, except such exemptions as allowed by the constitution and the laws of this state. 
(Code 1996,  13-524; Ord. No. 3427,  24) 
Chapter 34 - SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Planning and zoning, K.S.A. 12-715b et seq.; authority to adopt subdivision regulations, K.S.A. 12-749. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 34-1. - Purpose and intent. 
    It is the purpose of these regulations to provide for proper and harmonious development practices toward the goal of fostering wise use and conservation of the land resources of the city's planning and zoning jurisdiction. Within this purpose, these regulations are intended: 
(1)  To protect and provide for the public health, safety and general welfare of the city. 
(2)  To preserve the natural beauty and topography of the municipality and to ensure appropriate development with regard to these natural features. 
(3)  To provide for adequate light, air, and privacy; to secure safety from fire, flood, and other danger; and to prevent overcrowding of the land and undue congestion of population. 
(4)  To guide the future growth and development of the city in accordance with the comprehensive plan. 
(5)  To establish reasonable standards of design and procedures for subdivision and re-subdivisions; to further the orderly layout and use of land to ensure proper legal descriptions and proper monumenting of subdivided land. 
(6)  To provide for the actual construction of physical improvements. 
(7)  To provide equitable processing of all subdivisions and land development proposals by providing uniform procedures and standards. 
(Ord. No. 3826(2), art. I,  2, 7-3-2001) 
Sec. 34-2. - Authority. 
    These regulations are adopted pursuant to powers and jurisdictions authorized by K.S.A. 12-741 et seq. and other applicable laws, statutes, and regulations of the state and amendments thereto. 
(Ord. No. 3826(2), art. I,  3, 7-3-2001) 
Sec. 34-3. - Jurisdiction. 
    These regulations shall apply to all land located within the zoning jurisdiction of the city, and to such municipal jurisdictions as may be added by interlocal agreement. 
(Ord. No. 3826(2), art. I,  4, 7-3-2001) 
Sec. 34-4. - Applicability. 
    The regulations contained herein shall apply to the subdivision of a tract or parcel of land into two or more lots, tracts, or other divisions of land for the purpose of sale or building development, whether immediate or future, including the re-subdivision or replatting of land or lots. 
(Ord. No. 3826(2), art. I,  5, 7-3-2001) 
Sec. 34-5. - Exemptions. 
    The following shall be exempt from the requirements of these regulations: 
(1)  Any lot, parcel, or tract of land within the area of jurisdiction which was legally subdivided, re-subdivided, or replatted prior to the adoption of these regulations. 
(2)  Any lot, parcel, or tract of land which has been ordered by law to be partitioned. 
(3)  Correction of a legal description in a prior conveyance. 
(4)  Land which is to be used for cemetery purposes. 
(5)  A division of land in accordance with the provisions of these regulations which creates no more than one additional lot or tract and which does not involve any new streets or easements of access; is not located in area subject to flooding; which meets the standards set by these regulations for the disposal of sewage and for water supply including lot size; and which conforms with any applicable zoning regulations, provided that the resulting tracts shall not again be divided without replatting. 
(6)  A transaction between owners of adjoining land involving only a change in the boundary between the land owned by such persons and which does not create an additional lot or which does not result in the creation of a substandard lot by either owner according to any applicable zoning regulations or sanitary code. 
(7)  The re-subdivision of land used for industrial purposes. 
(8)  A division of land for agricultural purposes into parcels or tracts of not less than five acres, which will not involve any new streets or easements of access and will not affect major streets. 
(9)  Land used for a public purpose including the dedication of a parcel of land for a public use or instruments relating to the vacation of land for a public use. 
(10)  Land used for street or railroad right-of-way, a drainage easement or other public utilities subject to local, state or federal regulations, where no new street or easement of access is involved. 
(Ord. No. 3826(2), art. I,  6, 7-3-2001) 
Sec. 34-6. - Restrictive covenants. 
    The city shall have the right to confer with the subdivider regarding the type and character of development that will be permitted in the subdivision and may require certain minimum regulations be incorporated in the subdivision and/or deed restrictions. Such regulations shall protect the character and value of the development within the subdivision and the value of surrounding property. 
(Ord. No. 3826(2), art. I,  7, 7-3-2001) 
Sec. 34-7. - Interpretation. 
(a)  In their interpretation and application, the provisions of these regulations shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public health, safety, and general welfare. 
(b)  These regulations are not intended to interfere with, abrogate, or annul any other resolution, regulation, statute, or other provision of law. Where any provision herein imposes restrictions, different from those imposed by any other provision of these regulations or any other resolution, regulation, or other provision of law, whichever provisions are more restrictive or impose higher standards shall control. 
(c)  These regulations are not intended to abrogate any easement, covenant, or other private agreement, provided; however, that where the requirements of these regulations are more restrictive or impose higher standards or regulations than such easement, covenant, or other private agreement, the requirements of these regulations shall govern. 
(d)  A subdivision of land which was not lawfully existing at the time of the adoption of these regulations shall not become or be made lawful solely by reason of the adoption of the ordinance from which these regulations were derived. 
(Ord. No. 3826(2), art. I,  8, 7-3-2001) 
Sec. 34-8. - Rules of construction. 
    Unless the context clearly indicates to the contrary: 
(1)  The word "shall" is always mandatory and the word "may" is always permissive. 
(2)  The words "used" or "occupied," as applied to any land or building, shall be construed to include the words "intended, arranged, or designed to be used or occupied." 
(3)  The word "building" includes "structure," and a building or a structure includes any part thereof. 
(4)  The singular number includes the plural and the plural the singular. 
(5)  The present tense includes the past and future tenses and the future the present. 
(Ord. No. 3826(2), art. I,  9, 7-3-2001) 
Sec. 34-9. - Notice to county. 
    Whenever amendments to the text of these regulations are proposed, written notice of such proposed action shall be given to the board of county commissioners at least 20 days prior to the proposed action. 
(Ord. No. 3826(2), art. I,  10, 7-3-2001) 
Sec. 34-10. - Applicability and definitions. 
(a)  Applicability. For the purposes of these regulations, certain numbers, abbreviations, and words used herein shall be used, interpreted, and defined as set forth in this section. Any word or phrase which is defined in this section, or elsewhere in these regulations, shall have the meaning as so defined whenever the word or phrase is used, unless such definition is expressly limited in its meaning or scope. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words and phrases, when used in these regulations, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Administrator means a person designated by the governing body as the administrator of these regulations. 
    Agriculture means the use of a tract of land under one ownership for growing crops, pasturage, horticulture, nurseries, truck farms, dairying, or the raising of poultry or cattle and other livestock, including commercial feed lots and the structures necessary for carrying out farming operations and the dwelling of those owning and/or operating the premises such as a member of the family thereof or persons employed thereon and their families. The feeding or disposal of community or collected garbage shall not be deemed an agricultural use. 
    Alley means a public or private right-of-way primarily designed to serve as secondary access to the side or rear of those properties whose principal frontage is on some other street. 
    Applicant means the owner or duly designated representative of land proposed to be subdivided, or for which other action has been requested. Consent shall be required from the legal owner of the premises. 
    Approved public sanitary sewer system means a sewage disposal plant, main sanitary sewer lines and other lines approved by the city and by the state department of health. 
    Approved public water system means water treatment plant and service lines approved by the city and by the state department of health. 
    Area means the size of a piece of land, usually described in terms of square feet or acres. 
    Arterial street means any street serving major traffic movements which is designed primarily as a traffic carrier between cities or between various sections of a city or county, which forms part of a network of through streets, and which provides service and access to abutting properties only as a secondary function. 
    Block means a tract of land bounded by streets, or by a combination of streets and public parks, cemeteries, railroads, rights-of-way, shorelines, or boundary lines of the municipality. 
    Bond means a form of security, including a cash deposit, surety bond, collateral, property, or instrument of credit in an amount and form satisfactory to the city governing body. 
    Building means any covered structure built for the support, shelter, or enclosure of persons, animals, chattels, or movable property of any kind and which is permanently affixed to the land. 
    Building setback line means a line on a lot indicating the limit beyond which buildings or structures may not be erected or altered and establishing the minimum open space to be provided. Such line may be more, but not less restrictive than applicable zoning or other regulations. 
    Collector street means any street designed primarily to gather traffic from local or residential streets and carry it to the arterial system. 
    Comprehensive plan means the adopted comprehensive development plan for City of Wellington including modifications or refinements which may be made by amendments from time-to-time. 
    County means Sumner County, Kansas. 
    County engineer means the person responsible to perform the duties of the city engineer including any and all special engineers as appointed by the governing body. 
    Cul-de-sac means a street having only one outlet and being permanently terminated by a vehicle turnaround at the other end. 
    Dead-end street means a street having only one outlet. 
    Design means the location of streets, alignment of streets, grades and widths of streets, alignment of easements, grades and widths of easements, alignment and rights-of-way for drainage and sanitary sewers, and the designation of minimum lot area, width and length. 
    Developer means the legal or beneficial owner of all of the land proposed to be included in a subdivision or planned development or duly authorized agent thereof, the holder of an option or contract to purchase, a lessee having a remaining term of not less than 40 years, or other person having an enforceable proprietary interest in such land, shall be deemed to be a developer for the purpose of these regulations. 
    Easement means a grant by a property owner of the specific use of a strip of land by others. 
    Engineer . When used in the sense as designing or surveying the plat or subdivision, an engineer shall be a professional engineer or a surveyor licensed by the state or licensed to practice in the state. When used in connection with designing or engineering any improvements either on site or off site, an engineer shall be a professional engineer licensed by the state or licensed to practice in the state. 
    Fence means a freestanding structure of metal, masonry composition, or wood or any combination thereof resting on or partially buried in the ground and rising above ground level, used for confinement, screening or partition purposes. 
    Final plat means a subdivision as it is represented as a formal document by drawing and writing which is prepared in accordance with these regulations, to be placed on record with the county of register of deeds. 
    Floodplain means a watercourse and land adjacent to a watercourse subject to inundation from a flood having a chance occurrence in any one year of one percent. 
    Frontage means the property on one side of a street between two intersecting streets (crossing or terminating) measured along the line of the street; or with a dead-end street, all property abutting one side of such street measured from the nearest intersecting street and the end of the dead-end street. 
    Governing body means the city council of the City of Wellington, Kansas, unless otherwise identified as another city, township or county governing body cooperating in the installation of improvements. 
    Half-street means a street bordering one or more property lines of a subdivision tract to which the subdivider has allocated only a portion of the ultimate and intended street width. 
    Improvements means all facilities constructed or erected by a subdivider or the general public within a subdivision to permit and facilitate the use of lots or blocks for a principal residential, commercial, or industrial use. 
    Land use plan means a portion of the comprehensive plan indicating the general anticipated use of the land within the city planning jurisdiction. 
    Landscaping means the improvement of a lot, parcel, or tract of land with grass, shrubs, and/or trees. The term "landscaping" may include pedestrian walks, flowerbeds, ornamental objects such as fountains, statuary, and other similar natural and artificial objects designed and arranged to produce an aesthetically pleasing effect. 
    Local street means any street designed primarily to provide access to abutting property and of limited continuity within a neighborhood. 
    Lot means a portion of land in a subdivision, or other parcel of land, intended to be the unit by which such land would be individually transferred and/or developed, whether immediate or future. 
    Lot depth means the distance between the midpoint of the front lot line and the midpoint of the rear lot line. 
    Lot, double frontage, means a lot, two opposite lot lines of which abut upon streets which are more or less parallel. 
    Lot line means the boundary line of a lot. 
    Lot split means the dividing or re-dividing of a lot or lots in a recorded plat of a subdivision into not more than two tracts which meet the criteria established within these regulations. 
    Lot width means the distance on a horizontal plane between the side lot lines of a lot, measured at right angles to the line establishing the lot depth at the established building setback line. 
    Major street means a street, highway or roadway designated as such on the official major street plan of the comprehensive plan. 
    Marginal access streets means a local street which is parallel with and adjacent to a limited access highway or arterial street, and which provides access to abutting properties and protection from fast through traffic on the limited access highway or arterial street.
