ARTICLE III. - LOCAL TRAFFIC REGULATIONS 

Sec. 36-50. - School zones. 
    For purposes of enforcing speed limitations in school zones, the following zones are hereby determined and designated as school zones: 
(1)  For Roosevelt Elementary School and the middle and senior high schools: 
a.  A Street between Harvey Avenue and 12th Street; 
b.  B Street between Harvey Avenue and 9th Street; 
c.  7th Street between Ash Street and C Street; 
d.  8th Street between A Street and C Street; 
e.  9th Street between Woodlawn Street and B Street; 
f.  10th Street between A Street and B Street; and 
g.  11th Street between A Street and B Street. 
(2)  For Kennedy Elementary School: 
a.  Woodlawn Street between 9th Street and Waldo Street; and 
b.  Woodsway between Woodlawn Street and Gardner Street. 
(3)  For Lincoln Elementary School: 
a.  Harvey Avenue between Jefferson Avenue and H Street; 
b.  Lincoln Avenue between Jefferson Avenue and H Street; 
c.  F Street between 4th Street and 7th Street; 
d.  G Street between 4th Street and 7th Street; and 
e.  8th Street between U.S. Highway 81 and Jefferson Street. 
(4)  For Eisenhower Elementary School: 
a.  Plum Street between College Avenue and 17th Street; 
b.  Orchard Street between Poplar Street and Plum Street; 
c.  16th Street between Poplar Street and a point 300 feet west of High Drive; 
d.  Edgewood Drive between Morningside Drive and High Drive; and 
e.  College Avenue between Plum Street and High Drive. 
(5)  For Washington Elementary School: 
a.  Washington Avenue between 17th Street and 19th Street; 
b.  C Street between 17th Street and 19th Street; 
c.  18th Street between B Street and Jefferson Avenue. 
(Code 1996,  14-201; Ord. No. 3478,  8; Ord. No. 3809,  XII, 5-2-2000) 
Sec. 36-51. - Careless driving. 
    No person shall operate or halt any vehicle in such a manner as to indicate a careless or heedless disregard for the rights or the safety of others, or in such a manner as to endanger or be likely to endanger any person or property. 
(Code 1996,  14-203; Ord. No. 3345,  3) 
Sec. 36-52. - Insurance required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to own or operate any motor vehicle in violation of the provisions of K.S.A. 40-3104, relating to motor vehicle liability insurance. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  14-204) 
State Law reference- Required insurance coverage, K.S.A. 40-3104. 
Sec. 36-53. - Bicycles and motorcycles. 
(a)  Any person riding upon any bicycle, motorcycle, coaster, sled, roller skates or any toy vehicle shall not attach such person or such article to any moving vehicle upon any roadway. 
(b)  No person shall ride any bicycle or motorcycle on any sidewalk located in the central business district defined as Jefferson Avenue to C Street and 3rd Street to 9th Street. 
(c)  No person shall park any bicycle or motorcycle on the sidewalks on Washington Avenue between Ninth Street and Fourth Street, except in the racks if available for such parking. 
(d)  No person shall ride skateboards, skates, coasters, or similar devices upon any sidewalk in the area bounded by and including sidewalks on the west side of Jefferson Avenue, the south side of Third Street, the east side of C Street and the north side of Eleventh Street. Nothing herein contained shall be construed to prohibit the use of self-propelled wheel chairs or carts by person who are handicapped or are convalescing. 
(e)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than $1.00 and not exceeding $50.00. 
(Code 1996,  14-205; Ord. No. 3547,  1) 
Sec. 36-54. - Speed limits on Highway U.S. 160. 
    The speed limits on Highway U.S. 160, also known as East 16th Street, between North A Street in the city and the east corporate limits of the city shall be as follows: 
(1)  From the east line of North A Street to a point 1,200 feet east of the east line of said North A Street, as posted; 
(2)  From a point 1,200 feet east of the east line of North A Street to the east corporate limits of the city, as posted. 
(Code 1996,  14-206; Ord. No. 3117,  1) 
Sec. 36-55. - Main trafficways. 
    The following list of streets are hereby designated as main trafficways with primary functions of said trafficways for the moving of through traffic between areas of concentrated activities and between such areas within the city and traffic facilities outside the city all pursuant to K.S.A. 12-685: 
(1)  15th Street from its intersection with Vandenburgh Avenue east to its intersection with North A Street; 
(2)  East 16th Street from its intersection with North A Street to the east corporate limits of the city; 
(3)  The street running northeasterly from the intersection of North A Street and East 15th Street approximately 100 feet to East 16th Street; 
(4)  North A Street from its intersection with East 15th Street north to its intersection with Commerce Road; 
(5)  Vandenburgh Avenue northeasterly from 15th Street to North A Street; 
(6)  West Eighth Street from its intersection with North G Street in the city, west to the west corporate limits of the city; 
(7)  West Harvey Avenue in the city from its intersection with Vandenburg Avenue (U.S. Highway 81) west to the east line of Wood's Park; 
(8)  16th Street; 
(9)  8 th Street throughout the city; 
(10)  Jefferson Avenue from U.S. 160 to Botkin Street; 
(11)  Washington Avenue from 21 st Street to Botkin Street; 
(12)  H Street, G Street and C Street, at their crossings with BNSF Railway tracks; 
(13)  Fair Street from Lincoln Avenue to and including its intersection with 4 th Street; 
(14)  Lincoln Avenue located within the limits of the city; and 
(15)  9 th Street from Washington Avenue to Woodlawn Avenue. 
(Code 1996,  14-207; Ord. No. 3305; Ord. No. 3183; Ord. No. 3529,  1; Ord. No. 3571,  1; Ord. No. 3843,  1, 4-2-2002; Ord. No. 4157,  1, 5-20-2014; Ord. No. 4133,  1, 5-7-2017; Ord. No. 4232,  1, 10-2-2018) 
State Law reference- Designation of main trafficways, K.S.A. 12-685. 
Sec. 36-56. - Unlawful parking. 
    Rules and regulations governing unlawful parking shall be as follows: 
(1)  No person shall stand or park a vehicle upon any street or alley: 
a.  For the principal purpose of displaying any advertisement therefrom; 
b.  For the purpose of washing, greasing or repairing such vehicles, except repairs necessitated by an emergency; 
c.  For the principal purpose of displaying it for sale; 
d.  For a period of time longer than 24 consecutive hours. 
(2)  No motor vehicle connected to a semitrailer or a semitrailer alone, shall hereafter stand or park upon any street or alley for a period of time longer than one hour, except when loading or unloading; provided that the governing body may by resolution suspend the provisions of this section for purposes of public welfare, convenience or necessity. 
(Code 1974,  23-501; Code 1996,  14-208) 
Sec. 36-57. - Parking of trucks on Washington Avenue prohibited. 
    No vehicle or combination of vehicles which shall exceed an overall length of 18 feet shall be parked at any time on Washington Avenue from Fourth Street to Eighth Street. 
(Code 1974,  23-502; Code 1996,  14-209) 
Sec. 36-58. - Parking at city administration center restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful to stop, park or leave standing a motor vehicle of any kind whatsoever, or by any other means occupy or use, any area or areas of land on the north and on the south sides of the city administration center at 317 South Washington Avenue in the city on Lots 13 to 19, inclusive, Block 82, Original Town, City of Wellington, for any purpose other than conducting or transacting business at the city administration center, or attending meetings at the center, except that for the area on the north side of the city administration center between the hours of 5:00 p.m. Friday to 6:00 a.m. Monday, temporary parking will be allowed for the general use of the public in designated parking spaces. 
(Code 1996,  14-210; Ord. No. 3704,  1) 
Sec. 36-59. - Bus loading zone. 
    "No Parking-Bus Loading Zones" may be established by the city engineer and signs shall be posted in these areas. 
(Code 1996,  14-211; Ord. No. 3507,  1; Ord. No. 3524,  1; Ord. No. 3649,  1) 
Sec. 36-60. - No parking zones. 
(a)  No parking zones may be established by the city engineer and signs shall be posted in these areas. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person or operator to park a motor vehicle in front of or within the approach to a public or private driveway or alley, or within eight feet of the line formed by the extension of the edge of the public or private driveway or alley. 
(Code 1996,  14-212; Ord. No. 3507,  2:3; Ord. No. 3528,  1; Ord. No. 3669,  1) 
Sec. 36-61. - Weight limits; bridges. 
    The following truck load limits shall be established for the bridges designated herein: 
(1)  3rd Street bridge over Hargis Creek: 
a.  For single-axle trucks, as posted; 
b.  For three-axle tractor semi-trailers, as posted; and 
c.  For truck and trailer combinations, as posted. 
(2)  A Street bridge over Hargis Creek: A maximum load limit as posted. 
(Code 1996,  14-213; Ord. No. 3492,  1; Ord. No. 3553,  1) 
Sec. 36-62. - Loud sound amplification systems prohibited. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Plainly audible means any sound produced by a sound amplification system from within the vehicle, which clearly can be heard at a distance of 50 feet or more. Measurement standards shall be by the auditory senses, based upon direct line of sight. Words or phrases need not be discernible and bass reverberations are included. The motor vehicle may be stopped, standing, parked or moving on a street, highway, alley, parking lot, or driveway. 
    Sound amplification system means any radio, tape player, compact disc player, loudspeaker, or other electronic device used for the amplification of sound. 
(b)  No person operating or occupying a motor vehicle on a street, highway, alley, parking lot, or driveway shall operate or permit the operation of any sound amplification system from within the vehicle so that the sound is plainly audible at a distance of 50 or more feet from the vehicle. 
(c)  It is an affirmative defense to a charge under this section, that the operator was not otherwise prohibited by law from operating the sound amplification system, and that any of the following apply: 
(1)  The system was being operated to request medical or vehicular assistance or to warn of a hazardous road condition; 
(2)  The vehicle was an emergency or public safety vehicle; 
(3)  The vehicle was owned and operated by the city, or a gas, electric, communications or refuse company; 
(4)  The system was used for the purpose of giving instructions, directions, talks, addresses, lectures or transmitting music to any persons or assemblages of person in compliance with ordinances of the city; 
(5)  The vehicle was used in authorized public activities, such as parades, fireworks, sports events, musical productions and other activities which have the approval of the department of the city authorized to grant such approval. 
(Code 1996,  14-214; Ord. No. 3639,  1) 
Sec. 36-63. - Handicapped parking zones. 
    A handicapped parking zone may be established by the city engineer and signs shall be posted in these zones. 
(Code 1996,  14-215; Ord. No. 3654,  1; Ord. No. 3659,  1) 
Sec. 36-64. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4186,  II, adopted Oct. 20, 2015, repealed  36-64 in its entirety. Former  36-64 pertained to regulating parking and derived from the Code of 1996,  14-216; and Ord. No. 3669,  1:2. 
Sec. 36-65. - Speed limit; construction zones. 
    The maximum speed limit in a construction zone within the city limits, when properly posted, is as posted. 
(Code 1996,  14-217; Ord. No. 3610,  1) 
Sec. 36-66. - Penalty. 
    Any person convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this article for which another penalty is not provided shall be punished as provided in section 201 of the Standard Traffic Ordinance for Kansas Cities, as incorporated by section 36-19. 
(Code 1992; Code 1996,  14-218) 
Secs. 36-67-36-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TRUCK ROUTES 

Sec. 36-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Truck means any vehicle designed or operated for the transportation of property, and whose body weight exceeds 7,000 pounds. 
(Code 1996,  14-301; Ord. No. 3368,  1) 
Sec. 36-92. - Application of regulation. 
    No trucks shall be operated over and along any of the streets hereinafter designated in this article over which truck travel is prohibited; except, however, that this article shall not prohibit: 
(1)  The operation of trucks upon any street where necessary to the conduct of business at a point of origin or at a destination point, provided streets upon which such traffic is permitted are used until reaching the intersection nearest the destination point or the point of origin; 
(2)  The operation of emergency vehicles upon any street in the city; 
(3)  The operation of trucks owned or operated by the city public utilities or public utilities franchised by the city, or any contractor or material person, while engaged in the repair, maintenance or construction of public utilities, or in the repair, maintenance, construction or improvement of streets; 
(4)  The operation of trucks upon any established detour in any case where such truck could lawfully be operated upon the street for which such detour is established. 
(Code 1996,  14-302; Ord. No. 3368,  2) 
Sec. 36-93. - Truck travel prohibited. 
(a)  Truck travel is hereby prohibited on all streets, avenues, highways and public ways in the city, except the following: 
(1)  "A" Street (US-81) from the North City limits to 15th Street (US-160). 
(2)  Vandenburgh Avenue from "A" Street (US-81) to 15th Street (US-160). 
(3)  US-81/160 from 15th Street (US-160) to 8th Street (US-160). 
(4)  US-81 from 8th Street (US-160) to the south city limits. 
(5)  Crestview Road from the north city limits to 8th Street (US-160). 
(6)  Jefferson Avenue from 15th Street (US-160) to Botkin Street. 
(7)  Washington Avenue from 15th Street (US-160) to Botkin Street. 
(8)  Woodlawn Street from 16th Street (US-160) to Lincoln Avenue. 
(9)  High Street from 8th Street (US-160) to Harvey Street. 
(10)  Fair Street from Lincoln Street to 1st Street. 
(11)  Arthur Street from Lincoln Street to 4th Street. 
(12)  Woodlawn Street from 1st Street to Botkin Street. 
(13)  Hillside Street from "A" Street (US-81) to the west city limits. 
(14)  15th Street (US-160) from Vandenburgh Avenue to "A" Street. 
(15)  16th Street from "A" Street to the east city limits. 
(16)  16th Street from Vandenburgh Avenue to Crestview Avenue. 
(17)  8th Street from Washington Avenue to US-81/160. 
(18)  8th Street (US-160) from US-81/160 to the west city limits. 
(19)  Harvey Avenue from Washington Avenue to High Street. 
(20)  Lincoln Avenue from Washington Avenue to Arthur Street. 
(21)  4th Street from Arthur Street to the east city limits. 
(22)  1st Street from Fair Street to the east city limits. 
(23)  Botkin Street from US-81 to Woodlawn Street. 
(b)  The streets, avenues, highways and public ways described in subsection (a) of this section may be used for truck travel. 
(Code 1996,  14-303; Ord. No. 3480,  1; Ord. No. 3758,  1, 3-18-1997) 
Sec. 36-94. - Truck traffic in the city. 
(a)  All trucks entering the city for a destination point in the city shall proceed only over streets on which truck travel is not prohibited and shall deviate only at the intersection with a street upon which such traffic is permitted nearest to the destination point. Upon leaving the destination point, a deviating truck shall return to a street on which truck travel is permitted by the shortest possible route. 
(b)  All trucks entering the city for multiple destination points shall proceed only over streets on which truck travel is not prohibited and shall deviate only at the intersection with a street upon which such traffic is permitted nearest to the first destination point. Upon leaving the first destination point a deviating truck shall proceed to other destination points by the shortest possible route. Upon leaving the last designation point, a deviating truck shall return to a street on which truck travel is permitted by the shortest possible route. 
(c)  All trucks on a trip originating in the city and traveling in the city for a destination point outside the city shall proceed by the shortest direction over streets on which such traffic is permitted to the corporate limits of the city. 
(d)  All trucks on a trip originating in the city and traveling in the city for destination points in the city shall proceed only over streets upon which such traffic is permitted. 
(Code 1996,  14-304; Ord. No. 3368,  4) 
Sec. 36-95. - Maintain maps. 
    The city engineering department shall keep and maintain accurate maps setting out streets upon which truck traffic is prohibited; the maps shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk and shall be available for inspection by the public during regular business hours. 
(Code 1996,  14-305; Ord. No. 3368,  5) 
Sec. 36-96. - City engineer maintains signs. 
    The city engineer shall cause all streets upon which truck traffic is prohibited to be clearly signed to give notice that this article is in effect and that truck traffic is prohibited on such street. No person shall be charged with violating the provisions of this article by reason of operating a truck upon a street wherein truck travel is prohibited unless appropriate signs are posted on such street. 
(Code 1996,  14-306; Ord. No. 3368,  5) 
Sec. 36-97. - Weigh-in authorized. 
    The chief of police shall have the authority to require any person driving, or in control of any commercial vehicle proceeding over a street over which truck traffic is prohibited to proceed to any public or private scale within a reasonable distance for the purpose of weighing and determining whether this article has been complied with. 
(Code 1996,  14-307; Ord. No. 3368,  5) 
Sec. 36-98. - Penalties. 
    Any person who shall violate the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than $100.00, or be imprisoned not exceeding three months, or be both so fined and imprisoned. 
(Code 1996,  14-308; Ord. No. 3368,  6) 
Secs. 36-99-36-124. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - IMPOUNDMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Impoundment of abandoned vehicles, K.S.A. 8-1102. 

Sec. 36-125. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Highway means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. Where the term "highway" or the term "street" is used in this article, it means street, avenue, boulevard, thoroughfare, alley, and other public way for vehicular travel by whatever name, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
    Motor vehicle means every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, except devices moved by human power or used exclusively on stationary rails or tracks. 
    Owner or occupant means a party having fee simple title in the real property, or a party having a leasehold interest in the real property, or a party who is the beneficiary of a private easement for the purpose of egress or ingress to or from the real property. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  14-402) 
Sec. 36-126. - Impounding vehicles. 
    The police department may cause to be impounded: 
(1)  Any motor vehicle unlawfully parked on a highway in violation of any provision of a city ordinance which prohibits the parking of vehicles at the place where or time when the impounded motor vehicle is found. 
(2)  Any motor vehicle that has been abandoned and left on a highway or other property open to use by the public for a period in excess of 48 hours pursuant to K.S.A. 8-1102. 
(3)  Any motor vehicle which: 
a.  Is subject to removal pursuant to K.S.A. 8-1570 or 8-1102; or 
b.  Is subject to being held for use as evidence in a criminal trial. 
(4)  Any motor vehicle, the continued presence of which, because of the physical location or condition of the motor vehicle, poses a danger to the public safety or to the motor vehicle. 
(5)  Any motor vehicle which has been abandoned or parked on any real property, other than public property or property open to use by the public, may be moved and disposed of in accordance with the terms of this article by the police department upon the request of the owner or occupant of such real property. The real property referred to herein shall not be owned or leased by the person who abandons or parks the vehicle or by the owner or leasee of such vehicle. The city, or any person, partnership, corporation or their agent conducting a business enterprise for the purpose of towing vehicles which removes such vehicle from the real property at the request of the police department shall have a possessory lien on such vehicle for the cost incurred in removing, towing and storing such vehicle. For purposes of this article, common areas shall be construed not to mean public property or property open to the public. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  14-402) 
Sec. 36-127. - Police department may authorize storage of impounded vehicles. 
    The police department may authorize storage of such impounded motor vehicles at any location, public or private, which is zoned for the storage of motor vehicles. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  14-403) 
Sec. 36-128. - Notice of impoundment; storage of vehicle. 
(a)  When owner present. When the police department intends to impound a motor vehicle pursuant to section 36-126 and the owner of the motor vehicle is then present, the police department shall before the motor vehicle is removed, provide the owner with a notice, in the form prescribed by the police department that the motor vehicle is being impounded, that towing and storage charges will be assessed against the impounded motor vehicle, that the owner may claim and regain possession of the impounded motor vehicle at the location to which it is being removed for storage without prepayment of towing and storage charges and that the owner may request a hearing as to the propriety of the impoundment and as to the amount of and the owner's liability for the towing and storage charges. The notice shall also state the location where the impounded motor vehicle will be stored and the place where the owner may make his request for the hearing. The notice shall also state, in prominent language, that failure by the owner to request a hearing within five days after receipt of the notice may act as a waiver of his right to a hearing and that this may result in the placing of a lien against the motor vehicle for the towing and storage charges without further notice to the owner; and that the motor vehicle be sold at public auction to the highest bidder for cash after 15 days from the date of the mailing of the notice. The owner of the impounded motor vehicle shall sign the notice as an acknowledgment that he has received a copy of the notice and a copy of the notice shall be provided to the owner. 
(b)  When owner not present. 
(1)  When the police department impounds and remove a motor vehicle pursuant to section 36-126(1) and the owner of the motor vehicle is not present at the time of the impoundment, the police department shall, if such motor vehicle has displayed thereon a registration plate issued by the division of vehicles and has been registered with the division, mail a notice by certified mail to the registered owner thereof, addressed to the address as shown on the certificate of registration, and to the lienholder, if any, of record in the county in which the title shows the owner resides, if registered in the state. The notice shall be in the form prescribed by the police department, containing the same information as required by subsection (a) of this section. The police department shall use reasonable diligence in determining the title owner, or if from a non-title state, the registered owner, of the vehicle, and shall inquire by mail of the office of the register of deeds of the county in which the title shows the owner resides, if registered in this state, as to whether there are any lienholders of record. If the owner cannot be served by certified mail at the address on the motor vehicle registration and there is no other known address of the owner, the owner shall be deemed to be a resident of the state whose whereabouts are unknown and service shall be made on the secretary of state as provided in K.S.A. 8-401. 
(2)  If the owner does not reside in the state, as appears from the motor vehicle registration and the owner cannot be served by certified mail at the address on the motor vehicle registration and there is no other known address of the owner, the owner shall be deemed a nonresident of the state and service shall be made on the secretary of state as provided in K.S.A. 8-401. 
(c)  Failure or refusal to sign notice. If any person required by this section to sign a notice of impoundment willfully fails or refuses to do so, or if such person cannot be found, the police department shall note this fact on the face of the notice, which shall constitute prima facie evidence of delivery or service of notice as required by this section. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  14-404) 
Sec. 36-129. - Impoundment after request to leave motor vehicle. 
    In all cases wherein the owner or operator of a motor vehicle which is on a public street has requested that the motor vehicle be left unattended at that location, in lieu of impoundment of the motor vehicle pursuant to section 36-126, the police department may honor said request for a period of time not exceeding 24 hours, after which time the motor vehicle shall either be removed from the location by the owner or operator or be impounded by the police department pursuant to section 36-128. The police department shall be immune from liability for any damage, loss or destruction of the motor vehicle occasioned by its being left unattended pursuant to the request of the owner or operator thereof, in lieu of impoundment. Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the authority of the police department to order the removal of a motor vehicle by its owner or operator or to impound a motor vehicle pursuant to section 36-128 at any time whenever in his judgment the presence of the unattended motor vehicle constitutes a danger to the public safety. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  14-405) 
Sec. 36-130. - Release of motor vehicle from impoundment. 
(a)  Generally. Unless the vehicle is impounded pursuant to section 36-127(2), the owner of an impounded motor vehicle may secure the release of the motor vehicle from impoundment upon requesting such release and presenting proof of ownership satisfactory to the custodian of the place where the motor vehicle is stored. If the custodian is satisfied that the person making the request is the owner or the owner's authorized agent, the custodian shall release the motor vehicle to the owner or the owner's agent. Nothing in the preceding sentence shall preclude the owner of the impounded motor vehicle or the owner's agent from paying any towing and storage charges that may be assessed against the motor vehicle, but neither the police department nor the custodian of the storage space may require payment of any towing or storage charges as a condition precedent to such release. At the same time as the owner or the owner's agent requests release of the impounded motor vehicle, and if such request is made with 40 days after the owner receives a copy of the notice of impoundment, the police department shall provide the owner an opportunity to make a request for a hearing on the propriety of the impoundment and on the amount and the owner's liability for the towing and storage charges occasioned by the impoundment; provided that if the owner or the owner's agent requests release of the impounded motor vehicle more than 40 days after the owner receives a copy of the notice of impoundment, no hearing may be requested on the impoundment or on the towing and storage charges and the owner shall be conclusively presumed to have consented to the impoundment and to the amount of and the owner's liability for the towing and storage charges. 
(b)  Security for payment of charges. If the ownership of the impounded motor vehicle is evidenced by a title certificate issued by the state department of highway safety and motor vehicles, the owner or the owner's agent may secure the release of the motor vehicle from impoundment without the payment of any towing or storage charges or the deposit of any security for the payment thereof. If the ownership of the impounded motor vehicle is evidenced by a foreign title instrument, or if the jurisdiction in which title is recorded is not evidence from the document establishing ownership, the owner or the owner's agent, before the custodian of the place where the motor vehicle is stored authorizes release of the motor vehicle form impoundment, shall deposit with the custodian cash in the amount of the towing and storage charges to the date of the request. If the owner or the owner's agent refuses to provide the cash deposit, the custodian shall not authorize release of the impounded motor vehicle but if the request is timely made, a date shall be set for the hearing on the impoundment and charges. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  14-406) 
Sec. 36-131. - Hearing. 
(a)  If the owner of an impounded motor vehicle or the owner's agent timely requests the release of the motor vehicle from impoundment and a hearing on the impoundment and charges, as provided in section 36-130, a date shall be set, not more than five days after the date of request, for the hearing. The city attorney shall provide a hearing examiner to conduct the hearings required by this section. At the hearing, the owner, the owner's agent, or the owner's attorney shall be afforded an opportunity to present, by oral testimony or documentary evidence, the owner's objections to the impoundment of the motor vehicle; and the amount of the towing and storage charges and the owner's liability for the payment thereof. If the owner or the owner's agent requested the hearing more than five days but not more than 40 days after the owner received a copy of the notice of impoundment, the owner, the owner's agent or the owner's attorney shall be required at the hearing, as a condition precedent to the presentation of any objections by the owner, to show good cause for the delay in making the request more than five days after the owner received a copy of the notice of impoundment; if good cause cannot be shown, the hearing officer shall dismiss the hearing and make the finding stated in subsection (b) of this section; otherwise, the hearing examiner shall proceed to hear the owner's objections. At the conclusion of the hearing on the owner's objections, the hearing examiner shall render the hearing examiner's decision if the hearing examiner: 
(1)  Finds that the impoundment was improper, he shall: 
a.  Find that the owner is not liable for any towing or storage charges occasioned by the impoundment; and 
b.  Determine whether and to what extent the city shall be the expense of the towing and storage charges; or 
(2)  Finds that the impoundment was proper, he shall establish: 
a.  The amount of the towing and storage charges to be assessed against the impounded motor vehicle; and 
b.  The extent of the liability of the owner for payment of the towing and storage charges so established. The decision of the hearing examiner shall be final, and a copy of the decision shall be furnished to the owner of the impounded motor vehicle, to the custodian of the place where the motor vehicle is stored and to the city attorney. 
(b)  In the event that the impoundment was pursuant to K.S.A. 8-1102(6), the owner or occupant of the real property upon which the abandoned vehicle was located shall not be assessed the costs of towing and storage of the vehicle. Further, nothing within this article shall be construed to modify or effect the validity of the possessory lien of the person removing such vehicle from the real property established by K.S.A. 8-1102(b). 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  14-407) 
Sec. 36-132. - Charges constitute a lien. 
    The towing and storage charges occasioned by the impoundment of a motor vehicle pursuant to section 36-126 shall be and constitute a lien upon the impounded motor vehicle, except as provided in this section. If the hearing examiner finds pursuant to section 36-131 that the impoundment was improper and if the hearing examiner determines that the city shall bear part or all of the towing and storage charges, the lien created by this section shall be discharged. If the hearing examiner finds pursuant to section 36-130 that the impoundment was proper but that the towing and storage charges should be in an amount less than the amount of the lien, the lien created by this section shall be discharged to the extent that it exceeds the amount established by the hearing examiner. The holder of a lien created by this section may perfect such lien in any manner provided by law, but the lienholder may not retain possession of the motor vehicle when it has been released pursuant to section 36-130(a). In the event that the impounded motor vehicle is released from impoundment and the owner or the owner's agent has provided security for payment of charges as required by section 36-130(b), the lien created by this section shall also be a lien against the security so provided, subject to being wholly or partially discharged as provided in this section. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  14-408) 
Sec. 36-133. - Satisfaction of lien; notice of public sale. 
    The holder of a lien against a motor vehicle created by section 36-132, to the extent that such lien has not been discharged as provided in section 36-132 or otherwise satisfied, may enforce such lien in any manner provided by law after 60 days from the date the motor vehicle is impounded by the police department. If the owner of the motor vehicle or the owner's agent has provided security for the payment of the lien as provided in section 36-130(b), the lien shall first be satisfied out of the security so provided and, if any portion of the lien remains unsatisfied and undischarged, may then be enforced in any manner provided by law. If the motor vehicle against which the lien is created pursuant to section 36-132 is still under impoundment 60 days from the date it is impounded by the police department and the owner has not requested release of the motor vehicle from impoundment nor paid the towing and storage charges that are the basis for the lien, the motor vehicle shall be sold at public sale to the highest and best bidder for cash to satisfy the lien. Notice of the sale shall be given in accordance with K.S.A. 8-1102. Publication, required by K.S.A. 8-1102, may be made before the termination of the 60-day period for a sale thereafter. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  14-409) 
Sec. 36-134. - Redemption. 
    If the city is to conduct the sale: 
(1)  Any holder of a recorded lien or retained title on a motor vehicle to be sold by the city under the provisions of section 36-133 may claim and take possession thereof, upon payment of accrued charges and estimated costs of publication of the notice of sale to the police department and the deposit with the police department of sufficient assurance by surety bond or otherwise, approved by the city attorney, that the motor vehicle will be forthcoming for public sale thereof or upon claim of the rightful owner prior to the sale. The police department shall, within three days, make a report to the city treasurer and deliver the charges and costs so paid to the city treasurer, taking a receipt therefor and filing it, together with a duplicate copy of the report to the city treasurer, with the records in the city treasurer's office. The funds shall be held in a trust account until final disposition of the motor vehicle. Not less than five days before the date for sale of the motor vehicle, the police department shall notify the lienholder or retained title holder of the time and place for the sale, and the lienholder or retained title holder shall deliver such motor vehicle to the police department at or before 12:00 noon of the day before the sale. At the sale the amount paid shall be credited on the bid of the lienholder or retained title holder. If the lienholder or retained title holder is the successful bidder for the motor vehicle, the police department shall report this fact to the city treasurer and then the funds previously paid by the lienholder or retained title holder shall be relieved of the trust previously impressed and become the same as other funds received by the city for storage and costs of impounded motor vehicles. If the motor vehicle is sold for a higher bid to any person other than the lienholder or retained title holder, the police department shall report this fact to the city treasurer and the lienholder or retained title holder shall be refunded the amount previously paid by him out of the trust account. 
(2)  And if the rightful owner of the motor vehicle claims the same before the sale by payment of the accrued charges, the police department shall immediately notify the lienholder or retained title holder in possession of the motor vehicle and the lienholder or retained title holder shall return the same to the police department within 12 hours. The police department shall report this redemption by the rightful owner to the city treasurer and the lienholder or retained title holder shall be refunded the amount previously paid by him out of the trust account. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  14-410) 
Sec. 36-135. - Sale proceeds. 
    The proceeds of a public sale held pursuant to section 36-132 whether such sale was conducted by the city or by any other person, after payment of the towing and storage charges and costs and expenses incident to the sale, shall be deposited with the city treasurer, if the owner of the motor vehicle is absent from the sale, for credit to the trust account. The funds deposited in the trust account pursuant to this section shall remain in the account subject to the order of the person legally entitled thereto, but if no claim is made for these funds within a period of one year after the sale, the funds shall become the property of the city, be released from the trust account and be paid into the general fund as miscellaneous revenues. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  14-411) 
Sec. 36-136. - Statutory procedures. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to augment, diminish, supersede or otherwise interfere with any statutory procedure established by the legislature for the collection of unpaid towing and storage charges. The procedures in this article are supplementary and cumulative to any statutory procedures. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  14-412) 
Sec. 36-137. - Implementation of article. 
    The police department and city treasurer are authorized to make rules for the implementation and administration of this article. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  14-413) 
Sec. 36-138. - Reimbursement for discharged liens. 
    If a lien created by section 36-132 and held by a private wrecker or towing firm is discharged by section 36-132 pursuant to a determination by a hearing examiner that an impoundment was improper and that the city shall bear part or all of the towing and storage charges, the city shall pay to the firm the amount determined by the hearing examiner. No payment shall be made until it is authorized by the city attorney. 
(Code 1983; Code 1996,  14-414) 
Secs. 36-139-36-164. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - GOLF CARTS, WORK SITE UTILITY VEHICLES, MICRO-UTILITY TRUCES AND ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4123,  1-6, adopted Nov. 20, 2012, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, these provisions have been added at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 36-165. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except when the context requires otherwise: 
    All-terrain vehicle means any motorized non-highway vehicle 50 inches or less in width, having a dry weight of 1,500 pounds or less, traveling on three or more non-highways tires, and having a seat to be straddled by the operator. As used in this definition, non-highway tire means any pneumatic tire six inches or more in width, designed for use on wheels with rim diameter of 14 inches or less. 
    Golf cart means a motor vehicle that has not less than three wheels in contact with the ground, an unladen weight of not more than 1,800 pounds, is designed to be operated at not more than 25 miles per hour and is designed to carry not more than four persons, including the driver. 
    Micro-utility truck means any motor vehicle which is not less than 48 inches in width, has an overall length, including the bumper, of not more than 160 inches, has an unladen weight, including fuel and fluids, of more than 1,500 pounds, can exceed 40 miles per hour as originally manufactured and is manufactured with a metal cab. 
    Special purpose vehicle means golf cart, work-site utility vehicle, micro-utility vehicle and all-terrain, either individually or collectively. 
    Work site utility vehicles means any motor vehicle which is not less than 48 inches in width, has an overall length, including the bumper, of not more than 135 inches, has an unladen weight, including fuel and fluids, of more than 800 pounds and is equipped with four or more low pressure tires, a steering wheel and bench or bucket type seating allowing at least two people to sit side-by-side, and may be equipped with a bed or cargo box for hauling materials. "work site utility vehicle" does not include a micro utility truck. 
(Ord. No. 4123,  1, 11-20-2012) 
Sec. 36-166. - Operation of special purpose vehicles on city streets; special conditions and restrictions on operation. 
(a)  Golf carts may be operated upon the public highways, streets, roads and alleys within the corporate limits of the city. 
(1)  No golf cart may be operated upon any public highway, street, road and alley with a posted speed limit in excess of 30 miles per hour. 
(2)  No golf cart shall be operated on any interstate highway, federal highway or state highway; provided, however, that the provisions of this subsection shall not prohibit a golf cart from crossing a federal or state highway with a posted speed limit greater than 30 miles per hour. 
(3)  No golf cart shall be operated on any public highways, streets, roads and alleys between sunset and sunrise, unless equipped with lights. 
(b)  Work-site utility vehicles may be operated upon the public highways, streets, roads and alleys within the corporate limits of the city, except as follows: 
(1)  No work-site utility vehicle may be operated on any public highway, street, road and alley with a posted speed limit in excess of 30 miles per hour. 
(2)  No work-site utility vehicle may be operated on any public highway, street, road and alley between sunset and sunrise unless such vehicle is equipped with lights as required for motor vehicles under K.S.A. ch. 8, art. 17, and amendments thereto. 
(c)  Micro-utility trucks may be operated upon the public highways, streets, roads and alleys within the corporate limits of the city, except as follows: 
(1)  No micro-utility truck may be operated upon any public highway, street, road and alley with a posted speed limit in excess of 30 miles per hour. 
(2)  No micro-utility truck shall be operated on any public highway, street, road or alley unless such truck complies with the equipment requirements under K.S.A. ch. 8, art. 17, and amendments thereto. 
(d)  All-terrain vehicles may be operated upon the public highways, streets, roads and alleys within the corporate limits of the city, except as follows: 
(1)  No all-terrain vehicle may be operated upon any public highway, street, road, and alley with a posted speed limit in excess of 30 miles per hour. 
(2)  No all-terrain vehicle may be operated upon any public highway, street, road or alley between sunset and sunrise unless such vehicle is equipped with lights and reflectors as required for motorcycles under K.S.A. ch. 8, art. 17, and amendments thereto. 
(Ord. No. 4123,  2, 11-20-2012) 
Sec. 36-167. - Same-Valid driver's license required; penalty; duties and responsibilities. 
    No person shall operate a golf cart, work site utility vehicle, or a micro-utility truck on any public highway, street, road or alley within the corporate limits of the city unless such person has a valid driver's license. Furthermore, no person shall operate an all-terrain vehicle on any public highway, street, road, or alley within the corporate limits of the city unless such person has a valid driver's license and is 18 years of age or older. Violation of this section is punishable by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 or by imprisonment for not more than six months or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 4123,  3, 11-20-2012) 
Sec. 36-168. - Same-Insurance required; penalty. 
(a)  Every owner of a golf cart, work site utility vehicle, micro-utility truck, or all-terrain vehicle shall provide liability coverage in accordance with Section 200 of the 2012 Standard Traffic Ordinance, and amendments thereto, and the Kansas Automobile Injury Reparations Act, K.S.A. 40-3101 et seq., and amendments thereto. 
(b)  All provisions of Section 200 of the 2012 Standard Traffic Ordinance, and amendments thereto, including penalty provisions, shall be applicable to all owners and operators of golf carts or work site utility vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 4123,  4, 11-20-2012) 
Sec. 36-169. - Same-Registration and license; fee; application; inspection; penalty. 
(a)  Before operating any golf cart, work site utility vehicle, micro-utility truck, or all-terrain vehicle on any public highway, street, road or alley within the corporate limits of the city and each calendar year thereafter, the vehicle shall be registered with the city and a license shall be obtained and placed on the vehicle. The license fee shall be $25.00 per calendar year, payable in advance to the [city clerk] [police chief] [fire chief] [other person designated by the city]. The full amount of the license fee shall be required regardless of the time of year that the application is made. 
(b)  Application for registration of a special purpose vehicle shall be made by the owner, or owner's agent, in the office of the Wellington Police Department. The application shall be made upon forms provided by the city and each application shall contain the name of the owner, the owner's residence address, or bona fide place of business, a brief description of the vehicle to be registered (including make, model and serial number, if applicable). Proof of insurance, as required in section 36-170 shall be furnished at the time of application for registration. 
(c)  Prior to the issuance of the registration and license, each applicant for a special purpose vehicle license shall first present such vehicle for an official inspection. If, upon inspection such vehicle is found to be in safe mechanical condition, and upon completion of the registration application, establishing proof of insurance and payment of the fees herein provided, a license shall be issued to the owner who shall attach it to the vehicle. The license shall be displayed in such a manner as to be clearly visible from the rear of the vehicle. The license number on the application will be recorded and then filed in the police department. 
(d)  It is unlawful for any person to willfully or maliciously remove, destroy, mutilate or alter such license during the time in which the same is operative. 
(e)  The license issued hereunder is transferrable. In the event of sale or other transfer of ownership of any golf cart, work site utility vehicle, micro-utility truck, or all-terrain vehicle license under the provisions of this section, the existing license and the right to use shall pass onto the new owner for the balance of the calendar year during which such license was issued. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Operate, or for the owner thereof knowingly to permit the operation, upon a public street, road, highway, or alley within the corporate limits of the city any golf cart, work site utility vehicle, micro-utility truck, or all-terrain vehicle which is not registered and which does not have attached thereto and displayed thereon the license assigned thereto by the city for the current registration year. 
(2)  Display, cause or permit to be displayed, or to have in possession, any registration receipt, registration license or registration decal knowing the same to be fictitious or to have been canceled, revoked, suspended or altered. A violation of this subsection (2) shall constitute an unclassified misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00 and forfeiture of the item. A mandatory court appearance shall be required of any person violating this subsection. 
(3)  Lend to or knowingly permit the use by one not entitled thereto any registration receipt, registration license plate or registration decal issued to the person so lending or permitting the use thereof. 
(4)  Remove, conceal, alter, mark or deface the license number plate, plates or decals, or any other mark of identification upon any special purpose vehicle. Licenses shall be kept clean and placed as required by law so as to be plainly visible and legible. 
(5)  Carry or display a registered number plate or plates or registration decal upon any special purpose vehicle not lawfully issued for such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 4123,  5, 11-20-2012) 
Sec. 36-170. - Penalty. 
    Unless specifically provided for herein, a violation of this section shall be deemed an ordinance traffic infraction. Upon an entry of a plea of guilty or no contest or upon being convicted of such violation, the penalty imposed shall be in accordance with Section 201, 2012 Standard Traffic Ordinance, and amendments thereto, or such other similar provision as the city may then have in effect. 
(Ord. No. 4123,  6, 11-20-2012) 
Chapter 38 - UTILITIES[1]

Charter Ordinance reference- Investment of revenues, Charter Ordinance Number 13. 
State Law reference- Water, wastewater and watercourses, K.S.A. 14-701a et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 38-1-38-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 38-19-38-39. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OFFICE OF PUBLIC UTILITIES 

Sec. 38-40. - Position of public utilities director created. 
    There is hereby created an administrative position for the city, to be known as "public utilities director." The duties of public utilities director shall be to keep all necessary books, records and accounts with the customers of the water and sewage and electric departments of the city and make all reports in such manner as directed by the city manager or as prescribed by ordinances of the city, and to receive, collect and account for all moneys so collected and to pay the same over to the treasurer of the city at the end of each day's business, and take duplicate receipts from the treasurer for the same, one such receipt to be filed with the city clerk. The clerk shall enter in records kept for that purpose, all amounts so receipted for. 
(Code 1996,  15-101; Ord. No. 3289,  1) 
Sec. 38-41. - City treasurer to receive and account for funds. 
    The city treasurer, in addition to such other duties as the treasurer may be required to perform, shall receive daily all funds which shall be turned over by the utilities services administrator, and shall give duplicate receipts therefor. The city treasurer shall daily deposit said funds. The city clerk shall make daily balances with and shall carefully check all accounts of the administrator. 
(Code 1996,  15-102; Ord. No. 3168,  3) 
Secs. 38-42-38-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COMBINED WATERWORKS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Combined water and sewer systems, K.S.A. 12-856-12-868. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 38-71. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial user means any person whose premises are connected to the municipal sewer and does not constitute a residential user as herein defined. 
    Residential user means a household whose premises are used solely for residential and residential related purposes, are connected to the municipal sewer and whose water service is furnished through an individual meter. 
(Code 1996,  15-204; Ord. No. 3289,  5) 
Sec. 38-72. - Waterworks system and sewage disposal system combined. 
    The waterworks system and the sewage disposal system of the city are hereby declared to be a water and sewage system, and shall be operated and financed as provided by K.S.A. 12-856 and 12-869, inclusive, as amended. All revenues collected for such water and sewage system shall be credited to the water and sewer fund of the city for the use of the water and sewage system. 
(Code 1996,  15-201; Ord. No. 3289,  2) 
State Law reference- Authority to declare combined system, K.S.A. 12-857. 
Sec. 38-73. - Water and sewage department created. 
    There is hereby created a water and sewage department of the city which shall be under the jurisdiction of and managed by the city manager. All employees of the water department and all employees of the sewage department shall be employees of the water and sewage department. 
(Code 1996,  15-202; Ord. No. 3289,  3) 
State Law reference- Creation of water and sewage department, K.S.A. 12-859. 
Sec. 38-74. - Application for service; service charge. 
(a)  Any person desiring a connection with the water or sewage system of the city shall apply in writing to city utility office on a form provided by the city for that purpose. The application may contain an exact description, or street address of the property to be served, the estimated monthly water usage, the uses, general and specific, to which the water is to be put and the name of any person having an unpaid and undisputed bill for utility service who will occupy the property to be served; the application may require the applicant to provide credit information and all applications for water and sewer extensions shall conform to all subdivision regulations of the city. 
(b)  There shall be a service charge, which shall be on file in the city clerk's office, for meter sets and/or read-ins at any location regardless of the length of time for which the service is requested. This charge shall not apply to new connections on new structures, and there shall be no charge for meter removals or read-outs. 
(Code 1996,  15-203; Ord. No. 3289,  4; Ord. No. 3819,  I, 11-7-2000) 
Sec. 38-75. - Permit issued by utility office. 
    Upon receiving an application for water and sewer service, if the same is in proper form, there are no unsafe or hazardous condition orders placed on the service by the city inspector or the building official, the public utilities director or designee in the utility office, shall issue an order to connect with the municipal water and sewer lines. All applications of water and sewer extensions shall conform to all applicable subdivision regulations of the city. 
(Code 1996,  15-205; Ord. No. 3289,  6) 
Sec. 38-76. - City manager to have supervision. 
    The city manager, or whoever the city manager may designate to act in that capacity, shall have general supervision of the water and sewage system of the city. The city manager shall supervise the reading of meters monthly and prepare reports to the governing body of the amount of water pumped and consumed and total revenue and expenditures of the water and sewage system. 
(Code 1996,  15-206; Ord. No. 3289,  7) 
Sec. 38-77. - All water to be metered. 
    All water furnished by the municipal water and sewage system shall be measured by meters furnished by the city for that purpose. 
(Code 1996,  15-207; Ord. No. 3289,  8) 
Sec. 38-78. - City to make connections. 
    All taps shall be driven, street connections made, corporation cocks inserted, pipes installed from main to curb, and the curb cock inserted in an iron box or meter tile to which the service plug is to be connected by city employees only. The minimum service installed shall be one inch. The customer shall pay a connection fee which shall be posted in the city clerk's office for connections as follows: 
(1)  If the connection requires the repair or patching of a street or alley surfaced with concrete or asphalt, or requires boring under such a surfaced street or alley. 
(2)  If the connection is made without requiring the repair or patching of a street or alley surfaced with concrete or asphalt and without boring under such a surfaced street or alley. 
(3)  If a service larger than one inch is installed, a sum equal to the actual cost of time and material used in making such connection, but in no event less than the amounts set forth in subsections (1) and (2) of this section. 
All connection fees shall be paid before the water is turned on. 
(Code 1996,  15-208; Ord. No. 3413,  1; Ord. No. 3819,  II, 11-7-2000; Ord. No. 3838,  I, 3-5-2002) 
Sec. 38-79. - Separate connections. 
    Unless special permission is granted by the city manager, or the city manager's duly authorized agent, each premises shall have a separate and distinct service connection, and where permission is granted for branch service pipes, each branch pipe must have its own curb cock and separate meter. 
(Code 1996,  15-209; Ord. No. 3289,  10) 
Sec. 38-80. - Installation of service pipe. 
    No one except regular city employees of the water department or plumbers duly licensed in accordance with the ordinances of the city shall do any plumbing work on any pipes connected or to be connected to the municipal water and sewage system. 
(Code 1996,  15-210; Ord. No. 3289,  11) 
Sec. 38-81. - Trenching and backfilling. 
    Excavations made by plumbers in public ground shall not be kept open longer than is absolutely necessary to make the connection required, and while open shall be protected by suitable barriers, guards and lights as provided in the ordinances of the city, and backfilling shall be thoroughly compacted and left in a satisfactory condition. Where such excavations are unsatisfactorily filled, the city shall place them in a satisfactory condition and the cost thereof shall be charged to the plumber, and the plumber's license shall be suspended unless the sum is paid. 
(Code 1996,  15-211; Ord. No. 3289,  12) 
Sec. 38-82. - Character of pipe and service connections. 
    All water and sewer pipes in the city shall conform to the Uniform Plumbing Code, 2003 Edition, and ordinances of the city in effect at the time of installation or replacement. 
(Code 1996,  15-212; Ord. No. 3289,  13) 
Sec. 38-83. - Curb, stop and waste cocks. 
    There shall be a curb cock in every service line attached to the mains, the same to be placed near, the curb, if on a street, or as close as possible to the alley line if the main is located in the alley. Curb cocks shall be supplied with strong and suitable "T" heads, and shall be enclosed in a substantial meter tile covered with a tight fitting iron lid, with the letter "W" cast upon it. There shall be one or more stop and waste cocks attached to every supply pipe, at some point between the curb cock and meter, so that the water can be shut off and the meter and the house plumbing entirely drained. 
(Code 1996,  15-213; Ord. No. 3289,  14) 
Sec. 38-84. - Check valves required. 
    Check valves are hereby required on all connections to steam boilers or on other connections deemed by the building inspector to require one. Safety and relief valves shall be placed on all boilers or other steam apparatus connected with the water system where the steam pressure may be raised in excess of 40 pounds per square inch. 
(Code 1996,  15-214; Ord. No. 3289,  15) 
Sec. 38-85. - Cost of installation borne by applicant. 
    The cost of original installation of all piping or plumbing between the city mains and any service lines or devices maintained by the consumer, and all extensions hereafter made to such service pipes, as well as all repairs to same, shall be borne entirely by the applicant, although the service pipes and devices shall at all reasonable times be subject to inspection by duly authorized officials of the water and sewage department of the city, and repairs found to be necessary by the officials shall be made promptly or the city may discontinue service until the repairs are made. If a consumer requests the moving or relocating of the consumer's meter for the consumer's convenience and/or requests a larger service or meter than is currently installed the consumer shall be required to pay the actual cost of time and material in making the change. 
(Code 1996,  15-215; Ord. No. 3413,  II) 
Sec. 38-86. - Extension of mains. 
    The city may extend its water mains within or without the city by construction or purchase, when applications have been made and agreements entered into by persons along the proposed extension which will, in the judgment of the governing body, produce a revenue sufficient to pay interest on the cost of the extension and the operating cost of the service furnished. 
(Code 1996,  15-216; Ord. No. 3289,  17) 
Sec. 38-87. - Individual installations outside the city. 
    When the approval of the governing body has been obtained for a water main extension outside the city limits, individual connections by any person to the water main extension shall be made only after a permit therefore is issued by the city manager, or the city manager's duly authorized agent, as required by the codes and ordinances of the city. Notwithstanding other provisions of the codes and ordinances of the city, all customers whose premises are outside the city limits shall pay the entire cost of the labor and materials, including the meter, required for the original installation of the service, but not less than the amount which is on file in the city clerk's office, with the meter to remain the property of the city. All meters installed outside of the city limits shall be installed in accordance with the codes and ordinances of the city and the piping and the service in all respects shall be subject to the codes and ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1996,  15-217; Ord. No. 3413,  III; Ord. No. 3819,  III, 11-7-2000) 
Sec. 38-88. - Meters. 
(a)  Every consumer shall provide a suitable place where a meter can be installed, and the city shall install and maintain the meter. If, at any time, the consumer desires to have the meter tested for accuracy, the testing shall be done by the city, and the fees which are on file in the city clerk's office shall be charged to the consumer if the meter registers 97 percent accurate. 
(b)  If the meter registers less than 97 percent accurate, it shall be replaced and repaired and tested before installation on another service. 
(Code 1996,  15-218; Ord. No. 3413,  IV) 
Sec. 38-89. - Reading meters. 
    For the purpose of reading meters, duly authorized employees of the water and sewage department of the city may legally enter upon any premises at a reasonable hour. The city may install remote reading devices to unaltered premises at its expense. 
(Code 1996,  15-219; Ord. No. 3289,  20) 
Sec. 38-90. - Deposits and guarantees. 
(a)  At the time application for water service is made, the utility may require the customer to provide credit information before service is made available. In order to guarantee payment of bills for water service the city may, at the time of application for service, or at any time thereafter, upon five days notice, require residential customers to deposit with the city the sum of which is on file in the city clerk's office and other customer to deposit a sum equal to the amount of the projected largest two months bills, but not less than the amount which is on file in the city clerk's office, if: 
(1)  The utility establishes that the customer has an unsatisfactory credit rating, or has an insufficient prior credit history upon which a credit rating may be based; 
(2)  The customer has an outstanding undisputed and unpaid service account which accrued within the past five years; 
(3)  The customer has, in an unauthorized manner, interfered with, or diverted, or used the service of a utility within the past five years; 
(4)  The customer fails to pay an undisputed bill before the delinquency date for three consecutive billing periods. 
(b)  Upon termination of service, if the deposit is not to be transferred, the utility will refund the deposit to the customer less any unpaid utility bills due the utility. Deposits taken from residential customers who make less than two delinquent payments of an undisputed bill and which have received no service cutoffs for water service for a period of 12 consecutive months shall be refunded or credited to the customer's bill. Deposits taken from commercial customers who make less than two delinquent payments of undisputed bills and which have received no service cutoffs for water service for a period of 24 consecutive months shall be refunded or credited to the customer's bill. 
(Code 1996,  15-220; Ord. No. 3289,  21; Ord. No. 3819,  IV, 11-7-2000) 
Sec. 38-91. - Account in name of customer. 
    All water and sewage disposal accounts carried upon the books of the municipal water and sewage department of the city shall be with the consumer and the consumer shall be liable for water used upon and for sewage disposal fees in connection with the premises. 
(Code 1996,  15-221; Ord. No. 3289,  22) 
Sec. 38-92. - Use of water during fire. 
    It is hereby declared to be unlawful for any person to use or allow to be used any water from the water and sewage system of the city during any period of time for which the fire chief, or the fire chief's duly authorized agent, shall have publicly declared that all available water is needed to extinguish an existing fire, and upon receiving knowledge that such a declaration has been made, it shall be the duty of every person to see that all water services are tightly closed, and no water shall be used during such period of time except in cases of emergency. 
(Code 1996,  15-222; Code 1983; Ord. No. 3289,  23) 
Sec. 38-93. - Taking water without authority. 
    It is hereby declared unlawful for any person to take any water from the municipal water and sewage system of the city, except the same be drawn through a meter installed by the city, or from any premises not owned by such person without the permission of the owner thereof. 
(Code 1996,  15-223; Ord. No. 3289,  24) 
Sec. 38-94. - Tampering with cutoff valves. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, except a duly authorized employee of the water and sewage system of the city, to turn any curb cock on or off. For repair or replacement of a curb cock by the city which is necessitated by the fault of the consumer or the consumer's agents, the consumer shall be charged the sum of $50.00. 
(Code 1996,  15-224; Ord. No. 3413,  V) 
Secs. 38-95-38-116. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RATES, CHARGES AND BILLING PROCEDURE 

Sec. 38-117. - Right to discontinue service for repairs. 
    The city hereby reserves the right to discontinue service to any or all customers of the water and sewage system of the city without notice when the same is necessary in the repair of the system, or any part thereof. 
(Code 1996,  15-225; Ord. No. 3289,  26) 
Sec. 38-118. - Payment for water bills and sewage service charges; discontinuance of service for nonpayment; late payment charges and fees. 
(a)  All bills, when rendered, are due on the day following the date of the bill, and shall become delinquent on the 20th day after the date of billing, and if not paid on or before the 20th day after the date of billing, a late payment charge of ten percent will be added to all current bills for water and sewer service and will be collected at the time the bill is finally paid. If any bill for water used and/or for sewer service is not paid, the utility will give the customer seven days written notice before discontinuing service, unless discontinuance is upon the customer's request, or involves a dangerous condition or a violation of utility rules. Standards of practice provided by the ordinances of the city for the municipal electric system of the city as to discontinuance of service shall also apply and be applicable to the water and sewage system of the city. 
(b)  If after the seven days notice of discontinuance of service, water and/or sewer bills remain unpaid, water service shall be immediately discontinued, and shall not be resumed or reconnected until all water and/or sewer service bills, the late payment charge hereinabove established and the reconnection fee, hereinafter set forth are fully paid. If the service is reconnected between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on regular business days, a reconnection fee which is on file in the city clerk's office shall be charged; if the service is reconnected between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. of the following day, a reconnection fee which is on file in the city clerk's office shall be charged. 
(c)  The unpaid bills, the late payment charge and the reconnection fee may be paid at the utility office. 
(Code 1996,  15-226; Ord. No. 3309,  2; Ord. No. 3819,  V, 11-7-2000) 
Sec. 38-119. - Review of disputes. 
(a)  When a customer advises the utility office prior to the date of the proposed discontinuance of service that all or any part of any billing as rendered is in dispute, or that the city's reasons for discontinuance are factually invalid, the utility office shall: 
(1)  Immediately record the date, time and place the complaint is made; 
(2)  Postpone discontinuance of service until a full investigation is completed and the dispute found to be invalid; 
(3)  Investigate the dispute promptly and completely; and 
(4)  Attempt to resolve the dispute informally in a manner mutually satisfactory to both parties. 
(b)  A customer may advise the utility office that a bill is in dispute in any reasonable manner such as by written notice, in personal meetings or by a telephone call directed to the appropriate personnel of the city. 
(c)  The city, in attempting to resolve the dispute in a mutually satisfactory manner, may employ telephone communication, personal meetings, formal or informal hearings, on-site visits, or any other technique reasonably conducive to settlement of the dispute. 
(Code 1996,  15-227; Ord. No. 3289,  28; Ord. No. 3819,  VI, 11-7-2000) 
Sec. 38-120. - Records kept by office of public utilities. 
    The office of public utilities shall maintain a water and sewer fund and a customer's water deposit fund, and shall keep an accurate record of all meter sales, sales tax, installation charges, fees, late payment charges, deposits and all other receipts, and the disbursements from the water and sewer fund and from the customer's water deposit fund. It shall keep an accurate record of the meter readings and amounts of water consumed and total charges against and amounts paid on each customer's account. 
(Code 1996,  15-228; Ord. No. 3289,  29) 
Sec. 38-121. - Office of public utilities to make out bills; collections. 
    The office of public utilities shall figure all customers bills from the meter reading reports and shall post all meter readings and amount consumed in suitable records furnished by the city. It shall make out the monthly bills and supervise their collection. Bills may be rendered on the basis of estimated water usage, provided, however that the standards of procedure provided by the ordinances of the city for the municipal electric system of the city as to billings based upon estimated usage of electricity shall be followed when rendering water bills based upon estimated water usage. 
(Code 1996,  15-229; Ord. No. 3289,  30) 
Sec. 38-122. - Water rates. 
    Commencing for all bills for water service that become due and payable on or after July 1, 2015, the rates to be charged for water sold from the municipal water and sewage system of the city shall be as follows: 
(a)  The minimum charge for all water sold to individual customers within the city limits shall be $15.50 per month. The following rates shall apply to all individual water customers within the city limits: 
First 2,000 gallons, per month - $15.50; 
2,001 or more gallons, per month, per thousand gallons - $5.42. 
(b)  The minimum charge for all water sold to individual customers outside the city limits shall be $16.50 per month. The following rates shall apply to all individual water customers outside the city limits: 
First 2,000 gallons, per month - $16.50; 
2,001 or more gallons, per month, per thousand gallons - $6.03. 
(Code 1996,  15-230; Ord. No. 3625,  1; Ord. No. 3983,  I, 12-19-2006; Ord. No. 4159,  I, 6-17-2014; Ord. No. 4177,  I, 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 38-123. - State fee. 
(a)  In addition to all other charges made to and imposed upon water customers of the city for water sold, used or consumed by them there shall be charged, pursuant to the provisions of K.S.A. 82a-954 for the purpose of financing the state water plan, the amount which is on file in the city clerk's office for water sold at retail by the city water supply system. 
(b)  Such charge shall be billed and collected as other charges for water sold by the city to its retail water customers and shall be subject to all provisions of the ordinances of the city providing for penalties and other sanctions for late payment and nonpayment of water bills. 
(Code 1996,  15-230a; Ord. No. 3554,  1; Ord. No. 3819,  VII, 11-7-2000) 
State Law reference- Water protection fee, K.S.A. 82a-954. 
Sec. 38-124. - Water in bulk. 
    Commencing for all bills for water service that become due and payable on or after July 1, 2015, consumers buying water in bulk from water and sewage system of the city shall be charged $10.00 per 1,000 gallons of water, with a minimum charge of $10.00. 
(Code 1996,  15-231; Ord. No. 3625,  2; Ord. No. 3983,  II, 12-19-2006; Ord. No. 4159,  II, 6-17-2014; Ord. No. 4177,  II, 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 38-125. - Rural water districts. 
    Commencing for all bills for water service that become due and payable on or after July 1, 2015, Rural Water Districts Nos. 1, 2, 3, and the City of Mayfield shall be charged 1.25 times the rate established for customers being served within the city limits of the City of Wellington, Kansas, per 1,000 gallons of water, or fraction thereof, for all water use. 
(Code 1996,  15-233; Ord. No. 3356,  6; Ord. No. 3625,  4; Ord. No. 3974,  I, 9-19-2006; Ord. No. 3983,  III, 12-19-2006; Ord. No. 3995,  I, 5-15-2007; Ord. No. 4159,  III, 6-17-2014; Ord. No. 4177,  III, 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 38-126. - Unpaid sewer service charges a lien on real estate. 
    In the event any person, firm, corporation, political unit, except the United States of America and the state, or organization living or operating on premises connected to a sanitary sewer of the water and sewage system of the city shall neglect, fail or refuse to pay the service charges fixed in this article for the operation of the sewage disposal system of the city, such charges shall constitute a lien upon the real estate serviced by the connection to the system, and shall be certified by the city clerk to the county clerk to be placed on the tax roll for collection, subject to the same penalties and collected in a like manner as other taxes are by law collectible, and no water shall be delivered through the pipes and mains of the city waterworks until the charges are paid in full. 
(Code 1996,  15-236; Ord. No. 3289,  36) 
Sec. 38-127. - Amendment of rates. 
    For all bills for water service that become due and payable on or after January 1, 2017, and annually thereafter, a standard escalator of 2.25 percent will take effect on the existing rates. The governing body may take action, by resolution, to adjust or eliminate the escalator for that particular year. 
(Code 1996,  15-237; Ord. No. 3289,  37; Ord. No. 4177,  IV, 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 38-128. - Miscellaneous service charges. 
(a)  When a consumer requests the water supply to be turned off for the consumer's convenience to permit repairs or new piping on the consumer's premises, there shall be a service charge which shall be posted in the city clerk's office. 
(b)  When a consumer requests the city to make a survey for leaks on the consumer's facilities there may be a service charge which is on file in the city clerk's office during normal business hours and at any other time. 
(c)  When a consumer requests a reread of the consumer's meter because of an increase of usage there shall be a service charge of the amount which is on file in the city clerk's office and rereads will only be made during normal business hours. In the event there was an error in reading the meter the charge shall not be made. 
(d)  When a consumer requests the city to check on sewer discharge stoppages, there may be a charge of the amount which is on file in the city clerk's office during normal business hours and at any other time. In the event the stoppage is on the city system the aforesaid charges will not be made. 
(Code 1996,  15-238; Ord. No. 3413,  VI) 
Sec. 38-129. - Water rates; city reserves right to contract. 
    The city hereby reserves the right to contract with large consumers of water sold from the city utility system on such rates as may be agreed upon between the city and the consumer. The contracted rates shall be based on proximity of the consumer to adequate distribution lines, cost-to-serve analysis, investment cost, average and peak flow rates, and other factors relating to the particular consumer. 
(Code 1996,  15-239; Ord. No. 3517,  1) 
Sec. 38-130. - Sewer service rates; city reserves the right to contract. 
    The city hereby reserves the right to contract with large contributors of sewage to the city sewage system on such charges as may be agreed upon between the city and the contributor.
