(c)  The cash deposit required for commercial customers shall not exceed two months' bills. For the purpose of establishing deposits and projecting monthly bills, the utility shall consider the length of time the customer can reasonably be expected to take service and past consumption patterns of other similar customers. The amount of the cash deposit may be adjusted if the character or volume of the customer's service should change. The utility shall permit payment of any required residential deposit in equal installments over a period of at least four months. 
(Code 1996,  15-520; Ord. No. 3288,  12; Ord. No. 3819,  IX, 11-7-2000; Ord. No. 3853,  I, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 38-440. - Nonassignable receipt. 
    Whenever a security deposit is accepted, the utility will issue to the customer a non-assignable receipt containing the following minimum information: 
(1)  Name of customer; 
(2)  Place of deposit; 
(3)  Date of deposit; 
(4)  Amount of deposit; 
(5)  Utility name and address and the signature and title of the utility employee receiving the deposit; 
(6)  Current annual interest rate earned on the deposit; and 
(7)  Statement of the terms and conditions governing the use, retention and return of deposits. 
(Code 1996,  15-521; Ord. No. 3288,  12; Ord. No. 3819,  X, 11-7-2000) 
Sec. 38-441. - Refund of deposits; interest. 
    Upon termination of service, if the deposit is not transferred, the utility will refund the deposit to the customer or credit the customers utility bills under the following circumstances: 
(1)  To residential customers who have no more than two delinquent payments of undisputed bills and whose utility service has not been disconnected for a period of 12 consecutive months. 
(2)  To commercial customers whose utility service has not been disconnected for a period of 12 consecutive months. 
The refund or credit shall include accrued simple interest at the rate not less than that provided for by K.S.A. 12-822 and acts amendatory thereof. 
(Code 1996,  15-522; Ord. No. 3288,  12; Ord. No. 3819,  XI, 11-7-2000; Ord. No. 3856,  I, 11-5-2002) 
Sec. 38-442. - Nontransferable. 
    Service deposits shall be nontransferable from one customer to another customer; however, upon termination of the customer's service at the service address, the utility may transfer the deposit to the customer's new active account, if any. 
(Code 1996,  15-523; Ord. No. 3288,  12) 
Sec. 38-443. - Written guarantee. 
    In lieu of the security deposit, a letter of credit from a recognized financial institution, or a written statement from the customer's prior utility company verifying that the customer maintained a good credit rating for the 12 months prior to the customer leaving its service area may be accepted. The guarantor shall be released from liability on the guarantor's written guarantee upon nondelinquent payment of all undisputed bills for utility service for a period of 12 consecutive months for residential customers and for a period of 24 consecutive months for commercial customers, or upon the termination of service and the payment of all outstanding bills. 
(Code 1996,  15-524; Ord. No. 3288,  12; Ord. No. 3819,  XII, 11-7-2000) 
Sec. 38-444. - Taking electricity without authority. 
    It is hereby declared unlawful for any person to take any electricity from the municipal electric system in any manner whatsoever except through a meter installed by the city or from any premises not owned by that person without the permission of the owner thereof. 
(Code 1996,  15-525; Ord. No. 3288,  1) 
Sec. 38-445. - Discontinuance of service-Generally. 
(a)  The city hereby reserves the right to discontinue service to any or all customers of the municipal electric system, without notice, when the same is necessary to repair the system, or any part thereof, and otherwise may discontinue or refuse service for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  When the customer requests discontinuance of service; 
(2)  When a utility bill becomes delinquent after giving notice required by ordinances of the city; 
(3)  When any person residing at or occupying a premise has an outstanding, undisputed and unpaid bill for service furnished at any location; 
(4)  When a dangerous condition exists on the customer's premises; 
(5)  When the customer fails to provide credit information, security deposit or guarantee as required by ordinances of the city; 
(6)  When the customer misrepresents the customer's identity for the purpose of obtaining utility service, or makes a false statement in the customer's application for service; 
(7)  When the customer refuses to grant utility personnel access, during normal working hours, to equipment installed upon the premises of the customer for the purpose of inspection, meter reading, maintenance or replacement; 
(8)  When a customer violates any rule or the utility which violation adversely affects the safety of the customer or other persons, or the integrity of the utility's delivery system; or 
(9)  When the customer causes or permits unauthorized interference with, or diversion, or use of, utility service situated or delivered on or about the customer's premises. 
(b)  None of the following shall constitute sufficient cause for the utility to discontinue service: 
(1)  The failure of the customer to pay for non-utility charges; 
(2)  The failure of the customer to pay for a different class of service received at the same location. The placing of more than one meter at the same location for the purpose of billing the usage of specific devices under optional rate schedules or provisions is not construed as a different class of service for the purpose of this article; 
(3)  The failure of a customer to pay a bill which is in dispute; provided, however, that the customer pays that portion of the bill, that is not in dispute. 
(c)  Except for discontinuance pursuant to subsections (a)(1), (3), (4), (7) and (8) of this section, the utility shall not discontinue service unless at the time of the proposed discontinuance, for one hour after discontinuance and on the day following discontinuance, the utility office of personnel identified in the notices of discontinuance of service given pursuant to the provision of this article are open or available to the customer for the purpose of preventing such continuance, or provide for reconnection 
(Code 1996,  15-526; Ord. No. 3288,  14; Ord. No. 3819,  XIII, 11-7-2000) 
Sec. 38-446. - Same-Special circumstances. 
(a)  If a residential customer notifies the utility and establishes that discontinuance would be especially dangerous to the health of the customer, resident member of the customer's family or other permanent resident of the premises where service is rendered, and that such customer is unable to pay for such service in accordance with the requirements of the utility's billing, or is able to pay for such service only in installments, the utility shall either allow payment in reasonable installments or postpone discontinuance of service for at least 21 days so that the customer can make arrangements for reasonable installment payments. 
(b)  In determining whether discontinuance would be especially dangerous to health, consideration shall be given to the weather, and the customer's or other resident's medical condition, age or disability. 
(Code 1996,  15-527; Ord. No. 3288,  14) 
Sec. 38-447. - Notice of discontinuance. 
(a)  The utility will give the customer at least seven days written notice before discontinuing service, unless such discontinuance is at the request of the customer, or when a dangerous condition exists on the customer's premises, or when the customer violates any provision of this article in a manner that adversely affects the safety of the customer or others, or the integrity of the utility's delivery system, in which cases, the service may be discontinued immediately and without notice, provided, however, that if the customer causes or permits unauthorized interference with, or diversion or use of electric service situated or delivered on the customer's premises the service may be discontinued upon written or oral notice to the customer. 
(b)  Notice shall be sent to the account name and address and in the case of residential occupancy, to the address where service is provided, if different from the account address. Service of notice by mail is complete upon mailing. An accurate record of the date of mailing shall be maintained. 
(c)  If the records of the utility show that the service account which it proposes to discontinue serves more than one residential dwelling unit, notice of discontinuance shall then be posted in a common area of the residential building served at least five days prior to the date of discontinuance specified therein. 
(Code 1996,  15-528; Ord. No. 3288,  14) 
Sec. 38-448. - Notice information. 
    The required notice of discontinuance of service shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the customer and the address where service is rendered, if different from the customer's address; 
(2)  A clear and concise statement of the reason for the proposed discontinuance of service and the cost and conditions for reconnection; 
(3)  The date on or after which service will be discontinued unless the customer takes appropriate action; 
(4)  Terms under which the customer may avoid discontinuance; 
(5)  A statement that discontinuance may be postponed or avoided if a customer can demonstrate that special circumstances prevent complete payment and satisfactory credit arrangements are made with the utility for moneys not in dispute; 
(6)  A statement reasonably calculated to apprise the customer of the availability of the administrative procedure which may be utilized in the event of a bona fide dispute relating to the reasons of the utility for the proposed discontinuance of service. The address, telephone number and name of the utility office or personnel empowered to review disputed bills, rectify errors and prevent disconnection shall be clearly set forth. The notice shall state that the customer may meet with a designated employee of the utility and may present the customer's reasons for disputing a bill or the utility's reasons for discontinuance, requesting credit arrangements or requesting a postponement of discontinuance; 
(7)  A statement of amount of any reconnection charge to be made for a reconnection after discontinuance of service for nonpayment of a bill, and that such reconnection charge must be paid to the city utility office before the reconnection is made. 
(Code 1996,  15-529; Ord. No. 3288,  14; Ord. No. 3819,  XIV, 11-7-2000) 
Sec. 38-449. - Duty of utility employee. 
    The employee of the utility who is to disconnect service shall leave a notice upon the premises in a manner conspicuous to the customer disclosing the date and time of discontinuance and giving the address and telephone number of the utility where the customer may arrange to have service restored. 
(Code 1996,  15-530; Ord. No. 3288,  14) 
Sec. 38-450. - Restoration of service; fees. 
(a)  Upon the customer's request, restoration of service will be scheduled when the cause of discontinuance of service has been eliminated, applicable reconnection fees have been paid and satisfactory credit arrangements required have been made. 
(b)  At all time every effort will be made to restore service as soon as possible following such request, but in no event later than the first business day following the day on which the request is made by the customer to the utility. 
(c)  Restoration of service and reconnections will not be made between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. of the following day or on week-ends or holidays unless the customer demonstrates to the satisfaction of the utility that an emergency exists for which service is required as determined by the city manager. 
(d)  For the reconnection or restoration of service, fees in the amount which is on file in the city clerk's office shall be charged before the reconnection is made for: 
(1)  Reconnections made between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on regular business days; 
(2)  Reconnections made when an emergency exists. 
(Code 1996,  15-531; Ord. No. 3288,  14; Ord. No. 3819,  XV, 11-7-2000) 
Sec. 38-451. - Review of disputes. 
(a)  When a customer advised appropriate personnel of the utility by written notice, in person or by a telephone call prior to the date of the proposed discontinuance of service that all or any part of any billing as rendered is in dispute or that the utility's reasons for discontinuance are factually invalid, the utility shall: 
(1)  Immediately record the date, time and place the complaint is made. 
(2)  Postpone discontinuance until a full investigation is completed and the dispute found to be invalid. 
(3)  Investigate the dispute promptly and completely. 
(4)  Attempt to resolve the dispute informally in a manner mutually satisfactory to both parties. 
(b)  The utility, in attempting to resolve the dispute in a mutually satisfactory manner, may employ telephone communication, personal meetings, formal or informal hearings, on-site visits or any other technique reasonably conducive to settlement of the dispute. 
(c)  In the event that a dispute is not resolved to the satisfaction of the customer, after full investigation, and the utility intends to proceed with discontinuance, the utility shall advise the customer of formal and informal procedures available before the governing body. The utility may then discontinue service if proper notice has been given. 
(Code 1996,  15-532; Ord. No. 3288,  14) 
Sec. 38-452. - Office of public utilities bills; supervise collections. 
    The office of public utilities shall maintain a light fund and a customer's deposit fund and shall keep an accurate record of all electric sales, sales tax, installation charges, fees, penalties, deposits and all other receipts and disbursements from the electric fund and customers' deposit fund. It shall keep an accurate record of the meter readings and amounts of electricity consumed, and total charges against the consumer, and amounts consumed, in suitable record books furnished by the city. It shall make out monthly bills and supervise their collections. 
(Code 1996,  15-533; Ord. No. 3288,  15) 
Sec. 38-453. - Same-Rates and charges. 
    Customers taking electric service from the City of Wellington shall be charged for such service in accordance with the below rate schedule. 
    The current rate being charged to customers for electric service shall remain in effect, but commencing for all bills for electric service with a beginning billing cycle date on or after January 1, 2016, the following service types and rates are effective. 
    For all bills for electric service with a beginning billing cycle date on or after January 1, 2017, and annually thereafter, a standard escalator of 2.25 percent will take effect on the existing rates. The governing body may take action, by resolution, to adjust or eliminate the escalator for that particular year. 
Rate Schedule

Service Type

Thereafter, no further credits shall be given the business.

Industrial service shall be defined as service to any customer engaged in manufacturing that entails producing or processing products that are not normally sold to an end user. An industrial service customer must have an estimated average monthly peak of 500 kW and employ at least 50 people at their facilities, which shall be reviewed annually. Qualification for the industrial service rate shall be approved by the city manager contingent upon the estimated average peak monthly demand. The city may require direct reimbursement of any improvements installed if warranted by special circumstances or unusually large investments by the city.

Meter Charge Rate $20.00/meter $0.024/kWh  
Interdepartmental/other service shall be defined as service to any institution or organization as directed by the City Council of the City of Wellington. 
5. Economic Development Service: 
Economic development service may be available for use by customers with an estimated monthly peak demand of at least 1,000 kW. Rates and other terms and conditions of this service will be negotiated between the city and the customer and shall be memorialized in a written contract. 
B.  Power Supply Monthly Cost Adjustment 
An electrical power supply monthly cost adjustment, PSMCA, shall be charged to our customers for the fluctuating cost of generating and purchasing electric energy. 
The power supply monthly cost adjustment shall be computed based on the formula: PSMCA = (A/B) x 1.15 (dollars per kilowatt hour) 
Where: 
A = Total purchased energy costs and generated energy fuel costs for the preceding 3 months. 
B = Total kilowatts-hours generated and purchased for the preceding 3 months. 
1.15 = A factor applied to compensate for transmission, distribution line losses and interdepartmental usage. 
The city manager shall have the authority to adjust the power supply monthly cost adjustment, if needed. ;b0; For all bills for electric service with a beginning billing cycle date on or after January 1, 2017, and annually thereafter, a standard escalator of 2.25% will take effect on the existing rates. The governing body may take action, by resolution, to adjust or eliminate the escalator for that particular year. 
(Ord. No. 4183,  I-III, 10-6-2015)

Sec. 38-454. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4183,  II, adopted Oct. 6, 2015, repealed  38-454 in its entirety. Former  38-454 pertained to commercial incentive electric service rates and derived from Ord. No. 3852,  II, adopted Oct. 15, 2002. 
Sec. 38-455. - Temporary service. 
    Consumers requiring temporary electric service shall be charged the amount which is on file in the city clerk's office. The customer shall furnish the location for the meter set. Typical examples of temporary service are special events sponsored by organized groups and owners of rental property requiring electricity for rehabilitation purposes. 
(Code 1996,  15-540; Ord. No. 3501,  1) 
Sec. 38-456. - Interconnection standards. 
    The governing body hereby approves the Interconnection Standards for Parallel Installation and Operation of Customer-Owned Electric Generating Facilities prepared by the public utility department. The governing body directs that no interconnections to the city's electric distribution system be allowed for customer-owned electric generating facilities unless these standards are met and the customer requesting the interconnection has completed an application for interconnection and signed an interconnection agreement. 
(Res. No. 5204,  1, 12-18-2007) 
Sec. 38-457. - Payment of electric bills; late payment charge; discontinuance and reconnection of service. 
(a)  All bills for electric utility service are due and payable on the first day after the billing date shown on the bill, and, if not paid on or before the date stated on the bill, the bill will become delinquent for all customers the 20th day after the date of the bill. 
(b)  When a bill becomes delinquent, a late payment charge in an amount equal to five percent of the delinquent amount owed for current utility service will be added to the customers bill, and collection efforts by the utility will be initiated. 
(c)  If the last calendar day for remittance falls on Sunday, legal holiday, or other day when the offices of the utility are not open to the general public, the final payment date shall be extended through the next business day. 
(d)  The utility may discontinue service for a delinquent bill after issuing the notice of discontinuance as required by this article, provided, however, that such notice shall be sent so that services shall be discontinued prior to the date when the next bill is due to be sent; reconnection of the discontinued service shall be made and fees paid for such reconnection in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1996,  15-547; Ord. No. 3309,  1; Ord. No. 3819,  XVI, 11-7-2000) 
Sec. 38-458. - City may contract, with customer for electrical energy. 
    The city shall have the right to contract with any customer receiving electric service from the municipal electric system of the city whose maximum capacity does not exceed 25 kW for electrical energy to be supplied by the customer to the city's electric system. The contract and the performance of the same shall be subject to and controlled by the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1996,  15-549; Ord. No. 3298,  1) 
Sec. 38-459. - Contract requirements; sources. 
    The customer must be receiving electric service from the municipal electric system of the city at one point of delivery, and the customer's requirements for electrical energy are being supplied from a source other than the city's system that is connected for parallel operation with the service of the city's system. The customer's sources may include, but are not limited to, windmills, water wheels, solar conversion and geothermal devices. 
(Code 1996,  15-550; Ord. No. 3298,  2) 
Sec. 38-460. - Form of electric energy. 
    The customer's source shall provide energy in the form of alternative current, 60 cycles, at the voltage and phase of the established secondary distribution system of the city most available at the customer's point of delivery. 
(Code 1996,  15-551; Ord. No. 3298,  3) 
Sec. 38-461. - Energy source operation-Customer to maintain. 
    The customer shall furnish, install, operate and maintain in good working order without cost to the city such relays, locks and seals, breakers, automatic synchronizer and other control and protective apparatus as shall be required by the city for the operation of the customer's energy source in parallel with the city's system. 
(Code 1996,  15-552; Ord. No. 3298,  4) 
Sec. 38-462. - Same-City to maintain. 
    At the customer's expense, the city will supply, install and maintain a reverse meter, at a cost to be on file in the city clerk's office, and associated equipment necessary to provide a net reading for energy passing to and from the customer's system, and a disconnecting device located near the meter, and for purposes of monitoring the customer's generation and load, the city may install load research metering. 
(Code 1996,  15-553; Ord. No. 3298,  5; Ord. No. 4195,  I, 8-2-2016) 
Sec. 38-463. - Rates. 
    The city may purchase from the customer energy generated by the customer at the same rate the customer is charged for energy furnished the customer by the city and a net billing shall be rendered to the customer in accordance with ordinances and rules and regulations relating to the administration of the city's electric system which shall become due and payable as provided therein, provided, however, that the city shall have the right to require the customer to limit production of electrical energy from the customer's generating facility to an amount no greater than the load at such facility. 
(Code 1996,  15-554; Ord. No. 3298,  6) 
Sec. 38-464. - Customer to reimburse city. 
    The customer shall be required to reimburse the city for the cost of equipment and/or other facilities made necessary as a result of the customer's installation of generation of electricity in parallel with the city's service. Costs or fees will be on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1996,  15-555; Ord. No. 3298,  7; Ord. No. 4195,  I, 8-2-2016) 
Sec. 38-465. - Notice; testing. 
    The customer shall notify the city prior to the initial energizing and start-up testing of the customer's generator, and a representative may be present during such test. The city's duly authorized agent or representative shall at all times have the right to enter upon the premises upon which the customer's generator is located for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of this article and any contract that is entered into pursuant to this article and for the further purpose of examining, inspecting and observing the customer's generator and appurtenances thereto to determine if the installation is in compliance with all applicable ordinances, rules and regulations of the city. 
(Code 1996,  15-556; Ord. No. 3298,  8) 
Secs. 38-466-38-481. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - USE REGULATIONS 

Sec. 38-482. - Compliance with city laws. 
    The installation of all customer-owned generating facilities shall be in compliance with and shall conform to all ordinances, rules and regulations of the city relating to its electric system and the operation thereof, including, but not limited to, provisions of the National Electrical Code adopted by the city, pertaining to stand-by power generation systems, and relating to zoning, noise, or any other area of control that may affect or be affected by such generating facilities and their operation. 
(Code 1996,  15-557; Ord. No. 3298,  9) 
Sec. 38-483. - Cold weather rule; established. 
    There is hereby established for the electric system of the city a rule to be known as the "cold weather rule" which shall be available between November 1 and the following March 31 to any qualifying residential customer of said electric system who have unpaid arrearages and who meet the requirements of tests known as good faith tests, as follows: 
(1)  For customers whose point of service is within the corporate limits of the city and for customers whose point of service is outside said corporate limits, but not more than three miles from such corporate limits 
a.  If a customer meets and complies with the requirements of a "good faith test" hereinafter set forth, the customer's service shall not disconnected between November 1 and March 31 when the local National Weather Service Office forecasts that the temperature will drop below 35 degrees or will be in the mid 30s or colder within the following 48-hour period unless: 
1.  Disconnection is requested by the customer; 
2.  The service is abandoned; 
3.  A dangerous condition exists on the customer's premises; 
4.  The customer violates any rule of the utility which adversely affects the safety of the customer or other persons, or the physical integrity of the utility's delivery system; 
5.  The customer causes or permits unauthorized interference with or diversion by use of a meter bypass, or otherwise, utility service situated or delivered on or about the customer's premises; 
6.  If conditions described in subsections (1)a.3, 4, and 5 of this section exist, the service may be disconnected immediately and shall be restored as soon as possible after the conditions causing such disconnection have been corrected. 
b.  In order for the customer to qualify for the benefits of the cold weather rule the customer must meet the requirements of the good faith test which are: 
1.  Inform the utility of the customer's inability to pay the bill in full; 
2.  Give the utility sufficient information to allow the utility to make a payment agreement; 
3.  Make an initial payment to the utility of 25 percent of the arrearage plus the bill for consumption during the most recent billing period for which service was provided, and make a revised payment agreement calling for payment of the balance of the arrearage over a period of not more than six months; 
4.  Apply for federal, state, local or other funds for which the customer is eligible; 
5.  Not illegally divert utility service by use of a bypass meter or by any other means; and 
6.  Not default on the payment plan established by the payment agreement. 
c.  It shall be the utility's responsibility to: 
1.  Publish notice of the cold weather rule in the official city newspaper once a year at least 30 days prior to the date on which the cold weather rule becomes effective; 
2.  Mail by first-class mail, postage prepaid, at least seven days prior to termination or disconnection of service a written notice of such termination of disconnection to the person in whose name the service is placed; 
3.  Make no disconnection of service unless the National Weather Service has forecast for a 48-hour period a temperature above the temperature at which the cold weather rule is activated, and then only if, on the day of disconnection, the National Weather Service has forecast a temperature above the activating temperature for a 24-hour period; 
4.  Inform the customer of, or provide a list of, the requirements of the good faith test; 
5.  Inform the customer of, or provide a list of, organizations where funds may be available for the payment of utility bills; 
6.  Inform the customer of, or provide a list of, other payment arrangements for which the customer might qualify; 
7.  Encourage customers to renegotiate cold weather rule payments if the customer receives utility or other lump sum assistance; and 
8.  If the utility deems it appropriate, inform its customers of the long-range advantages of weatherization programs. 
d.  A diversion of service by use of a meter bypass, or otherwise, adequately documented by the utility, from which the customer has benefited shall be deemed a breach of the good faith test and a default of the payment agreement. Such default may be cured by payment by the customer of the value of the diverted service to be determined by an estimate of usage based on the historic use of the customer at the place of service. 
e.  All other breaches of the good faith test shall be deemed defaults of the payment agreement and may be cured by the customer making an initial payment as set forth in the good faith test; paying any disconnect and reconnect charges incurred as a result of such default; and complying with the provisions of the good faith test. 
(2)  For customers whose point of service is more than three miles from the corporate limits of the city the provisions of the cold weather rule set forth in section V of the Kansas Corporation Commission Order in Docket No. 97-GIMG-514-GIG, issued on March 7, 2000, incorporated by reference herein. 
(Code 1996,  15-558; Ord. No. 3380,  I; Ord. No. 3819,  XVII, 11-7-2000) 
Sec. 38-484. - Good faith test. 
(a)  For purposes of the cold weather rule of the Wellington Electric System, the good faith test shall require the customer to: 
(1)  Inform the system of the customer's inability to pay the customer's utility bill in full; 
(2)  Give the system sufficient information to allow a determination of payment agreement to be made; and 
(3)  Apply for federal, state, local or other funds available for the payment of utility bills for which the customer may be eligible. 
(b)  The electric system shall notify the customer, at the time the customer is required to meet the good faith test, of available assistance for the payment of electric bills either by providing a list of agencies where funds are available for the payment of such bills, or by informing the customer that such list is available at the city utility office. 
(Code 1996,  15-559; Ord. No. 3380,  II) 
Sec. 38-485. - Cold weather rule requirements. 
(a)  Electric service shall not be disconnected for any customer who qualifies under the cold weather rule and who meets the good faith test, if the customer makes an initial payment to the electrical system of 25 percent of the bill for consumption of electricity during the most recent billing period for which service was provided or $45.00, whichever is greater, plus one-twelfth of the arrearage and pays the remaining arrearage in 11 equal monthly payments in the months immediately following the initial payment. 
(b)  A customer may be disconnected or prevented from qualifying for the cold weather rule upon the customers breach of the good faith test which breach has not been cured by the customer. The customer shall be deemed to have breached the good faith test if it is documented that a diversion of electric service has occurred and the customer has benefited from such diversion, or the customer has defaulted in making payments on the agreement made under the cold weather rule and remains in default. A customer may cure a breach arising from diversion of service by paying the electric system for the value of the diverted service, which value is to be estimated based upon the historic use of the customer. A customer may cure a breach arising from default in making payment by making an initial payment as set forth in the cold weather rule, paying disconnect and reconnect charges incurred as a result of such default and complying with the good faith test. 
(c)  Before disconnecting any residential customer of the Wellington electric system for failure to comply with the good faith test the electric system in addition to the requirements of its other rules and regulations shall make one attempt to contact the customer by telephone; mail, by first class mail at least seven days prior to disconnection, one written notice of the proposed disconnection; and one attempt to contact the customer in person. The attempt at telephone contact with the customer may be made after the written notice is mailed. 
(d)  In addition to requirements of other ordinances of the city or other rules and regulations of the electric system, the electric system shall, in each of the customer contacts and in the written notice required by this section, inform the customer: 
(1)  Of the existence of the cold weather rule; 
(2)  That the customer can avoid disconnection by complying with the customer good faith test; 
(3)  Of the elements or requirements of the good faith test; 
(4)  Of the names of organizations where funds are available to pay electric bills; and 
(5)  Of all other pay arrangements for which the customer might qualify. 
(e)  Prior to disconnection of service between November 1 and the following March 31 to any customer who qualifies under the cold weather rule and who meets the good faith test the customer shall also be notified of the formal and informal complaint procedures available under other ordinances and policies of the city and rules and regulations of the electric system. 
(f)  In no event shall a customer's electric service be disconnected when the local national weather service office forecasts that the temperature will drop below 35 degrees Fahrenheit within the following 24-hour period. 
(Code 1996,  15-560; Ord. No. 3380,  III) 
Sec. 38-486. - Cold weather rule security deposit. 
    No customer shall be assessed an additional security deposit as a criterion for qualification under the cold weather rule, but an assessment of a security deposit may be made under other existing rules of the Wellington electric system and in conjunction with the cold weather rule if such assessment is permitted to be amortized over a 12-month period. 
(Code 1996,  15-561; Ord. No. 3380,  IV) 
Sec. 38-487. - Energy analysis. 
    The Wellington electric system shall inform customers that an energy analysis of the customer's residence is available through the Audit for Conservation Today Program. 
(Code 1996,  15-562; Ord. No. 3380,  V) 
Sec. 38-488. - Application for certain customers. 
    Ordinances of the city that are in conflict with any of the model rules and regulations hereinabove incorporated by reference may be applied to customers of the municipal electric utility whose point of service is within the corporate limits of the city and within three miles of the corporate limits. 
(Code 1996,  15-565; Ord. No. 3550,  2) 
Sec. 38-489. - Underground distribution system. 
    Any person or property owner who desires an underground electrical distribution system, regardless of the number of lots to be served by the distribution system, may pay the difference in cost between installing the underground distribution system and the standard overhead distribution system. Payment will be made in advance based on the estimated difference. If the cost exceeds or is less than the estimate, the adjustments will be made 
(Code 1996,  15-566; Ord. No. 3573,  1) 
Secs. 38-490-38-516. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SECURITY LIGHTING SERVICE 

Sec. 38-517. - Availability, type. 
(a)  Security lighting service shall be available to all electric customers of the city for the purpose of providing outdoor security lighting on premises occupied by the customer by ballast operated vapor lamp fixtures, overhead wiring and poles conforming to city specifications. The service may be installed on the city's side of the meter and be deemed unmetered service, or it may be installed on the customer's side of the meter and be deemed metered service. 
(b)  Unmetered service may consist of 100-watt high pressure sodium lighting fixtures affixed to existing poles owned by the city, or 100-watt high pressure sodium lighting fixtures, overhead wiring and 35-foot wooden poles located at such place or places and in such manner as desired by the customer, as in the sole discretion of the city, will be readily accessible for installation and maintenance by crews and equipment of the city. All equipment and facilities furnished by the city for unmetered service shall be the property of the city, and the installation of such service and all repairs and maintenance thereof shall be performed only by employees of the city. Unmetered service shall be available upon the execution of a written contract with the city describing the type unmetered service to be furnished, and obligating the customer to pay the rates established by the city for the full term of the contract. 
(Ord. No. 3859,  I, 12-3-2002) 
Sec. 38-518. - Rates. 
(a)  For unmetered service consisting of one 100-watt high pressure sodium lighting fixture, overhead wiring not exceeding 150 feet in length and one 35-foot wooden pole located at such place or places and in such manner as desired by the customer, as in the sole discretion of the city, will be readily accessible for installation and maintenance by crews and equipment of the city, the monthly charge shall be the amount which is on file in the city clerk's office. For each additional security light fixture installed a monthly charge shall be made. If an extension of the secondary circuit of the city and a new or additional support poles are required, an additional monthly charge for each additional pole installed shall be made. If the installation of such service requires extraordinary expenditures for special facilities or equipment, the city may require an additional guarantee of revenue or prepayment sufficient to cover such extraordinary expenditure. 
(b)  For metered service there shall charged, in addition to the charges for electricity used by the customer, a monthly maintenance fee in the amount which is on file in the city clerk's office shall be paid in advance for each month the customer desires such maintenance service. 
(Ord. No. 3859,  II, 12-3-2002) 
Secs. 38-519-38-546. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SOLID WASTE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Refuse collection and disposal, K.S.A. 12-2101 et seq. 

Sec. 38-547. - City to collect all refuse; exceptions. 
    The city shall provide facilities for the systematic collection and disposal of all refuse as defined herein from the corporate limits of the city, provided, however, that any person, tenant, householder, firm or corporation may on isolated occasions remove refuse from the property and premises he, she or it occupies and transport the refuse within the city in closed containers or otherwise secured, or in vehicles equipped with closed compartments or covers so as to eliminate leakage or littering from the vehicle. 
(Code 1996,  15-601; Ord. No. 3098,  1) 
Sec. 38-548. - Defining and classifying garbage, refuse and trash. 
    For the purposes of this article, refuse shall include garbage and trash. Garbage and trash are defined as follows and shall be divided into the following classes: 
(1)  Garbage shall include wastes from the preparation, cooking and consumption of foods and foodstuffs and market refuse and waste from the handling, preparation, storage and sale of foods and foodstuffs. 
(2)  Trash shall be defined as: 
a.  Combustible trash, which shall include paper, cartons, boxes, barrels, pieces of wood, excelsior. 
b.  Noncombustible trash which shall include the following: 
1.  Metals, tin cans, metal furniture, broken glass, crockery, bottles, jars and other mineral refuse and bones; 
2.  Manure and decayed animal and vegetable matter; 
3.  Loose earth, sand, gravel and ashes; 
4.  Dead animals. 
c.  Trash shall not include washrack, residue, earth and wastes from building operations, solid wastes resulting from industrial processes and manufacturing operations such as food processing wastes, boiler house cinders, lumber scraps sawdust and shavings, tree trimmings, logs, tree trunks and yard clippings and leaves. 
(Code 1974,  19-102; Code 1996,  15-602) 
Sec. 38-549. - Responsibility of owners and tenants on premises. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner and tenant of each lot or parcel of ground, regardless of the use to which the lot or parcel of ground is put, within the corporate limits of the city to keep the premises free and clear of all classes of refuse, garbage and trash. 
(Code 1996,  15-603; Ord. No. 3323,  1) 
Sec. 38-550. - Collection of refuse in residential area. 
(a)  Each family or family unit within the corporate limits of the city shall: 
(1)  Furnish for the storage of refuse a separate container with a tight lid, the size of which container shall not exceed 45 gallons unless otherwise purchased or provided by the city; 
(2)  No deposit in excess of 100 pounds of refuse in any one container; 
(3)  Drain all surplus water from garbage and wrap the same in heavy paper or newspaper before depositing the same in the receptacle; 
(4)  Place refuse container or containers at the rear of the lot adjacent to the alley unless otherwise ordered and directed by the public works department of the city. 
(b)  Collection of refuse in residential districts shall be made at least once each week or as often as may be deemed necessary by the public works department. 
(Code 1974,  19-104; Code 1996,  15-604) 
Sec. 38-551. - Collection of refuse in business district. 
    Each business enterprise having refuse shall furnish receptacles for the same in accordance with the provisions of section 38-550. Refuse shall be collected from the business establishments of the city daily except Sundays and holidays, or as often as may be deemed necessary by the health officer. 
(Code 1974,  19-105; Code 1996,  15-605) 
Sec. 38-552. - Provisions for fees. 
    Provisions for fees for the collection of refuse shall be as follows: 
(1)  The minimum charge for refuse collection by the city shall be as follows: 
a.  For each person over the age of 62 years living alone within the corporate limits of the city on a pension and not gainfully employed or operating a business out of the home; or, a couple, both or whom are of the city on a pension, or pensions, whether gainfully employed or not, having a total annual combined income not exceeding $22,150.00 from all sources, if a statement reciting facts sufficient to show that the person or persons meets the foregoing requirements is signed and filed by such person or persons with the city clerk and is approved by such, per month ..... $10.25 
b.  For each family or family unit living within the corporate limits of the city, per month ..... $15.50 
c.  For all other customers, the minimum charge shall be based upon frequency of service, size and number of containers and shall be as follows: 
1.  30 gallon container (two or less) 
one-time pickup ..... $16.50 
each extra pickup ..... $3.90 
each extra container ..... $2.30 
2.  55 gallon container 
one-time pickup ..... $16.50 
each extra pickup ..... $7.80 
each extra container ..... $4.65 
3.  Polycart 
one-time pickup ..... $16.50 
each extra pickup ..... $10.85 
each extra container ..... $7.80 
4.  one yard dumpster 
one-time pickup ..... $23.25 
each extra pickup ..... $15.50 
each extra container ..... $11.60 
5.  two yard dumpster 
one-time pickup ..... $31.00 
each extra pickup ..... $23.25 
each extra container ..... $15.50 
6.  three yard dumpster 
one-time pickup ..... $43.40 
each extra pickup ..... $32.55 
each extra container ..... $21.70 
(2)  The director of public works, based upon the frequency of collections, quantity of refuse, type of containers used, accessibility of collection point and other pertinent factors, may make additional charges above the minimum for refuse more than the usual or normal refuse collected, hauled and disposed of, or refuse the collection, hauling and disposal of which, is more difficult than usual or normal. For residential customers, the quantity of refuse shall be limited to the equivalent of two polycarts, or four 45-gallon containers, or two yards. Additional refuse will be taken for a fee of $7.00 per yard, which will be added to the customer's monthly charges. 
(3)  In case of multiple family or multiple occupant units, where the water or electric service is paid by a single party, the party billed for such service will be billed for the additional family units, or at business rates. 
(4)  No connection for utility service in any part of the city shall be made until the consumer or customer makes provision for municipal refuse collection and disposal service at the same time that application is made for said utility service. The monthly charge for refuse collection for a newly established business shall originally be based upon charges then being made for other businesses of similar type. 
(5)  The charges for municipal refuse collection and disposal service shall be due and payable on the day following the date of the billing rendered at the same place as fees or charges for other utility services and may be included as a separate item on the billings for other utility services. If such charges are not paid on or before the 20 th day after the date of the billing rendered, a penalty of ten percent of the charge shall be added to all current bills for refuse collection and shall be collected at the time the bill is finally paid. Failure or refusal of a user to pay the refuse collection fee shall be sufficient cause for discontinuing collection of the user's refuse, but neither electric service nor water service shall be discontinued for the failure or refusal of the user to pay such refuse collection fee. 
(Ord. No. 4089,  I, II, 3-15-2011; Ord. No. 4154, 4-1-2014; Ord. No. 4188,  I, 12-1-2015; Ord. No. 4218,  I, 12-5-2017; Ord. No. 4237,  I, 11-20-2018)

Former  38-552 pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 3016,  19-106, adopted 1974; Ord. No. 3121; Ord. No. 3283; Ord. No. 3308; Code 1983,  15-606; Ord. Sec. 38-553. - Sanitation reserve fund-Established. 
    There is hereby created and established, pursuant to the provisions of K.S.A. 12-1,117, a municipal equipment reserve fund of the city, to be known as the Sanitation Department Equipment Reserve Fund, which fund shall be used for the purpose of financing the acquisition of new and replacement equipment, including machinery, vehicles and any other equipment or personal property of any nature whatsoever which the city is authorized to purchase for the operation, maintenance and improvement of the sanitation department of the city. 
(Code 1996,  15-607; Ord. No. 3533,  1) 
Sec. 38-554. - Same-Use. 
    It is declared to be the policy of the governing body of the city that the Sanitation Department Equipment Reserve Fund shall be used as a financing mechanism to secure the planned and orderly acquisition and replacement of equipment for the efficient and effective operation, maintenance and improvement of the sanitation department of the city. To that end it is the intent of the governing body to annually approve in the future the budgeting of then current revenues sufficient to finance the acquisition of new equipment needed for the following year, and needed future replacements and acquisitions of equipment by setting aside as reserve amount. The amount to be annually reserved shall not be less than the then current use value of existing city equipment in the sanitation department of the city. 
(Code 1996,  15-608; Ord. No. 3533,  2) 
Sec. 38-555. - Same-Budget proposals. 
    The city manager shall submit a plan for the implementation of this article and for the achievement of the policy objectives expressed in section 38-554, and shall, beginning in 1989, annually submit, with the proposed annual budget, a proposed sanitation department equipment acquisition program for each of the following five years. The budget proposed shall include an amount sufficient to finance proposed sanitation department equipment acquisitions for the following year as well as an additional amount to be reserved as set forth in the currently submitted acquisition program. 
(Code 1996,  15-609; Ord. No. 3533,  3) 
Sec. 38-556. - Same-Investment. 
    Moneys in the Sanitation Department Equipment Reserve Fund may be invested in accordance with the provisions of K.S.A. 10-131, and the interest earned on such investments shall be credited to such fund. 
(Code 1996,  15-610; Ord. No. 3533,  4) 
Secs. 38-557-38-575. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - UTILITY RESERVE FUND[4] 

Footnotes:

Charter Ordinance reference- Investment of certain funds, Charter Ordinance Number 13.

Sec. 38-576. - Established. 
    There is hereby created and established, pursuant to K.S.A. 12-1,117 and 12-1,118 a fund of the city to be known as the Utility Multi-year Capital Improvement and Equipment Reserve Fund which fund shall be used only for the water, electric and sewer departments of the city for the purposes of financing, in whole or in part, any public improvement need for the departments, including the repair, restoration and rehabilitation of existing facilities and for the purpose of financing the acquisition of new and replacement equipment, including machinery, vehicles and any other equipment or personal property of any nature whatsoever which the city is authorized to purchase for the operation, maintenance and improvement of the aforesaid departments. The fund shall periodically be reimbursed from bond proceeds, special assessments or state or federal aid that may be available for the completed project. 
(Code 1996,  15-701; Ord. No. 3532,  1) 
Sec. 38-577. - Use. 
    It is declared to be the policy of the city that the Utility Multi-Year Capital Improvement Fund and Equipment Reserve Fund shall be used as a financing mechanism for the construction, repair and rehabilitation of public facilities of the departments, including costs of engineering and other advance improvement plans and studies for the departments and to secure the planned and orderly acquisition and replacement of equipment for the efficient and effective operation, maintenance and improvement of the electric, water and sewer departments of the city. The revenues derived from said electric, water and sewer departments of the city credited to the fund shall be paid out, disbursed or utilized to meet the present and future public infrastructure needs of said departments, all in accordance with the provisions of K.S.A. 12-825d and amendments thereto, and to annually approve in the future the budgeting of the then current revenues sufficient to finance the acquisition of new equipment needed for the following year, and needed future replacements and acquisitions of equipment by setting aside a reserve amount annually in an amount not less than the then current use value of the existing city equipment in the departments. 
(Code 1996,  15-702; Ord. No. 3532,  2; Ord. No. 3819,  XIX, 11-7-2000) 
Sec. 38-578. - Budget proposals. 
(a)  The city manager shall submit a place of operation for the implementation of this article and for the achievement of the policy objectives expressed in section 38-577 which shall provide that the annual, revised and adopted capital improvements plan of the city identify those improvements to be financed from the fund during the following year. 
(b)  Beginning in the year 1989, the city manager shall submit annually, with the proposed annual budget of the city, a proposed utility equipment acquisition program for each of the following five years, and shall submit annually as a part of the operating budget of the city: 
(1)  Such proposed revenue allocations and budget transfers as may be necessary: 
a.  To finance those improvements scheduled for completion next year, the cost of which is to be credited to the fund, as provided by the capital improvements plan; and 
b.  To set aside moneys to be annually reserved for future improvements, as provided in the capital improvements plan; and 
(2)  An amount sufficient to finance proposed utility equipment acquisitions for the following year as well as an additional amount to be reserved as set forth in the currently submitted acquisition program, all in accordance with the provisions of K.S.A. 12-825d and amendments thereto. 
(Code 1996,  15-703; Ord. No. 3532,  3; Ord. No. 3819,  XX, 11-7-2000) 
Sec. 38-579. - Investment. 
    Moneys in the Utility Multi-Year Capital Improvement and Equipment Reserve Fund may be invested in accordance with the provisions of K.S.A. 10-131, and the interest earned on such investments shall be credited to such fund. 
(Code 1996,  15-704; Ord. No. 3532,  4)

Chapter 40 - ZONING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Zoning regulations, K.S.A. 12-753 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 40-1. - Purpose and intent. 
    These regulations are adopted for the purposes and intent of providing for the health and welfare of the citizens of the city's zoning jurisdiction through promotion of appropriate patterns and practices of urban development. Within this general purpose, the zoning regulations are intended to: 
(1)  Promote the health and general welfare of the citizens. 
(2)  Provide for adequate light, air and acceptable noise levels. 
(3)  Encourage the most productive use of urban land resources through promotion of compatible land use patterns. 
(4)  Prevent the overcrowding of land and undue concentration of population. 
(5)  Facilitate the adequate provision of transportation, water, sewage, schools, parks, and other public requirements. 
(6)  Protect property values and conserve energy resources. 
(7)  Regulate and restrict the location and use of buildings and the uses of land within each district for residential, commercial, industrial, and other purposes. 
(8)  Regulate and restrict the height, number of stories, and size of buildings; and the size of yards and other open spaces. 
(9)  Guard against loss of life and damage to property due to flooding through protection of natural drainage features. 
(10)  Preserve features of historical significance and the conservation of natural resources. 
(11)  Implement goals, policies, and proposals of the long-range development plan for the zoning jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 3826(1), art. II,  1, 7-3-2001) 
Sec. 40-2. - Definitions. 
(a)  For the purpose of interpreting the provisions of these regulations, certain terms or words used herein shall be interpreted or defined as follows, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    Accessory building means a subordinate building which serves a function customarily incidental to the main use of the premises. Customary accessory buildings include garages, carports and small storage sheds. 
    Accessory use means a subordinate use which serves an incidental function to that of the main use of the premises. Customary accessory uses include tennis courts, swimming pools, air conditioners, barbecue ovens and fireplaces. 
    Agricultural use means the use of a tract of land for the growing of crops, pasturage, nursery, or the raising of poultry, including the structures necessary for carrying out farming operations and the residence or residences of those owning or operating the premises, a member of the family thereof, or persons employed thereon, and the family thereof, but such use shall not include feedlots. 
    Alley means a dedicated public right-of-way, other than a street, which provides only a secondary means of access to abutting property, the right-of-way of which is 20 feet or less in width. 
    Alley line means the line of division between the public travelway comprising the alley and the private lot. 
    Alteration means alteration, as applied to a building or structure, is a change or rearrangement in the structural parts of an existing building or structure. Enlargement, whether by extending a side, increasing the height, or the moving from one location or position to another, shall be considered as an alteration. 
    Animal hospital or clinic means an establishment where animals are admitted principally for examination, treatment, board or care by a doctor of veterinary medicine. (This does not include open kennels or runs.) 
    Apartment. See Dwelling, multiple . 
    Apartment house means a building or portion thereof intended, designed, used, or suitable for use as a residence for three or more families living in separate apartments. 
    Approved private sewer system means a sewage disposal system meeting the sanitary requirements of the county which is approved for use by the governing body of the city. 
    Approved public sanitary sewer system means a sewage disposal plant, main sanitary sewer lines and other lines approved by the governing body of the city and the state department of health. 
    Approved public water system means water treatment plant and service lines approved by the governing body of the city and the state department of health. 
    Automobile service station means a structure and surrounding land used for the storage and sale of petroleum fuel, including self-service, primarily to passenger vehicles and/or for accessory uses, such as the sale of lubricants, accessories, or supplies; the incidental washing of motor vehicles, and the performing of minor repairs; but not including tire recapping, body repairs, major overhaul, provision of rental equipment, or open sales lots. No inoperative vehicles may be stored outside of the building. 
    Babysitting means home occupation operated by the resident of the home, caring for no more than two children under the age of 11 years, other than the resident's own children, and which is operated less than 20 hours per week. This occupation is not regulated by state or county and is permitted in residentially zoned districts. 
    Basement means that portion of a building having more than one-half of its height below grade. 
    Bed and breakfast includes those establishments commonly known as bed and breakfast, tourist homes, guesthouses, and historic inns. Such establishment provides lodging and one or more meals, provided for compensation, for one or more transient guests. 
    Block means a series of lots entirely surrounded by public rights-of-way, railroad rights-of-way, park, greenstrips, open land, or waterways. 
    Board of zoning appeals means that board which has been created by the governing body having jurisdiction and which has the statutory authority to hear and determine appeals, exceptions and variances to the zoning regulations. 
    Boarding home for children means a residential facility which is licensed by the state department of health and environment where children not related to the family by blood, marriage, or adoption are cared for 24 hours a day by adult supervision. 
    Boardinghouse or lodginghouse means a building other than a hotel where for compensation and by pre-arrangement for definite periods, meals, or lodging and/or meals, are provided for three or more persons but not exceeding 20 persons. Individual cooking facilities are not provided. 
    Buildable area means that area of a parcel or lot within which a structure can be constructed without conflicting with any requirements established by these regulations. 
    Building means a structure designed or intended for the enclosure, shelter or protection of persons, animals, or property. 
    Building height means the highest point on the building. 
    Building, main, means a building in which is conducted the principal use of the lot or parcel upon which it is situated. 
    Building official means the person designated to administer these zoning regulations, whether such person is entitled building official, building inspector, administrative official, city engineer, city administrator, city clerk or zoning official. 
    Building site means the land area, consisting of one or more lots or parcels of land under common ownership or control, considered as the unit of land occupied or to be occupied by a main building or buildings and accessory building, or by a principal use or uses accessory thereto, together with such parking and loading spaces, yards, and open spaces as are required by these regulations. 
    Bulk regulations means regulations controlling the size of structures and the relationships of structures and uses to each other and to open areas and lot lines. The term "bulk regulations" includes regulations controlling maximum height, maximum lot coverage, and minimum size of yard and setbacks. 
    Business and professional office means the office of an engineer, dentist, doctor, attorney, real estate or insurance agent, architect, or other similar professional person, and any office used primarily for accounting, correspondence, research, editing, or administration. 
    Campgrounds means any piece, parcel, tract or plat of ground which provides space for transient occupancy and is used or intended to be used for the parking of one or more camping trailers, tents, or similar recreational vehicles. Under no circumstances shall any one camper occupy a campground for a period exceeding 30 consecutive days. The term "campgrounds" does not include sales lots of which unoccupied camping trailers, whether new or used, are parked for the purpose of storage, inspection, or sale. 
    Camping trailer means any vehicular portable dwelling unit designed especially for short-term occupancy such as: travel trailers, tent trailers, converted buses and trucks, and all other similar units whether self-propelled, pulled, or hauled, and designed primarily for highway travel without the necessity of a special permit. 
    Canopy means any structure, movable or stationary, attached to and deriving its support from framework or posts or other means independent of a connected structure for the purpose of shielding a platform, stoop, or sidewalk from the elements, or a roof-like structure of a permanent nature which projects from the wall of a structure and overhangs the public way. 
    Car wash means an establishment having facilities designed or used exclusively for washing or cleaning motor vehicles. 
    Cellular tower means a wireless communications tower providing service for cellular telephone users. 
    Child care center means business in which a qualified program director is employed which allows 13 or more children and is state and county regulated and inspected by the county. Locations of child care centers must be commercially zoned. 
    Clinics. See Medical, dental or health clinic . 
    Club or lodge, private, means a nonprofit association or organization formed for either fraternal, social, educational, philanthropic, or other similar purpose, including professional organizations, unions, and other similar organizations. 
    Common open space means an area of land or water or combination thereof planned for passive or active recreation, but does not include areas utilized for streets, alleys, driveways or private roads, off-street parking or loading areas. However, the area of recreational activities such as swimming pools, tennis courts, shuffleboard courts, etc., may be included as common open space. 
    Comprehensive plan means the duly adopted comprehensive plan for the development of the city. 
    Condominium means a multiple-family dwelling structure wherein the separate dwelling units are individually owned as opposed to rental units in an apartment or units with lots in a townhouse. 
    Corporate hog farm means any confined swine feeding operation of 1,000 head or more and operated as one individual or facility owned business. 
    Density means restrictions on the number of dwelling units that may be constructed per acre or per square foot of a zoning lot area. 
    Developer means the legal or beneficial owner or owners of all of the land proposed to be included in a planned development or the duly authorized agent thereof. The holder of an option or contract of purchase, a lessee having a remaining term of not less than 40 years, or other person having an enforceable proprietary interest in such land, shall be deemed to be a developer for the purpose of these regulations. 
    District means a section of the county and/or cities specifically declared within which the regulations governing the use of buildings and premises are uniform. 
    Dog means any canine species over six months of age. 
    Drive-in service means a type of retail sales establishment which encourages, recognizes, or permits patrons or customers to call for service by the flashing of lights or by the parking of motor vehicles at a particular place, intended to result in a cash sale and delivery outside of the places of business to such patrons or customers of food or beverage ready and intended for immediate human consumption without cooking or further preparation. 
    Dump means a lot or land or part thereof used primarily for the disposal by abandonment, dumping, burial, burning, or any other means, and for whatever purpose, of garbage, sewage, trash, refuse, junk, discarded machinery, vehicles or parts thereof, or waste material of any kind. 
    Dwelling means a building or portion thereof, not including manufactured homes, which is designed and used primarily for residential purposes. 
    Dwelling, attached, means a residential building which is joined to another dwelling at one or more sides by a party wall. 
    Dwelling, detached, means a residential building which is entirely surrounded by open space on the same lot as the main dwelling. 
    Dwelling, multiple, means a residential building having accommodations for and occupied exclusively by more than two families, independently. 
    Dwelling, seasonal, means a residence intended for occasional occupancy. 
    Dwelling, single-family, means a residential building having accommodations for and occupied exclusively by one family. 
    Dwelling, two-family, means a residential building having accommodations for and occupied exclusively by two families, independently. 
    Dwelling unit means one or more rooms in a residential building or residential portion of a building which are arranged, designed, used, or intended for use by one family, and which includes cooking space and lawful sanitary facilities reserved for the occupants thereof. 
    Exception means the allowance of a use within a given district by the board of zoning appeals. Exceptions shall be limited to only those specifically authorized and listed in these zoning regulations. 
    Exotic animal means any animal not commonly maintained as a household pet and/or not commonly raised as agricultural livestock. 
    Family means either an individual or two or more persons related by blood, marriage, or adoption living together as a single housekeeping unit in a dwelling unit; or a group of not more than four persons who need not be related by blood, marriage, or adoption living together as a single housekeeping unit in a dwelling unit; plus in either case, domestic servants. A family may include any number of gratuitous guests or minor children not related by blood, marriage, or adoption. 
    Feed lot means the confined feeding of livestock in lots, pens, pools or ponds which are not normally used for raising crops and in which no vegetation, intended for animal food, is growing. This will not include a wintering operation for livestock in lots or on farming ground unless the operation causes a pollution problem. Livestock shall include horses, cattle, swine and sheep. 
    Fence means a freestanding structure of metal, masonry, glass, or wood or any combination thereof resting on or partially buried in the ground and rising above ground level and used for confinement, screening, or partition purposes constructed of uniform material. 
    Floodplain means a watercourse and land adjacent to a watercourse subject to inundation from a flood having a chance occurrence in any one year of one percent as identified on an official FEMA flood hazard map. 
    Floor area means floor area shall mean the gross floor area of all floors in the building including: 
(1)  Stairwells, elevator shafts, and mechanical equipment enclosures, except roof-mounted mechanical equipment. 
(2)  Penthouses. 
(3)  One-half the basement floor area. 
(4)  Interior balconies and mezzanines. 
(5)  Enclosed porches. 
(6)  Floor area devoted to accessory uses. 
(7)  Interior and exterior walls, except where adjoining units share a common wall. In such case, measurement shall be from the center of the common wall. 
    Foster home means a residence or building in which more than 12-hour care is provided to no more than five children, two or more of which are unrelated to the foster parents. Foster homes shall be permitted in all residential structures, the same as would a family. 
    Fraternal and/or service clubs means an association formally organized for either fraternal, social, educational, philanthropic, or other similar purposes, including union and professional organizations, and operated not for profit for persons who are bona fide members paying annual dues, which owns, hires, or leases premises, the use of which premises is restricted to such members and their guests. The affairs and management of such association are conducted by a board of directors, executive committee, or similar body chosen by the members at their annual meeting. Food, meals, and beverages may be served on such premises provided adequate dining space and kitchen facilities are available. Alcoholic beverages may be sold or served to members and their guests provided such service is secondary and incidental to the promotion of some other common objective of the organization, and further provided that such sale or service of alcoholic beverages is in compliance with all federal, state, county, and local laws. 
    Frontage means the length of the property abutting on one side of a street measured along the dividing line between the property and the street. 
    Gambling casino means any building, room, enclosure, vehicle, vessel, or other place, whether open or enclosed, which is intended to be used for professional gambling. 
    Garage, private, means any accessory building designed or used only for the storage of motor-driven vehicles owned and used by the occupants of the building to which it is accessory. 
    Garage, public, means any building or portion thereof, other than a private garage, designed or used for equipping, repairing, hiring, servicing, selling, or storing motor-driven vehicles. 
    Garage, storage , means a building, or portion thereof, designed or used exclusively for housing four or more motor-driven vehicles. 
    Governing body means that body having jurisdiction in the zoning area. 
    Grade means: 
(1)  For buildings having walls facing one street only, the elevation of the sidewalk at the center of the wall facing the street shall be the grade. 
(2)  For buildings having walls facing more than one street, the grade shall be the average of the grades as defined in subsection (1) of this definition of all walls facing each street. 
(3)  For buildings having no wall facing a street, the average level of the finished surface of the ground adjacent to the exterior walls of the building shall be the grade. 
(4)  Any wall approximately parallel to and not more than five feet from a street line is considered as facing the street. 
    Group day care means business that is state and county regulated and inspected by the county, in which the operator is a resident of the home and cares for no more than 12 children, including the resident's own children, all under the age of 11 years. If the operator cares for more than ten children, a second operator is required. Commercial zoning is required if the operator is not a resident of the home or if the second operator is required and is not a family member. 
    Group homes means any dwelling occupied by not more than ten persons, including eight or fewer persons with a disability, who need not be related by blood or marriage and not to exceed two staff residents who need not be related by blood or marriage to each other or to the residents of the home, which dwelling is licensed by a regulatory agency of the state. 
    Home occupation means any lawful activity conducted within the principal building (dwelling) or accessory buildings by members of the immediate family residing on the premises, for the purpose of earning income, except as expressly prohibited in this definition, which requires personal appearances by customers or delivery of their personal property at the dwelling for the purpose of providing goods and/or services. Home occupations shall meet all of the following conditions: 
(1)  The residential character of the property is maintained. 
(2)  The activity is conducted in such a manner as not to give an outward appearance nor manifest any characteristic of a business in the ordinary meaning of the term, nor infringe upon the right of neighboring residents to enjoy the peaceful occupancy of their homes. 
(3)  No display or storage shall indicate from the exterior of the buildings that they are being used in part for any purpose other than a dwelling or accessory building. 
(4)  No advertising signs shall be permitted, however a nonilluminated announcement sign not exceeding two square feet in area may be permitted for use on the property. 
(5)  No equipment or process shall be used in such home occupation, which creates noise, vibration, glare, fumes, odors, or electrical interference detectable to the normal senses of a person off the lot if the occupation is conducted in a residence, or outside the individual dwelling unit if conducted in other than a residence. In the case of electrical interference, no equipment or process shall be used which creates visual or audible interference in any radio or television receivers off the premises or causes fluctuations in line voltage off the premises. 
(6)  No traffic shall be generated by such home occupation in substantially greater volumes than would normally be expected in a residential neighborhood. 
(7)  All day care home occupations must have fenced-in play areas. 
(8)  The following uses shall not in any event be considered home occupations within this definition: 
a.  Funeral homes. 
b.  Restaurants. 
c.  Small grocery stores. 
d.  Stables, animal kennels, or hospitals. 
e.  Tourist homes, unless specifically permitted in the district. 
f.  Renting of trailers or equipment. 
g.  Auto and other vehicle repair or service. 
(9)  No more than one (1) non-family employee shall be permitted. 
    Hospital means an establishment used primarily for inpatient care and to provide health, medical, mental, and surgical care of the sick or injured, excluding animal hospitals. 
    Hotel means a building or portion thereof, or a group of buildings, used as a transient abiding place which may or may not serve meals and whether such establishments are designed as a hotel, inn, automobile court, motel, motor inn, motor lodge, motor court, tourist cabin, tourist court, or other similar designation. 
    Inoperable vehicle means a vehicle in a condition of being junked, wrecked, wholly or partially dismantled, discarded, abandoned or unable to perform the function or purpose for which it was originally constructed. 
    Institution of higher learning means a college, university, or incorporated academy providing general academic instruction equivalent to the standards prescribed by the state board of education. Dormitories, fraternity houses, sorority houses, and other student housing, which are constructed on campus, shall be considered accessory buildings. 
    Institution (nonprofit) means a building occupied by a nonprofit corporation or a nonprofit establishment for public use. 
    Kennel-boarding means any place, area, building, or structure where dogs (including those under six months of age) are boarded, housed, cared for, fed or trained by other than the owner. 
    Kennel-breeder means any place, area, building or structure where more than four dogs are kept for purposes of breeding, raising, or as pets. 
    Laboratory, medical, means an establishment which provides bacteriological, biological, medical, X-ray, pathological, and other similar analytical or diagnostic services. 
    Landscaping means the improvement of a lot, parcel, or tract of land with grass and shrubs and/or trees. Landscaping may include pedestrian walks, flower beds, and ornamental objects such as fountains, statuary, and other similar natural and artificial objects designed and arranged to produce an aesthetically pleasing effect. 
    Laundry means an establishment where commercial laundry and dry-cleaning work is undertaken. 
    Laundry (self-service) means an establishment equipped with individual coin-operated washing, drying, or dry cleaning machines. 
    Licensed day care means permitted home occupation in residential zoned locations, in which the operator is a resident of the home and cares for no more than ten children, including resident's own children, all under the age of 11 years. Licensed day care is state and county regulated and inspected by the county. If the operator is not resident of the home, commercial zoning is required. 
    Lodginghouse. See Boardinghouse . 
    Lot means a parcel of land occupied or intended for occupancy by one main building or a complex of buildings together with the accessory structures and including the open spaces and parking required by this regulation, which may include more than one lot of record or metes and bounds described tract having its principal frontage upon a public street or officially-approved place. 
    Lot area means the total horizontal area within the lot lines of a lot. 
    Lot, corner, means a lot abutting upon two or more streets at their intersection. 
    Lot coverage means the total area of building expressed as a percentage of the total lot, plot, or tract. (Includes both principal and accessory buildings.) 
    Lot, depth of, means a mean horizontal distance between the front and rear lot lines. 
    Lot, double frontage, means a lot having a frontage on two non-intersecting streets, as distinguished from a corner lot. 
    Lot, interior, means any lot which does not constitute a corner lot. 
    Lot line, front, means a boundary line of a lot which coincides with street boundary lines. The term "street" as used in this definition shall not include alley. Where a lot is situated at the intersection of two streets, the lot line adjacent to the streets shall both be considered front lot lines.
